455. the average annual rate of 1083000 in the second half of the	sixties is still considerably below the annual rate of 1525000 in	with	the expansion of family formation in the sixties a continued substantial	rise in expenditures by state and local government units seems	to be indicated	4799.002511574501
456. this is an area in which there is still a large backlog	of demand	1397.3640255135374
457. state and local expenditures increased	persistently from $26	167.5853862046039
458. 5-billion in 1949 to $44	22.1815251698021
459. 3-billion in 1959 and	it would not be surprising if they showed a comparable increase in this	decade which would carry them to the neighborhood of $75-billion	by 1970	3107.3314265063404
460. here would be a powerful force for raising business activity	563.3432045461378
461. the rate of business and industrial plant and equipment expenditures	should continue to move upward from the levels of the fifties	2042.4058130383976
462. spurred	by keen competition in our industrial system and still further	increases in the funds devoted to industrial research plant and equipment	expenditures by business and industry should rise during the decade	5167.191090215803
463. i suspect that the reservoir of demand for consumer goods and housing	which was dammed-up during the thirties and world war 2 is finally	in the process of running dry	3225.797118596101
464. there is some clear-cut evidence	of this	138.91288216681943
465. for example the huge postwar demand on the part of veterans	for housing under the va home loan guaranty program seems to have	largely exhausted itself	2732.838854142561
466. indeed the failure of home-building as a	whole to respond this year to somewhat greater availability of mortgage	financing and the increasing reports of pockets of unsold homes and	rising vacancy rates in apartment buildings may also signal in part	that the lush days of big backlog demand for housing are reaching an	end	7770.59377988239
467. in a way we may be witnessing the same thing in the sales of automobiles	today as the public no longer is willing to purchase any car	coming on the market but is more insistent on compact cars free of	the frills which were accepted in the fifties	4838.323450534817
468. the huge backlog of demand	which was evident in the first decade and a half after the war	was fed by liquid assets accumulated by the public during the war and	even more so by the easier and easier credit in the consumer loan and	home loan fields	7256.630059276019
469. the consuming public has used up a good part of these	liquid assets or they have been drained by the rising price level	and we have apparently gotten to the end of the line in making consumer	or home mortgage terms easier	4372.8554591109905
470. this is not to say that the level	of consumer expenditures will not continue to rise in the sixties	2572.9203995245325
471. i	am confident that it will but consumer spending in the sixties will	not be fortified by the great backlog of wants and desires which characterized	most of the fifties	3215.1249610179475
472. markets should become more competitive	as consumers become more selective	569.0093375302918
473. accordingly during the sixties our national economy is likely	to grow at as fast a rate as in the fifties and in the process to	require enormous amounts of capital funds	3344.380826458682
474. wage-price policies of industry are the result of a complex of	forces- no single explanation has been found which applies to all cases	3474.607961254609
475. the purpose of this paper is to analyze one possible force which	has not been treated in the literature but which we believe makes a	significant contribution to explaining the wage-price behavior of a few	very important industries	4046.8335762448214
476. while there may be several such industries	to which the model of this paper is applicable the authors make particular	claim of relevance to the explanation of the course of wages	and prices in the steel industry of the united states since world	war 2	6903.834958483536
477. indeed the apparent stiffening of the industry's attitude	in the recent steel strike has a direct explanation in terms of the	model here presented	2461.8315691508665
478. the model of this paper considers an industry	which is not characterized by vigorous price competition but	which is so basic that its wage-price policies are held in check by continuous	critical public scrutiny	5485.319735375693
479. where the industry's product price	has been kept below the profit-maximizing and entry-limiting	prices due to fears of public reaction the profit seeking producers	have an interest in offering little real resistance to wage demands	3769.4302053278866
480. the contribution of this paper is a demonstration of this proposition	and an exploration of some of its implications	2590.5975787953957
481. in order	to focus clearly upon the operation of this one force which we may call	the effect of public-limit pricing on key wage bargains	we deliberately simplify the model by abstracting from other forces	such as union power which may be relevant in an actual situation	4746.928606361341
482. for	expository purposes this is best treated as a model which spells	out the conditions under which an important industry affected with the	public interest would find it profitable to raise wages even in the absence	of union pressures for higher wages	6574.484891514076
483. part 1 below describes	this abstract model by spelling out its assumptions	633.2605298918938
484. part 2	discusses the operation of the model and derives some significant	conclusions	1181.1361428689775
485. part 3 discusses the empirical relevance and policy	implications of the conclusions	641.2291100393957
486. part 4 is a brief summary	65.33056912827979
487. the	mathematical appendix presents the rigorous argument but is best read	after part 1 in order that the assumptions underlying the equations	may be explicit	2596.01682973699
488. the industry with which this model is concerned is a	basic industry producing a substantial share of gross national product	2835.864456602437
489. for the purposes of setting the product	price the industry behaves as a single entity	1106.5875430144956
490. the demand	we are concerned with aggregate	demand for the industry's product	967.3042840962884
491. the manner in which this is shared	among firms is taken as given	791.5138555634801
492. in any given time period the aggregate	demand for the industry's product is determined by two things:	the price charged by the industry and the level of gnp	4480.171084281206
493. for	the purposes of this discussion the problem of relative prices is encompassed	in these two variables since gnp includes other prices	2175.90910650605
494. the form of	the industry demand function is one which makes quantity demanded vary	inversely with the product price and vary directly with the level of	gnp	4298.47759728046
495. the industry of	this model is so important that its wage and price policies are affected	with a public interest	1879.4373156015695
496. because of its importance and because the	lack of price competition is well recognized the industry is under considerable	public pressure not to raise its price any more than could	be justified by cost increases	5614.655840798393
497. the threat of effective anti-trust action	provoked by gouging the public through price increases not	justified by cost increases and fears of endangering relations with	customers congress the general public and the press all operate	to keep price increases in some relation to cost increases	4622.338564560617
498. for the	industry of this model the effect of such public pressures in the	past has been to hold the price well below the short-run profit-maximizing	price and even	below the entry-limited price	5330.845747619982
499. for	such an industry it is only safe to raise its price if such an	increase is manifestly justified by rising costs		1450.4178570891036
500. thus if public pressure sets the effective limit to	the price that the industry may charge this pressure is itself a function	of the wage rate	4094.9395191003327
501. in this model we abstract from all non-wage	sources of cost changes so that the public-limit price only	rises as the wage rate rises	2476.8933890242583
502. in such circumstances it may well be	to the advantage of the industry to allow an increase in the basic wage	rate	3252.838758975792
503. since marginal costs rise when the wage rate rises the	profit-maximizing price also rises when the public-limit price is elevated	and is likely to remain well above the latter	3106.250660951072
504. the entry-limiting	price will also be raised for potential domestic competition but	unless general inflation permits profit margins to increase proportionately	throughout the economy we might expect the public-limit price	to approach the entry-limit price	5642.251843078468
505. the foreign-entry-limit price would	be approached more rapidly since domestic wage-rates do not enter foreign	costs directly	1412.6509730643695
506. where this approach becomes critical the industry	can be expected to put much emphasis on this as evidence of its	sincerity in resisting the wage pressures of a powerful union	requesting	tariff relief after it has reluctantly acceded to the union	pressure	6582.383885125464
507. whether or not it is in the industry's interest	to allow the basic wage rate to rise obviously depends upon the extent	to which the public-limit price rises in response to a basic wage	increase and the relation of this response to the increase in costs accompanying	the wage increase	4943.490367083574
508. the extent to which the public-limit price	is raised by a given increase in the basic wage rate is itself a	function of three things: the passage of time the level of gnp	and the size of the wage increase	6313.462456150594
509. we are abstracting from	the fact of strikes here but it should be obvious that the extent to	which the public-limit price is raised by a given increase in the basic	wage rate is also a function of the show of resistance put up by the	industry	4752.522850260095
510. the industry may deliberately take a strike not to put pressure	on the union but in order to educate the government and	the customers of the industry	4297.832024657602
511. as a strike continues these parties increase	their pressure on the industry to reach an agreement	1265.3869850484443
512. they become	increasingly willing to accept the price increase that the industry	claims the wage bargain would entail	2362.305320935534
513. public indignation and	resistance to wage-price increases is obviously much less when the increases	are on the order of 3% per annum than when the increases are	on the order of 3% per month	3656.9556929102714
514. the simple passage of an additional	eleven months' time makes the second 3% boost more acceptable	1883.9309678204693
515. thus	the public-limit price is raised further by a given wage increase	the longer it has been since the previous price increase	2177.1858300248923
516. notice however	that the passage of time does not permit the raising of prices	per se without an accompanying wage increase	3030.1951266034944
517. similarly higher	levels of gnp do not in themselves provide grounds for raising	prices but they do relax some of the pressure on the industry so that	it can raise prices higher for a given wage increase	3943.7218960912783
518. this is not	extended to anticipated levels of gnp however- only the current	level of gnp affects the public pressure against wage-price increases	3472.647639302594
519. finally since the public requires some restraint on the part	of the companies larger wage increases call for less than proportionately	larger price increases	a price increase of 7% a wage increase of 10% allows a price		3039.6385008230345
520. we	assume that average total unit cost in the relevant region of operation	is constant with respect to quantity produced		and is the same for every firm	4285.657807416437
521. the level of this average cost is determined by factor prices technology	and so forth	1095.569235879276
522. as we have noted however we are abstracting	from changes in all determinants of this level except for changes in	the wage rate	3465.3864021011445
523. the level of average cost is	e	93.50952566595014
524. union policies and collective	the single union which faces the industry	does not restrict its membership and there is an adequate supply	of labor available to the firms of the industry at the going wage rate	5774.763346192908
525. the union does not regard unemployment of its own members as a matter	of concern when setting its own wage policy- its concern with employment	makes itself felt in pressure upon the government to maintain	full employment	3943.555695417853
526. the union vigorously demands wage increases from	productivity increases and wage increases to offset cost-of-living	increases but we abstract from these forces here	3496.0013242700784
527. for our present	purposes we assume that the sole subject of bargaining is the basic wage	rate	and it is this basic wage rate which determines the	level of costs	3217.736451525704
528. productivity is something of an amorphous concept and	the amount of productivity increase in a given time period is not even	well known to the industry much less to the union or to the public	5634.2020649169535
529. disagreement on the amount of productivity increase exacerbates the	problem of agreeing how an increase in profit margins related to a productivity	increase should be shared	2724.065876110588
530. the existence of conflict and of	vigorous union demand for an increase in money wages does not contradict	the assumption that the union is willing to settle for cost-of-living	and productivity-share increases as distinct from a cost-raising increase	in the basic wage rate	6700.830720985563
531. we assume further that the union	recognizes the possibility that price-level increases may offset wage-rate	increases and it does not entirely disregard the effect of price	increases arising from its own wage increases upon the real	wage rate	4036.0996001553212
532. for internal political reasons the union asks for	increases in the basic wage rate and would vigorously oppose	a reduction in this rate but the adjustment of the basic wage rate	upwards is essentially up to the discretion of the companies of the industry	6808.558182709033
533. changes in the basic wage rate are cost-raising and	they constitute an argument for raising prices	1257.1926113576678
534. however it is not known	to either the union or the public precisely how much of a cost increase	is caused by a given change in the basic wage rate although the	companies are presumed to have reliable estimates of this magnitude	6571.305275569728
535. in this model then the industry is presumed to realize that	they could successfully resist a change in the basic wage rate but since	such a change is the only effective means to raising prices they may	in circumstances to be spelled out in part 2 below find it to	their advantage to allow the wage rise	5333.197110008658
536. thus for non-negative changes	in the basic wage rate the industry becomes the active wage-setter	since any increase in the basic wage rate can occur only by reason	of industry acquiescence	4986.038106831029
537. the presumption in the literature would appear	to be that the basic wage rate would be unchanged in this case on	the grounds that it is clearly not in the interest of the industry	to raise wages gratuitously	4030.7341632855764
538. from this presumption it is an easy	step to the conclusion that any observed increases in the basic wage rate	must be due to union behavior different and more aggressive than assumed	in our model	5629.635038467899
539. it is this conclusion that we challenge; we do	so by disproving the presumption on which it is based	1719.052820515757
540. of the model	it is convenient to assume that the union-industry	contract is of one year's duration	2130.8896267989535
541. in the century from 1815 to 1914 the law of nations became international	law	944.1380632241535
542. several factors contributed to this change	64.5735066541649
543. the	congress of vienna is a convenient starting point because it both	epitomized and symbolized what was to follow	1728.4894551408647
544. here in 1815 the great	nations assembled to legislate not merely for europe but for the world	2119.1262107486355
545. thus the congress marks a formal recognition of the political system	that was central to world politics for a century	1878.8527478144467
546. international	law had to fit the conditions of europe and nothing that could not	fit this	system or the interests of the great european nations collectively	could possibly emerge as law in any meaningful sense	5639.404035817786
547. essentially	this imposed two conditions: first international law had to recognize	and be compatible with an international political system in which	a number of states were competitive suspicious and opportunistic	in their political alignments with one another; second it had to	be compatible with the value system that they shared	4923.418467222941
548. in both respects	international law was europeanized	140.12420531298304
549. it was not always easy	to develop theory and doctrine which would square the two conditions	1266.4999467378912
550. on the one hand the major european nations had to maintain vis-a-vis	each other an emphasis upon sovereignty independence formal equality-	thus insuring for themselves individually an optimal freedom of	action to maintain the flexibility of alignment that the system	required and to avoid anything approaching a repetition of the disastrous	napoleonic experience	7693.887724969124
551. but there was no pressing need to maintain	these same standards with regard to most of the rest of the world	2030.6287643458786
552. thus theory and doctrine applicable among the great nations and the	smaller european states did not really comfortably fit less developed	and less powerful societies elsewhere	4097.550373719158
553. political interference in africa	and asia and even in latin america	by the special interest of the united states as expressed in	the monroe doctrine itself from the outset related to european politics	was necessary in order to preserve both common economic values	and the european balance itself	4828.674419134726
554. a nation such as switzerland	could be neutralized by agreement and could be relied upon to protect	its neutrality; more doubtful but possible	was the neutralization of the latin american countries;	out of the question was the neutralization of asia and africa	6560.073704809848
555. this europeanization of the law was made explicit by a number of	19th century scholars	1101.145352139975
556. more emphasis was put upon the fact that international	law was the law of civilized nations; kent and story	the great early american scholars repeatedly made use of this phrase	or of christian nations which is a substantial equivalent	6177.793145635581
557. wheaton stated that the public law was essentially limited to the	civilized and christian peoples of europe or to those of european	origin	2330.744446224935
558. of course it had always been of european origin in fact	but it had maintained a universal outlook under the natural law theory	3500.5701371427117
559. now with virtually every writer not only was the european origin	of public law acknowledged as a historical phenomenon but the rules	thus established by the advanced civilizations of europe were to be imposed	on others	3866.8387730328095
560. the european customs on which international law was	based were to become by force and fiat the customs that others were	to accept as law if they were to join this community as sovereign states	5600.13393203217
561. hall for example was quite explicit on this point when he said	states outside european civilization must formally enter into the	circle of law-governed countries	2585.3721986655737
562. they must do something with the	acquiescence of the latter or some of them which amounts to an acceptance	of the law in its entirety beyond all possibility of misconstruction	4811.180714205745
563. during the nineteenth century these views were protested by	virtually all the latin american writers though ineffectively just	as the new nations of africa and asia protest them with more effect	today	3445.41744209896
564. a number of other nineteenth-century developments	contributed	to the transmutation of the law of nations into international	law; that is from aspects of a universal system of justice into	particular rules governing the relations of sovereign states	5900.330446747722
565. the difference	is important for although the older law of nations did cover	relationships among sovereigns this was by no means its exclusive domain	2450.7904825932687
566. the law of nature governed sovereigns in their relationship to	their own citizens to foreigners and to each other in a conceptually	unified system	3697.5891960491704
567. the theory of international law which in the nineteenth	century became common to virtually all writers in europe and america	broke this unity and this universality	2715.2571251702225
568. it lost sight of the	individual almost entirely and confined itself to rules limiting the exercise	of state power for reasons essentially unconnected with justice	or morality save as these values might affect international relations	5635.06220741612
569. no longer did the sovereign look to the law of nations to determine	what he ought to do; his search was merely for rules that might limit	his freedom of action	3327.0835024639937
570. to appreciate this development we	must relate it to other aspects of nineteenth-century philosophy	1399.3078504169866
571. first	and most obvious was the growing nationalism and the tendency to	regard the state and the individual's identification with the state	as transcending other ties of social solidarity	3110.358805057227
572. national identification	was not new but it was accelerating in intensity and scope throughout	europe as new unifications occurred	2584.3261699554496
573. it reached its ultimate	philosophical statement in notions of state will put forward by	the germans especially by hegel although political philosophers will	recognize its origins in the rejected doctrines of hobbes	3446.491288833834
574. national	identification was reflected jurisprudentially in law theories which	incorporated this hegelian abstraction and saw law domestic and international	simply as its formal reflection	3686.587380567815
575. in the international community	this reduced law to jellinek's auto-limitation	373.286144121595
576. a state the	highest form of human organization in fact and theory could be subjected	to law only by a manifestation of self-will or consent	3892.5494249121048
577. according	to the new theories the nineteenth century corporate sovereign	was sovereign in a quite new and different sense from his historical	predecessors	2340.0530380565765
578. he no longer sought to find the law; he made it;	he could be subjected to law only because he agreed to be	3484.3081123943716
579. there was	no law domestic or international except that willed by acknowledged	by or consented to by states	1562.412732387343
580. hidden behind hegelian abstractions	were more practical reasons for a changing jurisprudence	961.8298435908713
581. related	to but distinguishable from nationalism was the growth of democracy	in one form or another	1256.124675381791
582. increased participation in politics and	the demands of various groups for status and recognition had dramatic	effects upon law institutions	2825.899317621258
583. the efforts of various interest groups	to control or influence governmental decisions particularly when	taken in conjunction with the impact of industralization led to a concentration	of attention on the legislative power and the means whereby	policy could be formulated and enforced as law through bureaucratic institutions	4758.0514424696
584. law became a conscious process something more than simply	doing justice and looking to local customs and a common morality for	applicable norms	3491.190241908317
585. particularly was this true when the norms previously	applied were no longer satisfactory to many when customs were rapidly	changing as the forces of the new productivity were harnessed	3105.3505491572655
586. the	old way of doing things which depended on a relatively stable community	with stable ideas dealing with familiar situations was no longer	adequate to the task	4287.365081362389
587. first was the period of codification of existing	law: the code napoleon in france and the peculiar codification	that in fact resulted from austin's restatement and ordering of	the common law in england	3548.40702452429
588. codification was followed in all countries	by a growing amount of legislation some changing and adjusting	the older law much dealing with entirely new situations	3876.2579269424555
589. the legislative	mills have been grinding ever since and when its cumbersome processes	were no longer adequate to the task a limited legislative authority	was delegated in one form or another to the executive	3668.123072479234
590. whereas	the eighteenth century had been a time in which man sought justice the	nineteenth and twentieth have been centuries in which men are satisfied	with law	4283.142506766283
591. indeed with developed positivism the separation of law	from justice or from morality generally became quite specific	1424.7449063323272
592. in municipal systems we tend to view what is called positivism as	fundamentally a movement to democratize policy by increasing the power	of parliament- the elected representatives- at the expense of the	more conservative judiciary	5631.03363268838
593. when the power of the latter was made	both limited and explicit- when norms were clarified and made more precise	and the creation of new norms was placed exclusively in parliamentary	hands- two purposes were served: government was made subservient	to an institutionalized popular will and law became a rational	system for implementing that will for serving conscious goals for embodying	the public policy	5707.6435150638745
594. it is true that initially the task	was to remove restrictions that it was thought inhibited the free	flow of money goods and labor; but even laissez-faire was a conscious	policy	4992.630058216683
595. law was seen as an emanation of the sovereign will	377.10059016891495
596. however the sovereign was not hobbes' absolute monarch but rather	the parliamentary sovereign of austin	1646.7313558152018
597. it was too an optimistic	philosophy and though it separated law from morality it was by no means	an immoral or amoral one	2330.7552841899897
598. man through democratic institutions	of government and economic freedom was master of his destiny	1405.8656481867856
599. the theory	did not require though it unfortunately might acquire a hegelian	mystique	789.6665528878056
600. it was merely a rationalization and ordering of new institutions	of popular government	1176.0294371343498
601. it was not opposed to either justice	or morality; it merely wished to minimize subjective views of officials	who wielded public authority	2174.129474277679
602. particularly was this true as	laissez-faire capitalism became the dominant credo of western society	1412.8087638199816
603. to free the factors of production was a major objective of the rising	bourgeoisie and this objective required that governmental authority-	administrative officials and judges- be limited as precisely	and explicitly as possible; that old customs which inhibited trade be	abrogated; that business be free from governmental supervision and	notions of morality which might clog the automatic adjustments of the	free market; that obligations of status that were inconsistent with	the new politics and the new economics be done away with	0.20124717349522497
604. contract-	conceived as the free bargain of formal equals- replaced the implied	obligations of a more static and status-conscious society	2840.3692398056455
605. indeed	contract was the dominant legal theme of the century the touchstone	of the free society	1262.0182569496967
606. government itself was based upon contract; business	organization- the corporation- was analyzed in contractual terms;	trade was based on freedom of contract and money was lent and	borrowed on contractual terms; even marriage and the family was seen	as a contractual arrangement	6554.408354943665
607. it is not surprising that the international	obligations of states were also viewed in terms of contract	1405.3842916118592
608. in	fact some- anzilotti is the principle example- went so far as	to say that all international law could be traced to the single legal	norm pacta sunt servanda	4655.350065540646
609. the displacement	of the ethical jurisprudence of the seventeenth	and eighteenth centuries by positivism reshaped both international law	theory and doctrine	2046.6070423624526
610. in the first place the new doctrine brought	a	formal separation of international from municipal law rejecting the earlier	view that both were parts of a universal legal system	4656.320848438243
611. one result	was to nationalize much that had been regarded as the law of nations	1100.4584081143535
612. admiralty law the law merchant and the host of problems which arise	in private litigation because of some contact with a foreign country	were all severed from the older law of nations and made dependent	on the several national laws	6323.620164623803
613. private international law	was thus segregated from international	law proper or as it is often called public international law	1727.8268405062092
614. states were free to enact within broad though determinate	limits their own rules as to the application of foreign law by their	courts to vary the law merchant and to enact legislation with regard	to many claims arising on the high seas	6585.933160018928
615. the change was not quite	so dramatic as it sounds because in fact common norms continued to be	invoked by municipal courts and were only gradually changed by legislation	and then largely in marginal situations	3759.456054588171
616. mr justice black was one of the minority that rested on the article	1 power	1649.488646803212
617. in this view supported by only three members of the	court a power denied by the specific provisions of article 3	was granted by the generality of article 1	3099.3503672101992
618. if this seems arbitrary	its effect was to treat citizens of the district of columbia equally	with citizens of the states- at the expense of expanding a troublesome	jurisdiction	4635.228712078494
619. for almost	a hundred years we relied upon state courts	for the protection of most rights arising under national	law	1877.1542066504821
620. then in 1875 apparently in response to the nationalizing	influence of the civil war congress first gave the lower federal courts	general authority- concurrently with state tribunals- to decide	cases involving federal-right questions	5321.042113925019
621. one purpose of the change	was to attain sympathetic enforcement of rights insured by the civil	war amendments against state interference	2024.0404629169432
622. serious difficulty arose	with the advent of substantive due process	559.6741085986991
623. an amendment presumably	designed to deal with the problems of newly freed slaves became	a laissez-faire limitation upon state economic policy	2034.8391692253822
624. a flood	of federal lower court injunctions seriously impeded the processes of	local government	1407.0114782893982
625. congress reacted with a series of measures modifying	in various ways what it had granted in 1875	1408.087621470622
626. in 1910 it required the	convening of a special three-judge court for the issuance of certain	injunctions and allowed direct appeals to the supreme court	3909.5370398479668
627. such	legislation was clarified and extended from time to time thereafter	499.7629243579043
628. in 1913 an abortive provision was made for the stay of federal injunction	proceedings upon institution of state court test cases	3039.6519935653596
629. the essential	ineffectiveness of these measures resulted in 1934 in substantial	elimination of federal jurisdiction to enjoin state public utility rate	orders	2194.332292321096
630. three years later similar restraints were imposed upon injunctions	against collection of state taxes	1391.1705673043846
631. this saved for state adjudication	in the first instance the two major areas where federal injunctions	had been most obnoxious but other areas remained vulnerable	2606.7218214593463
632. meanwhile the supreme court like congress showed misgivings	concerning this aspect of government by injunction	1646.2186557842892
633. drawing upon	the traditional discretion of the chancellor mr justice holmes	introduced a series of self-imposed judicial restraints that culminated	in mr justice frankfurter's famous doctrine of abstention	2960.8180454900535
634. whereas the earlier cases turned rather narrowly upon the availability	of adequate state remedies the new emphasis is upon the nature of	the state policy at issue	4291.687012179982
635. the classic case is railroad commission	v pullman	167.73480752361402
636. the commission had issued an administrative order	which was challenged as discriminatory against negroes	1411.5661097701595
637. its enforcement	was enjoined by a federal trial court	264.2280901606772
638. on review the supreme	court via mr justice frankfurter found southern racial problems	a sensitive area of social policy on which the federal courts ought	not to enter unless no alternative to h adjudication is open	5783.518237018037
639. an alternative was found in the vagueness of state law as to whether	the offending order had in fact been authorized	2037.0092792488626
640. reluctant as usual	to interpret state legislation- such interpretation can only be	a forecast rather than a determination- mr justice frankfurter	led a unanimous court to vacate the injunction	4651.9460927959735
641. but it is crucial	that here unlike burford the trial court was ordered to retain	the case until the state courts had had a reasonable opportunity	to settle the state-law question	3347.2416931752814
642. the resources of equity are equal	to an adjustment that will avoid the waste of a tentative decision as	well as the friction of a premature constitutional adjudication	4477.999073138917
643. temporary abstention ie postponement is one thing;	refusal to adjudicate is another	644.6045019689527
644. to the extent that the jurisdictional	principle of 1875 stands unmodified by subsequent legislation federal	equitable relief against state action must be available- or so	it seems to mr justice frankfurter	4993.760635009363
645. in alabama public service	commission v southern ry co the commission had	refused to permit abandonment of certain uneconomic train facilities	2034.658787926599
646. the railroad claiming deprivation of property without due process	of law sought injunctive relief	1408.4849163772153
647. the court held that federal	jurisdiction should not be exercised lest the domestic policy of the state	be obstructed; this in the name of equitable discretion	2733.6995233665793
648. justices frankfurter and jackson concurred in the court's result	for they found no merit in the railroad's claim	2347.4923376210913
649. but they objected	vigorously to the proposition that federal courts may refuse to exercise	jurisdiction conferred in a valid act of congress:   by	one fell swoop the court now finds that congress indulged in needless	legislation in the acts of 1910 1913 1925 1934 and 1937	4692.81488378692
650. by	these measures congress so the court in effect now decides gave	not only needless but inadequate relief since it now appears that	the federal courts have inherent power to sterilize the act of 1875 against	all proceedings challenging local regulation	6430.126043168061
651. a most	revealing recent case is textile workers union v lincoln	mills	642.4797644832016
652. the taft-hartley act gave the federal courts jurisdiction	over suits for violation of contracts between an employer and a	labor organization representing employees in an industry affecting commerce	4480.434409008117
653. on its face this merely provides a federal forum; it does	not establish any law for the federal judges to enforce	2032.7993466250646
654. how	can judges exercise jurisdiction to enforce national rights when congress	has created none	1416.0955125731007
655. the court held that congress had intended	the federal judiciary to fashion an appropriate law of labor-management	contracts	1574.5127775097076
656. in short congressional power to grant federal-question	authority to federal courts is now apparently so broad that congress	need not create or specify the right to be enforced	4488.472349692447
657. the lincoln mills decision authorizes a whole new body of federal	common law which as mr justice frankfurter pointed out	in dissent leads to one of the following incongruities:	conflict in federal and state court interpretations of collective	bargaining agreements; displacement of state law by federal law	in state courts h in all actions regarding collective bargaining agreements;	or exclusion of state court jurisdiction over these matters	5846.22124393239
658. the justice's elaborate examination of the legislative history	of the provision in question suggests that congress' purpose	was merely to make unions suable	3455.3705545894254
659. with a few exceptions the lawmakers	seemed unaware of the technical problems of federal jurisdiction	involved- to say nothing of the delegation of lawmaking power to judges	2858.8534906779337
660. to avoid these constitutional difficulties mr justice frankfurter	was prepared to read the taft-hartley provision as concerned	with diversity rather than federal question jurisdiction	3692.9707313359622
661. this	would satisfy what presumably was congress' major purpose- the suability	of unions	783.3589796333201
662. it would also leave intact the states' traditional	authority in the realm of contract law	1649.2425827681047
663. and york decisions require federal courts in diversity cases	here again mr justice frankfurter	could not lightly accept the principle of wholesale judicial	legislation	2461.5255836898295
664. if congress wants to displace the states from areas	which they have customarily occupied let it do so knowingly and explicitly	3047.585928002763
665. and let it do its own lawmaking and not leave that to federal	judges	944.2000785474984
666. does lincoln mills suggest that if congress granted jurisdiction	over interstate divorce cases the federal courts would be	authorized to fashion a national law for the dissolution of marriages	4669.197311800583
667. there is a common problem behind most of these federal question	and diversity cases	940.3658434596093
668. congress has not clearly defined the bounds	between state and federal court competence	1190.6608555229168
669. it has the power to do	so but for the most part has left the matter for solution by judges on	a case-by-case basis	2477.441853400626
670. a careful student has suggested that in any	new revision of the judicial code the legislators would do well	to remember that the allocation of power to the federal courts should	be limited to those matters in which their expertise in federal law	might be used leaving to the state judiciaries the primary obligation	of pronouncing state law	8108.441843006835
671. obviously the goal here proposed is the	guiding principle in mr justice frankfurter's opinions- to	the extent that congress leaves the problem to judicial discretion	2589.610327616904
672. the same rule of specialization and division of labor guides him in	the fela certiorari cases in the administrative law area	and indeed in the whole realm of judicial review	4820.201512939873
673. mr justice black	no doubt concurs in principle but is more apt to make exceptions to	achieve a generous and just result	2178.5535339086455
674. he will not be fooled	by technicalities	140.2012816978106
675. with few	exceptions congress has not given federal courts exclusive authority	to enforce rights arising under federal law	1580.2354783712512
676. to put it differently	state and federal courts have concurrent jurisdiction with respect	to most claims of federal right	2598.4513009900484
677. to insure uniformity in the meaning	of national law however state interpretations are subject to supreme	court review	1576.4304627622982
678. it may be noted parenthetically that to evade	desegregation	an ex-justice and former southern governor has urged	congress to abolish this reviewing authority	3469.555295952895
679. the result of course	would be that federal law inevitably would mean different things in	different states	1411.0948677313763
680. it would also probably mean different things within	the same state- depending upon what court rendered	decision	2120.9537605872106
681. we consider here only a few of many problems involved	in this crucial federal-state relationship	1095.9587969451568
682. the first is that enforcement	of national law in state litigation raises in reverse the old	diversity puzzle of the relation of procedure to substance	3863.928562589996
683. subject to	certain constitutional restraints in favor of fair trials each level	of government is free to devise its own judicial procedures	2167.339261321723
684. litigants	who choose to assert federal claims in a state court go into that	court subject to its rules of procedure	3042.262028103902
685. a similar canon applies to those	who press state claims in federal tribunals eg in diversity	cases	1400.9307952555926
686. in an fela	controversy the state court followed established state procedure	by construing a vague complaint most strongly against the complainant	3054.8258211830803
687. in other words the burden of pleading clearly rested upon	the pleader by state law	1093.569903471785
688. the result was that the plaintiff's case	was dismissed	390.3764349980764
689. mr justice black led a reversing majority: strict	local rules of pleading cannot be used to impose unnecessary burdens	upon rights of recovery authorized by federal law	2839.255754947403
690. here as	in the byrd case another element of state procedure was subsumed	to federal judge-made law	2111.511433206856
691. justices frankfurter and jackson dissented:	one state may cherish formalities more than another one	state may be more responsive than another to procedural reforms	2459.6636482567687
692. if	a litigant chooses to enforce a federal right in a state court he	cannot be heard to object if he is treated exactly as are plaintiffs who	press like claims arising under state law with regard to the form	in which the claim must be stated- the particularity for instance	with which a cause of action must be described	8300.420828077937
693. federal law though invoked	in a state court delimits the federal claim- defines what	gives a right to recovery and what goes to prove it	2598.202214403396
694. but the form in	which the claim must be stated need not be different from what the state	exacts in the enforcement of like obligations created by it so long	as a requirement does not add to or diminish the right as defined	by federal law nor burden the realization of this right in the actualities	of litigation	8125.063851590285
695. another problem in the area of federal-state	relationships is this: what constitutes reversible error in	a state decision	1567.280641421685
696. terminiello v chicago involved a conviction	for disorderly conduct under a local ordinance	1185.6693059151671
697. the conduct	in question was a speech	93.84970825954741
698. the accused did not object to the trial court's	charge to the jury that discourse may constitute a breach of	the peace if it stirs the public to anger invites dispute brings about	a condition of unrest h	6075.024509286389
699. for present purposes it may be assumed	that this charge so narrowly limited speech as to violate the federal	constitution	1886.2234814790904
700. though the accused raised many other objections he	did not object on this crucial point at any stage of the proceedings	3018.8304707122006
701. that is he did not claim in any of the four courts through which his	case progressed that the jury charge had denied him any federal right	2851.7811493631766
702. how else can one explain for example allowing the survival of the right	to amortize bond discount and premium but not	the right to amortize bond issue expenses; or allowing a deduction	for payment of certain obligations of a transferor assumed in the reorganization	but not a deduction for theft losses	sustained by a transferor prior to a reorganization but discovered	after it; or requiring a transferor to carry over its method of depeciation	but not allowing rapid amortization of	emergency facilities transferred in a reorganization; or allowing survival	of a dividend carryover to a personal holding company	381 but not carryover of excess tax credits for foreign taxes	0.30166232349522504
703. these items and most of the others listed above seem	quite comparable to items whose right of survival is provided for in section	381	2447.9255355797777
704. there does not seem to be any reasonable basis for distinction	either in terms of the nature of the tax attribute or in terms of	tax-avoidance possibilities	4275.185983541719
705. with respect to items such as these the	provisions of section 381 viewed in historical perspective suggest	a rule requiring survival whether the items are beneficial or detrimental	to the surviving corporation	3447.3965018794092
706. to this extent some stretching	of the literal meaning of the committee report seems justified since	the literal meaning conflicts with the clear implication if not the	language of the statute	4989.526165976858
707. it is not contended that section	381 should prescribe the survival of all of the transferor's tax attributes	1566.9775996871683
708. such an interpretation could not be justified by a construction	of the statute alone; it would certainly violate the intention of	congress as expressed in the committee report; and in at least	one instance involving refund claims it might be contrary to another	provision of the united states code	7321.3276425954755
709. section	203 of the united states code voids an assignment of a claim against	the government unless made after it has been allowed the amount due	has been ascertained and a warrant for its payment has been issued	4051.915931117951
710. if it were not for judicial development of certain exceptions this	section would prohibit a suit for refund by an acquiring corporation for	taxes paid by a transferor corporation even though the reorganization	meets the requirements of section 381	6195.8816379984655
711. a clearly recognized	exception is a statutory merger or consolidation	378.16466068709144
712. the leading case	seaboard air line railway v united states held that	the transferee could sue for a refund of taxes paid by the transferor	and it has been consistently followed	4990.407016550787
713. the court said the purpose	of the section was principally to spare the government the embarrassment	and trouble of dealing with several parties one of them a stranger	to the claim and to prevent traffic in claims particularly tenuous	claims against the government	4457.194542743505
714. neither reason said the court applied	to the case at hand; furthermore congress could not be presumed	to have intended to obstruct mergers approved by the states	4252.42378293895
715. other	exceptions are assignments for the benefit of creditors corporate dissolutions	transfers by descent or transfers by subrogation	1568.2912941732327
716. exceptions	are often classified as transfers by operation of law	560.039405109879
717. a tax-free reorganization not complying with the merger or consolidation	statutes of the states involved is difficult to fit into an operation	of law mold	2603.060486849655
718. although it is in some ways comparable to	a voluntary sale of assets for cash to which section 203 quite clearly	applies the courts and treasury have held that acquiring corporations	in several types of non-taxable reorganizations may sue for refund	of taxes paid by transferors	6968.091192882833
719. a recent case in point is mitchell	canneries v united states in which a claim against the government	was transferred first from a corporation to a partnership whose	partners were former stockholders and then to another corporation formed	by the partners	4294.479346264975
720. holding the final corporation entitled to sue on	the claim the court cited the seaboard novo trading and roomberg	cases for the proposition that h transfers by operation	of law or in conjunction with changes of corporate structure are not	assignments prohibited by the statute	6901.188919117539
721. in an earlier case	kingan + co v united states an american corporation	was formed for the purpose of acquiring the stock of a british corporation	in exchange for its own stock and then liquidating the british	corporation	3035.0304631175177
722. the anti-assignment statute was held not to prevent the	american corporation from suing for a refund of taxes paid by the british	corporation	3476.8329848552094
723. the transaction presumably would have qualified under	section 368 as a contractual reorganization followed	by a section 332 liquidation but not under section 368	as a statutory merger of consolidation	3211.9275765766984
724. the court nevertheless relied	on the seaboard case and also mentioned that the shareholders	of the two corporations were the same	3032.5218403773024
725. in substance said the court	there was no transfer of equitable title	640.2681470488701
726. the treasury arrives	at substantially the same conclusion but skirts the problem of section	203 of the united states code	2803.6738244202766
727. revenue ruling 54-17 provides	that if the corporation against which a tax was assessed has since been	liquidated by merger with a successor corporation a claim for refund	should be filed by the successor in the name and on behalf of the	corporation which paid the tax followed by the name of the successor	corporation	5265.069215227961
728. proper evidence of the liquidation and succession must also	be filed	752.5919736438071
729. if the succession is a matter of public record certificates	of the secretaries of state or other public officials having custody	of the documents will suffice; if the succession is not of record	all documents relating to such succession properly certified are	required	4465.668862045326
730. the former proof seems applicable to a statutory merger	or consolidation the latter to a contractual acquisition	2125.62555658811
731. the ruling	would not however apply to an acquisition of assets for cash	781.5459269155258
732. a recent	ruling although rather confusing cites and follows rev rul	54-17	970.1348476851574
733. the ruling suggests also that it applies to either a statutory	or contractual reorganization	939.1702512931
734. hence a successor corporation	in a c reorganization appears entitled to sue for a refund of taxes	paid by the merged corporation despite section 203	3884.0285405681543
735. in a b	reorganization followed by a section 332 liquidation those cases	which hold that section 203 is inapplicable to transfers in liquidation	appear to permit the successor corporation to sue for refund of taxes	paid by the transferor	4098.568699377263
736. in fact a cash purchase of a corporation's	stock followed by liquidation might also be an effective way to transfer	a claim for refund if the kimbell-diamond doctrine is not	applied to eliminate the intermediate step	5788.9555579919015
737. as stated in seaboard and numerous other cases the two	primary reasons for the enactment of section 203 of the united states	code were to prevent the government from having to deal with more	than one claimant and to prevent the assignment of meretricious claims	on a contingent-fee basis	4886.285861931231
738. the cases have allowed transfer of claims	if beneficial ownership is not changed	1177.9903140285965
739. the first reason would never	apply to a reorganization transfer which meets the conditions of section	381 which is the only type presently under discussion	2614.8200430638526
740. section	381 applies only to a transfer by liquidation of a subsidiary	owned to the extent of at least 80 per cent a statutory merger or consolidation	an acquisition of substantially all a corporation's assets	solely in exchange for voting stock or a change of identity form	or place of organization	7538.185444715302
741. in virtually every case the transferor corporation	is liquidated and its former stockholders either own outright	or have a continuing stock interest in the assets which gave rise	to the tax	3338.860860579465
742. in these circumstances the possibility of multiple or conflicting	claims is exceedingly remote	1184.8330487378823
743. furthermore in a c reorganization	the continuing interest of stockholders of the corporation	which paid the tax must be greater than is necessary in a statutory merger	to which the statute is clearly inapplicable	3663.6675138304627
744. nor is it	at all likely that a desperate claim against the government will	be assigned on a contingent-fee basis in the guise of a tax-free reorganization	4290.136762630058
745. if the transferor has substantial assets other than the	claim it seems reasonable to assume no corporation would be willing to	acquire all of its properties in the dim hope of collecting a claim	for refund of taxes	4037.445906625691
746. if such an unlikely transaction were to take place	it would more logically be accomplished by a stock purchase followed	by the prosecution of the claim by the wholly-owned subsidiary followed	by liquidation	5306.849257192392
747. in the rare case where a corporation's only	substantial asset or its most important one is a claim for refund perhaps	its transfer should not be permitted whether the reorganization	takes the form of a statutory merger or of the acquisition of assets	for stock	4626.6172780617535
748. it appears then that although the matter is not	dealt with in section 381 a successor corporation in a reorganization	of a type specified in section 381 is entitled to sue for refund	of taxes paid by a transferor corporation	6311.0948631770825
749. section 203 of the united	states code has been interpreted as not applying to claims against	the government transferred in tax-free reorganizations	2178.734515917383
750. the successor	corporations have been held entitled to sue on such claims	949.8157916690847
751. tax attributes of the transferor	there are certain tax attributes	of a corporation whose nature and effect might depend on the facts	of the particular reorganization involved	2878.5150398118853
752. for example property used	in the trade or business of a transferor corporation as defined	in section 1231 presumably would not retain its special status following	a non-taxable reorganization if it is not so used in the business	of the acquiring corporation	6590.909482612871
753. the parent of a group filing consolidated	returns might be treated as the same corporation following a reorganization	defined in section 368 but as a different corporation	for this purpose after a tax-free acquisition by another corporation	which had not for example elected to file consolidated returns	with its own subsidiaries	5004.02367472626
754. similar considerations presumably made	it difficult to prescribe a general rule where the acquired and acquiring	corporations have different methods of accounting	or depreciation	3694.86021515258
755. other sections	of the 1954 internal revenue code provide for survival of certain of	a transferor's tax attributes following a tax-free reorganization	2180.0171559153378
756. section 362 requires carryover of the transferor corporation's basis	for property transferred and section 1223 provides for tacking on	the transferor's holding period for such property to that of the transferee	4993.562778070989
757. section 169 permits a person acquiring grain-storage facilities	to elect to continue amortization over a 60-month period	1422.2163686949534
758. however	a similar privilege was not specifically provided in section 168 for	attributes similar to a loss	there may be certain items which are quite similar	to a net operating loss carryover or operating deficit and whose right	to survive a reorganization should perhaps be subject to the conditions	applicable to those items	7710.676529274196
759. for example suppose another excess profits	tax similar to prior laws is enacted providing for carryover of	excess profits credits	1879.2386386756323
760. this carryover right has a number of things in	common with a net operating loss carryover	1886.4150363001402
761. it is an averaging device	intended to ease the tax burden of fluctuating income; it is a tax	benefit which might be of substantial value to a corporation which expects	to have a high excess profits tax	3959.1038713360044
762. under the 1939 code this item	was permitted to survive a tax-free reorganization in the stanton	brewery case but only over the dissent of judge learned hand	who wrote the majority opinion in the sansome case a leading case	requiring carryover of earnings and profits in a non-taxable reorganization	7292.74837991491
763. since this type of item was not in the statute when	section 381 was enacted in 1954 one cannot say with certainty what effect	the enactment of that section should have	3314.1825512124606
764. with respect to this	type of item one might properly apply the language of the committee	report quoted above which cautions against using section 381 as a	basis for treating other tax attributes not mentioned therein	5783.5641599568535
765. actually there do not presently appear to be items in the statute comparable	to a net operating loss carryover	1726.4126382236968
766. probably the primary reason	for special treatment of a net operating loss carryover is the unique	opportunity it presents for tax avoidance	3266.95562671104
767. there were two	methods that could have been used for conducting the study within the	resources available: interviews in depth with a few selected	companies and the more limited interrogation of a large number of	companies by means of a mail questionnaire	4385.091939606793
768. while the method	of interviewing a small number of companies was appealing because of the	opportunity it might have furnished to probe fully the reasons and	circumstances of a company's practices and opinions it also involved	the risk of paying undue attention to the unique and peculiar problems	of just a few individual companies	7768.910583094689
769. as a result it was decided that	a mail questionnaire sent to a large number of companies would be more	effective in determining the general practices and opinions of	small	firms and in highlighting some of the fundamental and recurring problems	of defense procurement that concern both industry and government	4944.0880115836235
770. it was also hoped that responses to a mail questionnaire would suggest	fruitful inquiries that might be made in subsequent studies of a more	detailed nature	4088.9564394955064
771. it is recognized that a mail questionnaire	has inherent limitations	371.47364391280047
772. there is the danger that the questions will	mean different things to different respondents	1410.6098165554067
773. simple yes or	no answers do not reveal the different shades of opinion that the	various respondents may have	1716.0422241807682
774. a respondent may want to make alternative	answers because he does not know the precise circumstances assumed	in the question	2814.4190439385075
775. there is also the problem of the respondent's frame	of reference	501.07426104958165
776. is the respondent making a recommendation for his own	benefit for the benefit of his industry for the benefit of a specific	government department or service for the benefit of the defense	program for the benefit of small business or for the benefit of the	taxpayers	7034.178470694514
777. there is also the question of whether the respondent	based his answers on factual information and carefully considered	judgment or whether his answers were casual guesses	2727.9572998791655
778. finally there	is the question of how strongly an expressed opinion is held- whether	it is a firm opinion or one that the respondent favors only slightly	over the alternatives	4866.041024574425
779. the research team was very mindful of	these dangers and limitations of a mail questionnaire	1095.198734087922
780. under the circumstances	however the team considered it would provide the most useful	information at this point	2113.1986533894997
781. in the preparation of the questionnaire	the problems noted above were carefully considered and the structure	and phraseology used were designed to minimize the effects of these	limitations	2976.8547139898924
782. the questionnaire was	designed to elicit three types of information: the facts regarding	certain characteristics of the respondents including their experience	with and interest in securing defense business; the actual	selling and buying practices of the respondents; and the attitudes	and opinions of the respondents concerning bidding procedures and	the methods of awarding defense contracts	7892.188050775362
783. it was hoped that the facts	concerning the characteristics and practices of the respondents would	offer clues to the reasons why they took the positions and made the	recommendations which they did	3448.0586890981313
784. the major sections of the questionnaire	are devoted to the following:	information for classifying respondents	characteristics of defense sales activities	respondents' practices in participating	in advertised bidding for defense business	respondents' practices in participating in	negotiated bidding for defense purposes	respondents' opinions regarding advertised bidding	respondents' opinions regarding	negotiated bidding	respondents' preferences regarding the methods of awarding defense	contracts   the questionnaire	provided a place for the name of the respondent but stated that identification	of the respondent was optional	0.30166232349522504
785. the questionnaire also stated	that in any event all replies would be treated confidentially	939.5444754622928
786. it is interesting to note that 75 per cent of those who returned the	questionnaire identified themselves	2102.2404655062446
787. the questionnaire	the research team prepared and then revised the questionnaire	over a period of six months	1408.3744034665901
788. in june 1960 an early draft	of the questionnaire along with a cover letter was mailed to fourteen	companies in the state of washington	3687.5709294531466
789. several days after the companies	had received the questionnaire members of the research team contacted	the presidents of eleven of these companies in person or by phone	to discuss any ambiguities or difficulties the addressees might have	experienced in completing the questionnaire	4391.605679514921
790. this test resulted in	further revisions of the questionnaire	390.6312432666206
791. the research team was	concerned that responses from firms in the state of washington might	not be typical of those throughout the country or that the results might	be different when no phone or personal follow-up was made	4050.767854343487
792. accordingly	another test of the questionaire was made	250.60185657786815
793. the revised draft	was mailed in july 1960 to 100 firms throughout the united states	1099.5633992620014
794. fifty of the 100 firms were selected on a random basis from 3500 names	submitted by member companies of the aerospace industries association	and fifty were selected in a similar manner from	a list of 1500 names compiled by the research team from the thomas	register	7052.96438031136
795. the method of compiling the aia and	tr lists will be described later	789.6738802919514
796. ten days after the questionnaires	were mailed follow-up airmail postcards were sent urging	those companies which had not yet returned their questionnaires to do	so at once	4259.457153164492
797. twenty-eight returns in all were received	43.19272920519672
798. the responses	were carefully checked for obvious errors in the answers or for questions	that were apparently not understood by the respondent	3263.1149829035007
799. the cover	letter questionnaire and follow-up postcard were then revised into	final form	of mailing lists	the objective of the study was to determine the	opinions and practices of small firms selling to defense programs	3745.772685382176
800. the	firms to receive the questionnaires were selected with this objective	in mind	1184.5017644797351
801. three lists of companies were made and used in the	study	502.71175311945024
802. the first was a list of fourteen manufacturing companies	located in the state of washington which were personally known to	the research team to be active in defense work	4641.919394423645
803. the primary consideration	in the compilation of this list was convenience in discussing the	questionnaire with company officers	1564.7693517061566
804. the second list was derived	from a group of approximately 8000 names supplied to the research	team by the aerospace industries association	3273.382821224929
805. these names were secured	from member companies by the association from the forty-four sources	listed in appendix f	1578.7048951114452
806. each source selected from its approved	bidders list about 200 firms which it believed to be small businesses	that participated in the production of weapons and weapon support systems	4641.011275320264
807. where possible the name of an executive was supplied along with	the company name and address	1266.5716313856105
808. the forty-four lists supplied	by the aia member companies were merged and duplicate names were	eliminated	1873.6669155448756
809. there was further elimination of all companies that were	not accompanied by the name of a responsible company executive	1725.6833628731915
810. the	remaining names were then checked against the thomas register list	and duplicate names were removed from the aia lists	2822.4538680862356
811. by these steps the final aia list was reduced from 8000 to 3500	791.2267010931613
812. the third list was selected by the research team on a random	basis from the thomas register	2136.6728712145205
813. it was compiled as a control sample	to determine if the opinions and practices of companies on the	lists	submitted by the members of the aerospace industries association	were materially different from those of other small firms selling to defense	programs	4290.5590538955785
814. such a difference might have resulted from:	the fact that the aerospace industries association members whose	lists were used did not comprise all firms engaged in defense programs	4453.499560221365
815. the fact that companies on the aia lists were already	participating in the defense program because of the manner of their	selection	2173.8565879706207
816. accordingly as in-group they might have different	opinions	and practices than an out-group composed of those companies	not so participating but interested in defense business	3885.034207748394
817. the fact that aia lists might not have been selected on a random	basis	944.0942120550593
818. the control sample was selected by taking the bottom	name of each of the two columns of names on each page of the alphabetical	listing of manufacturers in the thomas register	5007.84289353752
819. if the bottom	name in each column did not have a responsible executive identified	the next name above which identified such a responsible executive was	substituted	2736.700426078302
820. fifteen hundred names were selected in this fashion	249.29979040195067
821. mailing the questionnaire	each questionnaire was mailed with a	cover letter addressed personally to the president or other executive	of each firm	2180.4006304867276
822. the questionnaires were mailed in seattle washington	and sent by regular mail to addresses in the states of idaho montana	oregon and washington	3462.4321530216985
823. airmail was used for the addresses outside	the pacific northwest	375.73275630233144
824. each letter contained a postage-prepaid	return envelope by regular mail for addresses in the pacific	northwest and by airmail for those outside the pacific northwest	3875.4183102643337
825. approximately ten days after the questionnaire was mailed a	follow-up	airmail postcard was sent to each of the original names	1881.5610652973232
826. the	first test mailing was made in june 1960	392.80341370911333
827. the second	test mailing was made in july 1960	261.7860913365673
828. the final	mailing of the questionnaire was made late in august 1960 to 4900	firms consisting of 3450 from the aia list and 1450 from the	tr list	4503.396586802089
829. returns received	over 1000 returns were received	within two weeks after the final mailing was made	1256.2813791317326
830. they continued	to arrive until the end of december 1960 by which time a total of	1343 returns were received representing 26	3244.999826758895
831. 8 per cent of the 5014	questionnaires	sent out	260.2382461272887
832. fifty-seven returns could not be used because	they were incomplete or received too late to be processed	2113.05845595574
833. the remaining	1286 returns that were processed came from the categories in table	2	939.1190876745235
834. each questionnaire was audited	for obvious mistakes and for comments and was identified by a serial	number by the source list from which the company name was selected	and by the geographical location of the company as determined by the postmark	on the return envelope	6935.602888707361
835. all responses except comments were	numerically coded to permit use of data-processing equipment	781.3094829729538
836. the codes	were key-punched	into ibm punch cards and verified	563.2751057155859
837. each return	required three cards and involved key punching 228 digital columns	644.1110041478279
838. in order to be able to properly relate the data for a single company	each of the three cards comprising the set for each firm was identified	with the appropriate serial number of the respondent	5644.49269596719
839. the cards were	then processed using standard ibm punch card equipment including	an ibm 650 computer	1248.6547555744223
840. the first step in processing was	to analyze the returns from questions 1 2 and 3 to determine	whether the respondents were large businesses or small businesses in	accordance with the definitions contained in aspr section 1-701	5921.986506242393
841. the results are shown in table 3	93.59225776926327
842. the returns from companies classified as large businesses were set aside	and not used because they were not relevant to a study of the opinions	and practices of small firms	4813.024022336542
843. the second step in processing	was to compare the responses from companies on the aia list with	those from companies on the tr list in order to determine whether	it would be appropriate to merge the responses for the purposes of	the study	4480.289014356832
844. the methods and results of this comparative analysis are	described in appendix h	1180.8836078843199
845. it was concluded that it would be appropriate	to process the two groups of responses as a single sample of all	small businesses engaged in or wishing to sell to defense programs	3435.8572757095963
846. in the first place the two groups of firms when combined had characteristics	and practices that were more representative of companies	that were the subject of this study than did the firms from the aia	list alone	5932.712875250907
847. the vast central valley of california is one of the most	productive agricultural areas in the world	1421.774814370781
848. during the summer of 1960	it became the setting for a bitter and basic labor-management struggle	1890.3699877094066
849. the contestants in this economic struggle are the agricultural	workers organizing committee of the afl-cio	and the agricultural employers of the state	2191.2877149374344
850. by virtue of	the legal responsibilities of the department of employment in the	farm placement program we necessarily found ourselves in the middle between	these two forces	4283.481923473749
851. it is not a pleasant or easy position but one	we have endeavored to maintain	1099.4150750007734
852. we have sought to be strictly neutral	as between the parties but at the same time we have been required	frequently to rule on specific issues or situations as they arose	5002.257867466355
853. inevitably one side was pleased and the other displeased regardless	of how we ruled	937.1865680834353
854. often the displeased parties interpreted our decision	as implying favoritism toward the other	1187.8838799441369
855. we have consoled ourselves	with the thought that this is a normal human reaction and is one	of the consequences of any decision in an adversary proceeding	2853.846939061718
856. it	is disconcerting nevertheless to read in a labor weekly perluss	knuckles down to growers and then to be confronted with a growers'	publication which states perluss recognizes obviously phony and	trumped-up strikes as bona fide	5745.834062036019
857. for a number of years	there have been sporadic attempts in california to organize farm workers	1255.3207672668766
858. these attempts met with little sucess for a variety of reasons	749.2125974071157
859. they were inadequately financed without experienced leadership and	lacked the general support of organized labor as a whole	1582.128060115217
860. this past	year the pattern has been different: the organizing program had the	full support of the afl-cio which supplied staff and money	to the awoc as well as moral support	5042.363359157606
861. leadership was experienced	and skillful and financial resources were significant	373.30157585580525
862. regardless	of where personal sympathies may lie as between the parties failure	to recognize these changed conditions would be to ignore the facts	of life	3905.7003563003586
863. as a result of these changed conditions the impact	of the organizational effort on agricultural labor-management relations	has been much greater than in the past	2613.5790067279554
864. the awoc has been able	to employ the traditional weapons of labor- the strike and the	picket	line- with considerable success particularly in the area of wages	4282.730828515935
865. by the very nature of the situation it is the union which	has been able to select the time and place to bring pressure upon management	2731.799711984293
866. to date at least the strategy of the awoc has been	selective; that is to say to concentrate on a particular crop or activity	in a particular area at a strategic time rather than any broadside	engagement with management throughout an area or the state	6944.261991831149
867. primarily we became involved in these disputes because of our referral	obligations under our farm placement program	1423.5627188856192
868. normally because	agricultural labor is not covered by unemployment insurance we would	not expect any issues to arise regarding benefit payments under the trade	dispute provision of the unemployment insurance code although	such a situation is quite within the realm of possibility	6558.377499187556
869. but the current	issues arose out of the wagner-peyser act concerning referrals	to an establishment where a labor dispute exists and out of public	law 78 and the migrant labor agreement if mexican nationals were	employed at the ranch	4136.659971258842
870. most of us remember and think of the wagner-peyser	act in its historical sense as a major milestone in the	development of public placement services	3912.770542345524
871. infrequently do we think	of it as a living continuing operating control over the system	1101.2835120898258
872. however	when labor disputes arise its provisions come clearly into play	748.4524491959297
873. california has accepted the provisions of that act	by enacting into our code a provision that	the state of california accepts the provisions of the	wagner-peyser act h and will observe and comply with the requirements	of that act	4134.921541599193
874. with respect to labor disputes the wagner-peyser	act states only   in carrying out the provisions	of this act the secretary is authorized and directed to provide for	the giving of notice of strikes or lock-outs to applicants before they	are referred to employment	6666.026358218811
875. other provisions of the act empower	the secretary to adopt regulations necessary to carry out its provisions	and he has done so	2184.4282012970875
876. the pertinent regulation for our purposes	is section 602	393.80155368813996
877. 2 as follows:   referrals in labor	dispute situations	167.32260644838072
878. no person shall be referred to a position the	filling of which will aid directly or indirectly in filling a job which	is vacant because the former occupant is on strike or is being locked	out in the course of a labor dispute or the filling of which	is an issue in a labor dispute	7913.679635856264
879. with respect to positions not covered	by subparagraph of this paragraph any individual may be	referred to a place of employment in which a labor dispute exists provided	he is given written notice of such dispute prior to or at the time	of his referral	4595.105027045755
880. in analyzing this regulation let us take	the last sentence first	746.4412140484931
881. it permits referrals under certain circumstances	even when there is a labor dispute provided the individual is	given written notice of such a dispute	2483.469999921319
882. assume for example a situation	where a farm has a packing shed and fields	1430.2390361664598
883. the packing shed workers	go on strike	94.52321200330059
884. there is no dispute involving fieldwork	65.37509840216369
885. we concluded	that we may refer workers to the fieldwork	provided we give them written notice of the packing shed dispute	2035.0123868414503
886. so far no troublesome cases have arisen under this provision	559.9068089213811
887. it is the first part of the regulation that is currently at issue	781.4624089653005
888. note that it prohibits referrals under either condition	or condition	561.5237220054333
889. employer representatives have contended that the secretary	has gone beyond his authority by such a prohibition on the	grounds that the wagner-peyser act requires only written notice to	the prospective worker that a dispute exists	3770.6757259477563
890. the matter	got into the courts this way: one of the early strikes called	by the awoc was at the digiorgio pear orchards in yuba county	4090.1056707911
891. we found that a labor dispute existed and that the workers had left	their jobs which were then vacant because of the dispute	2326.6550296927826
892. accordingly	under clause of the secretary's regulation we suspended	referrals to the employer	1177.1518476853148
893. the employer seeking to continue his harvest challenged	our right to cease referrals to him and sought relief in the superior	court of yuba county	2600.7626864068143
894. the court issued a temporary restraining	order directing us to resume referrals	965.8557766122528
895. we of course obeyed the court	order	94.48734586367628
896. however the attorney general of california at the request	of the secretary of labor sought to have the jurisdiction over	the issue removed to the federal district court on grounds that	it was predominantly a federal issue since the validity of the secretary's	regulation was being challenged	7140.293459151391
