897. however the federal court	held that since the state had accepted the provisions of the wagner-peyser	act into its own code and presumably therefore also the	regulations it was now a state matter	3571.715830491716
898. it accordingly refused to assume	jurisdiction whereupon the california superior court made the	restraining order permanent	1896.734790319575
899. under that order we have continued referring	workers to the ranch	502.80842994134673
900. a similar case arose at the bowers ranch	in butte county and the superior court of that county issued similar	restraining orders	3280.860948748933
901. the growers have strenuously argued	that i should have accepted the superior court decisions as conclusive	and issued statewide instructions to our staff to ignore this provision	in the secretary's regulation	3335.264842996546
902. i cannot accept that view	either as a lawyer or as an administrator	1196.9901925213182
903. first let us examine briefly some of the legal considerations involved	507.32128550644177
904. it is an accepted juridical principle in california that a superior	court decision does not constitute a binding legal precedent	2822.7875298615863
905. it	is conclusive unless appealed only upon the particular parties to	the particular action which was heard	1417.8625761815597
906. it is not binding upon another	superior court which could rule to the contrary	1403.7182739165999
907. only when a decision	is rendered by the district court of appeal	is a binding precedent established	1416.641835916336
908. in that event	we can correctly say that we have received an authoritative interpretation	of the matter and one which we can follow statewide with confidence	that the policy will not be overthrown in other superior courts	5916.5224341354515
909. but over and beyond the compelling need for a binding precedent	decision i am convinced that the decisions of the superior courts	which in effect nullify the secretary's regulation are not a	correct interpretation of the secretary's power under the federal	law	4389.48175263251
910. i believe i am in good company in this view	556.8390996235206
911. the attorney general	of california concurs in this interpretation and has filed an appeal	from these decisions to the district court of appeal	2328.6301194798025
912. the attorney	general of the united states in considering the power of the	secretary to issue similar regulations under the wagner-peyser act	relating to the interstate recruitment of farm workers has rendered	an opinion sustaining his authority	5935.488399312943
913. further and as an evidence of	legislative intent only the senate of the united states recently	defeated by a substantial majority the holland amendment to the	fair labor standards act which would have specifically limited	the regulatory authority of the secretary in these matters	4564.204564241307
914. next	let us consider briefly the program and administrative implications	of a failure on our part to pursue our appeals	2837.601468919526
915. there is far	too much at stake for all of the parties concerned to leave the matter	hanging in midair	1881.0870538201937
916. the ramifications of the issue are enormous	141.42795083550052
917. a	decision to refer workers to jobs vacant because of a strike would have	to be applied equally to nonagricultural situations and might in	effect place the public employment services in the position of acting	as strikebreakers	3950.7585816475876
918. the public interest is so dominant in such an issue	that i cannot be so presumptuous as to attempt to settle it by an administrative	order based upon conclusions reached in a summary action	in one or two superior courts in the state	6683.198451663108
919. it is an issue which	may well reach the supreme court of the united states before judicial	finality is achieved	1880.8639598564564
920. as an administrator i cannot place	the employment service in california in jeopardy of being out of compliance	with the federal laws by my failure to pursue the avenues of	appeal open to me	5476.265079861516
921. to have applied statewide the decisions of the two	cases heard in superior court in my opinion would have placed us	clearly out of compliance with the wagner-peyser act and would have	immediately opened the way for the secretary of labor were he so	inclined to notify the governor of such noncompliance set a date for	hearing and issue his finding	5563.4346933052775
922. the impact of noncompliance under	the wagner-peyser act is clear: the withdrawal of some $11 million	a year of administrative funds which finance our employment service	program or as a corollary the taking over by the federal government	of its operation	6492.190080185838
923. thus far the cases which have come before	the courts have involved only the issue of referral where the job is	vacant due to a strike- condition in the regulation of the secretary	3567.098710881579
924. none has yet arisen under condition relating to referral	to jobs the filling of which is an issue in a labor dispute	3272.7026208278653
925. here the problem is essentially one of defining the word filling	507.89065153299146
926. should it be defined in a narrow sense to include only such elements	as job specifications union membership union jurisdiction and	the like	3505.5112496367474
927. or should it have a broader connotation of including wage	demands and other factors not necessarily associated with the	mechanics of filling the job	2461.553307024523
928. because of the uncertainty	of this definition i solicited the interpretation of the secretary	of labor	1878.320750570978
929. he has advised me that the narrower interpretation is the	proper one; that is that if wages for example is the only issue	in a labor dispute and no workers have left their jobs because of the	dispute we may continue to make referrals	4536.678153548723
930. martin and stendler present evidence that infants and young	children can and do solve many problems at a relatively simple perceptual	level simply by combining objects and counting them	4662.177322998633
931. after they	have developed concepts they are free from the necessity of manipulating	objects; they do symbolically what they once had to do concretely	2471.12648958494
932. the ability to think seems to increase consistently with age	558.7549995501885
933. one	experiment showed the greatest one-year difference occurring between	the eleventh and twelfth years	949.0789231826008
934. many studies indicate that	elementary-school children's interests cover the whole field of science;	that their questions indicate a genuine interest in social processes	and events; and that as they mature their interests and capabilities	change and broaden	5929.568928688679
935. how a child	feels about himself about other people and about the tasks confronting	him in school may have as much influence on his success in school	as his physical and intellectual characteristics	3554.2681041342753
936. a considerable amount	of evidence exists to show that an unhappy and insecure child is not	likely to do well in school subjects	3464.3203827295415
937. emotional maturity is the result	of many factors the principal ones being the experiences of the	first few years of the child's life	2334.9660717109878
938. however the teacher who understands	the influence of emotions on behavior may be highly influential	in helping pupils gain confidence security and satisfaction	3472.002449630688
939. concerning this responsibility of the teacher suggestions for helping	children gain better control of the emotions are presented in chapter	11	2021.3535710182762
940. the following generalizations about the emotional characteristics	of elementary-school children may be helpful	1179.4683043986306
941. typically	the young child's emotional reactions last for a relatively short	time as contrasted to those of an adult	1727.5423583148167
942. as the child grows	older his emotional reactions lead to moods or emotional states	drawn out over a period of time and expressed slowly rather than in	short abrupt outbursts	4816.155619651623
943. studies of the growth and decline	of children's fears indicate that fears due to strange objects noises	falling and unexpected movement decline during the preschool years	but that fears of the dark of being alone and of imaginary creatures	or robbers increase	4365.896869751026
944. ridiculing a child for being afraid	or forcing him to meet the feared situation alone are poor ways of dealing	with the problem; more effective solutions include explanations	the example of another child or conditioning by associating the feared	object place or person with something pleasant	7046.53347957606
945. children	need help in learning to control their emotions	260.2551614010543
946. the young child	learns from parents and teachers that temper tantrums screaming kicking	and hitting will not get him what he wants; the older child learns	that intense emotional outbursts will not win approval by his peers	and therefore makes a real effort to control his emotions	7133.536794912378
947. children differ widely in their emotional responses	94.06462627610824
948. among infants	the patterns of emotional responses are similar; as the influence	of learning and environment are felt emotional behavior becomes individualized	3270.8364086767215
949. although no national norms exist	for the social development of children the teacher can find a great	deal of information concerning types of social behavior normally displayed	by children at various age levels	3563.865656395729
950. the following summary will	give the student some idea about the social characteristics of elementary-school	children; the student will certainly want to explore more	deeply into the fascinating study of immature individuals struggling	to meet their developmental needs and at the same time trying to learn	the rules of the game in the ever-expanding number of groups in which	they hold membership	8426.155706188556
951. during early childhood children	are more interested in the approval of their parents and teachers than	they are in the approval of other children; after they have been in	school a few years their interest in playmates of their own age increases	and their interest in adults decreases; the child who had once	considered it a treat to accompany his parents on picnics and family	gatherings now considers it a bore	0.20124717349522497
952. in late childhood the influence	of the group on the social behavior of the child continues to increase;	the group sets the styles in clothing the kind of play engaged in	and the ideals of right and wrong behavior	6190.2666086450345
953. in early childhood	the choice of a companion is likely to be for another child of his	own age or a year or two older who can do the things he likes to do;	such factors as sex intelligence and status in the group do not	influence his choice much at this time	5159.335604376831
954. in later childhood	an interest in team games replaces individual play; loyalty to the group	a feeling of superiority over those who are not members and unwillingness	to play with members of the opposite sex become dominant traits	6039.5551022678455
955. during early childhood boys tease and bully on the average	more than girls; those who feel inferior or insecure engage in	these activities more than do well-adjusted children	2996.1785542430416
956. during	late childhood boys like to tease jostle and talk smart to girls;	girls who are more mature than boys frown upon the youthful antics	of boys of their own age	5032.739508709843
957. by the time pupils reach the sixth	grade their ethical and moral standards are fairly well developed;	they exhibit a keen interest in social political and economic problems	but they frequently have vague and incorrect notions about the	terms they use rather glibly in their routine school work	4820.0734337282065
958. between	the ages of two and four years negativism or resistance to adult	authority is noticeable; after the fourth year it begins to decline	3707.087586313395
959. however as we have seen in later childhood the child begins to	substitute the standards of the peer group for those of parents and teachers	2591.284570054768
960. the elementary-school child grows gradually in his ability	to work in groups	959.208474799649
961. the child in the primary grades can play harmoniously	with one companion but his desire to be first in everything	gets him into trouble when the group gets larger; he wants to be with	people but he hasn't yet learned to cooperate	4372.105752725747
962. in the middle grades	however he begins to participate more effectively in group activities	such as selecting a leader helping to make plans and carry on	group activities and setting up rules governing the enterprise	5616.373960679371
963. the teacher should study the individual pupil	much progress has	been made in the last two decades in developing techniques for understanding	children yet in almost any classroom today can be found children	whose needs are not being met by the school program	4463.823634655024
964. some are failing	to achieve as much as their ability would permit; others never	seem able to enter fully into the life of the classroom	3899.620292123317
965. these children	have been described as those who were trying to say something to adults	who did not understand	1713.3043456578137
966. many school systems now employ school	psychologists and child guidance specialists	748.7299006208242
967. these specialists	perform valuable services by helping teachers learn to identify children	who need special attention by suggesting ways of meeting the needs	of individual children in the regular classroom and by providing clinical	services for severely maladjusted children	4113.376450484902
968. it is the classroom	teacher however who has daily contacts with pupils and who is in a	unique position to put sound psychological principles into practice	4083.5924251098113
969. indeed a study of the individual child is an integral part of the work	of the elementary-school teacher rather than merely an additional	chore	2466.7142033730443
970. teachers and administrators in many elementary schools	have assumed that dividing the pupils in any grade into groups on the	basis of test scores solves the problem of meeting the needs of individuals	5306.4919972696525
971. what they should recognize is that children who have been placed	in one of these groups on a narrow academic basis still differ widely	in attributes that influence success and that they still must be	treated as individuals	4030.4517837157155
972. although the teacher must be concerned with	maintaining standards he must also be concerned about understanding	factors that inhibit	studies conducted in various	sections of the united states indicate that many children in elementary	schools are maladjusted emotionally and that many of them are	failing to make satisfactory progress in school subjects	7582.147306188255
973. one study	which involved 1524 pupils in grades one to six found that 12 percent	of the pupils were seriously maladjusted and that 23 percent were reading	a year below capacity	3319.65565467268
974. it is apparent therefore that the teacher	needs to know what factors have a vital bearing on the learning and	adjustment of children	3497.7439246729678
975. when a child fails to meet the standards of	the school in his rate of learning insecurity unhappiness and other	forms of maladjustment frequently follow	2594.2613108861233
976. these maladjustments in	turn inhibit learning and a vicious cycle is completed	966.4428932561716
977. it is	easy for the teacher to rationalize that the child who is not achieving	in accordance with his known ability is just plain lazy or that the	child who lacks interest in school who dislikes the teacher or who	is overaggressive is a hopeless delinquent	4685.7992837421825
978. the causes of retardation	and maladjustment may be found in physical factors such as defective	speech or hearing impaired vision faulty motor coordination a frail	constitution chronic disease malnutrition and glandular malfunctioning	5183.110457875567
979. they may be caused by poor health habits such as faulty eating	and sleeping habits	1093.0185775038822
980. they may be related to mental immaturity or lack	of aptitude for certain types of school work	2124.6740688955547
981. the curriculum may	be too difficult for some and too easy for others	791.4092572946936
982. teaching methods	learning materials and promotion policies may inhibit learning and lead	to maladjustments for some children	2126.9631100371603
983. unwholesome family relations	broken homes and undesirable community influences may also be contributing	factors	937.6488926524162
984. this is only a minimum list of the factors that inhibit	learning and contribute to maladjustment among children	2368.8915188209075
985. moreover	these conditions do not influence all children in the same manner	642.0447767777364
986. a	vision handicap that may produce nervous tension and reading	disability	for one child may spur another child on to even greater achievement	in reading	3874.6064710821556
987. an impoverished home that may discourage one child may constitute	the motivation causing another to work harder for successful	achievement in school	2171.2138981300873
988. at any rate the teacher who recognizes common	causes of retardation and maladjustment can frequently do a great deal	to eliminate the causes of pupil discouragement failure and maladjustment	4674.408669897903
989. successful teaching	involves getting enough information about each pupil to understand	why he behaves as he does in certain situations and how his achievement	in school is being influenced by various factors in his environment	3753.7947821959146
990. the classroom teacher cannot be expected to be as proficient in the	use of the techniques of child study as the clinical psychologist;	he cannot be expected to administer all the tests and gather all the information	needed about each child in his classroom	6802.573118406403
991. he can be expected	however to examine and interpret the information already available;	to refine and extend his own techniques for studying individual children;	and to utilize opportunities arising in connection with regular	classroom activities for gaining a better understanding of his	pupils	4444.3237823137715
992. this section deals with some of the sources of information that	can be tapped by the classroom teacher; chapter 15 provides more	detailed information about specific techniques used in evaluating pupil	progress	5160.998321253153
993. most school systems today maintain	a system of cumulative records of pupils	636.4276465033166
994. these records when systematically	maintained provide much information about the children which	the teacher can use in guidance instruction grouping and reporting	to parents	3691.1397687719123
995. each teacher has in his classroom a metal file equipped	with a lock which is used to store cumulative record folders	2037.242061758272
996. during	summer vacation periods these records are stored in the office of	the principal	1425.9323618652206
997. only the teacher and other professional personnel are	permitted to see or use these records	1103.553586315896
998. each new teacher to whom the	pupil goes is expected to study the information in the cumulative record	and to bring it up to date	3894.518179244528
999. some school systems provide written instructions	to principals and teachers designating when certain information	is to be recorded on cumulative record forms and explaining how	the information is to be summarized and used	3545.84871468723
1000. the summary report on desegregation progress in education in	the middle-south region 1959-1960 clearly shows two pieces of	information	2588.584581770598
1001. the summary report which was prepared for this conference	indicates first that actual or pending school desegregation is	increasing; second that both actual and pending desegregation is	with few exceptions the product or result of court order	3949.602148911039
1002. the report	together with other information suggests that desegregation in the	schools is slow	1410.8945282036298
1003. the middle-south region as defined by the	national association of intergroup relations officials	consists of the states of kentucky maryland tennessee west	virginia delaware virginia and the district of columbia	3218.0421416881545
1004. the	states and the nation's capital all have some desegregation in	fact some dating back to 1954; but the region also embraces some of	the staunchest opposition	4303.692166694641
1005. desegregation has been opposed by massive	resistance interposition pupil assignment	and hate bombings	782.5595193987199
1006. now let's look at the evidence that shows the increase in desegregation	and such increase as a result of court order	3047.0309782448226
1007. elementary school desegregation came to owen and union counties	which already had high school desegregation	1102.1138783802926
1008. the action was a result	of a court order the citation for which	is taken from the summary report for this	conference	3267.6471090992263
1009. in maryland the harford county board of education	had prepared a desegregation plan which the court approved but	which a plaintiff had challenged; thus county school board and federal	court joined hands here to promote school desegregation	3976.314009164388
1010. additional	school desegregation in tennessee resulted from a court	order opening a school serving children of military personnel	2368.8946728882493
1011. similarly	further desegregation may come from suits pending in three tennessee	cities chattanooga knoxville and memphis	1255.4868894692145
1012. in west virginia	the number of white and negro children attending the same school	has increased almost twofold	2355.727407880121
1013. there are no court decisions here	43.688847289346434
1014. as in maryland a district court has approved an official plan	of school desegregation in delaware	1891.3579965672532
1015. as a result of the state	board of education plan negro children entered heretofore white	elementary schools in five districts	1874.4749302941666
1016. the third circuit court of	appeals is reviewing an appeal from the plan	1193.038863494124
1017. in virginia	court orders led to desegregation in charlottesville and floyd counties	641.1082673519384
1018. desegregation in pulaski county is pending because of court	order although date of admission is not yet determined	2361.1668446647604
1019. negro parents	have filed application for admission of additional children to schools	in alexandria arlington fairfax and warren counties	1720.7657401322044
1020. desegregation	can also result from additional suits brought by negro plaintiffs	against school boards in newport news fairfax county arlington	county and norfolk	3491.0395226986902
1021. as a school district the district	of columbia has had desegregated schools since 1954 shortly	after the supreme court decision	1881.8586114308644
1022. this recapitulation makes	it clear that school desegregation continues including the old dominion	state in spite of its stern resistance	2819.137825104839
1023. the record is clear that	increase in school desegregation last year came largely as a result	of a court order; that on the immediate horizon if further large-scale	desegregation comes it will result from court	orders on suits filed in several middle-south states	4474.041017379974
1024. knowledge	that thousands of school districts are involved and observation that	school desegregation has occurred in only a handful in 1959-1960 leads	to a conclusion that desegregation-from-court-order is slow	4651.323637531471
1025. before turning to my views as to the problems and issues before us at	this regional conference i wish to note a small item in the summary	report as it refers to the district of columbia	3840.432950792393
1026. that reference	in the report is continuation of the trend toward an all-negro	school system a remark apparently occasioned by the increase of negro	school population from 74	4471.078807189728
1027. 1 per cent to 76	14.77445603464152
1028. i see no	real prospects for an all-negro school population	562.7305957112901
1029. west of rock creek	park is still monolithically white and is in fact increasingly white	as a result of georgetown's conversion-by-renovation housing program	2325.4175382106982
1030. nearby foggy bottom is ousting negroes	65.61236932223508
1031. the large acreage	in the southwest redevelopment area beckons white people- what with	high-priced town houses and elevator apartments	1726.096193438206
1032. the capitol hill	rehabilitation like foggy bottom replaces negroes with whites		395.10469277535674
1033. the sharpest	break with tradition the past and present of white ring around	a black core may come with the opening of nearby montgomery county	suburbs to negro residents and presumably the consequent conclusion	of some whites that they cannot escape the negro by fleeing to	the suburbs	4834.494664248492
1034. in fact short of fleeing to warrenton virginia or rockville	maryland white people may have to live with negroes	2583.460825826574
1035. all	of this must be taken into account before the image of an all-negro	dc public school system is conjured up	2026.979771926249
1036. solve	from the summary report before us at this conference a number	of problems are apparent	1867.4841979713067
1037. they vex us and perplex us but generally	do not divide us like the issues which follow the problems	1733.3937546739332
1038. first how can we step up the desegregation movement	393.37989636745664
1039. it is slow	0.20041515
1040. i believe we all want more schools where white and negro together	can and do attend	1897.026073358164
1041. i believe we all want no child denied admission to	a school on account of his color	1410.5866490532026
1042. in general members of nairo	would certainly want a child admitted to a school nearest his residence	or within his residence zone	3261.07589761158
1043. how to achieve this objective is	a problem but we are not divided on what we want	1411.2978733667283
1044. second as	we increase the number of desegregated school districts and schools themselves	how can we achieve this action through school board action	3472.218564153529
1045. it may be county school board or state school board action as well	as that of municipal school boards	1730.1958365956386
1046. correlatively can we reduce the	role of the district courts so that the action is that of the people	of the community or other school district and not that of the law court	5302.844890929269
1047. this is a problem and i believe there is little difference of	opinion that wherever possible a local school board should devise and	effect a plan of desegregation	2991.896482225019
1048. third how can we insure a systematic	and continuing group relations education in the schools	1650.3776838267252
1049. not	simply a brief program when the schools are actually desegregated but	a continuing program that also promotes integration that encourages	the children and teachers not to look at each other as white or negro	but as human beings	4141.090130875629
1050. again the problem is how to get it done and	in what form to offer the group relations education; not whether it	should be done	3898.1264054757667
1051. fourth in the segregated school system during	the period before desegregation how can we assure equal opportunity	1410.9272886447113
1052. in fact in the desegregated school system which may have a good	many schools with all-negro population how can we assure equal opportunity	3478.9085380670003
1053. this is a problem but we are not divided over its importance	or by its existence	1250.3549035739118
1054. fifth in the segregated school system	or in the all-negro or all-white schools how can we encourage better	group relations or an improved attitude toward people who do not belong	to the group	5341.767446819283
1055. can we help children adjust to images of other	children when the latter are not actually present	1407.8624834228776
1056. if we have five problems whose solution we seek in relatively	united fashion then there are twice as many issues which i judge sharply	issue	since on the one hand school	desegregation	has come in virginia hand-in-glove with pupil assignment shall	we support the plan	6922.404739961321
1057. on the basis of pupil assignment criteria	judge albert bryan has assigned negro children to formerly white	schools in arlington and alexandria virginia	2325.701847115035
1058. shall we support pupil	assignment	22.112585741649077
1059. on the other hand looking at the larger picture	is it true that pupil assignment has effectively cut off blocked or	reduced school desegregation to a trickle	2853.3382537990487
1060. shall we therefore	oppose the plan	65.83876307917619
1061. this question is an issue because it likely divides	issue	no 2	640.0218309572923
1062. in large cities	like baltimore louisville and washington dc should school	desegregation be extended to all-negro and all-white schools by	assigning white and negro teachers respectively	4097.208293179136
1063. on the one hand	do we argue the supreme court decision required only that a child	not be denied admission to a school on account of his race	2985.2554297922975
1064. or should	we argue that if we want adjustment of children to children of different	races and that that is impossible in an all-something-or-the-other	school we must at least provide him some opportunity to adjust	to people of another race within the school namely to a teacher of another	race	7394.783707994187
1065. we can argue that where residence makes pupil desegregation	impossible teacher assignment can create a partially desegregated	issue no 3	1892.6680562034956
1066. the earlier part of my statement deals with the court orders that	resulted in desegregation	1647.9670744523123
1067. in each instance the plaintiff was a private	citizen	263.42709009502823
1068. in thousands of school districts indeed in the entire	state of mississippi no plaintiff has come forth	2119.8116276098867
1069. and i have established	that the action of municipal county or state school boards	or boards of education is small infinitesimally small in comparison	with the number of districts	3095.270076679136
1070. is the requirement that the plaintiff be	a person actually denied admission to a school a sound requirement	2371.91961700946
1071. should congress authorize the attorney general to file suit to accomplish	admission of a child to a school to which he is denied entrance	2477.037446001503
1072. even though in civil rights legislation in 1957 and 1960 the provision	for the attorney general to act was eliminated should we	nevertheless	support such a clause	4309.517011294803
1073. this is an issue for it divides	issue no 4	373.12836711730085
1074. withholding of funds to	schools	that deny children on account of race	952.6487284759969
1075. which in 1957 divided even a liberal group like the american	veterans committee	792.8148219440559
1076. should we support a clause in federal	school construction or school assistance legislation that would	deny federal funds to a school district that denies admission to a	child on account of his race	5335.7758787605035
1077. this is softer than earlier powell amendments	which would have denied funds to all segregated school districts	1412.2124316679303
1078. there is nonetheless considerable argument against the clause	softened though it be on the grounds that federal aid is so necessary	to the public schools	3916.6467008100526
1079. the federal funds limitation enlists the support	issue no 5	376.43100999840345
1080. state or county	or municipality be required to furnish public education	752.8159413084638
1081. for the	school year 1959-1960 the prince edward county board	of supervisors voted not to provide funds for public education and	the school board therefore could provide no public education- for white	or negro children	3775.231568293035
1082. is public education in this american democracy	of such importance that no child should be denied public education	2342.808804743118
1083. or is this subject a matter of self-determination a matter of states	rights or county rights	1260.2583690006209
1084. if people don't want to provide public	education should they be forced to do so	1646.0325769629121
1085. even if we marshal substantial	agreement behind mandatory public education we likely cannot	expect that all the states will enact the legislation	2170.397216517426
1086. should the	requirement which must therefore be federal in nature be legislated	by the united states congress	2118.1634660757104
1087. or must it become law by amendment	of the united states constitution	638.5524990750729
1088. we actually have two issues	issue no 6	252.4932253939309
1089. federal	responsibility	if the above issue is settled	by requiring public education for all citizens issue no 6 may	be moot	2030.1059271428762
1090. if on the other hand it is not settled or while it is being	debated and resolved does the federal government have a responsibility	in situations like that in prince edward county	5171.6600152281535
1091. nearly	half the children still receive no education	166.6472478747473
1092. must or should the federal	government help	142.05093586239005
1093. should the government directly provide education	for the children who want public education	786.978231330063
1094. the next question is whether board members favor their own social	classes in their roles as educational policy-makers	2378.8479562778502
1095. on the whole	it appears that they do not favor their own social classes in an explicit	way	1577.2071280790683
1096. seldom is there an issue in which class lines can be clearly	drawn	1179.3371035521218
1097. a hypothetical issue of this sort might deal with the establishment	of a free public junior college in a community where there already	was a good private college which served the middle-class youth adequately	but was too expensive for working-class youth	4296.366653084939
1098. in situations	of this sort the board generally favors the expansion of free education	1412.5410040227348
1099. campbell studied the records of 172 school board members in twelve	western cities over the period of 1931-40 and found little or no	relationship between certain social and economic factors and school	board competence as judged by a panel of professional educators who	studied the voting records on educational issues	4965.382309252722
1100. the few cases	of clear favoritism along social-class lines are as likely as not	to involve representatives of the working class on the school board who	favor some such practice as higher wages for janitors rather than pay	increases for teachers and such issues are not issues of educational	policy	7411.577509747515
1101. in general it appears that trustees and board members	attempt to represent the public interest in their administration of	educational policy and this is made easier by the fact that the dominant	values of the society are middle-class values which are generally	thought	to be valid for the entire society	4953.183963159382
1102. there have been very few cases	of explicit conflict of interest between the middle class and any	other class in the field of educational policy	3885.3747054868763
1103. if there were more such	cases it would be easier to answer the question whether the policy-makers	favor their own social classes	2186.8866712779245
1104. there is currently a major	controversy of public education in which group interests and values	are heavily engaged	2354.151961214675
1105. this is the issue of segregated schools in the	south	374.48350221266827
1106. in this case it is primarily a matter of conflict of racial	groups rather than social-class groups	2121.5789969777325
1107. thus the white middle and	lower classes are arrayed against the negro middle and lower classes	1265.364816502221
1108. this conflict may be resolved in a way which will suit white middle-class	people better than it suits white lower-class people	3033.360005514541
1109. if this happens	there may be some class conflict in the south with school boards	and school teachers taking the middle-class position	2176.014395917182
1110. profession	the members of the educational profession have	a major voice in the determination of educational policy their position	being strongest in the universities	3694.4037427966387
1111. they are mostly upper-middle-	and lower-middle-class people with a few in the upper class	941.7229839142062
1112. do they	make class-biased decisions	22.24169819825139
1113. in a society dominated by middle-class	values and working in an institution which transmits and strengthens	these social values it is clear that the educational profession	must work for the values which are characteristic of the society	3946.8674829203746
1114. there is no problem here	22.35142444513704
1115. the problem arises if it does arise when	the educator has to make a choice or a decision within the area of his	professional competence but which bears some relation to the social	structure	3658.8589252353295
1116. for instance in giving school grades or in making recommendations	for the award of a college scholarship does he consciously	or unconsciously favor students of one or another social class	4846.969970902653
1117. again	in deciding on the content and method of his teaching does he favor	a curriculum which will make his students stronger competitors in the	race for higher economic status or does he favor a curriculum which	strengthens students in other ways	4403.262834080864
1118. the answers to questions	such as these certainly depend to some extent upon the educator's	own social-class position and also upon his social history as well as	upon his personality and what he conceives his mission to be as an educator	6464.382978058597
1119. in a set of case studies of teachers with various social-class	backgrounds wattenberg illustrates a variety of approaches to students	and to teaching which depend upon the teacher's personality as	well as on his social-class background	3848.9855506152307
1120. one upward-mobile teacher may	be a hard taskmaster for lower-class pupils because she wants them to	develop the attitudes and skills that will enable them to climb while	another upward-mobile teacher may be a very permissive person with	lower-class pupils because he knows their disadvantages and deprivations	at home and he hopes to encourage them by friendly treatment	8078.567065980099
1121. one social-class factor which plays a large part in educational policy	today is the fact that a great many school and college teachers are	upward mobile from urban lower-class and lower-middle-class families	3451.2029690830523
1122. their own experience in the social system influences their work and	attitudes as teachers	1417.3377121433914
1123. while this influence is a complex matter depending	upon personality factors in the individual as well as upon his	social-class experience there probably are some general statements about	social-class background and educational policy that can be made with	a fair degree of truth	4478.525057229765
1124. teachers who have been upward mobile	probably see education as most valuable for their students if it serves	students as it has served them; that is they are likely to favor	a kind of education that has vocational-advancement value	6188.724082477391
1125. this does	not necessarily	mean that such teachers will favor vocational education	as contrasted with liberal education but they are likely to favor	an approach to liberal education which has a maximal vocational-advancement	value as against a kind of pure liberal education that	is not designed to help people get better jobs	5072.368199130772
1126. there is no doubt	that higher education since world war 2 has moved away from	pure liberal education toward greater emphasis on technology and	specialization	3890.8962970869834
1127. there are several causes for this one being rapid economic	development with increasing numbers of middle-class positions	requiring engineering or scientific training	2179.4477786902607
1128. but another cause may	lie in the experience of so many new postwar faculty members with their	own use of education as a means of social advancement	4276.111796747711
1129. compared	with the college and university faculty members of the period from	1900 to 1930 the new postwar faculty members consist of more children	of immigrants and more children	of urban working-class fathers	3560.2467973019093
1130. their experience is quite in contrast	with that of children of upper- and upper-middle-class native-born	parents who are more likely to regard education as good for its own	sake and to discount the vocational emphases in the curriculum	6042.21602998347
1131. public interest groups	educational policies are formed by	several groups who are officially or unofficially appointed to act in	the public interest	2179.104308732308
1132. legislators are one such group and state legislators	have major responsibility for educational legislation	1416.6081778421656
1133. they generally	vote so as to serve their own constituency and if the constituency	should be solidly middle class or solidly lower class they might	be expected to vote and work for middle- or for lower-class interests	in education	4138.178048114247
1134. however there are relatively few such political constituencies	and as has been pointed out there is seldom a clear-cut distinction	between the educational interests of one social class and those	of another	5154.7561101932715
1135. another public interest group is the commission	of laymen or educators which is appointed to study an educational problem	and to make recommendations	2329.2201384400028
1136. generally these commissions work	earnestly to represent the interest of the entire society as they conceive	it	2116.810419234513
1137. nevertheless their conclusions and recommendations cannot	please everybody and they often represent a particular economic or political	point of view	1884.2992231506985
1138. for instance there have been two presidential	commissions on higher education since world war 2	1644.9877064804682
1139. president	truman's commission on higher education tended to take a liberal	expansionist position while president eisenhower's committee	on education beyond the high school was slightly more conservative	2859.3330244658805
1140. both commissions consisted of upper-middle- and upper-class people	who attempted to act in the public interest	1886.7042605982012
1141. an example of a	more definite class bias is noted in proceedings of the commission on	the financing of higher education sponsored by the association of	american universities and supported by the rockefeller foundation	and the carnegie corporation	4033.341716155485
1142. this commission recommended against	the use of federal government funds for the assistance of private universities	and against a broad program of government-supported scholarships	3701.774018809635
1143. this might be said to be an upper- or an upper-middle-class bias	but the commission published as one of its staff studies a book by	byron s hollingshead entitled who should go to college	3672.152341704064
1144. which recommended a federal government scholarship program	142.09258496641877
1145. furthermore	the commission set up the council for financial aid to education	as a means of encouraging private business to increase its support	of private higher education	2863.456693966003
1146. thus the commission acted with a	sense of social responsibility within the area of its own convictions	about the problem of government support to private education	4102.613465563951
1147. then	there are the trustees and officers of the great educational foundations	who inevitably exert an influence on educational decisions by	their support or refusal to support various educational programs experiments	and demonstrations	3575.347618715902
1148. these people are practically always upper-	or upper-middle-class persons who attempt to act in what they regard	as the interest of the entire society	3692.8897839131496
1149. finally there are	the parent organizations and the laymen's organizations such as the	national association of parents and teachers and the citizens committee	on public schools	2749.3810794592273
1150. these have an upper-middle-class leadership	and a middle-class membership with rare exceptions where working-class	parents are active in local p-ta matters	3040.514058405398
1151. like	the	other policy-making groups these are middle class in their educational	attitudes and they attempt to act in the general public interest	as they see it	2868.3764972350505
1152. in general it appears that educational decisions	and educational policies are made by people who intend to act in the	interests of the society as a whole	4299.11933978246
1153. they are predominantly middle-	and upper-class people and undoubtedly share the values and attitudes	of those classes	1410.8019674262564
1154. they may be unaware of the existence of lower-class	values and consequently fail to take them into account	2329.355982313778
1155. but there	is very little frank and conscious espousal of the interests of any one	social class by the people who have the power to make decisions in education	3097.025565344039
1156. they think of themselves as trustees for the entire society	and try to serve the entire society	2124.396626908659
1157. structure through education	educational policy in the united states	has as an explicit goal the maximization of economic and cultural	opportunity	2049.7999881548913
1158. in so far as this goal is achieved the society becomes more	fluid artificial barriers to social mobility are reduced and people	at the lower end of the social hierarchy share more fully in the	material	and cultural goods of society	6459.7404074105225
1159. on the other hand there is a counterbalancing	purpose in education which is to pass on the advantages	of the parents to their children	2459.3818249006704
1160. this leads to efforts at exclusiveness	through private schools and to the maintenance of social stratification	in the schools	2598.390804702153
1161. both of these purposes exist side by side without much	overt conflict under present conditions	1092.6632588250302
1162. cultural opportunity	the broad expansion of free education results	both in raising the average economic and cultural level of the society	and in promoting fluidity within the social structure	4655.283220185661
1163. fifty years	ago the general raising of the school-leaving age to sixteen was an	example of this movement	1566.0527826016316
1164. during the past decade the program has been	carried on through expansion of free higher education in state universities	state colleges and community colleges	3682.4703322443174
1165. the reaffirmation of	american faith in the comprehensive high school as expressed in the	conant study is another indication of the liveliness of the ideal of	maximizing opportunity through the equalizing of educational opportunity	3648.2833932815147
1166. the recent federal government's student-loan program is	another step in the direction of making higher education more available	to lower-status youth	3027.2604831116723
1167. it is probably more effective than the expanded	scholarship programs of the past decade because the scholarship programs	mainly aided the students with the best academic records	and these students tended to use the scholarship	funds to go to more expensive colleges	4412.15083478094
1168. meanwhile the private	colleges have increased their tuition rates so much that they have raised	an economic barrier which dwarfs their scholarship funds	3470.31713659517
1169. the gains	in educational opportunity during the past decade have taken place	largely in the publicly supported institutions	1577.2628810489166
1170. unfortunately however and for reasons to be discussed in the	following chapter no rate relationships can be made completely nondiscriminatory	as long as all or some of the rates must be set above marginal	costs in order to yield adequate revenues	6441.260486588948
1171. and this fact may explain	some of the disagreements among the experts as to the more rational	formulas for the apportionment of total costs among different units	of service	3103.02983988027
1172. one such disagreement which will receive attention in	this next chapter concerns the question whether rates for different kinds	of service in order to avoid the attribute of discrimination must	be made directly proportional to marginal costs or whether they	should be based instead on differences in marginal costs	7303.221384010549
1173. here	the choice is that between the horns of a dilemma	503.2148847952769
1174. of fully distributed cost analysis	despite	an ambiguity due to its failure clearly to define relative costs	the above exposition of fully distributed costing goes about as	far as one can go toward expressing the basic philosophy of the practice	6344.814651368913
1175. for more explicit expositions one must distinguish different types	of analyses	500.97442495876095
1176. by all means the most important distinction is that	between those total-cost apportionments which superimpose a distribution	of admittedly unallocable cost residues on estimates of incremental	or marginal costs and those other apportionments which recognize no	difference between true cost allocation and mere total-cost distribution	6926.908131204073
1177. the first or double-step type might also be called the railroad	type because of its application to railroads	by the cost section of the interstate commerce	commission	2849.573069820478
1178. the cost section distinguishes between	variable costs and constant costs in a manner noted in the preceding	chapter	2354.1356437949453
1179. the variable costs alone are assigned to the different units	of freight traffic as representing long-run out-of-pocket costs-	a term with a meaning here not distinctly different from that of	the economist's long-run marginal costs	3762.9157421060313
1180. there remains a residue	of total costs or total revenue requirements which since	it is found to behave as if it were constant over substantial variations	in traffic density is strictly unallocable on a cost-finding basis	5774.306546116879
1181. nevertheless because the cost section has felt impelled to make	some kind of a distribution of total costs it has apportioned this residue	which it sometimes calls burden among the units of carload	traffic on a basis which is concededly	quite arbitrary from the standpoint of cost determination	4800.80181830545
1182. in recent	years this burden	has amounted to about one third of those total revenue requirements	which the carload freight business is supposed to be called upon to	meet	4647.07830409685
1183. since this book is concerned only incidentally with railroad	rates it will not attempt to analyze the methods by which the staff	of the interstate commerce commission has estimated out-of-pocket	costs and apportioned residue costs	3761.001754538697
1184. suffice it to say that the usefulness	of the latter apportionment is questionable	1180.9758923116442
1185. but in any event	full credit should be given to the cost section for its express and	overt recognition of a vital distinction too often ignored in utility-cost	analyses: namely that between a cost allocation designed to	reflect the actual behavior of costs in response to changes in rates	of output of different classes of utility service; and a mere cost apportionment	which somehow spreads among the classes and units of service	even those costs that are strictly unallocable from the standpoint	of specific cost determination	0.20124717349522497
1186. we turn	now to a type of fully distributed cost analysis which unlike the railroad	type draws no distinction between cost allocation and cost	apportionment: the single-step type	4486.628085010039
1187. it might be called the public	utility type because of the considerable use to which it has	been put in gas and electric utility rate cases	2730.4241407561376
1188. here no attempt is	made first to determine out-of-pocket or marginal costs and then to superimpose	on these costs reasonably distributed residues of total	costs	3895.8153719710367
1189. instead all of the total costs are treated as variable costs	although these costs are divided into costs that are deemed to be	functions of different variables	2855.100463596653
1190. moreover whereas in interstate commerce	commission parlance variable cost means a cost deemed to	vary in direct proportion to changes in rate of output in the type	of analysis now under review variable cost has been used more	broadly so as to cover costs which while a function of some one variable	are not necessarily	a linear function	8147.639214832115
1191. as already noted in an earlier	paragraph the more familiar cost analyses of utility enterprises or	utility systems divide the total costs among a number of major classes	of service such as residential commercial industrial power street	lighting etc	4134.5187943288765
1192. this grand division permits many costs to be	assigned in their entirety to some one class such as street lighting	or at least to be excluded completely from some important class or classes	5355.501091099834
1193. high-tension industrial power service for example would not	be charged with any share of the maintenance costs or capital costs of	the low-tension distribution lines	2587.264355469049
1194. but the major portions of the total	costs of a utility business are common or joint to all or nearly	all classes of customers; and these costs must somehow be apportioned	among the various classes and then must somehow be reapportioned among	the units of service in order to report unit costs than can serve	as tentative measures of reasonable rates	8344.181540388981
1195. the general basis on	which these common costs are assigned to differently measured units	of service will be illustrated by the following highly simplified problem	of an electric-utility cost analysis	3221.8753150207144
1196. but before turning to this	example we must distinguish two subtypes of analysis both of which belong	to the single-step type rather than to the double-step type	4273.074861637842
1197. in the first subtype the analyst	distributes both total operating	costs and total annual capital costs	among the different	classes and units of service	2466.7587182084385
1198. here an apportionment say of $5000000	of the total costs to residential service as a class would include	an allowance of perhaps 6 per cent as the cost of whatever capital	is deemed to have been devoted to the service of the residential consumers	6813.0333417769525
1199. but in the second subtype which i take to be the one	more frequently applied only the operating expenses and not the cost	of capital or fair return are apportioned directly among the	various classes of service	3958.872224852055
1200. to be sure the capital investments in	the plant and	equipment are apportioned among the different classes as are also the	gross revenues received from the sales of the different services	5043.349586976043
1201. but	any resulting excess of revenues received from a given class of service	over the operating costs imputed to this class is reported as a return	realized on the capital investment attributed to the same	service	3872.757997570312
1202. thus during any given year if the revenues from the residential	service are $7000000 if the operating expenses imputed	to this class of service come to $5000000 and if the net investment	in the plant and equipment deemed devoted to this	service amounts to $30000000 the cost analyst will report that residential	service in the aggregate has yielded a return of $2000000	or 6-23 per cent	8714.344673461554
1203. other services will show different rates of return	some probably much lower and some higher	1099.4900535433815
1204. there are obvious	reasons of convenience for this practice of excluding cost of capital	from the direct apportionment of annual costs among the different	classes of service- notably the avoidance of the controversial question	what rate of return should be held to constitute cost of capital	or fair rate of return	7481.706757585637
1205. but the practice is likely to be	misleading since it may seem to support a conclusion that as long	as the revenues from any class of service cover the imputed operating	expenses plus some return on capital investment however low the	rates of charge for this service are compensatory	4886.609899033367
1206. needless to say any	such inference would be quite unwarranted	557.0915978815158
1207. for the reason just	suggested i shall assume the use of the first subtype of fully distributed	cost apportionment in the following simplified example	2457.0138399516495
1208. that	is to say an allowance for cost of capital will be assumed to	be included directly in the cost apportionment	3044.24343025588
1209. of the costs of an electric utility business	in order to simplify	the exposition of a typical fully apportioned cost analysis let us	assume the application of the analysis to an electric utility company	supplying a single city with power generated by its own steam-generation	plant	4689.023453230357
1210. let us also assume the existence of only one class or type	of service all of which is supplied at the same voltage phase etc	to residential commercial and industrial customers	5005.357739933964
1211. this latter	assumption will permit us to center attention on the most controversial	aspect of modern public utility cost analysis- the distinction among	costs that are functions of outputs of the same service measured along	different dimensions	3939.879020589188
1212. since the company under review is supplying	what we are here regarding as only one kind of service we might	suppose that the problem of total cost apportionment would be very	simple; indeed that it would be limited to a finding of the total annual	operating and capital costs of the business followed by a calculation	of this total in terms of annual cost per kilowatt-hour of consumption	8794.237130822585
1213. in fact however the problem is not so simple	263.290219878222
1214. for a statement	of costs per kilowatt-hour would ignore the fact that many of these	costs are not a function of kilowatt-hour output of	energy	3884.1968338669626
1215. a recognition of multiple cost functions is therefore required	262.98041535420026
1216. the simplest division and the one most frequently used	in gas and electric rate cases is a threefold division	of the total operating and capital costs into customer costs	energy or volumetric costs and demand or capacity	costs	6083.078163996085
1217. if this threefold division of costs were to have its counterpart	in the actual rates of charge for service as it actually does	have in some rates there would result a three-part rate for any one	class of service	4125.775357622229
1218. for example the monthly bill of a residential	consumer might be the sum of a $1 customer charge a $5 charge for 250	kilowatt-hours of energy at 2 per kilowatt-hour and a $2 charge for	a maximum demand of 2 kilowatts during the month at the rate of $1	per kilowatt- a total bill of $8 for that month	8177.47900965343
1219. but our present interest	lies in the measurement of costs of service and only indirectly	in rates that may or may not be designed to cover these costs	2972.0754836983087
1220. let	us therefore consider each of the three types of cost in turn recognizing	that this simplified classification is used only for illustrative	1	3680.6857760838298
1221. the	these are those operating and capital costs found to	vary with number of customers regardless or almost regardless of power	consumption	2167.773023020599
1222. included as a minimum are the costs of metering and	billing along with whatever other expenses the company must incur in	taking on another consumer	3894.2381368413176
1223. these minimum costs may come to $1 per month	more or less for residential and small commercial customers although	they are substantially higher for large industrial users who require	more costly connections and metering devices	3744.0084336533714
1224. while costs on this	order are sometimes separately charged for in residential and commercial	rates in the form of a mere service charge they are more	frequently wholly or partly covered by a minimum charge which entitles	the consumer to a very small amount of gas or electricity with no further	payment	7639.973050021088
1225. but the really controversial aspect of customer-cost	imputation arises because of the cost analyst's frequent practice	of including not just those costs that can be definitely earmarked	as incurred for the benefit of specific customers but also a substantial	fraction of the annual maintenance and capital costs of the secondary	distribution system- a fraction equal to the estimated	annual costs of a hypothetical system of minimum capacity	5833.717244676791
1226. the preconditions of sociology have remained largely unexamined	by the sociologist	757.0501538404504
1227. like primitive numbers in mathematics the entire	axiological framework is taken to rest upon its operational worth	1407.9417591391543
1228. but what is the operational worth of a sociology which mimetically reproduces	the idea of physical models	2127.227969400554
1229. is it not the task of philosophy	to see what intelligible meaning can be assigned to the most sacred	canons in social science	2330.9368418430704
1230. it has become painfully clear that the	very attempt to make the language of social research free of values by	erecting mathematical and physical models is itself a conditioned response	to a world which pays a premium price for technological manipulation	6461.803684542475
1231. this push to confine the study of mass behaviour to the	measurements of parameters involved in differential equations has led	sociology perilously close to the reduction of the word mass to	mean a small group in which certain relations between all pairs of individuals	in such a group can be studied	5000.587237150473
1232. here i think the role of the philosopher becomes apparent	560.4715398418319
1233. the simple pragmatic success of the sociology of small groups needs	to be questioned	934.3234045294382
1234. for if the small group notion involves the implicit	claim that the phenomena of sociological investigations are of atomic	or subatomic proportions the philosopher needs to know the extent to	which such entities are valid	5649.122786938756
1235. the mere exploration of the unconscious	ground of present-day sociology offers a rich vein of philosophical	and logical investigation	1725.694672288567
1236. a parallel function for philosophy is the study of the relation	between perceptions experientially received and conceptions logically	formed	2593.591790449679
1237. philosophy can supply adequate criteria of meaning in the selection	of socially viable categories	938.400925111395
1238. this involves a sifting of the	empirical and rational elements entering into each social science statement	1876.9564891471389
1239. merton's functional sociology may have great practical use in	the study of different cultures yet it is perfectly clear as nagel	and hempel indicate that the concept	of function in sociology has been built up from physiological and biological	models in which the notions of teleology ie metaphysical	purpose are central	5012.678907187598
1240. functionalism as	a sociological credo is therefore not a direct consequence of observations	but rather an indirect consequence of philosophical inference	and judgment	3491.3539038400254
1241. the purpose of this sort of philosophical study	of sociology is not to tyrannize but to clarify the principles of social	science	2172.160999287077
1242. it is absurd to speak of philosophy as a superior enterprise	to sociology since the former is a logical rational discipline	where sociology is essentially descriptive and empirical	4482.665428657094
1243. such a position	entails the negation of philosophy in its platonic form as something	soaring above and embracing the empirical and mathematical sciences	2328.7956568243058
1244. but contrary to whitehead philosophy is not a synonym for plato	750.5246753404867
1245. the uses of philosophy as a logical clearing house are manifest to	any approach that does not descend to pure sensationalism	2020.7342189283968
1246. however	when philosophy attempts to stand above the sciences to dictate the	conditions of empirical research	it becomes formal metaphysics; shaping	the contours of life to fit the needs of legends	4978.717345129795
1247. the notion of philosophy	as queen bee may fit well with authoritarian modes of political	ideology but it has been noted that the price of such an imperial	notion of philosophy is the frustration and flagellation of the social	sciences	4199.24224865844
1248. metaphysics is no longer a direct grappling with	nature as it was in antiquity	1411.380537021897
1249. it has surrendered any claims of description	in favor of psychological accounts of nothingness as in heidegger's	system	1557.5604569416948
1250. science is mocked for wishing to know nothing	of nothing in a last ditch effort to save the gods at the expense	of men	3687.0373299675803
1251. it is not positivism which has isolated metaphysics from reality	by distinguishing between description and prescription	1264.1658005072882
1252. it is	simply revealing the state to which metaphysical thinking has fallen during	this century	1654.48295477358
1253. consider the traditional four fields	of philosophy: logic ethics epistemology and esthetics	637.5430490891497
1254. it is a	commonplace that to the degree these special preserves of past philosophic	hunting grounds establish an empirical content and suitable methodological	criteria they move away from philosophy as such	5012.182593850655
1255. what is left	to traditional systems of philosophy is in effect only the history	of these fields prior to their becoming rigorous enough to abide by	the canons of scientific method	3322.9663995718884
1256. in this situation philosophy has survived	by separating itself from metaphysics by showing the ultimate	questions to be the meaningless questions	3049.0529858393857
1257. the relinquishing	by philosophy of pretentious claims to empirical priority gives it an	ability to treat problems of meaning and truth which in the past it was	unable to examine because of its missionary attitude to knowledge of	more humble sorts	4284.362519822991
1258. in the new situation philosophy is able to provide	the social sciences with the same guidance that mathematics offers	the physical sciences a reservoir of logical relations that can be used	in framing hypotheses having explanatory and predictive value	6184.010909527337
1259. beyond	this philosophy may urge the social sciences forward by asking the	type of question that falls outside the present scope of social inquiry	but within its potential domain of relevance	3317.000345336496
1260. in this connection	it might be noted that the theory of games was a mathematical discovery	long before its uses in political science were exploited	3870.331622363688
1261. likewise	kant formulated the nebular hypothesis according to which the solar	system was evolved from a rotating mass of incandescent gas nearly	a half century before its scientific value was made plain by laplace	in his systeme du monde	4130.742599847607
1262. this does not mean that philosophy resolves	the problems it generates any more so than riemann's geometry	settled the physical status of the space-time continuum	3906.5706225680574
1263. but the forceful	presentation of new issues for the sciences to work on is itself	a monumental task	1576.8111654085171
1264. to those raised on marcel's homo viator	and heidegger's das nichtige this may seem a modest	role for philosophy	2583.9180182049668
1265. however modesty and triviality are different qualities	93.74250469345439
1266. philosophy conceived of as servant to the sciences might appear	as less dramatic than philosophy which jeers as the sciences evolve	3048.960486122494
1267. the ceaseless effort to understand and measure the distance mankind	has traversed since its primitive anthropological status offers a	more durable sort of drama	2462.8999082184237
1268. by clarifying fundamental premises in the	social sciences and defining the logical problems emergent at the borderlands	of each new scientific discipline philosophy can offer the	sort of distinction that can accelerate growth in human understanding	5765.912105559302
1269. philosophy can prevent the working scientist from becoming slothful	and self-content by noting the assumptions and level at which a hypothesis	or theory is framed	2608.65943528462
1270. the dissection of scientific theory the examination	of a theory from the vantage-points of language epistemology	and ethics is itself a distinct contribution to knowledge no less	so because of its removal from empirical research	5654.199294467687
1271. the realm	of science whatever the degree of precision in formulations covers	the range of prediction and explanation	1572.6594540018832
1272. whatever philosophy is conceived to be its rationalist	logistic attitude to evidence should make it clear that it is	something other than science	3455.7618132967364
1273. for some forms of philosophy this very	division between the empirical and the rational becomes a sign of the	metaphysical superiority of the latter	2460.322377187921
1274. bergson and leroy announce	that the secret is the center of a philosophy and thereafter a	hundred followers declare secrecy a higher verity	3503.181916028162
1275. this is simply a	confession of intellectual sterility spruced up to look virtuous	788.7697404789168
1276. for	as merleau-ponty indicated it is not the secret which is important	but the removal of secrecy	2110.9189418387386
1277. in this philosophy and science	share a common goal	261.5836169750942
1278. the hypostatization of the secret nonetheless guarantees	that the division of analytical and synthetic philosophies shall	not be overcome by even the most persuasive argument; for this	division is but an abstract representation of the social struggle between	mysticism and science	6452.764226918913
1279. the mystification of metaphysical systems	does not imply the demise of philosophy only the close of a philosophic	age which demanded metaphysics to be rational and logical	2856.815553742032
1280. the	tenacity with which present metaphysical attitudes fetishize private	intuition offers the strongest evidence that the gulf between scientific	and delphic ways of philosophizing is built into the present conflict	over the limits and purpose of science religion and ideology	6309.986068356514
1281. scientific systems and this includes even	the relation of mechanist to relativist physics are built upon refined	and corrected	1725.39898250151
1282. philosophic systems by the very nature of their completeness	are overthrown by rival systems	1411.4232708550023
1283. in addition to the incompleteness	of science and the completeness of metaphysics they differ	in that science is essentially descriptive while philosophy in its inherited	forms tends to be goal-oriented teleological and prescriptive	3535.7510635567355
1284. the threadbare notion that belief unlike behaviour is not subject	to objective analysis has placed intuitive metaphysics squarely against	the sociology of knowledge since it is precisely the job of the	sociology of knowledge to treat beliefs as social facts no less viable	than social behaviour	7008.3501575443615
1285. when dealing with the actual relation	of philosophy to the sociology of knowledge or better the role of philosophy	in assisting research on the social sources of ideas one has	to become necessarily selective	3660.8528581532432
1286. certain features we have touched upon:	philosophy as a logical deductive system from which a social science	methodology can be built up; philosophic analysis of the assumptions	and presumptions of the social sciences; and philosophy as a	guide to possible integration of supposedly disparate sociological	investigations	7018.31392609443
1287. the objection will be raised that the most important	role of philosophy in relation to social science has been omitted	namely the status of ultimate value questions and norms operative in	the social sciences	3648.735070591054
1288. specifically it will be asked whether the real	questions people ask are not the ultimate questions that	social science finds itself impotent in the face of	4096.148374672391
1289. what then is the	status of such questions as: is society the ground of human existence	or a means to an individual goal	2328.295975884378
1290. do societies develop according	to cosmic patterns or are they subject only to the free choice of individuals	2361.023271524514
1291. does society really exist as an entity over and above the	agglomeration of men	944.5707194182902
1292. i think it must be said that contrary to metaphysical	insistence these are questions so framed as to defy either	empirical exploration or rational solutions	3900.172828527911
1293. as simmel and dilthey	indicated questions of whether the value of life is individual	or social are not questions but assertions of faith made to	appear as legitimate questions	3105.0433622155933
1294. such pseudo-questions assume that answers	of concrete significance can be supplied to statements involving	undefined universals	1874.1889599186227
1295. social theory has no more right to expect results	from meaningless questions than physics has the right to expect a	theological solution to the wave-particle controversy	2742.8966511204094
1296. it is not	that such questions are not asked	389.07659108174005
1297. it is rather that introducing them	into social analysis reflects not so much a search for truth as for	certainty	1883.7395034818262
1298. an operational approach to sociology can never expect abstract	certainty since it is certainty which every new discovery in science	either replaces or reshapes	3691.139510140557
1299. to raise the added objection that	men require certainty on psychological grounds answers to ultimate questions	having an irrational rather than scientific basis is in a real	sense to undermine the objection itself	3561.2381418409095
1300. for what concerns all scientific	disciplines is precisely that which can be captured for the rational	ie for the scientific determination of what in past ages	was considered ultimate and irrational	4989.842117686349
1301. a philosophy which attempts	to supply ultimate answers in an ultimate way reveals its acquiescence	in the shortcomings of men an impatience with partial tentative	solutions	2723.9202648662335
1302. men have always lived in a tentative world and in suspension	of ultimate judgments where and when necessary	2364.7690123841003
1303. uncertainty	overcoming itself is the precondition of the quest for new and more precise	information about the world	1578.73379223005
1304. without such uncertainty we are left	with a set of dogmas and myths	1182.3873006417575
1305. the functional interplay of philosophy	and science should as a minimum guarantee a meaningful option to	myth-making	1420.1703040589196
1306. a degree of indefiniteness is a salutary condition	for the growth of science	1184.8904101323524
1307. but neither was the statement empirical for goodness was not a quality	like red or squeaky that could be seen or heard	2176.188872111622
1308. what were they to	do then with these awkward judgments of value	961.460018256591
1309. to find a place for	them in their theory of knowledge would require them to revise the	theory radically and yet that theory was what they regarded as their	most important discovery	3445.288042903864
1310. it appeared that the theory could be saved	in one way only	969.8887427704269
1311. if it could be shown that judgments of good and bad	were not judgments at all that they asserted nothing true or false but	merely expressed emotions like hurrah or fiddlesticks	then these wayward judgments would cease from troubling and weary heads	could be at rest	4688.72804729103
1312. this is the course the positivists took	141.1121557945376
1313. they	explained value judgments by explaining them away	167.02195532006857
1314. now i do not	think their view will do	394.4802885280987
1315. but before discussing it i should like	to record one vote of thanks to them for the clarity with which they	have stated their case	2591.730485017781
1316. it has been said of john stuart mill that	he wrote so clearly that he could be found out	2584.0393030905934
1317. this theory has been	put so clearly and precisely that it deserves criticism of the same kind	and this i will do my best to supply	2730.1931775292187
1318. the theory claims to show	by analysis that when we say that is good we do not mean to assert	a character of the subject of which we are thinking	4814.665039658561
1319. i shall argue	that we do mean to do just that	503.13543695513397
1320. let us work through an example	and the simpler and commoner the better	1191.940164145373
1321. there is perhaps no value	statement on which people would more universally agree than the statement	that intense pain is bad	2035.262009231698
1322. let us take a set of circumstances	in which i happen to be interested on the legislative side and in which	i think every one of us might naturally make such a statement	5320.813143492776
1323. we	come upon a rabbit that has been caught in one of the brutal traps in	common use	1566.6680563779084
1324. there are signs that it has struggled for days to escape	and that in a frenzy of hunger pain and fear it has all but eaten	off its own leg	4815.145582813008
1325. the attempt failed: the animal is now dead	168.35828143009107
1326. as we	think of the long and excruciating pain it must have suffered we are	very	likely to say: it was a bad thing that the little animal should	suffer so	4977.408002161629
1327. the positivist tells us that when we say this we are	only expressing our present emotion	1255.1582185420334
1328. i hold on the contrary that we	mean to assert something of the pain itself namely that it was bad-	bad when and as it occurred	4073.1411004118127
1329. consider what follows from the	positivist view	94.60589251473985
1330. on that view nothing good or bad happened in the case	until i came on the scene and made my remark	3050.664017280663
1331. for what i express	in my remark is something going on in me at the time and that of course	did not exist until i did come on the scene	3199.692868828103
1332. the pain of the rabbit	was not itself bad; nothing evil was happening when that pain was	being endured; badness in the only sense in which it is involved	at all waited for its appearance till i came and looked and felt	6525.346802507798
1333. now	that this is at odds with our meaning may be shown as follows	942.5991469374392
1334. let	us put to ourselves the hypothesis that we had not come on the scene	and that the rabbit never was discovered	3253.8708094774797
1335. are we prepared to say that	in that case nothing bad occurred in the sense in which we said it did	2015.3215706130056
1336. clearly not	0.30041514999999996
1337. indeed we should say on the contrary that the accident	of our later discovery made no difference whatever to the badness	of the animal's pain that it would have been every whit as bad	whether a chance passer-by happened later to discover the body and feel	repugnance or not	4898.784512628888
1338. if so then it is clear that in saying the suffering	was bad we are not expressing our feelings only	2813.153583691619
