2227. the original d minor seems	to symbolize blindness inescapable in spite of all attempts to move	away from it	1713.1260403058682
2228. as the child addresses the shepherd in a dream light-	in the form of the major mode- begins to appear and at the moment	of the miracle we hear a clear and shining d major	5651.467638231734
2229. varlaam	and missail always appear together and often sing together in a straightforward	rhythmically	vigorous idiom that distinguishes them from	the more subtle and well-educated pimen	2728.93604874738
2230. their begging song might	easily be a folk melody:    the same could be said for the	song to which they make their entrance in the final scene	4277.925968195666
2231. apparently	their origin is humble their approach to life direct and unsophisticated	641.6081502049112
2232. whatever learning they may have had in their order doesn't disturb	them now	1182.563480697069
2233. missail is the straight man not very talkative	mild-mannered when he does speak	788.3276878711897
2234. varlaam is loud rowdy uninhibited	in his pleasures and impatient with anyone who is not the same	2117.4184027913752
2235. a	rough ostinato figure heard first in the introduction to the inn	scene characterizes him amusingly and reappears whenever he comes into	the action:    the song of kazan in which this figure	becomes a wild-sounding accompaniment fills in the picture of undisciplined	high spirits	4557.513225868928
2236. the phrasing is irregular and the abrupt key	changes have a primitive forcefulness	1190.403153540321
2237. varlaam's music begins to ramble	as he feels the effects of the wine but he pulls himself together	when the need arises	2179.5221773110256
2238. both monks respond to the guard's challenge	with a few phrases of their begging song; a clever naturalistic touch	is varlaam's labored reading of the warrant	4089.2085802440574
2239. as the knack gradually	comes back to him his rhythm becomes steadier with the rigid monotony	of an unskilled reader	1880.7941839875555
2240. for the only time in the opera words	are not set according to their natural inflection; to do so would	have spoiled the dramatic point of the scene	4488.436744296651
2241. musically and	dramatically rangoni is as far removed from the conventional monk as	varlaam	951.6729627779307
2242. his music shows a sensuality coupled with an eerie quality	that suggest somehow a blood-kinship with dappertutto in offenbach's	hoffman	2826.9147194691736
2243. his speech shows none of the native accent of the	russian characters; in spite of the italian name he sounds french	2037.9981521775885
2244. his personality appears more striking by contrast with marina who	is- perhaps purposely- rather superficially characterized	1876.270181917548
2245. rangoni's first entrance is a musical shock a sudden open fifth	in a key totally unrelated to what has preceded it	2040.2089357497694
2246. the effect is as	if he had materialized out of nowhere	753.7420348542539
2247. he speaks quietly concealing	his authority beneath a smooth humility just as the shifting harmonies	that accompany him all but hide the firm pedal point beneath them	2853.190653824536
2248. he addresses marina with great deference calling her princess	at first; it is only after he has involved her emotions in his scheme	that he uses her given name placing himself by implication in the	position of a solicitous father	6314.077707319034
2249. curiously this scene is a close	parallel to one that verdi was writing at the same time the scene	between amonasro and aida	2321.086256878986
2250. rangoni and amonasro have the same	purpose- forcing the girl to charm the man she loves into serving her	country's cause- and their tactics are much the same	4477.194107075777
2251. rangoni begins	by describing the sad state of the church; this brings a reaction	of distress from marina	1582.2254608211947
2252. the music becomes ethereal as he calls	up a vision of her own sainthood: it is she he tells her who can	bring the truth to russia and convert the heretics	5004.974926523888
2253. as if in a trance	she repeats his words- then realizes with a shock her own audacity	1419.914427309086
2254. this is no assignment for a frivolous girl she assures him	758.6310064364699
2255. now rangoni comes to the point and we hear for the first time	a long downward chromatic scale that will become the characteristic	motif of his sinister power	2974.3815750052604
2256. it is a phrase as arresting as a magician's	gesture with a piquant turn of harmony giving an effect of strangeness	3044.585640644406
2257. another theme sinuously chromatic appears as he directs her	to gain power over grigori by any means even at the cost of her honor	2461.793922364718
2258. coming from a priest the music sounds as odd as the advice:	marina rebels at this suggestion	2115.946184641922
2259. her pride is as much at	stake as her virtue; she is the unattainable beauty the princess who	turns away suitors by the dozen	2459.6374720476188
2260. indignantly she denounces rangoni	for his evil thoughts and orders him to leave her	1411.9251378576937
2261. at once the	jesuit pulls out all the stops	259.87860710522693
2262. to music of a menacing darkness	he describes the powers of satan gaining control of the girl poisoning	her soul with pride and destroying her beauty	4088.5340234875575
2263. the combined threat	of hell-fire and ugliness is too much for her and she falls terrified	at his feet	1720.4628179229244
2264. with another sudden change of mood he is again calm and	protective exhorting her to trust and obey him as god's spokesman-	and the chromatic scale descends in ominous contradiction	4843.470994213057
2265. whatever	the source of rangoni's power marina is his captive now; we	are reminded of this at the end of the next scene when his theme cuts	through the warmth of the love duet again throwing a chill over the	atmosphere	4311.02569920233
2266. the most unusual feature of boris however	is the use of the greatest character of all the chorus	2350.8079619526607
2267. this is the	real protagonist of the drama; the conflict is not boris versus grigori	or shuiski or even the ghost of the murdered child but boris	versus the russian people	3350.9740027149296
2268. mussorgsky makes this quite clear by the	extent to which choral scenes propel the action	1641.1490177209303
2269. boris' first entrance	seems almost a footnote to the splendor of the coronation scene	with its dazzling confusion of tonalities	1867.6687504545214
2270. we have a brief glimpse	of the tsar's public personality the official boris but our	real focus is on the excitement of the crowd- a signigicant contrast	with its halfhearted acclamation in the opening scene its bitter	resentment and fury in the final act	6832.286900686608
2271. one reason for the unique	vitality of the chorus is its great variety in expression	1098.784431115939
2272. it rarely	speaks as a unit	66.24129907520472
2273. even in its most conventional appearance the guests'	song of praise to marina there are a few female dissenters criticizing	the princess for her coldness	2596.5608206598654
2274. in many passages- for example	the council of boyars- each section of the chorus becomes a character	group with a particular opinion	3281.0870363707554
2275. hot arguments arise between	tenors and basses who will sing in harmony only when they agree on an	idea	1725.8824277922054
2276. the opening scene shows this method at its most individual	561.0538758233579
2277. mussorgsky paints a telling picture of the common people those	who must suffer the effects of their rulers' struggle for power without	understanding the causes	2589.730126162236
2278. they are held in control by force but	barely	390.98578430687746
2279. they will kneel and plead for boris' leadership in a strangely	intense song its phrases irregularly broken as if gasping for breath	but when the police with their cudgels move away they mock and	grumble and fight among themselves	4133.214227949405
2280. there is a quick change from the	plaintive song to a conversational tone	1190.2309945365807
2281. hey mityukh asks one	group what are we shouting about	376.8192506444393
2282. and mityukh apparently	the intellectual leader of the crowd replies that he has no notion	1643.8881602032748
2283. the jokes and arguments grow louder until the police return; then	the people strike up their song with even more fervor than before ending	it with a wail of despair	3231.756898359327
2284. mussorgsky frequently uses liturgical	music with considerable dramatic force	395.36070463803884
2285. in pimen's cell the	soft prayers of the monks heard from offstage not only help to set	the scene but emphasize the contrast between young grigori's thoughts	and his situation	3234.54047017714
2286. this is especially striking between pimen's	quiet exit and grigori's vehement outburst against boris	1412.3115872392189
2287. again as boris feels himself nearing death a procession files into	the hall singing a hymn its modal harmonies adding a churchly touch	to the grim atmosphere:  the words are hardly calculated	to put the tsar's mind at ease	4162.980707243518
2288. they echo the words with which	he has described his own vision of the dying child who trembles and	begs for mercy- and there is no mercy	4297.852834194531
2289. the living as well as	the dead now accuse him; this final reminder of his guilt is the fatal	one	1891.8536802168674
2290. one of the outstanding assets of the present production	is the restoration of the st basil's scene usually omitted	from performances and rarely included in a published score	4483.696450838952
2291. though brief	it has a sharp dramatic edge and great poignancy	509.63138977367606
2292. in addition	it is an important link in the plot giving us a revealing glimpse of	the people's attitude toward boris and the false dimitri	3898.1507830362125
2293. the mayhem	in the forest of kromy is a natural sequel	504.16752265113007
2294. the st basil's	scene opens with little groups of beggars milling around the	square the ever present police keeping them under scrutiny	3262.5204030514496
2295. in the	orchestra we hear first a hushed hesitant pizzicato figure then	the insistent police motif as it appeared in the opening scene	2331.495634703254
2296. the service is over and a number of people come from the church	with their spokesman mityukh in the lead	2833.426237045041
2297. they bring the news that	the pretender has been excommunicated; this is met with scorn by	the hearers who claim that mityukh is lying or drunk	2737.66499123456
2298. contrasts the two groups by their orchestral accompaniment solemn	there is still more news mityukh	announces: they have prayed for the soul of the tsarevich	3888.1624850197863
2299. so far these remarks like most criticisms of hardy have tacitly	assumed that his poetry is all of a piece one solid mass of verse	expressing a sensibility at a single stage of development	3655.4848017096133
2300. for critics	hardy has had no poetic periods- one does not speak of early hardy	or late hardy or of the london or max gate period but simply	of hardy as of a poetic monolith	5650.724916897847
2301. this seems odd when one recalls	that he wrote poetry longer than any other major english poet: domicilium	is dated between 1857 and 1860; seeing the	moon rise is dated august 1927	3447.572175678074
2302. one might expect that in a poetic	career of seventy-odd years some changes in style and method would	have occurred some development taken place	3702.0196775909635
2303. this is not however	the case and development is a term which we can apply to hardy	only in a very limited sense	2338.9639527254085
2304. in a time when poetic style and poetic	belief as well seem in a state of continual flux hardy stands out	as a poet of almost perverse consistency	4482.485109205985
2305. though he struggled with	philosophy all his life he never got much beyond the pessimism of his	twenties; the sober opinion of his letter to noyes written	when hardy was eighty years old is essentially that of his first philosophical	notebook entry made when he was twenty-five:	the	world does not despise us: it only neglects us		4501.156097615302
2306. and though in his later years he revised his poems many	times the revisions did not alter the essential nature of the style	which he had established before he was thirty; so that while it usually	is easy to recognize a poem by hardy it is difficult to date one	7423.191124033401
2307. there is only one sense in which it is valid to talk about	hardy's development: he did develop toward a more consistent and	more effective control of that tone which we recognize as uniquely his	3762.7939812579425
2308. there is only one hardy style but in the earlier poems that style	is only intermittently evident and when it is not the style is the	style of another poet or of the fashion of the time	5923.230528496583
2309. in the later poems	however the personal tone predominates	262.75136907575217
2310. the bad early poems are	bad shakespeare or bad swinburne; the bad late poems are bad	hardy	2144.718144352084
2311. there are two ways of getting at a poet's development:	through his dated poems and through the revisions which he made in later	editions of his work	2851.2145311162594
2312. about a quarter of hardy's poems carry	an appended date line usually the year of completion but sometimes inclusive	years or two separate dates when hardy worked	on the poem or an approximate date		4152.134450208379
2313. these dates are virtually the only clues we have to	the chronology of the poems since the separate volumes are neither chronological	within themselves nor in relation to each other	3229.053876558316
2314. with the	exception of satires of circumstance each volume contains dated	poems ranging over several decades	; the internal organization rarely has any chronological order	except in obvious groups like the poems of pilgrimage the	poems of 1912-13 and the war poems	5094.003469391707
2315. from the dated poems	we can venture certain conclusions about hardy's career in poetry	always remembering that conclusions based on a fraction of the whole	must remain tentative	2983.459541088636
2316. the dated poems suggest that while hardy's	concern with poetry may have been constant his production was not	2333.1492292041853
2317. he had two productive periods one in the late 1860's the other	in the decade from 1910 to 1920	latter period and these alone total about one-tenth of all hardy's		2367.3302644001506
2318. there was one sterile period: only one poem is dated between	1872 and 1882 and except for the poems written on the trip to italy	in 1887 very few from 1882 to 1890	5365.189723984162
2319. the dated poems also	give us an idea of the degree to which hardy drew upon past productions	for his various volumes and therefore probably are an indication	of the amount of poetry he was writing at the time	4121.074505865918
2320. poems of the past	and the present and time's laughingstocks both published	while hardy was at work on the dynasts draw heavily on poems	written before 1900	4295.954145793534
2321. satires of circumstance and moments of	vision coming during his most productive decade are relatively self-contained;	the former contains no poem dated before 1909-10- that	is no poem from a period covered by a previous volume- and the	latter has only a few such	4554.623664346411
2322. the last three volumes are again more dependent	on the past as hardy's creative powers declined in his old	age	2841.8674430556907
2323. these observations about hardy's productivity tally with	the details of his life as we know them	1259.639236792641
2324. the first productive period	came when he was considering poetry as a vocation before he had decided	to write fiction for a living	he wrote that he wrote verses 1865-1868; gave up verse for prose		4306.523310156857
2325. during the poetically sterile	years he was writing novels at the rate of almost one a year and was	in addition burdened with bad health		1800.5003826496807
2326. two entries in the early life support the assumption that	during this period hardy had virtually suspended the writing of poetry	3038.552415393994
2327. mrs hardy records that h at the end of november 1881	he makes a note of an intention to resume poetry as soon as possible	; and on christmas day 1890 hardy	wrote: while thinking of resuming 'the viewless wings of	poesy' before dawn this morning new horizons seemed to open and worrying	pettinesses to disappear	4372.550495494843
2328. there	are more poems dated in the 1890's than in the '80's- hardy	had apparently resumed the viewless wings as he decreased the volume	of his fiction- but none in 1891 the year of tess and only one	in 1895 the year of jude	6830.59582845846
2329. after 1895 the number increases and	in the next thirty years there is only one year for which there is no	dated poem- 1903 when hardy was at work on the dynasts	3451.490198169795
2330. the second productive period the decade from 1910 to 1920 can	be related to three events: the completion of the dynasts in 1909	which left hardy free of pressure for the first time in forty years;	the death of emma hardy in 1912 which had a profound emotional	effect on hardy for which he found release in poetry; and the first	world war	8474.335977216162
2331. it may seem strange that a poet should come to full	fruition in his seventies but we have it on hardy's own authority	that h he was a child till he was sixteen a youth till he was	five-and-twenty	and a young man till he was nearly fifty	life		3993.1663157213106
2332. we may carry this sequence one step further and say	that at seventy he was a poet at the height of his powers wanting only	the impetus of two tragedies one personal the other national to	loose those powers in poetry	6457.205579819494
2333. hardy's two productive decades	were separated by forty years yet between them he developed only in	that he became more steadily himself- it was a narrowing not an expanding	process	3200.6686535749977
2334. like a wise gardener hardy pruned away the shakespearian	sonnets and songs and the elements of meter and poetic diction	to which his personal style was not suited and let the main stock	of his talent flourish	5923.419581403563
2335. the range of the later poetry is considerably	narrower but the number of successful poems is far greater	1570.4297879895728
2336. we	can see the general characteristics of the earlier decade if we look	at two poems of very different qualities: revulsion	and neutral tones	3717.460563680101
2337. there is not much to be said for revulsion	259.62995296119306
2338. like about half of the 1860-70 poems it is a sonnet	on a conventional theme- the unhappiness of love	2608.6577838630724
2339. almost anyone could	have written it; it is competent in the sense that it makes a coherent	statement without violating the rules of the sonnet form but it	is entirely undistinguished and entirely unlike hardy	3755.811051764346
2340. the language	is the conventional language of the form; there is no phrase or image	that sounds like hardy or that is striking enough to give individuality	to the poem	4849.517998152898
2341. it is smoother than hardy usually is but with the	smoothness of anonymity	787.0582701308576
2342. it is obviously a young man's poem written	out of books and not out of experience; it asserts emotion	without evoking it- that is to say it is sentimental	4622.381768048852
2343. there are many	such competently anonymous performances among the earlier poems	506.63599472146507
2344. neutral tones we immediately recognize as a fine poem in	hardy's most characteristic style: the plain but not quite colloquial	language the hard particular colorless images the slightly odd	stanza-form the dramatic handling of the occasion the refusal to	resolve the issue- all these we have seen in hardy's best poems	7555.673166238843
2345. the poem does not distort the syntax of ordinary speech nor draw on exotic	sources of diction yet it is obviously not ordinary speech-	only hardy would say a grin of bitterness swept therebylike an	ominous bird a-wing or wrings with wrong or would describe	a winter sun as god-curst	4978.267666567133
2346. the details of the setting	of neutral tones are not strictly speaking metaphorical but	they combine to create a mood which is appropriate both to a dismal	winter day and to the end of love and in this way love and weather the	emotions and the elements symbolize each other in a way that is common	to many of hardy's best poems	and to	some moving passages in the novels as well		0.30166232349522504
2347. neutral	tones is an excellent example of hardy's mature style drawn	from his earliest productive period; i cite it as evidence that he	did not develop through new styles as he grew older	but that he simply learned to use better what he already had	4591.5576720335
2348. in the	poem we recognize and acknowledge one man's sense of the world; if	it is somber it is also precise and the precision lends authority to	the vision	4669.324302137744
2349. in revulsion on the other hand the pessimism is	a case not proven; the poem offers nothing to persuade us of the speaker's	right to speak as he does	3111.674409692387
2350. in the 1860-70 decade there are	many poems like revulsion but there is only one neutral tones	2138.189850913448
2351. hardy was not hardy very often	43.72959889518696
2352. the poems of 1912-13	offer a good example of hardy's style as it was manifested	in the later productive decade	2816.911682872834
2353. these are the poems hardy wrote after	the death of his first wife; they compose a painful elegy to what	might have been to a marriage that began with a promise of happiness	and ended in long years of suffering and hatred	4376.840421930697
2354. hardy obviously felt	that these poems were peculiarly personal and private; he sometimes	called them an expiation and he would not allow them to be published	in periodicals	4472.455538588835
2355. they are the only poems that he rearranged as	a group between their first appearance	and the publication of the collected poems	2187.665001894108
2356. the elegiac	tone is hardy's natural tone of voice and it is not surprising	that the 1912-13 poems are consistently and unmistakably his	3502.5471039487284
2357. the	view is always toward the past; but the mood is not quite nostalgic-	hardy would not allow sentiment to soften his sense of the irredeemable	pastness of the past and the eternal deadness of the dead	3965.250882889287
2358. the	poems are the epigraph tells us the traces of an ancient flame;	the fire of love is dead and hardy stands as the speaker does	in the last poem of the sequence over the burnt circle of charred sticks	and thinks of past happiness and present grief honest and uncomforted	7566.000560320373
2359. critically invisible modern revolt like x-rays and radioactivity	is perceived only by its effects at more materialistic social levels	where	it is called delinquency	2472.0494456594906
2360. disaffiliation by the way	is the term used by the critic and poet lawrence lipton who has	written several articles on this subject the first of which in the	nation quoted as epigraph we disaffiliate h- john l	lewis	6222.501932867346
2361. like the pillars of hercules like two ruined titans	guarding the entrance to one of dante's circles stand two	great dead juvenile delinquents- the heroes of the post-war generation:	the great saxophonist charlie parker and dylan thomas	3952.828846925987
2362. if	the word deliberate means anything both of them certainly deliberately	destroyed themselves	1178.2646320090055
2363. both of them were overcome by the horror	of the world in which they found themselves because at last they	could no longer overcome that world with the weapon of a purely lyrical	art	3653.040788430004
2364. both of them were my friends	65.0635115516768
2365. living in san francisco i saw	them seldom enough to see them with a perspective which was not distorted	by exasperation or fatigue	2307.514536681634
2366. so as the years passed i saw them	each time in the light of an accelerated personal conflagration	2355.033255288391
2367. the last time i saw bird at jimbo's bob city he was so	gone-	so blind to the world- that he literally sat down on me before he	realized i was there	3440.7573978705104
2368. what happened man	0.30041514999999996
2369. i said referring	to the pretentious jazz concert	167.393886162083
2370. evil man evil he	said and that's all he said for the rest of the night	1888.5097816807113
2371. about dawn	he got up to blow	93.89031064241428
2372. the rowdy crowd chilled into stillness and the fluent	melody spiraled through it	1186.7222512031217
2373. the last time i saw dylan	his self-destruction had not just passed the limits of rationality	1257.306470105348
2374. it	had assumed the terrifying inertia of inanimate matter	391.33228918388807
2375. being with	him was like being swept away by a torrent of falling stones	939.5266933139526
2376. now dylan thomas and charlie parker have a great deal more in common	than the same disastrous end	2352.453623882242
2377. as artists they were very similar	43.36154182164843
2378. they were both very fluent	22.423288149749066
2379. but this fluent enchanting utterance had	compared with important artists of the past relatively little content	1255.4471755806778
2380. neither of them got very far beyond a sort of entranced rapture	at his own creativity	1887.3650857624384
2381. the principal theme of thomas's poetry was	the ambivalence of birth and death- the pain of blood-stained creation	1563.8284429804733
2382. music of course is not so explicit an art but anybody who knew	charlie parker knows that he felt much the same way about his own	gift	4273.726029228157
2383. both of them did communicate one central theme: against the	ruin of the world there is only one defense- the creative act	2189.258894709235
2384. this	of course is the theme of much art- perhaps most poetry	955.8303746153846
2385. it is	the theme of horace who certainly otherwise bears little resemblance	to parker or thomas	1248.7751297594275
2386. the difference is that horace accepted his theme	with a kind of silken assurance	1403.9183003002245
2387. to dylan and bird it was an agony	and terror	373.82444169305205
2388. i do not believe that this is due to anything especially	frightful about their relationship to their own creativity	2587.8614452112147
2389. i believe	rather that it is due to the catastrophic world in which that creativity	seemed to be the sole value	2023.411752196086
2390. horace's column of imperishable	verse shines quietly enough in the lucid air of augustan rome	1633.5321053621071
2391. art	may have been for him the most enduring orderly and noble activity	of man	1097.4150400386445
2392. but the other activities of his life partook of these values	746.3073135599936
2393. they did not actively negate them	43.3000841208303
2394. dylan thomas's verse had to	find endurance in a world of burning cities and burning jews	1880.008685022558
2395. he was	able to find meaning in his art as long as it was the answer to air	raids and gas ovens	2174.110928650877
2396. as the world began to take on the guise of an immense	air raid or gas oven i believe his art became meaningless to him	3893.6195145806932
2397. i think all this could apply to parker just as well although because	of the nature of music it is not demonstrable- at least not	conclusively	2726.2721822314143
2398. thomas and parker have more in common than theme	attitude life pattern	959.428397726648
2399. in the practice of their art there is an	obvious technical resemblance	640.6130943505925
2400. contrary to popular belief they were	not great technical innovators	557.8926556229085
2401. their effects are only superficially	startling	44.057304016814776
2402. thomas is a regression from the technical originality and	ingenuity of writers like pierre reverdy or apollinaire	2134.6454332444087
2403. similarly	the innovations of bop and of parker particularly have been vastly	overrated by people unfamiliar with music especially by that ignoramus	the intellectual jitterbug the jazz aficionado	2971.1129251523253
2404. the tonal novelties	consist in the introduction of a few chords used in classical music	for centuries	2109.8675840563747
2405. and there is less rhythmic difference between progressive	jazz no matter how progressive and dixieland than there is	between two movements of many conventional symphonies	2603.1898847311486
2406. what parker	and his contemporaries- gillespie davis monk roach	etc- did was to absorb the musical ornamentation	of the older jazz into the basic structure of which it then became	an integral part and with which it then developed	6179.447438497524
2407. this is true	of the melodic line which could be put together from selected passages	of almost anybody- benny carter johnny hodges	2169.5559675127543
2408. it is true of	the rhythmic pattern in which the beat shifts continuously or at least	is continuously sprung so that it becomes ambiguous enough to allow	the pattern to be dominated by the long pulsations of the phrase or	strophe	6437.571415730317
2409. this is exactly what happened in the transition from baroque	to rococo music	786.1624563997043
2410. it is the difference between bach and mozart	250.01979107523204
2411. it is not a farfetched analogy to say that this is what thomas	did to poetry	1249.600884709993
2412. the special syntactical effects of a rimbaud or an edith	sitwell- actually ornaments- become the main concern	2133.904511316812
2413. the metaphysical	conceits which fascinate the reactionary generation still	dominant in backwater american colleges were embroideries	1245.891890731011
2414. thomas's	ellipses and ambiguities are ends in themselves	248.51834632453557
2415. the immediate	theme if it exists is incidental and his main theme- the terror of	birth- is simply reiterated	1732.2917819875788
2416. this is one difference between	bird and dylan which should be pointed out	1176.2772059284919
2417. again contrary to popular	belief there is nothing crazy or frantic about parker either musically	or emotionally	1419.3221810844657
2418. his sinuous melody is a sort of nai^ve transcendence	of all experience	957.1210236055573
2419. emotionally it does not resemble berlioz	or wagner; it resembles mozart	500.47333267904077
2420. this is true also of a painter	like jackson pollock	564.1654039512729
2421. he may have been eccentric in his behavior	but his paintings are as impassive as persian tiles	1417.8543667830238
2422. partly this difference	is due to the nature of verbal communication	756.2165137366419
2423. the insistent talk-aboutiveness	of the general environment obtrudes into even the most	idyllic poetry	948.4321189864746
2424. it is much more a personal difference	141.7831985782025
2425. thomas certainly	wanted to tell people about the ruin and disorder of the world	945.5461824904529
2426. parker and pollock wanted to substitute a work of art for the world	1183.4250004634434
2427. technique pure and simple rendition is not of major importance	but it is interesting that parker following lester young was	one of the leaders of the so-called saxophone revolution	3097.71537483707
2428. in modern	jazz the saxophone is treated as a woodwind and played with conventional	embouchure	1668.643884045232
2429. metrically thomas's verse was extremely conventional	as was incidentally the verse of that other tragic enrage hart	crane	1569.0792067032266
2430. i want to make clear what i consider the one technical	development in the first wave of significant post-war arts	2815.7623467839285
2431. ornament	is confabulation in the interstices of structure	165.91854323559153
2432. a poem by dylan	thomas a saxophone solo by charles parker a painting by jackson	pollock- these are pure confabulations as ends in themselves	3706.1331362186875
2433. confabulation	has come to determine structure	43.3182161511377
2434. uninhibited lyricism should	be distinguished from its exact opposite- the sterile extraneous	invention of the corn-belt metaphysicals or present blight of poetic	professors	3490.0216141534665
2435. just as hart crane had little influence on anyone	except very reactionary writers- like allen tate for instance	to whom valery was the last word in modern poetry and the felicities	of an apollinaire let alone a paul eluard were nonsense- so dylan	thomas's influence has been slight indeed	4905.006165823173
2436. in fact his only	disciple- the only person to imitate his style- was w s graham	who seems to have imitated him without much understanding and	who has since moved on to other methods	5475.668283265021
2437. thomas's principal influence	lay in the communication of an attitude- that of the now extinct	british romantic school of the new apocalypse- henry treece j	f hendry and others- all of whom were quite conventional	poets	3850.7160018449636
2438. parker certainly had much more of an influence	250.89223587855463
2439. at one	time it was the ambition of every saxophone player in every high school	band in america to blow like bird	2179.4129297299087
2440. even before his death this influence	had begun to ebb	562.0315839707341
2441. in fact the whole generation of the founding	fathers of bop- gillespie monk davis blakey and the	rest-	are just now at a considerable discount	2623.744631905721
2442. the main line of development	today goes back to lester young and by-passes them	1408.523890462688
2443. the point	is that many of the most impressive developments in the arts nowadays	are aberrant idiosyncratic	1400.7046178646945
2444. there is no longer any sense of continuing	development of the sort that can be traced from baudelaire to	eluard or for that matter from hawthorne through henry james to	gertrude stein	5157.504387490955
2445. the cubist generation before world war 1 and	on a lower level the surrealists of the period between the wars both	assumed an accepted universe of discourse in which to quote andre	breton it was possible to make definite advances exactly as in the	sciences	4608.974198771315
2446. i doubt if anyone holds such ideas today	250.45887371130857
2447. continuity exits	but like the neo-swing music developed from lester young it is	a continuity sustained by popular demand	1737.4386643059545
2448. in the plastic arts	a very similar situation exists	392.0238126981588
2449. surrealists like hans arp and max	ernst might talk of creation by hazard- of composing pictures by	walking on them with painted soles or by tossing bits of paper up in	the air	3540.4083449179293
2450. but it is obvious that they were self-deluded	246.86472572234862
2451. nothing looks	anything like an ernst or an arp but another ernst or arp	949.9129526439863
2452. nothing	looks less like their work than the happenings of random occasion	964.107188581224
2453. many of the post-world war 2 abstract expressionists apostles	of the discipline of spontaneity and hazard look alike and do look	like accidents	2335.390835625216
2454. the aesthetic appeal of pure paint laid on at random	may exist but it is a very impoverished appeal	2583.3030785853994
2455. once again what has	happened is an all-consuming confabulation of the incidentals the accidents	of painting	1262.0559728977912
2456. it is curious that at its best the work of this	school of painting- mark rothko jackson pollock clyfford still	robert motherwell willem de-kooning and the rest- resembles	nothing so much as the passage painting of quite unimpressive painters:	the mother-of-pearl shimmer in the background of a henry mcfee	itself a formula derived from renoir; the splashes of light and	black which fake drapery in the fashionable imitators of hals and sargent	0.30166232349522504
2457. often work of this sort is presented as calligraphy- the pure	utterance of the brush stroke seeking only absolute painteresque values	2034.4657541801867
2458. you have only to compare such painting with the work of say	sesshu to realize that someone is using words and brushes carelessly	3480.697004731474
2459. at its best the abstract expressionists achieve a simple rococo	decorative surface	641.5141611356679
2460. its poverty shows up immediately when compared	with tiepolo where the rococo rises to painting of extraordinary profundity	and power	2816.932319087369
2461. a tiepolo painting however confabulated is a	universe of tensions in vast depths	788.7266056662897
2462. a pollock is an object of art-	bijouterie- disguised only by its great size	1413.8448613889254
2463. in fact once the size	is big enough to cover a whole wall it turns into nothing more than	extremely expensive wallpaper	2180.55748332066
2464. now there is nothing wrong with complicated	wallpaper	251.03504368060763
2465. there is just more to tiepolo	43.70955804749629
2466. the great ashikaga	brush painters painted wallpapers too- at least portable ones	screens	1190.349309386597
2467. a process of elimination which leaves the artist with	nothing but the play of his materials themselves cannot sustain interest	in either artist or public for very long	2998.016018623134
2468. so in the last couple	of years abstract expressionism has tended toward romantic suggestion-	indications of landscape or living figures	2824.3526945220196
2469. anglo-saxon and greek epic each provide on two occasions	a seemingly authentic account of the narration of verse in the heroic	age	2182.4927977721677
2470. hrothgar's court bard sings of the encounters at finnsburg	and improvises the tale of beowulf's exploits in	a complimentary comparison of the geatish visitor with sigemund	; alcinou^s' court bard sings of the discovered adultery	of ares and aphrodite and takes up	a tale of odysseus while the ithacan wanderer listens on		5123.1673321544495
2471. nothing in all this is autobiographical: unlike	the poets of deor and widsith the poet of beowulf is	not concerned with his own identity; the poet of the odyssey	reputed blind reveals himself not at all in singing of the blind minstrel	demodocus	4472.9723749780305
2472. since none of these glimpses of poetizing without writing	is intended to incorporate a signature into the epic matter there	is prima-facie evidence that beowulf and the homeric poems each	derive from an oral tradition	5649.1375061259805
2473. that such a tradition lies behind	the iliad and the odyssey at least is hard to deny	1416.0255950679418
2474. milman	parry rigorously defended the observation that the extant homeric	poems are largely formulaic and was led to postulate that they could	be shown entirely formulaic if the complete corpus of greek epic survived;	he further reasoned that frequent formulas in epic verse indicate	oral composition and assumed the slightly less likely corollary	that oral epic is inclined towards the use of formulas	8474.907725379559
2475. proceeding from	parry's conclusions and adopting one of his schemata francis p	magoun jr argues that beowulf likewise was created from	a legacy of oral formulas inherited and extended by bards of successive	generations and the thesis is striking and compelling	4298.90587061827
2476. yet a fresh	inspection will indicate one crucial amendment: beowulf and	the homeric poems are not at all formulaic to the same extent	3493.8271312787883
2477. the bondage endurable by an oral poet is to be estimated only by a	very skilful oral poet but it appears safe to assume that no sustained	narrative in rhyme could be composed without extreme difficulty even	in a language of many terminal inflections	4536.2790514160015
2478. assonance seems nearly	as severe a curb although in a celebrated passage william of malmesbury	declares that a song of roland was intoned before the battle	commenced at hastings	4649.722379170484
2479. the anglo-saxon alliterative line and the	homeric hexameter probably imposed less of a restraint; the verse	of beowulf or of the iliad and the odyssey was not easy	to create but was not impossible for poets who had developed their talents	perforce in earning a livelihood	4691.62298479324
2480. yet certain aids were valuable	and quite credibly necessary for reciting long stretches of verse without	a pause	2357.209469365883
2481. the poet in a written tradition who generally never blots	a line may once in a while pause and polish without incurring blame	2313.179030029265
2482. but the oral poet cannot pause; he must improvise continuously	with no apparent effort	1412.053142834633
2483. even though the bondage of his verse is not	so great as the writing poet can manage it is still great enough for	him often to be seriously impeded unless he has aids to facilitate rapid	composition	3943.324376455638
2484. the germanic poet had such aids in the kennings which	provided for the difficulties of alliteration; the homeric poet	had epithets which provided for recurring needs in the hexameter	4669.933936069595
2485. either	poet could quickly and easily select words or phrases to supply	his immediate requirements as he chanted out his lines because the kennings	and the epithets made possible the construction of systems of numerous	synonyms for the chief common and proper nouns	4457.020005929612
2486. other synonyms	could of course serve the same function and for the sake of ease i	shall speak of kennings and epithets in the widest and loosest poss1ble	sense and name for example gar-dene a kenning for the danes	6201.451174066869
2487. verbal and adverbial elements too participated in each epic diction	but it is for the present sufficient to mark the large nominal and	adjectival supply of semantic near-equivalents and to designate the	members of any system of equivalents as basic formulas of the poetic	language	4600.666073848102
2488. limited to a few thousand lines of heroic verse in anglo-saxon	as in the other germanic dialects we cannot say how frequently	the kennings in beowulf recurred in contemporary epic on the same	soil	5470.973743066123
2489. but we can say that since a writing poet with leisure before	him would seem unlikely to invent a technique based upon frequent and	substantial circumlocution the kennings like the epithets must reasonably	be ascribed to an oral tradition	4132.527344848196
2490. one of the greatest	homerists of our time frederick m combellack argues that when	it is assumed the iliad and the odyssey are oral poems the	postulated single redactor called homer cannot be either credited with	or denied originality in choice of phrasing	6686.143363190533
2491. any example of grand	or exquisite diction may have been created by the poet who compiled numerous	lays into the two works we possess or may be due to one of his	completely	unknown fellow-craftsmen	3767.0503336255824
2492. the quest of the historical homer	is likely never to have further success; no individual word in the	iliad or the odyssey can be credited to any one man; no strikingly	effective element of speech in the extant poems can with assurance	be said not to have been a commonplace in the vaster epic corpus	that may have existed at the beginning of the first millennium before	christ	8831.93891107659
2493. this observation is of interest not only to students of homeric	poetry but to students of anglo-saxon poetry as well	1873.8132081621575
2494. to the	extent that a tale is twice told its final author must be suspect although	plagiarism in an oral tradition is less a misdemeanor than the	standard modus dicendi	4827.644556885351
2495. combellack argues further and here	he makes his main point that once the iliad and the odyssey	are thought formulaic poems composed for an audience accustomed to	formulaic poetry homeric critics are deprived of an entire domain they	previously found arable	4309.1933014897
2496. with a few important and a few more unimportant	exceptions no expression can be deemed le mot juste for its	context because each was very probably the only expression that long-established	practice and ease of rapid recitation would allow	6210.666239249282
2497. words	or phrases that connoisseurs have admired as handsome or ironic or	humorous must therefore lose merit and become regarded as mere inevitable	time-servers sometimes accurate and sometimes not	3113.323947822577
2498. this observation	too may have reference to anglo-saxon poetry	389.56787121576747
2499. to the extent that	a language is formulaic its individual components must be regarded	as no more distinguished than other cliches	2029.2456281415496
2500. w f bryan	suggests that certain kennings in beowulf were selected sometimes	for appropriateness and sometimes for ironic inappropriateness but	such a view would appear untenable unless it is denied that the language	of beowulf is formulaic	5921.46923345854
2501. if the master of scops who was most	responsible for the poem ever used kennings that were traditional he	was at least partly deprived of free will and not inclined towards shrewd	and sophisticated misuse of speech elements	4035.2210258426844
2502. once many significant	phrases are found in theory or in recurrent practice to provide for	prosodic necessity they are not to be defended for their semantic properties	in isolated contexts	4831.948462041329
2503. it is false to be certain of having discovered	in the language of beowulf such effects as intentional irony	1721.4364547294904
2504. yet if the argument is turned awry there may be found a	great deal in bryan's view after all	2596.453069846598
2505. a formulaic element need not	be held meaningless merely because it was selected with little conscious	reflection	1407.8370392172285
2506. time-servers though the periphrastic expressions are	they may nevertheless be handsome or ironic or humorous	1636.197047223713
2507. a long evolution	in an oral tradition caused the poetic language of the heroic	age to be based upon formulas that show the important qualities of things	and these formulas are therefore potentially rather than always actually	accurate	4026.4787367341514
2508. true we do not know how they were regarded in their	day but we need not believe the epic audience to have been more insensitive	to the formulas than the numerous scholars of modern times who	have read germanic or homeric poetry all their lives and still found	much to admire in occasional occurrences of the most familiar phrases	8170.281407084125
2509. nouns and adjectives in a written tradition are chosen for the nonce;	in an oral tradition they may be chosen for the entire epic corpus	and tend towards idealization rather than distinctive delineation	3546.338685990492
2510. reliance is therefore not to be placed upon the archaeological particulars	in an oral poem; no-one today would hope to discover the unmistakable	ruins of heorot or the palace of priam	5005.260086769707
2511. a ship at dry-dock	could be called a foamy-necked floater in anglo-saxon or a swift	ship in greek	1568.8113310798508
2512. even when defenseless of weapons the danes would be	gar-dene and priam would be |e|u|m|m|e|l|i|h|s	1644.9990364422586
2513. achilles like siegfried in the nibelungenlied	is potentially the swiftest of men and may accordingly	be called swift-footed even when he stands idle	2318.1948721466542
2514. in coriolanus	the agnomen of marcius is used deliberately and pointedly but the	homeric epithets and the anglo-saxon kennings are used casually and	recall to the hearer a familiar story or situation or a useful or	pleasant quality of the referent	6479.410313561611
2515. the epic language was not entirely	the servant of the poet; it was partly his master	1255.6842721026278
2516. the poet's	intentions are difficult to discern and except to biographers unimportant;	the language however is a proper object of scrutiny and the	effects of the language are palpable even if sometimes inevitable	5318.582436070992
2517. beowulf and the homeric poems appear oral compositions	167.21291874372264
2518. yet	they are written; at some stage in their evolution they were transcribed	1173.8708696124886
2519. albert b lord suggests that the homeric poems were dictated	to a scribe by a minstrel who held in his mind the poems fully matured	but did not himself possess the knowledge of writing since it	would	be useless to his guild and magoun argues that the beowulf	poet and cynewulf may have dictated their verse in the same fashion	5516.89694356349
2520. this explanation is attractive but is vitiated at least in part by	the observation that cynewulf though he used kennings in the traditional	manner was a literate man who four times inscribed his name by runes	into his works	6187.068008075721
2521. if cynewulf was literate the beowulf poet	may have been also and so may the final redactor of the iliad and	the odyssey	2326.838399748655
2522. in lieu of the amanuensis to the blind or illiterate	bard one may conceive of a man who heard a vast store of oral poetry	recited and became intimately familiar with the established aids	to poetizing and himself wrote his own compositions or his edition of	the compositions of the past	7531.704779609921
2523. other theories of origin are compatible	with the formulaic theory: beowulf may contain a design for	terror and the iliad may have a vast hysteron-proteron pattern answering	to a ceramic pattern produced during the geometric period in	pottery	4041.4936954549084
2524. the account of the growth and final transcription of these	epics rests partly however upon the degree to which they were formulaic	3259.012999863002
2525. carl eduard schmidt counted 1804 different lines repeated	exactly in the two homeric poems and by increasing this figure so	as to include lines repeated with very slight modifications he counted	2118 different lines used a total of 5612 times	4216.188793523108
2526. thus one line in	five from the iliad and the odyssey is to be found somewhere	else in the two poems	3059.6118976868925
2527. the ratio is thoroughly remarkable because the	lines are so long- half again as long as those of beowulf	1724.7581807474191
2528. anglo-saxon	poetry appears to have no comparable amount of repetition;	there is no reason to think that the scop used and re-used whole lines	and even lengthy passages after the manner of his homeric colleague	5622.317684428247
2529. in determining the extent to which any poem is formulaic it is idle	however to inspect nothing besides lines repeated in their entirety	for a stock of line-fragments would be sufficient to permit the poet	to extemporize with deftness if they provided for prosodic needs	4601.364236393734
2530. the closest scrutiny is owed to the anglo-saxon kennings and the homeric	epithets; if any words or phrases are formulaic they will be	3500.2651486334516
2531. the iliad has two words for the shield |a|s|p|i|s	and |s|a|k|o|s	505.1308379931638
2532. recent criticism of great expectations has tended to emphasize	its symbolic and mythic content to show as m d zabel has	said of dickens generally that much of the novel's impact resides	in its allegoric insight and moral metaphor	6177.115935550582
2533. j h miller's	excellent chapter on great expectations has lately illustrated	how fruitfully that novel can be read from such a perspective	2179.8145427039067
2534. in his analysis however he touches upon but fails to explore an idea	generally neglected in discussions of the book which i believe is	central to its art- the importance of human hands as a recurring feature	of the narrative	6302.0508006534155
2535. this essay seeks to make that exploration	92.82603365888981
2536. dickens was not for nothing the most theatrical of the great victorian	writers	1184.3219726310483
2537. he knew instinctively that next to voice and face an	actor's hands are his most useful possession- that in fiction as	in the theatre gesture is an indispensable shorthand for individualizing	character and dramatizing action and response	3958.3448195162264
2538. it is hardly accidental	therefore that many of his most vivid figures do suggestive or	eccentric things with their hands	2818.816887202571
2539. in great expectations the hands	become almost an obsession	262.5246545499902
2540. mr jaggers habitually bites his	forefinger	a gesture which conveys both contempt and the inscrutable abstractedness	that half fascinates half terrifies all who have dealings with him	4264.257594478587
2541. miss havisham's withered hands heavy as if her unhappiness were	somehow concentrated in them move in restless self-pity between her	broken heart and her walking stick	2714.52230755211
2542. pumblechook's signature	is the perpetually extended glad hand	248.89538088615828
2543. wemmick reveals his self-satisfaction	by regularly rubbing his hands together	370.17176409200226
2544. old mr pocket's	frantic response to life imprisonment with a useless social-climbing	wife is to put his two hands into his disturbed hair and make	an extraordinary effort to lift himself up by it whereas	joe gargery endures the shrewish onslaughts of mrs joe by apologetically	drawing the back of his hand across and across his nose	8007.923083598691
2545. such mannerisms would be less worthy of remark were it	not that in great expectations as in no other of dickens' novels	hands serve as a leitmotif of plot and theme- a kind of unifying	symbol or natural metaphor for the book's complex of human interrelationships	and the values and attitudes that motivate them	5173.768606674212
2546. dickens	not only reveals character through gesture he makes hands a crucial	element of the plot a means of clarifying the structure of the novel	by helping to define the hero's relations with all the major characters	and a device for ordering such diverse themes as guilt pursuit	crime greed education materialism enslavement	friendship romantic love forgiveness and redemption	8218.02480237556
2547. we have only to think of lady macbeth or the policeman-murderer	in thomas burke's famous story the hands of mr ottermole	to realize that hands often call up ideas of crime and punishment	3534.2784162674952
2548. so it is with great expectations whether the hands be	orlick's	as he strikes down mrs gargery or pip's as he steals a	pie from her pantry	4303.695577794189
2549. such associations suit well with the gothic or	mystery-story aspects of dickens' novel but on a deeper plane they	relate to the themes of sin guilt and pursuit that have recently	been analyzed by other critics	3854.0545172815823
2550. the novel opens with a fugitive	convict frantically trying to avoid the nemesis of being laid hands	on- a mysterious figure who looks into pip's frightened	eyes in the churchyard as if he were eluding the hands of the dead	people stretching up cautiously out of their graves to get a twist	upon his ankle and pull him in	8194.020833847926
2551. magwitch terrifies pip into	stealing a pork pie for him by creating the image in the boy's imagination	of a bogy man who may softly creep h his way to him and tear	him open in him	3957.2022826208863
2552. as pip agonizes	over the theft that his own hands have committed his guilty conscience	projects itself upon the wooden finger of a local signpost transforming	it into a phantom devoting me to the hulks	5628.66130228853
2553. held	upside down in the graveyard pip clings in terror with both hands	to his convict; later he flees in panic from the family table	just as his theft is about to be discovered and is blocked at the	front door by a soldier who accusingly holds out a pair of handcuffs which	he has brought to gargery's forge for mending	5555.085744840818
2554. through such details	dickens indicates at the outset that guilt is a part of the ironic	bond between pip and magwitch which is so unpredictably to alter	both their lives	4848.152438644508
2555. since they commonly translate thoughts and	feelings into deeds hands naturally represent action and since nearly	half the characters in great expectations are of the underworld	or closely allied to it the linking of hands with crime or violence	is not to be wondered at	4619.625417200653
2556. dickens for excellent psychological reasons	never fully reveals magwitch's felonious past but pip at the	convict's climactic reappearance in london shrinks from clasping	a hand which he fears might be stained with blood	5329.79629388713
2557. orlick	slouches about the forge like cain with his hands in his pockets	and when he shouts abuse at mrs joe for objecting	to his holiday she claps her hands in a tantrum beats them upon her	bosom and upon her knees and clenches them in her husband's	hair	4869.1830035158055
2558. this last rampage is only the prelude to the vicious	blow upon her head dealt by some unknown hand whose identity	is later revealed not verbally but through a manual action- the tracing	of orlick's hammer upon a slate	6200.979087832261
2559. pip himself is to feel the	terror of orlick's murderous hand in his secret rendezvous	at the sluicehouse on the marshes	2027.3738665281512
2560. dickens lays great emphasis on	the hands in this scene	559.3946863851804
2561. orlick shakes his hand at pip bangs the table	with his fist draws his unclenched hand across his mouth as if	his mouth watered for his victim lets his hands hang loose and	heavy at his sides and pip observes him so intensely that he knows	of the slightest action of his fingers	5123.139855889721
2562. orlick might almost	be magwitch's bogy man come alive a figure of nemesis from pip's	phantasy of guilt	2355.2975488248308
2563. the scarred disfigured wrists of mr	jaggers' housekeeper are the tell-tale marks of her sinister	past for her master coolly exhibiting them to his dinner guests makes	a point of the force of grip there is in these hands	4116.4035406848
2564. jaggers'	iron control over her	any dish she put before him hesitatingly as if she dreaded his calling	rests on his having once got her acquitted	of a murder charge by cleverly contriving her sleeves at the trial to	conceal her strength and by passing off the lacerations on the backs	of her hands as the scratches of brambles rather than of human fingernails	8545.920658457786
2565. it is the similarity between estella's hands and molly's	that provides pip with a vital clue to the real identity of both and	establishes a symbolic connection between the underworld of crime and	the genteel cruelty of satis house	4120.251887465904
2566. finally magwitch's pursuit	of compeyson his archenemy and betrayer begins by his holding him	in a vicelike grip on the river flats to frustrate his escape and culminates	in his laying his hand on his cloak to identify him	thus precipitating the death-locked struggle in the water during which	compeyson drowns	7513.41448803254
2567. magwitch's hand here ironically becomes the agent	of justice	260.1372894085857
2568. but only in one of its aspects is great expectations	a tale of violence revenge and retribution	2122.3929222660236
2569. money so	important a theme elsewhere in dickens is here central and hands are	often associated in some way with the false values- acquisitiveness	snobbery self-interest hypocrisy toadyism irresponsibility injustice-	that attach to a society based upon the pursuit of wealth	4298.252389109974
2570. dickens suggests	the economic evils of such a society on the first page	of his novel in the description of pip's five little dead brothers	who gave up trying to get a living exceedingly early in that universal	struggle who seemed to have all been born on their backs	with their hands in their trousers-pockets and had never taken them	out	in this state of existence	8626.189864671253
2571. pip's great expectations his	progress through illusion and disillusionment turn somewhat as they	do for the naive hero of dreiser's american tragedy upon	the	lure of genteel prosperity through unearned income- what wemmick calls	portable property and what jaggers reproaches pip for letting	slip through his fingers	4728.185978637494
2572. since a gentleman	must if possible avoid sullying them by work his hands as importantly	as his accent become the index of social status	3704.9927123113057
2573. almost the first	step in the corruption of pip's values is the unworthy shame he	feels when estella cruelly remarks the coarseness of his hands: they	had never troubled me before but they troubled me now as vulgar	appendages	4121.274913134826
2574. pip imagines how estella would look down upon	joe's hands roughened by work in the smithy and the deliberate contrast	between her white hands and his blackened ones is made to symbolize	the opposition of values between which pip struggles- idleness	and work artificiality and naturalness gentility and commonness coldness	and affection- in fact between satis house and the forge	8269.427350416383
2575. when the snobbery that alienates pip from joe finally gives way before	the deeper and stronger force of love the reunion is marked by an	embarrassed handshake at which pip exclaims no don't wipe it	off- for god's sake give me your blackened hand!	pip's abject leave-taking of miss havisham during which he kneels	to kiss her hand signalizes his homage to a supposed patroness who	seems to be opening up for him a new world of glamour; when on the	journey to london that immediately follows he pauses nostalgically	to lay his hand upon the finger-post at the end of the village the wooden	pointer symbolically designates a spiritual frontier between innocence	and the corruption of worldly vanity	0.20124717349522497
2576. incidentally one cannot	miss the significance of this gesture for dickens reintroduces it associatively	in pip's mind at another moral and psychological crisis-	his painful recognition in a talk with herbert pocket that his	hopeless attachment to estella is as self-destructive as it is romantic	6895.900862032747
2577. in both cases the finger-post represents pip's heightened awareness	of contrary magnetisms	639.5207766057907
2578. a variety of hand movements helps	dramatize the moral climate of the fallen world pip encounters beyond	the forge	2605.157804335472
2579. the vulturelike attendance of the pocket family upon	miss havisham is summed up in the hypocritical gestures of miss camilla	pocket who puts her hand to her throat in a feigned spasm of	grief-stricken choking then lays it upon her heaving bosom with	an unnatural fortitude of manner and finally kisses it to	miss havisham in a parody of the lady's own mannerism toward estella	5709.554335574788
2580. pumblechook's hands throughout the novel serve to travesty greed	and hypocritical self-aggrandizement	961.6523807878502
2581. we first see him shaking mrs	joe's hand on discovering the sizable amount of the premium paid	to her husband for pip's indenture as an apprentice and later pumping	pip's hands for the hundredth time at least	in effusive congratulation to pip on	his expectations	4594.737981553184
2582. we take leave of pumblechook as he gloats over pip's	loss of fortune extending his hand with a magnificently forgiving	air and exhibiting the same fat five fingers one of which	he identifies with the finger of providence and shakes at pip	in a canting imputation of the latter's ingratitoode and	his own generosity as pip's earliest benefactor	8121.70777586167
2583. pip first learns the stupendous power of money from the	sycophantic tailor mr trabb whose brutality to his boy helper exactly	matches	the financial resource of each new customer and whose fawning	hands touch the outside of each elbow and rub	pip out of the shop	4686.7576294817645
2584. the respectability which money confers implies	a different etiquette and upon taking up the life of a london gentleman	pip must learn from herbert pocket that the spoon is not generally	used over-hand but under	5662.960899038207
2585. the following items may be specified in actual or symbolic form in the	operands of those instructions which refer to the particular items:	channel unit combined channel and unit combined arm and file unit	record synchronizers inquiry synchronizers and alteration switches	4335.496521976302
2586. the declarative operation equ is used to equate symbolic names	to item numbers	1175.9964210706914
2587. certain autocoder	statements make provision for more parameters than may be contained	in the operand of a single line on the autocoder	coding sheet	2459.3177829780507
2588. when this is the case the appropriate section of this	manual will indicate that continuation cards may be used	2575.7094818498013
2589. thus	when specifically permitted the operand of a given line on the autocoder	coding sheet may be continued in the operand of from one to	four additional lines which immediately follow	3343.900004890408
2590. the label and	operation columns must be blank and the continuation of the operand	must begin in column 21; ie it must be left-justified in the	operand column of the coding sheet	5161.577200222186
2591. the operand need not extend across	the entire operand column of either the header card or continuation	cards but may end with the comma following any parameter	2854.811294096612
2592. remarks may	appear to the right of the last parameter on each card provided they	are separated from the operand by at least two blank spaces	4089.908999847293
2593. illustration	of the use of continuation cards are included throughout the	examples illustrating the various statements	1261.0904068466532
2594. if a continuation	card follows a statement that does not permit continuation cards	the compiler will generate a nop and issue an error message	3712.0672629210567
2595. additional	restrictions regarding the use of continuation cards with macro-instructions	appear on page 106	939.475544314763
2596. electronic switches	the assignment of actual addresses to symbolic	index word and electronic switch names occurs in phase 3 of the	autocoder processor	3481.601588535097
2597. the initial availability of index words and electronic	switches is determined by a table which is included in the compiler	systems tape	2181.340770819352
2598. this table originally indicates that index words	1 through 96 and electronic switches 1 through 30 are available for	assignment to symbolic references; index words 97 through 99 are	not available	4976.465177741637
2599. the initial setting of this table may be altered however	as described in the 70707074 data processing system bulletin	ibm 70707074 compiler system: operating procedure	form j28-6105	2847.4868253581203
2600. during the first pass of phase 3 references	to the actual addresses of index words and electronic switches	are collected and the availability table is updated	4093.4623488470256
2601. at the end	of this pass the table indicates which index words and electronic switches	are not available for assignment to symbolic references	2308.7913833693665
2602. both index words and electronic switches may have been made unavailable	before the start of assignment in one of the following ways:	the initial setting of the availability table indicated that the	index word or electronic switch was not available for assignment	6563.471090970741
2603. the one- two-digit number of the index word or electronic switch	was used in the operand of a symbolic machine instruction to specify	indexing or as a parameter which is always an index word or electronic	switch eg   the one- or two-digit number of	the index word or electronic switch was used in the operand of an equ	statement eg    when the index words or electronic	switches are reserved because of actual usage in the statements	described above the position or order of the statements within the program	is not important; any such reference will make the index word	or electronic switch unavailable at the end of this pass	0.20124717349522497
2604. during	the assignment pass of phase 3 index words and electronic switches	are reserved as they are encountered during assignment	2819.5946377741134
2605. index	words and electronic switches may be reserved in the following ways	640.5496158344911
2606. the first two methods apply to both index words and electronic switches;	the third applies only to index words	2614.616955521516
2607. during the assignment	pass each instruction is examined for reference to the symbolic	name of an index word or electronic switch	2039.5764606060334
2608. when such a reference	is found an actual address is assigned and the availability table is	changed so that the assigned index word or switch is no longer available	for later assignment	5189.926867412036
2609. if the one- or two-digit address of	an index word or electronic switch is used or is included in the operand	of an xreserve or sreserve statement	the corresponding index word or electronic switch is reserved	3872.9225923389736
2610. if a statement has been assigned an address in the index word	area  by means of an	origin statement which refers to an actual address the	corresponding index word will be reserved	5176.183573602926
2611. these entries should normally	appear at the beginning of the program or immediately following each	litorigin statement	1418.4217383278324
2612. otherwise symbolic names may have	previously been assigned to these same index words	1182.992061571395
2613. the preceding methods allow	efficient use of index words and electronic switches during a sectionalized	or multi-phase program particularly when used in conjunction	with the litorigin statement	2862.117241162746
2614. extreme caution should	be used however to avoid the conflicting usage of an index word or electronic	switch which may result from the assignment of more than one	name or function to the same address	5657.0640803011875
2615. if the symbolic name or	actual address of an index word or electronic switch appears or is included	in the operand of an xrelease or srelease	statement the specified index word or electronic switch	will again be made available regardless of the method by which it	was reserved	4843.6481755385375
2616. it will not however be used for symbolic assignment until	all other index words or electronic switches have been assigned for	the first time	3684.985065176814
2617. if at any time during the assignment pass	the compiler finds that there are no more index words available for assignment	the warning message no more index words available	will be placed in the object program listing the table will be altered	to show that index words 1 through 96 are available and the assignment	will continue as before	5482.146329380621
2618. if the compiler finds that there are	no more electronic switches available for assignment the warning message	no more electronic switches available will be placed in	the object program listing the table will be altered to show that electronic	switches 1 through 30 are available and assignment will continue	as before	7556.512350949366
2619. the resultant conflicting usage of index words or electronic	switches may be avoided by reducing the number of symbolic names	used eg through the proper use of the equ xrelease	or srelease statements	3541.484382507554
2620. as noted in appendix	c index words 97 through 99 are never available for assignment	to symbolic names by the compiler; also index words 93 through	96 may have been made unavailable for assignment	5457.341647359668
2621. statements	autocoder declarative statements provide the processor	with the necessary information to complete the imperative operations	properly	1424.3414176772867
2622. declarative statements are never executed in the object program	and should be separated from the program instruction area placed	preferably at its beginning or end	3905.938212499812
2623. otherwise special care must be	taken to branch around them so that the program will not attempt to execute	something in a data area as an instruction	2856.214854305431
2624. if the compiler does	encounter such statements a warning message will be issued	1187.4139086872906
2625. 70707074	autocoder includes the following declarative statements: da	dc drdw	dsw dline	equ code dtf	diocs	and duf	1563.142636648745
2626. da dc	dtf and dline require more than one entry	562.2228756395509
2627. the da statement is used to name and define the positions and	length of fields within an area	1578.7917166425323
2628. the dc statement is used to name	and enter constants into the object program	1416.9452464360375
2629. since the 7070 and 7074	make use of record definition words to read write move	and otherwise examine blocks of storage the da and dc statements	provide the option of generating rdws automatically	3552.5784571867493
2630. when so instructed autocoder will generate one or more rdws	and assign them successive locations immediately preceding the area	with which they are to be associated	4104.159321927963
2631. an rdw will be of the	form f where xxxx is the starting location of the area and yyyy	is its ending location	2330.396480074464
2632. these addresses are calculated automatically	by the processor	251.95879075347585
2633. in some cases it may be more advantageous	to assign locations to rdws associated with da and dc	areas in some other part of storage ie not immediately preceding	the da or dc areas	3646.67516748913
2634. the drdw statement may be	used for this purpose	388.2757759089753
2635. the drdw statement may also be used to	generate an rdw defining any area specified by the programmer	1570.5641463457273
2636. as many as ten digital switches may be named and provided	by the dsw statement for consideration by the setsw and	logic macro-instructions	3483.838024007837
2637. each switch occupies one digit position	in a word can be set on or off and is considered	as logically equivalent to an electronic switch	2617.727669678253
2638. it cannot however	be referred to by electronic switch commands eg esn bsn	etc	1408.4972393386956
2639. an individual switch or the entire set of switches in	a word may be tested or altered as desired	1733.4264949286558
2640. through use of	the dline statement a means is provided for specifying both	the editing of fields to be inserted in a print line area and the layout	of the area itself	5172.138354553277
2641. the area may include constant information supplied	by the programmer	376.33257259224445
2642. the area may also be provided with additional	data during the running of the object program by means of edmov	or move macro-instructions	3486.5486967719103
2643. the declarative statement	equ permits the programmer to equate symbolic names to actual	index words electronic switches arm and file numbers tape channel	and unit numbers alteration switches etc and to equate a symbol	to another symbol or to an actual address	4409.440191901405
2644. the diocs	dtf and duf statements are used when required by the inputoutput	control system	1640.6639163434295
2645. diocs is used to select the major	methods of processing to be used and to name the index words used	by iocs	2185.8486926225187
2646. each tape file must be described by tape file specifications	produced by dtfs	1180.8392719385088
2647. in addition to information related	to the file and its records the file specifications contain subroutine	locations and the location of tape label information	2465.765801487868
2648. a duf	entry must be supplied for every unit record file describing the type	of file and the unit record equipment to be used	3716.445496755473
2649. the duf also	supplies the locations of subroutines written by the user that are	unique to the file	1571.738958580096
2650. a full description of the diocs	dtf and duf statements is contained in the 7070 data processing	system bulletin ibm 7070 inputoutput control system	form j28-6033-1	4082.916285198016
2651. brief descriptions of these three declarative	statements and detailed descriptions of the formats and functions	of each of the other 70707074 autocoder declarative statements follow	below	2734.097249524934
2652. when	the inputoutput control system is to be used in a program a	diocs statement must be used to select the major methods of processing	to be used	4465.848077108401
2653. this statement also allows the naming of the index	words used by iocs	794.0047070728052
2654. the basic	format of the diocs statement is as follows:  anylabel	is any symbolic label; it may be omitted	2590.329260720361
2655. the entry diocs	must be written exactly as shown	261.9904815991651
2656. the first item in the	operand iocsixf is used to specify the first iocs index	word for programs using tape files	3056.9882496705136
2657. this item may be a symbolic	name or an actual one-digit or two-digit index word address in the range	3-94	1891.334234499746
2658. if the first item in the operand is omitted the symbolic name	iocsixf will be assigned	1895.261365816185
2659. when an actual index word or a	symbolic address is specified autocoder will equate the name iocsixf	to it	1741.2019866406197
2660. the second item in the operand iocsixg	is used to specify the second iocs index word for programs	using tape files	3043.8085904337854
2661. this item may be a symbolic name or an actual one-digit	or two-digit index word address in the range 3-94	1891.334234499746
2662. if the second	item in the operand is omitted the symbolic name iocsixg	will be assigned	1890.0800224332918
2663. when an actual index word or a symbolic address	is specified autocoder will equate iocsixg to it	1419.1376419719359
2664. in the midwest oxidation ponds are used extensively for the treatment	of domestic sewage from suburban areas	2134.7621912352897
2665. the high cost of land	and a few operational problems resulting from excessive loadings have	created the need for a wastewater treatment system with the operational	characteristics of the oxidation pond but with the ability to treat	more organic matter per unit volume	4486.489292135952
2666. research at fayette missouri	on oxidation ponds has shown that the bod in the treated	effluent varied from 30 to 53 mgl with loadings from 8 to	120 lb boddayacre	4837.554465600995
2667. since experience indicates that effluents	from oxidation ponds do not create major problems at these bod	concentrations the goal for the effluent quality of the accelerated	treatment system was the same as from conventional oxidation ponds	3883.1389361816073
2668. recent studies by weston and stack had indicated that a turbine	aerator could be added to an oxidation pond to increase the rate of oxygen	transfer	4079.7525985955735
2669. their study showed that it was possible to transfer 3	to 4 lb of oxygenhrhp	1089.5134726404106
2670. o'connor and eckenfelder	discussed the use of aerated lagoons for treating organic wastes	1178.552075413382
2671. they indicated that a 4-day retention aerated lagoon would give 60	to 76 per cent bod reduction	1425.0138208798958
2672. later eckenfelder increased	the efficiency of treatment to between 75 and 85 per cent in the summer	months	2349.1548848750294
2673. it appeared from the limited information available that the	aerated lagoon might offer a satisfactory means of increasing the capacity	of existing oxidation ponds as well as providing the same degree	of treatment in a smaller volume	3982.5648555730745
2674. with	the development of the red bridge subdivision south of kansas city	missouri the developer was faced with the problem of providing adequate	sewage disposal	3897.6482899745897
2675. the sewage system from kansas city was not	expected to serve the red bridge area for several years	1570.13489855936
2676. this necessitated	the construction of temporary sewage treatment facilities with	an expected life from 5 to 15 yr	2364.765020368045
2677. for the initial development an	oxidation pond was constructed as shown in figure 1	942.8104565748193
2678. the oxidation pond	has a surface area of 4	392.6572725865602
2679. 77 acres and a depth of 4 ft	167.3076078889667
2680. the pond	is currently serving 1230 persons or 260 persons per acre	962.8557056417751
2681. in the summer	of 1960 the oxidation pond became completely septic and emitted	obnoxious odors	1105.207566449196
