2682. it was possible to maintain aerobic conditions in the	pond by regular additions of sodium nitrate until the temperature decreased	and the algae population changed from blue-green to green algae	4804.800092832558
2683. the anaerobic conditions in the existing oxidation pond	necessitated examination of other methods for supplying additional oxygen	than by sodium nitrate	2024.9627207557278
2684. at the same time further expansion in the	red bridge subdivision required the construction of additional sewage	treatment facilities	2594.134186733761
2685. the large land areas required for oxidation	ponds made this type of treatment financially unattractive to the developer	1569.3302184617833
2686. it was proposed that aerated lagoons be used to eliminate the	problem at the existing oxidation ponds and to provide the necessary	treatment for the additional development	4316.373367903205
2687. the lack	of adequate data on the aerated lagoon system prompted the developer	to construct an aerated lagoon pilot plant to determine its feasibility	for treating domestic sewage	3000.9467560280405
2688. the pilot plant was a circular lagoon	81 ft in diam at the surface and 65 ft in diam at the bottom	4 ft below the surface with a volume of 121000 gal	5338.507933759216
2689. the	side slopes were coated with fiberglas matting coated with asphalt to	prevent erosion	936.3669109331701
2690. the pilot lagoon was located as shown in figure 1	to serve the area just south of the existing housing area	3055.4324209072615
2691. the major	contributor was a shopping center with houses being added to the system	as the subdivision developed	1582.5537711055017
2692. the pilot lagoon was designed to handle	the wastes from 314 persons with a 4-day aeration period	2124.0076841190144
2693. initially	the wastewater would be entirely from the shopping center with the	domestic sewage from the houses increasing over an 18-month period	2195.9018777599786
2694. this	operation would permit evaluation of the pilot plant with a slowly	increasing load over a reasonable period of time	2824.920964558126
2695. the pilot	plant was equipped with a 3-hp turbine aerator	375.07118941165066
2696. the	aerator had a variable-speed drive to permit operation through a range	of speeds	1420.8868976171816
2697. the sewage flow into the treatment plant was metered and	continuously recorded on 24-hr charts	1098.3995106229063
2698. the raw sewage was introduced	directly under the turbine aerator to insure maximum mixing of the	raw sewage with the aeration tank contents	3491.891678215533
2699. the effluent was collected	through two pipes and discharged to the blue river through a surface	drainage ditch	1573.058024758135
2700. composite samples were collected at	weekly intervals	140.50509114575775
2701. the long retention period and the complete mixing	concept prevented rapid changes in either the mixed liquor or in the effluent	2034.7386236268067
2702. weekly samples would make any changes more readily discernible	than daily samples	949.7198858282609
2703. the composite samples were normally collected	over a 6-hr period but an occasional 24-hr composite was made	1415.6224191506267
2704. examination of the operations of the shopping center permitted correlation	of the 6-hr composite samples with 24-hr operations	2354.76621468053
2705. the	data indicated that the organic load during the 6-hr composites was	essentially 50 per cent of the 24-hr organic load	2021.2896772612708
2706. grab samples	were collected from the existing oxidation pond to determine its	operating conditions	1419.0084674855643
2707. efforts were made to take the grab samples at	random periods so that the mass of data could be treated as a 6-hr	composite sample	2594.0758425358704
2708. a single 24-hr composite sample indicated that the	sewage flow pattern and characteristics were typical	1643.3349471008726
2709. operations	the bod of the influent to the pilot plant varied	between 110 and 710 mgl with an average of 350 mgl	2177.7306472102296
2710. this was equivalent to 240 mglbod on a 24-hr basis	559.9409404711012
2711. the	bod of the raw sewage was typical of domestic sewage from a	subdivision	947.4440767146004
2712. the bod in the effluent averaged 58 mgl a 76-per	cent reduction over the 24-hr period	1877.0454094902202
2713. examination of the data	in table 1 shows that a few samples contributed to raising the effluent	bod	1567.3999174479873
2714. the periods of high effluent bod occurred during	cold periods when operational problems with the aerator resulted	2123.2689397688478
2715. ice caused the aerator to overload straining the drive belts	375.44180967273326
2716. the	slippage of the drive belts caused the aerator to slow down and reduce	oxygen transfer as well as the mixing of the raw sewage	3919.3964156186835
2717. the	organic loading on the unit averaged 32 lb of bodday or about	2 lb bodday1000 cu ft aeration capacity	1887.403260415337
2718. needless	to say the organic load was very low on a volumetric basis but was	270 lb boddayacre on a surface loading basis	3476.1745505224835
2719. it seems that	the aerated lagoon was a very heavily loaded oxidation pond or a lightly	loaded activated sludge system	1896.8984995921492
2720. the flow rate remained relatively	constant during the winter months as shown in table 1	1643.7032115413429
2721. with	the spring rains the flow rose rapidly due to infiltration in open	sewers	941.2033099639086
2722. as construction progresses the volume of storm drainage will	be sharply reduced	962.1106646715383
2723. the retention period in the aerated lagoon ranged	from 9	377.28746293740517
2724. 6 days averaging 6	4.462847317279411
2725. the large amount	of vegetable grindings from the grocery store in the shopping center	created a suspended solids problem	1728.9953863919648
2726. the vegetables were not readily metabolized	by the bacteria in the aeration unit and tended to float on	the surface	2821.985310558149
2727. a skimming device at the effluent weir prevented loss of	most of these light solids	1097.3556684092628
2728. the average volatile suspended solids in	the effluent was 75 mgl while mlss averaged 170 mgl	volatile suspended solids	2564.7443612374523
2729. the average sludge age based on displacement	of solids was calculated to be 14	938.3516216653934
2730. the oxygen uptake rate	in the mixed liquor averaged 0	560.3280189643531
2731. 8 mglhr during the first	four months of this study	373.7462246209271
2732. variations in aerator speeds during the latter	two months of this study caused increased mixing and increased oxygen	demand	2590.4172395891414
2733. the increase in oxygen uptake rates from 1	167.9603499513425
2734. 6 mglhr	which followed an increase in rotor speed was believed to	be related to resuspension of solids which had settled at the lower	rotor speeds	4089.9785699233203
2735. it appeared that most of the mixed liquor suspended solids	were active microbial solids with the heavier less active solids	settling out	2167.653291959709
2736. the suspended solids discharged in the effluent	were found to be the major source of the bod	2119.611748646719
2737. removal of the suspended	solids by a membrane filter yielded an average effluent containing	only 20 mgl bod	1572.2787800286671
2738. the bod in the drainage ditch	receiving the pilot plant effluent averaged 12 mgl	1409.98278383239
2739. this low bod	was due to removal of the excess suspended solids by sedimentation	since the only dilution was surface runoff which was very low during	this study	2978.7733895611846
2740. routine microscopic examinations	were made of the mixed liquor as indicated by mckinney and	gram for the various types of protozoa	3045.8028367192705
2741. it was found that the	aerated lagoon was an activated sludge system rather than an oxidation	pond	1419.0184186411695
2742. at no time were algae found in the mixed liquor	558.3402963637903
2743. the bacteria	formed typical activated sludge floc	94.73467946769415
2744. the floc particles were all small	as the heavier floc settled out	960.1469428698931
2745. initially the flagellated	protozoa predominated but they soon gave way to the free swimming ciliated	protozoa	1257.5785459746126
2746. as the temperature decreased the number of free swimming	ciliated protozoa decreased	970.1056580707478
2747. very little protozoa activity existed	below 40`f	94.15721947879476
2748. when the temperature reached 32`f all protozoan	activity ceased; but as the temperature rose the numbers of	protozoa increased rapidly	2821.888324056189
2749. only once were stalked ciliates found in	the mixed liquor	374.8191906706735
2750. the predomination of free swimming ciliated protozoa	is indicative of a high bacterial population	1424.2373515324211
2751. one of the important aspects of this study was to determine the oxygen	transfer relationships of the mechanical aerator	1715.0854561188037
2752. routine determinations	were made for dissolved oxygen in the mixed liquor and for oxygen	uptake rates	1880.9640848084969
2753. the data given in table 2 show the routine operation	of the aerator	790.681496984346
2754. the dissolved oxygen in the aeration unit was consistently	high until january 29 1961	1411.1707299972243
2755. an extended cold spell caused	ice to build up on the aerator which was mounted on a floating platform	and caused the entire platform to sink lower in the water	3216.686755784717
2756. the added	resistance to the rotor damaged the drive belts and reduced the oxygen	transfer capacity	1895.2131853552473
2757. it was approximately one month before the belt	problem was noticed and corrected but at no time was there a deficiency	of dissolved oxygen	2461.7399356974033
2758. a series of eight special tests were	conducted at different rotor speeds to determine the oxygen transfer	rate	2349.8594534228955
2759. five of the tests were conducted with a polyethylene cover to	simulate an ice cover	1095.242744510059
2760. the rate of oxygen transfer at 1	140.56145789045232
2761. 0-mgl	dissolved oxygen concentration and 10`c for various rotor speeds	is given in table 3	1099.2801387888185
2762. the maximum rate of oxygen transfer at 1	249.3783056728426
2763. 0	mgl dissolved oxygen was calculated as 220 lbday at a maximum	rate of 9	1093.345178455657
2764. the actual power requirements indicated	2lb oxygen transferhrhp	249.34706352201124
2765. the polyethylene cover reduced	the oxygen transfer rate by 10 per cent indicating that the maximum	oxygen transfer is at the rotor rather than through the surface	2860.033695523303
2766. pond	during this study septic conditions developed in the	oxidation pond in the spring when the ice melted	2358.7636617880808
2767. shortly after this	study ended septic conditions resulted which required the addition of	sodium nitrate	1096.773532336201
2768. the location of the oxidation pond in a high-value	residential area makes odor nuisances a sensitive problem for the developer	2834.489859253073
2769. the organic concentration in the influent raw sewage ranged from	160 to 270 mgl of bod with an average of 230 mgl	2170.8051990303215
2770. the bod data are given in table 4	249.49833994954642
2771. a single 24-hr composite	sample had a bod of 260 mgl indicating a typical	domestic sewage	1266.435374616837
2772. the daily sewage volume to the oxidation pond averaged	147000 gpd giving a retention period of 42 days	2346.926503451853
2773. the organic	loading on the pond was slightly under 60lbboddayacre	375.1972829943751
2774. the effluent bod averaged 34 mgl a little lower	than that of the study at fayette indicated for a loading of 60lb	boddayacre	3460.1544398272335
2775. the bod of the effluent ranged from a	minimum of 13 to a maximum of 47mgl	1253.5961899851443
2776. microscopic examination of	the effluent showed that minimum bod occurred when the algae began	to decrease with cold weather	2587.623687699493
2777. when the algae began to build up	again the effluent bod rose	638.5994120271217
2778. during the two weeks when the algae	disappeared from the effluent bod's in the effluent were 18	and 16 mgl	2808.2674688537195
2779. thus the three main categories of antisubmarine warfare operations	are defense of shipping defense of naval forces and area defense	1874.434360827951
2780. the last category overlaps the others in amphibious operations and	near terminals and bases	1414.7507211261045
2781. to effect these operations five elements	exist	fixed installations	261.29116560645633
2782. surface forces have been used to provide defense	zones around naval and merchant ship formations air to furnish area	surveillance and mines for protection of limited areas	4291.461880141232
2783. submarines and	shore installations are new elements	93.33175577889295
2784. the submarine now has a definite	place in submarine defense particularly in denying enemy access to	ocean areas	2356.672769055938
2785. fixed installations offer possibilities for area detection	93.98684951763386
2786. mine warfare is being reoriented against submarine targets	248.87148356206916
2787. a sixth element not always considered is intelligence	167.4493870442147
2788. it includes	operational intelligence of the enemy and knowledge of the environment	967.5867169071989
2789. operational intelligence presumably will be available from our	national intelligence agencies; intelligence on the environment will	come from the recently augmented program in oceanography	2479.8446319787354
2790. the major	postwar development is the certainty that these elements should not be	considered singly but in combination and as being mutually supporting	3491.4542269948133
2791. thinking on submarine defense	has not always been clear-cut	261.25876550058746
2792. proponents of single elements tend	to ensure predominance of that element without determining if it is justified	and the element with the most enthusiastic and vociferous proponents	has assumed the greatest importance	5163.635179738834
2793. consequently air surface	and submarine elements overshadow the mine fixed installations	and intelligence	792.6158718438093
2794. these have sought more and more of what they have	560.1360397614715
2795. each seems to strive for elimination of the necessity for the others	644.3693940640458
2796. this despite postwar experience demonstrating that all elements are	necessarily mutually supporting	960.5263489167471
2797. thus the most productive areas are	not necessarily the most stressed	503.17038794678604
2798. this is stated to emphasize the necessity	for an over-all concept of submarine defense one which would	provide positions of relative importance to asw elements based on	projected potentialities	4638.535602800668
2799. then the enthusiasm and energy of all elements	can be channeled to produce cumulative progress toward a common	objective	1731.4869873848406
2800. an over-all concept would have other advantages	141.16420713589864
2801. it would	allow presentation to the public of a unified approach	503.7206271900062
2802. now the problem	is presented piecemeal and sometimes contradictorily	392.52626537422975
2803. while one	element	is announcing progress another is delineating its problems	502.0904873614484
2804. the	result can only be confusion in the public mind	565.7522340925594
2805. a unified concept	can serve as a guide to budgeting and if public support is gained will	command congressional support	1898.5670501998557
2806. industry's main criticism of the	navy's antisubmarine effort is that it cannot determine where any	one company or industry can apply its skills and know-how	3905.8407725448255
2807. lacking guidance	industry picks its own areas	94.00625090316598
2808. the result coupled with the salesmanship	for which american industry is famous is considerable expenditure	of funds and efforts in marginal areas	3267.0480083780812
2809. an over-all concept	will guide industry where available talents and facilities will yield	greatest dividends	1105.095705067829
2810. therefore a broad concept of over-all submarine	defense is needed for co-ordination of the navy's efforts for a logical	presentation to the public for industry's guidance and as a	basis for a program to the congress	5784.760537372723
2811. concept	that which follows will be a discussion of principles	and possible content for an over-all concept of antisubmarine warfare	1882.4573499378905
2812. russia possesses the preponderance of submarines in the world divided	between her various fleets	1405.4666432638069
2813. some are also in albania and others	are on loan to egypt	642.6218782757603
2814. other countries which may willingly or unwillingly	become communist can furnish bases	966.4472173405165
2815. communist target areas can	be assumed but there is no certainty that such assumptions coincide	with soviet intentions	1567.8943917190186
2816. attack can come from almost any direction against	many locations	557.8852110687076
2817. logically then the first principle of the plan	must be that it is not rigidly oriented toward any geographical area	1872.6286411453216
2818. it is often stated that the submarine can be destroyed while	building at bases in transit and on station	2570.6240941054402
2819. destruction of the enemy's	building and base complex however requires attacks on enemy	territory which is possible only in event of all-out hostilities	2323.049277341163
2820. in	transit or on station it may not be possible to attack the submarines	until commission of an overt act	2798.7622947860414
2821. the communists are adept at utilizing	hostilities short of general war and will do so whenever it is	to their advantage	2040.0549157872094
2822. therefore the second principle of the plan must be	that while providing for all-out hostilities its effectiveness is	not dependent on general war	3477.123786286074
2823. antisubmarine warfare does not involve	clashes between large opposing forces with the decision a result	of a single battle	1724.2115356503996
2824. it is a war of attrition of single actions	of an exchange of losses	1406.0772370312977
2825. this exchange must result in our ending up	with some effective units	645.0266770237255
2826. initially having fewer units of some elements-	especially submarines- than the opponent our capabilities need	to be sufficiently greater than theirs so that the exchange will	be in our favor	4840.503336287018
2827. therefore the third principle of the plan must be that	it does not depend for effectiveness on engagement by the same types	unless at an assured favorable exchange rate	3098.189109137731
2828. the submarine	has increased its effectiveness by several orders of magnitude since	world war 2	1648.1373485464756
2829. its speed has increased it operates at increasingly	greater depths its submerged endurance is becoming unlimited and	it will become even more silent	2336.63910642666
2830. the next developments will probably	be in weaponry	251.0256589039805
2831. the missile can gradually be expected to replace the	torpedo	375.27741751016384
2832. as detection ranges increase weapons will be developed to	attack other submarines and surface craft at these ranges	2352.342638848463
2833. therefore	the fourth principle of the plan must be that it provide for continuously	increasing capabilities in the opponent	1726.6211968890336
2834. no element can accomplish	the total objective of submarine defense	558.0275054941895
2835. some elements support	the others	but all have limitations	260.4492347012345
2836. some limitations of one element	can be compensated for by a capability of another	1410.666811718378
2837. elements used	in combination will increase the over-all capability more than the sum	of the capabilities of the individual elements	1889.0479031045184
2838. therefore the plan's	fifth principle must be that it capitalize on the capabilities of	all elements in combination	2351.654095570882
2839. conceivably the submarine defense	problem can be solved by sufficient forces	505.5044087822069
2840. numbers would be astronomical	and current fiscal policies make this an impractical solution	1174.9640813066276
2841. shipbuilding aircraft procurement and weapon programs indicate that	there will not be enough of anything	1089.0770783357232
2842. therefore any measures taken	in peacetime which will decrease force requirements in war will contribute	greatly to success when hostilities occur	3029.952130736779
2843. therefore the sixth	principle of the plan must be that it concentrate on current measures	which will reduce future force requirements	2017.6271701140915
2844. the world is constantly	changing; what was new yesterday is obsolescent today	955.2434283238948
2845. the	seventh principle of the plan is self-evident; it must be flexible enough	to allow for technological breakthroughs scientific progress and	changes in world conditions	2597.4167321668933
2846. to this point the need for an over-all plan for submarine defense	has been demonstrated the mission has been stated broad principles	delineating its content laid down and the supporting elements listed	5190.545578040659
2847. before considering these elements in more detail an additional	requirement should be stated	795.7025804315905
2848. large area coverage will accomplish all	other tasks	248.34068901481388
2849. therefore because reduction in tasks results in reduction	of forces required the plan should provide for expanding area coverage	1723.919915549719
2850. but it must be remembered that the plan should not be oriented	geographically	1184.8810926713763
2851. consequently the system giving area coverage	must be flexible and hence at least	partially mobile	1099.697101576242
2852. since effective area coverage appears fairly remote	the requirement can be borne in mind while considering the elements:	air surface sub-surface fixed installations mines and intelligence	4118.883738984479
2853. these are arranged approximately in the order of the vociferousness	of their proponents but will be discussed in the reverse order	in the hope that the true order of importance will result	3426.0547964677235
2854. intelligence	as used herein will include information on possible	opponents and on the environment which can affect operations	2359.8380312952486
2855. these can	be referred to as operational intelligence and environmental intelligence	504.05022078451304
2856. in submarine defense these must have maximum stress	250.12553321446384
2857. good operational	intelligence can ensure sound planning greatly reduce force	requirements	and increase tactical effectiveness	1099.9717397022846
2858. environmental intelligence	is just as important	65.5149581797016
2859. the ocean presently co-operates with the	target	93.50495034740635
2860. full knowledge of the science of oceanography can bring the	environment to our side resulting in an increase in effectiveness of	equipment and tactics a decrease in enemy capabilities and the development	of methods of capitalizing on the environment	6193.388400960584
2861. therefore improved	intelligence will result in reduced force requirements and as	it supports all other elements rates a top priority	1885.8999135448807
2862. gathering intelligence	is important but of equal importance is its translation into	usable form	1410.7036681725695
2863. a program is needed to translate the results of oceanographic	research into tactical and operating instructions	1259.3041969865567
2864. approaching	this problem on a statistical basis is invalid because the opponent	has the same sources available and will be encountered not under	average conditions but under the conditions most advantageous to him	5333.592243944147
2865. therefore the on-the-scene commander must have detailed operating	instructions based on measurement of conditions in the area at the time	of encounter	2171.3800612921405
2866. all capabilities must be used to maximum advantage	then	390.22530393251475
2867. temperature wind oxygen content depth bottom character and	animal life are the chief environmental variables	1106.1514858144853
2868. variations in sound velocity should be measured rather than temperature	because more of the variables would be encompassed	2356.144078977844
2869. these variations	must eventually be measured horizontally as well as vertically	503.15753790019335
2870. progress in predicting water conditions is encouraging but little	guidance is available to the man at sea on the use of such information	3461.123873060905
2871. a concurrent effort is needed to make oceanographic data useful on	the spot	791.0028457678357
2872. mine warfare has in the past been directed against	surface targets	756.0707246830386
2873. by its nature it has always been of great psychological	advantage and small efforts have required considerably greater	counter-efforts	1727.2746195597106
2874. mines are being increasingly oriented against submarine	targets	249.72818685747848
2875. they are still considered to be for use in restricted waters	however and targets must come within a few yards of them	2164.8735589524517
2876. mines	need to be recognized as a major element in anti-submarine warfare employment	extended to deep water and have their effective area per unit	increased	3903.126711980693
2877. mines can be used to deny access to great areas; they	are difficult to counter cost little to maintain until required and	can be put into place quickly	2965.970588126952
2878. a most attractive feature is that detection	and attack are combined in a single package	1647.4045790718974
2879. effective employment	will reduce force requirements	43.62112532052739
2880. for example effective mine	barriers from florida to cuba and across the yucatan channel from	cuba to mexico would remove all requirements for harbor defense	inshore patrol convoy escort shipping control and mine defense for	the entire gulf of mexico	6322.243892570967
2881. more extended systems covering all passage	into the caribbean would free the caribbean and the gulf of mexico	from the previously listed requirements	2342.1958552048063
2882. systems covering the gulf	of st lawrence and possibly the entire coasts of the united	states are not impossible	2591.737926668928
2883. such mine defense systems could permit concentration	of mobile forces in the open oceans with consequent increase	in the probability of success	2170.159205808371
2884. the advantages inherent in mine warfare	justify as great an importance for this element as is accorded any	of the other elements	3268.5118851417524
2885. fixed installations are increasingly	advocated as the problem of area defense emerges	641.5561631048125
2886. the proponents	are scientific and technical men who exercise considerable influence	on their military counterparts	1647.2166826696598
2887. systems which detect submarines over	wide areas are attractive although they can be only burglar alarms	1258.4600433720852
2888. mobile forces are required to localize and attack detected targets	since the systems are not capable of pinpointing a target	2804.6590627431488
2889. such systems	are expensive and are oriented geographically	166.4578576415233
2890. in an over-all	asw concept dependence on and effort expended for such systems	should be limited to those with proven capabilities	3041.7320737161
2891. no general installation	should be made until a model installation has been proved and	its maximum capability determined	1575.420617663646
2892. in addition proposals for fixed installations	should be carefully weighed against a counterpart mobile	system	1650.7157102467713
2893. for fixed installations will always lack the flexibility that	should be inherent in naval systems	1090.556636973331
2894. the submarine has become	increasingly attractive as an antisubmarine weapon system	758.3989910215871
2895. it operates	in its target's environment and any advantage gained therefrom	by the target is shared by the attacker	1727.9696332734736
2896. but the submarine is a weapon	of ambush and therefore always in danger of being ambushed	1888.4703101832395
2897. two metabolites	which act as cofactors for the hydroxylation of aniline by acid-fast	bacteria are biosynthesized from paba	1570.3158440290567
2898. the 7 carbons of paba	are incorporated directly into metabolite 2		393.31948130359507
2899. thirty-five of the 36	carbon atoms arise from paba	261.96368703986315
2900. all 28 carbons of metabolite 1	arise from paba	392.8364313023116
2901. metabolite 1 isolated from the medium however showed a lower specific	activity which indicates endogenous synthesis of this metabolite	1736.1594756375248
2902. vigorous acid hydrolysis of metabolite 1 destroyed the	biological activity of the compound and liberated two aryl amines	2363.7855133420053
2903. fragment a has been obtained in crystalline form as a dioxalate salt	and free base	1109.6787038132875
2904. preliminary evidence tentatively indicates that the	molecule is cleaved at a secondary amide bond	1418.3161467494497
2905. h sloane; chemical studies are being pursued with the cooperation	- research	on esterases in mammalian sera was continued	985.3646435744442
2906. one of the most interesting	findings was the extreme sensitivity of plasma arylesterases to	rare earth ions	2112.6698687055014
2907. the inhibition of the enzyme by very low concentrations	of lanthanum ion is probably the strongest known biological effect	of rare earth salts	2321.0909110007974
2908. various metal ions have been found to protect plasma	arylesterase against inactivation by urea and guanidine	1874.941000441178
2909. the effects	can be related to the structure of this -sh enzyme	637.9250891804977
2910. the non-identity	of serum and red blood cell arylesterase was also established	953.441669929635
2911. furthermore the hydrolysis of paraoxon was studied in mammalian	sera and it was found that it is hydrolyzed by albumin	in addition to arylesterase	2444.678894079745
2912. selective inhibitors can	distinguish the two activities	140.87117725669378
2913. investigations on the acceleration of	human plasma cholinesterase were carried further	498.3129602090855
2914. biophysical studies on	- electron-microscopical and physical-chemical	methods were used to demonstrate the renaturation of heat-denatured	collagen and ribonucleic acid	1648.5347970979
2915. a method	was devised for extracting and purifying soluble earthworm collagen		262.2876235445891
2916. it was observed that ewc macromolecules are the	same diameter than	vertebrate tropocollagen	1184.0437940773656
2917. this unusual collagen also was shown to undergo	a reversible thermal phase transformation	792.3321134180609
2918. this investigation	involved several aspects	22.215333655296835
2919. substance z an active urinary	peptide was purified by extraction in organic solvents and repeated	column chromatography; high-voltage electrophoresis and paper chromatography	were used in preliminary structural studies; pharmacological	effects in vitro on isolated surviving organs and in vivo	on blood pressure were assayed; special equipment required for registering	respiration and for recording the contraction of smooth muscles	under various conditions was developed by the instruments section	; and enzymes	which terminate the action of peptides such as bradykinin and perhaps	substance z were studied	0.20124717349522497
2920. experiments are in progress to develop	ultraviolet spectrophotometric techniques for assaying these enzymes	and for studying their sensitivity to metal ions	3042.093322101863
2921. c d mackey a g renfrew w b severs	- in a physiochemical study	of seed proteins the globulins of the brazil nut have been investigated	1804.829039798872
2922. in addition to the known principal globulin excelsin three	other ultracentrifugally distinct components have been observed	1882.2109858656943
2923. a	water-soluble protein of quite low molecular weight has	also been found in this system and partly characterized	1575.0840549338784
2924. on the basis of	a differentiability assumption in function space it is possible to prove	that for materials having the property that the stress is given by	a functional of the history of the deformation gradients the classical	theory of infinitesimal viscoelasticity is valid when the deformation	has been infinitesimal for all times in the past	7968.671811836257
2925. by strengthening	the differentiability assumption it has been possible to derive second	and higher order theories of viscoelasticity	1570.18880541095
2926. in the second-order	theory one of the normal stress differences can be calculated from the	first-order stress relaxation function	2616.338996998635
2927. an extensive series of	measurements was made on a high-density polyethylene in a torsion pendulum	instrument using forced sinusoidal oscillation free vibration and	creep measurements over the temperature range of f to 80`c	3543.3812075232613
2928. as many as seven decades of the time scale were thus covered isothermally	1185.351356469257
2929. the simple time-temperature equivalence valid for many amorphous	systems did not hold here	783.8718111862047
2930. it was possible however to decompose	the compliance into a sum of a frequency-independent component and two	viscoelastic mechanisms each compatible with the boltzmann superposition	principle and with a consistent set of time-temperature equivalence	factors	5640.4055145200455
2931. and related	- the results of microanalysis of tektites	for gallium and germanium have shown that	these glasses are probably produced from terrestrial	matter by impact of a celestial body	2254.7323079355515
2932. the galliumgermanium	ratio is higher than that for ordinary igneous metamorphic or sedimentary	matter as a result of selective volatilization of the components	of the tektite	4099.980021200668
2933. gallium oxide is less volatile than silica	and germanium oxide is more volatile	792.1544010729119
2934. australites	give the appearance of a second	melting	249.33478630965928
2935. in conformity with this conclusion a higher trace gallium	content was found in the portion that has undergone a second	melting	2031.2385567345268
2936. the silicate fractions of stony meteorites show galliumgermanium	ratios similar to those of tektites because they too have undergone	melting at some point in their histories	4078.8259806184624
2937. libyan desert silica-glass	another natural glass is composed of nearly pure silica	and has the same trace germanium content as sands in the area	2470.6308233667246
2938. the gallium	content however has been enhanced five-fold	250.90394076019635
2939. this glass is probably	formed from libyan desert sands by comet or stony-meteorite	impact	942.9050983616441
2940. nickel-iron meteorites with sufficient kinetic energy	to produce large terrestrial-explosion craters may nevertheless melt only	small quantities of material	2584.2966955891743
2941. most of the impact energy is spent	in crushing and fragmentation	503.8124902433886
2942. when rapid quenching follows melting	impact glasses may result	393.76173573808575
2943. these always contain metallic inclusions	14.982563634433436
2944. impact glasses not containing elemental nickel-iron may have been	produced by stony meteorites or comets	1639.2805750905452
2945. no meteorites have ever been	recovered from paleoexplosion craters and recent craters containing	impact glass have all been produced by metallic meteorites with the exception	of aouelloul crater adrar western sahara desert	3422.691393955195
2946. this	crater contains impact glass with no metallic inclusions and no meteoritic	material has been recovered	1892.9987371458599
2947. preparation of a coordination compound is often	accomplished by the simple method of reacting a metal salt with a	ligand in a suitable solvent such as an alcohol	2994.897321065823
2948. by applying this general	principle a great number of complex compounds of osmium ruthenium	iridium and rhenium with triphenylphosphine triphenylarsine	and triphenylstibine	have been obtained in this laboratory during the past few	years	5316.9311330872415
2949. in the absence of direct evidence to the contrary decomposition of	solvent alcohol and coordination of its fragments to the metal were	not considered following the above heretofore-accepted assumption in	preparative coordination chemistry	3541.299892643842
2950. recent work with radiocarbon and	deuterated alcohols as solvents however has given evidence that metal-hydrido	and -carbonyl complexes may be readily formed by reaction	with alcohol in some of these systems	4982.900545484701
2951. some of the previously reported	compounds have thus been reformulated and a series of new hydrido and	carbonyl compounds discovered the more representative examples being	f f f f and f	3333.805908145944
2952. the coordination complexes	formed by transition metals with primary and secondary phosphines and	arsines are being investigated	2122.149986444114
2953. particular interest	is directed towards the condensation of these ligands with metal	halides to form substituted phosphide or arside complexes	1897.4152601881674
2954. during the	past year these ligands have yielded some unusual five-coordinate complexes	of nickel and some interesting binuclear phosphorus-bridged	complexes of palladium as well as new compounds	of the well-known type f	5182.265084130889
2955. the structures properties and reactions	of these compounds are being studied	503.4104132872243
2956. in another study	chromium-substituted aluminum oxyhydroxides and related species prepared	homogeneously by high-temperature hydrolysis are being characterized	and investigated spectrally in the ultraviolet region with a view	to identification and semiquantitative estimation of the phases formed	under varying preparative conditions	6352.982962254285
2957. _elasticity	- the theory of elasticity of	gaussian networks has been developed on a more general basis and the	equations of state relating variables of pressure volume temperature	stress and strain have been precisely formulated	2765.708694431959
2958. simple elongation	has been treated in detail	140.76551455302894
2959. the various stress-temperature coefficients	for constancy of volume and strain constancy of pressure and strain	and constancy of pressure and length have been interrelated	2453.4341872731043
2960. the	dilation accompanying elongation and the simultaneously developed anisotropy	of compressibility have been related to the elongation	2119.936276798827
2961. in continuation	of these theoretical studies a more precise elucidation of	the effects of imperfections in network structure is sought	1886.8481714873883
2962. chain conformations of polymeric	- recent theoretical work to calculate the dimensions	of polymeric chains by volkenstein and lifson has been extended to include	more general types of chains	3219.3048943950307
2963. the mean-square end-to-end distance	of the polyisobutylene chain has been calculated in reasonable agreement	with values deduced from viscosity data	1886.183477237192
2964. these studies are being	extended to different polymers to increase our knowledge about the	hindrances to rotation around chain bonds	2811.9735444499015
2965. the crystallization of copolymers comprising f units interspersed	with a minor percentage of f is limited by the inability of the	crystal lattice characteristic of the former to accommodate the bulky	side group of the latter	3857.562322211448
2966. only uninterrupted sequences of the former	are eligible for formation of crystallites	955.4899957879877
2967. limitations on the lengths	of these sequences diminish the stability of the comparatively short	crystallites which can be formed and this is reflected in a broadening	of the melting range	3212.6759578623796
2968. carefully executed melting studies on this system	permit quantitative estimation of the instability	engendered by reduced crystallite length	2349.8602294555376
2969. the complex morphology of	polycrystalline homopolymers is necessarily dependent on the same factor	788.1366906024856
2970. hence the present studies offer a possible basis for interpretations	in the latter field	1421.2940044275367
2971. glycerinated	muscle in the presence of the physiological agent	262.7667213147875
2972. responsible	for delivering energy to the mechanochemically active proteins	of muscle has been shown to undergo a contraction which is highly sensitive	both to temperature and to solvent composition in mixtures of	alcohols and water	5635.302738078861
2973. experiments carried out over long periods of time	in order to allow establishment of a steady state have shown that the	onset of contraction and its completion are confined to an interval of	several degrees centigrade and to a concentration range of only several	per cent	4668.785339874613
2974. the contraction therefore partakes of the character of	a phase transition	755.0980383903212
2975. while atp appears to be necessary for the	occurrence of contraction its presence and enzymatic hydrolysis of it	by the muscle protein myosin are not the only criteria for contraction	3229.094003952877
2976. one of the principal aims of anionic polymerization techniques	is the synthesis of polymers of extremely narrow molecular weight	distribution	2814.4993329418294
2977. a simple process for the preparation of nearly monodisperse	polystyrene of predictable molecular weight has been developed	1416.401770299292
2978. the preparation of such products is not new but the systems heretofore	employed in polymerizations have commanded considerable experimental	skill and starting materials of a high purity	4276.563853041409
2979. in the new process	impurities present in the solvent the monomer and in the	reaction system which would cause deactivation of propagation centers	are rendered inactive prior to polymerization by gradual addition of	initiator a mixture of butyl-lithium and telomeric styryl-lithium at	a temperature low enough to suppress chain growth	4936.696947170639
2980. upon completion	of the purging step additional initiator appropriate for the molecular	weight of the sample desired is added and the system is then warmed	to the polymerization temperature at which the reaction is allowed	to go to completion	6197.273871238893
2981. the predictability of the molecular weights was	found to be within 10% for the polymers prepared with f ratios less	than 1	2171.1476868470772
2982. contrary to observations with ethers no apparent	change of the reactivity of the chain ends takes place over considerable	periods of time in benzene as solvent	4075.011779720545
2983. in this publication measurements of interfacial	angles of crystals are used to classify and identify chemical substances	1408.85507471165
2984. t v barker who developed the classification-angle system	was about to begin the systematic compilation of the index when he	died in 1931	3466.436824987447
2985. the compilation work was undertaken by a number of interested	crystallographers in the department of mineralogy of the university	museum at oxford	2167.910440251099
2986. since 1948 the working headquarters has	been the	department of geology and mineralogy	1180.0634228317558

2988. great interest	and practical help have been given by the barker index committee	1181.838842879205

2990. editors for volumes	1 and 2 were m w porter and the late r c	spiller both of oxford university	2849.691577036221
2991. a third volume remains to be	published	93.59237199815767
2992. volume 1 deals with 2991 compounds	belonging to the tetragonal hexagonal and trigonal and orthorhombic	systems; and volume 2 with about 3500 monoclinic substances	3678.2012209180043
2993. volume 3 in preparation will treat the anorthic compounds described	in groth's chemische krystallographie	943.8451115998099
2994. the barker system is based on the use of the smallest number of	interfacial angles necessary for indexing purposes	2582.8941058538353
2995. other morphological	sources	the index is essentially a new treatment of previously	compiled morphological data	1102.3012621461717
2996. most of the data used are from groth's	chemische krystallographie	563.3090812550523

3058. system of mineralogy	six editions of	james dwight dana's system appeared between 1837 and 1892	1644.4728431773754
3059. in 1915 edward s dana editor of the sixth edition asked w	e ford of yale university to prepare a seventh edition of his	father's work	2724.7424242624156
3060. a number of people became involved in the preparation	but work was slow until 1937	1649.4400526528595
