3085. the groth institute	the groth institute	which was established in 1958 is a group activity affiliated	with the physics department of the pennsylvania state university	university park pa	2991.8653719602235
3086. ray pepinsky is the director	22.228676897061476
3087. the institute	derives its name from paul von groth's chemische krystallographie	a five-volume work which appeared between 1906 and 1919	1884.9354657612312
3088. the resident staff is large and consists of professional assistants	graduate students abstractors librarian technical editor machine	operators secretarial help and others	3256.9228809352544
3089. there are also corresponding	members and outside advisory groups	261.76149604859313
3090. the air force office of scientific	research has provided financial assistance in the early stages	of the institute's program	2597.3047152083827
3091. all crystalline	substances and other solid-state materials	94.42877154283507
3092. the	aim is to collect a very broad range of physical chemical morphological	and structural data for crystals on an encyclopedic scale and to	seek all possible useful and revealing correlations of properties with	internal structure	5762.41063713869
3093. the first stage of operation	has centered on the literature imaging of critical or summarizing	tabulations such as the barker index	2038.45872582518
3094. coverage of primary literature	will follow	64.96772057574027
3095. unpublished data will be available to the groth institute	from cooperating groups and individuals	944.1483805341719
3096. critical evaluation of all data compiled is not a primary aim of this	project	1415.259054297249
3097. however the proposed correlation of the many interrelated	properties of crystals will reveal discrepancies in the recorded data	and suggest areas for reinvestigation	2302.8715829116218
3098. in addition the availability	of computers will permit recalculation and refinement of much structural	information	1633.8120258251943
3099. physical	for punched-card or tape storage of information all	literature values must be conformed to a common language	1560.1426258261536
3100. in this	way a degree of unification of nomenclature symbols and units will be	realized	1657.4226168358691
3101. because individual classes of foods differ in their requirements	for preservation a number of methods have been developed over the years	involving one or a combination of procedures such as dehydration	fermentation salting chemical treatment canning refrigeration and	freezing	4141.549471197206
3102. the basic objectives in each instance are to make available	supplies of food during the intervals between harvesting or slaughter	to minimize losses resulting from the action of microorganisms and	insects and to make it possible to transport foods from the area of	harvest or production to areas of consumption	7403.655218263161
3103. in earlier years	the preservation of food was essentially related to survival	640.5173821056085
3104. in	the more sophisticated atmosphere of today's developed nations food-preservation	techniques have sought also to bring variety peak freshness	and optimum taste and flavor in foods at reasonable cost to the	comsumer	5175.058557863959
3105. with the development of nuclear technology isotopic	materials and machine radiation sources in recent years the possibilities	of applying ionizing radiation to the preservation of foods attracted	the attention of investigators in the united states and throughout	the world	4142.786355864066
3106. an early hope that irradiation might be the ultimate	answer to practically all food preservation problems was soon dispelled	2572.2516621021477
3107. interest remained however in the possibility that it would serve	as a useful supplementary method for counteracting spoilage losses	and for preserving some foods at lower over-all costs than freezing or	without employing heat or chemicals with their attendant taste alterations	4306.358386323336
3108. the chief	factors responsible for the spoilage of fresh foodstuffs are microorganisms	such as bacteria molds and yeasts insects	sprouting and chemical reactions	3507.766891532277
3109. microorganisms are often	responsible for the rapid spoilage of foods	372.8478965022251
3110. of special concern is	the growth of bacteria such as clostridium botulinum which generate	poisonous products	1884.6841444885188
3111. enzymatic action in stored food produces changes	which can adversely affect the appearance of food or its palatability	1573.0961801641079
3112. spoilage by chemical action results from the reaction of one group	of components in the food with others or with its environment as in	corrosion of the walls of metal containers or the reaction of fats with	oxygen in the air to produce rancidity	6816.149342229973
3113. sprouting is a naturally	occurring phenomenon in stored potatoes onions carrots beets	and similar root vegetables	1260.1739953779731
3114. insect infestation is a problem of importance	chiefly in stored grain	755.8517942539447
3115. the presence of parasitic organisms	such as trichinella spiralis in pork introduces another factor which	must be dealt with in food processing	2169.4993035551283
3116. to permit the storage	of food for long periods of time a method of preservation must accomplish	the destruction of microorganisms and inhibition of enzymatic	action	4070.1014127984117
3117. the term sterilization applies to methods involving essentially	complete destruction of all microorganisms	780.6471607000504
3118. food treated in	this manner and protected from recontamination by aseptic methods of packaging	and containment presumably could be stored for long periods without	refrigeration	3883.59869244113
3119. the process of pasteurization involves milder	and less prolonged heat treatment which accomplishes the destruction	of most but not all of the microorganisms	2310.4452637537406
3120. less severe thermal	treatment as by blanching or scalding serves to inactivate enzymes	1185.2695862835033
3121. effects of ionizing radiation	ionizing radiation can cause	the destruction of microorganisms and insects involved in food spoilage	or at lower doses can inhibit their action	2740.0364024169503
3122. it furnishes a means	of destroying insects in stored grain products as well as certain parasitic	organisms present in meats	2834.855774199074
3123. deactivation of enzymes is also	possible although some types require extremely heavy doses of 10 mrad	or more	1585.0402051971482
3124. because of undesirable flavors odors colors and generally	low palatability associated with radiation treatment of this magnitude	the inactivation of enzymes is best accomplished prior to irradiation	by the conventional heat-processing methods of blanching	5481.874251160019
3125. radiation does not retard the chemical spoilage of food	262.31496163077
3126. it will	however inhibit the sprouting of potatoes and other root vegetables	964.6797413659149
3127. the radiation doses required for the preservation of foods	are in the following ranges:  for radiosterilization to destroy	all organisms for long-term preservation- about 4	2586.925403882522
3128. 5 mrad for	nonacid foods of low salt content	391.07008264792313
3129. for radiopasteurization	to partially destroy microorganisms; results vary with types of food	storage conditions and objectives of treatment- commonly of the	order of 0	2458.9971718224515
3130. 2 mrads but up to about 0	141.02175197143006
3131. for	destruction of insects- about 25000 rads	94.19013509978272
3132. for inhibiting	the sprouting of root vegetables- 4000 to 10000 rads	751.599156101869
3133. preserving foods with ionizing radiation leads to some undesirable side	effects particularly at the higher radiation dosages	1418.5590793733943
3134. in this respect	the general palatability and individual acceptance of most radiosterilized	foods has to date been found to be low in comparison with	fresh and commercially processed foods	4650.326654811814
3135. a number of foods are quite	acceptable as regards taste and palatability however at dosages substantially	less than sterilization levels	1889.7258459270827
3136. moreover the nutritive value	of irradiated foods apparently undergoes little if any change although	some of the fat-soluble vitamins are affected by sterilization	doses	3694.397268850279
3137. for irradiation of food the results	obtained depend upon the dose rather than the specific type of radiation	and x-ray gamma and high-energy electron radiation are suitable	2864.506046820599
3138. aside from availability and economic considerations each has certain	practical advantages; for example gamma rays give deeper penetration	but cannot be focused or collimated whereas unidirectional electron	beams may be split and directed to both the top and bottom of the	food package to be irradiated	7031.168910206546
3139. selection of a source for commercial irradiation	would involve consideration of numerous factors including required	dose rate load factor throughput convenience safety and most	important costs	2717.896456344606
3140. of the potentially useful sources of ionizing	radiations gamma sources cobalt-60 cesium-137 fission products	or a reactor irradiation loop system using a material such as an indium	salt have received most attention for food-preservation systems	5626.593178114628
3141. of the various particle accelerators the van de graff machines resonant	transformers and linear accelerators are the principal ones available	for commercial use	2332.3266574384206
3142. costs of the effective energy produced	by these sources is a major obstacle in the development of food-preservation	processes	2602.9437079241734
3143. estimated production costs of radiation energy	from machine and nuclide sources range from $1 to $10 per kwhr	1581.3312024707643
3144. conventional	energy for processing foods is available in the range of	at most a few cents per kwhr for electric power and the equivalent	of a few mills per kwhr for process steam	5310.210703655101
3145. radiation therefore is	at an initial cost disadvantage even though only 1 to 10 per cent as	much radiation energy as heat energy is required for radiopasteurization	or radiosterilization	3138.792944571932
3146. what are the possibilities of lowered radiation	production costs for the future	963.9302164842178
3147. it has been estimated that for	applications on a megawatt scale costs might reach values in the neighborhood	of 10 cents per kwhr for large-scale accelerators or for	gamma radiation generated in a reactor core	3754.0571179356302
3148. no comparable reductions	in the cost of nuclide radiation are foreseen	754.4577857453921
3149. such projections however	appear highly	speculative and the capacities involved are far beyond	those foreseen for food-preservation facilities	1577.5068524074798
3150. because agricultural	activities are seasonal and the areas of production and harvest	of many foods are widely scattered geographically and because of	the high cost of transporting bulk food items any substantial distance	to a central processing location the use of large central processing	stations where low-cost radiation facilities approaching the megawatt	range might be utilized is inherently impracticable	8183.6233547980955
3151. of irradiation preservation of foods	the objective of complete	sterilization of foods is to produce a wholesome and palatable product	capable of being stored without refrigeration for extended periods	of time	3333.767537612409
3152. chief interest in radiosterilization resides in the military	services	391.62862493143405
3153. for them providing appetizing food under battle or emergency	conditions is a paramount consideration	947.346746480786
3154. they require completely	sterile foods capable of being stored without refrigeration preferably	items already cooked and ready to eat	2578.9088092914144
3155. high nutritional value variety	palatability and appetizing appearance are important for reasons	of morale	937.9761618050941
3156. foods for rear stations which require cooking but no refrigeration	are also of interest	1409.1367528227684
3157. of primary interest are meats	14.944964191564136
3158. radiopasteurization which produces fewer adverse sensory changes	in food products has potential usefulness in prolonging the keeping	qualities of fresh and refrigerated food items	3697.228205070286
3159. thus food so processed	might reach more remote markets and permit the consumer to enjoy more	produce at peak freshness and palatability	2191.4273164216443
3160. commercial interest is chiefly	in this type of treatment as is military interest under peacetime	conditions	1887.3723461883576
3161. the present status of food preservation by ionizing	radiation is discussed by food classes in the following paragraphs	1568.704246098728
3162. the radiation processing of meat has received extensive	investigation	393.383635098573
3163. to date the one meat showing favorable results at	sterilization doses is pork	788.6020567361365
3164. of particular interest to the military	services is the demonstration that roast pork after radiosterilization	is superior in palatability to available canned pork products	3689.742679742542
3165. tests	with beef have been largely unsuccessful because of the development	of off-flavors	787.1871733782663
3166. a prime objective of the army quartermaster corps	program is to find the reasons for beef's low palatability and means	of overcoming it since it is a major and desirable dietary item	5156.988997857762
3167. partly	because low-level heat treatment is needed to inactivate enzymes	before radiosterilization treated fresh meats have the appearance of	boiled or canned meat	2317.1499345974303
3168. off-flavor is a less severe problem with	the radiopasteurization of meats but problems of commercial acceptability	remain	2115.9241527193453
3169. moderate radiation doses of from 100000 to 200000 rads	can extend the shelf life of fresh beef from 5 days	to 5 or 6 weeks	2603.8918986920316
3170. however the problem of consumer acceptability remains	140.7287306738896
3171. the preradiation blanching process discolors the treated beef	and liquid accumulates in prepackaged cuts	943.3779636378183
3172. cooked beef irradiated in	the absence of oxygen assumes an unnatural pink color	1178.1450045257102
3173. when lamb	and mutton are irradiated at substerilization doses the meat becomes	dehydrated the fat become chalky and again unnatural changes in	color occur	2463.9360929985764
3174. ground meats such as fresh pork sausage and hamburger	have a relatively short shelf life under refrigeration and radiopasteurization	might be thought to offer distinctly improved keeping	qualities	4476.722747873101
3175. however a major problem here is one of scale of processing;	ground meats are usually prepared from scrap meats at the local	level whereas irradiation at economic volumes of production would require	central processing and distribution facilities	3957.6906112028455
3176. the problems of	color change by blanching and liquid accumulation within the package are	the same as for solid cuts	2823.2480363906134
3177. specialty cooked items containing	meat portions as in frozen dinners might offer a potential use	for radiopasteurization	1417.0507123894452
3178. the principal potential advantage would be	that the finished product could be transported and stored at lower cost	under refrigeration instead of being frozen	3712.5450715524958
3179. a refrigerated item	could also be heated and served in less time than is required for frozen	foods of the same type	2175.452475794291
3180. competitive processes for preserving	meats are by canning and freezing	566.2566112451732
3181. costs of canning meat are in the	range of 0	371.89218763600536
3182. 8 to 5 cents per pound; costs of freezing are in the area	of 2 to 3	2118.8568748958305
3183. the table on page 10 shows costs of canning	and freezing meat and estimated costs for irradiation under certain	assumed conditions	2038.151286038168
3184. under the conditions of comparison it will	radiosterilization is more	radiopasteurization by either the electron accelerator or cesium-137	irradiation	using the nuclide source is more expensive than use of an electron accelerator	5183.900121860696
3185. results of irradiation tests with poultry have	been quite successful	374.0002974278896
3186. at sterilizing doses good palatability results	with a minimum of changes in appearance taste and odor	1887.0795650648677
3187. radiopasteurization	has also been successful and the shelf life of chicken	can be extended to a month or more under refrigerated storage as compared	with about 10 days for the untreated product	3459.2386007564505
3188. acceptable taste and	odor are retained by the irradiated and refrigerated chicken	965.4924081238263
3189. acceptance	of radiopasteurization is likely to be delayed however for two	reasons: the storage life of fresh chicken under refrigeration	is becoming a minimal problem because of constantly improved sanitation	and distributing practices and treatment by antibiotics a measure	already approved by the federal food and drug administration	serves to extend the storage life of chicken at a low cost of about 0	5672.990093112081
3190. fresh seafood products are extremely	perishable	65.76599191200023
3191. although refrigeration has served to extend the storage	life of these products substantially increased consumption might be possible	if areas remote from the seacoast could be served adequately	3000.282451641553
3192. furthermore it has made an exact assessment of the removal mechanisms	possible	969.9370310530473
3193. the instrument is shown in fig 1 and consists	essentially of a hard sharp tungsten carbide knife which is pushed	along the substrate to remove the coating	2855.7027637835586
3194. the force required to accomplish	removal is plotted by means of an electronic recorder against	distance of removal	2353.0727792428575
3195. since the removal force is a function of coating	thickness a differential transformer pickup has been incorporated into	the instrument to accurately measure film thickness	2614.9126016507985
3196. this too is	recorded against distance by a repeat run over the same track previously	cut	1881.8735919363494
3197. a number of adjustment features are included in the hesiometer	to facilitate measurement and permit ready removal of coatings deposited	on such substrates as iron and other metals glass wood and	plastic surfaces	3547.5820431311477
3198. the measurement of topcoats on primers can also readily	be carried out	958.5563889786906
3199. hesiometer results have been found to compare	excellently with manual knife scratching tests	784.7078257098349
3200. the instrumental	method however is about 100 times more sensitive and yields numerical	results which can be accurately repeated at wil over a period of time	4098.0455710077895
3201. if a wedge-shaped coating of increasing thickness is removed from	a substrate by an instrument like the hesiometer with a knife of constant	rake angle a number of removal mechanisms are often observed	which depend upon the thickness of the coating	4306.116683429611
3202. at low thicknesses a	cutting phenomenon is often encountered	394.0894293332641
3203. as the coating	becomes thicker the cutting may abruptly change to a cracking type of	failure	1251.3218132582963
3204. if the coating becomes still thicker a peeling type failure	finally can occur	1179.888251544129
3205. the typical appearance of these various mechanisms	is illustrated in figs 2 3 and 4 which are single frame enlargements	of high speed movies taken during the course of the knife removal	process	3560.0288168220272
3206. it can be seen from fig 2 that the cutting removal	of a coating from its substrate involves pure cohesive failure of the	coating	3692.5407200759864
3207. the molecular forces holding the coating to the substrate are	obviously greater than the cohesive strength of the coating and	failure occurs by shear along a plane starting at the tip of the knife	and extending to the coating surface	4225.612316114286
3208. the pictures of figs	3 and	4 show the cracking and peeling types of removal where the coating	is detached by failure in a region at or close to the interface between	coating and substrate	5652.269113931872
3209. if the force required to remove the	coatings is plotted against film thickness a graph as illustrated schematically	in fig 5 may characteristically result	2457.962562300342
3210. here h	is the coatings removal force measured parallel to the surface of the	substrate and t is the film thickness	3057.134322027955
3211. it can be seen that	the force is characteristic of the removal process and changes abruptly	from cutting to cracking to peeling removal	2331.471833839967
3212. also it can be readily	seen that the cutting and peeling types of failure show a steady state	response while the cracking mechanism is of a dynamic nature	4484.820369631098
3213. it should be recalled that these three mechanisms can occur on the	same coating deposited upon the same substrate merely as a function of	changes in coatings thickness	2976.09320428734
3214. presumably the interfacial bond strength	and gross cohesive properties are identical in each case	1410.9995967953105
3215. what then	are the factors that contribute to these phenomena	376.37611232021453
3216. why should	the practical adhesion of a coating as assessed by a knife method	change initially increasing rather rapidly and then decreasing stepwise	to very low values as the knife is forced through a coating of increasing	thickness	6060.192877111462
3217. the	cutting removal process has been previously described	167.62390797656843
3218. it was found that the coating is separated from its substrate entirely	by cohesive failure	1636.7247848078132
3219. the details of the removal process are shown	schematically in fig 6	646.0173986137291
3220. the various forces result from the reaction	of the removed paint chip against the face of the knife and along	the shear plane which makes an angle |f with the substrate	5030.830809497641
3221. the	action and reaction forces are r and f respectively and	are equal and opposite in direction	1419.2569653776222
3222. all the other force vectors are	derived from these	397.6541659629212
3223. f is the force required to cut a coating of thickness	t from the substrate	1094.3705013443914
3224. f is the shear force along the shear	plane; f and f are the thrust forces acting against coating	and knife respectively; f is the normal compressive force acting	on the shear plane; f is the friction force between chip and knife	surfaces and p is the normal force acting on the face of the	knife	8048.073982260119
3225. |a is the rake angle of the knife; |f is the angle	the shear plane makes with the substrate; |t is the friction	angle; and |b is the angle the resultants make with the plane of	the substrate	4060.6015617737007
3226. an analysis of the vector relationships shows	that the rake angle |a and the friction angle |t determine	the vector direction f of the force resultants r and f	4669.935868556115
3227. consequently	both the rake angle of the knife as well as the friction	occurring between the back of the removed coating and the front of the	knife will determine in large part the detailed mechanism of the cutting	removal process	4224.628713745838
3228. it is difficult to measure the direction	and magnitude of r directly	964.7475346960842
3229. in actual practice the values most	readily amenable to measurement are the cutting force f and the	shear angle |f	1889.5479009210653
3230. these two values and the rake angle |a are	sufficient to determine the other parameters of these relationships	2363.621543723771
3231. |a is defined by the geometry of the knife; |f can readily	be determined by measuring the thickness of the coating before and after	cutting from the substrate; f is instrumentally determined	3447.1149081964186
3232. from	fig 6 the relationship between these parameters can readily be	derived and the cutting force is f where |l is the shear strength	of the coating and is a parameter of the coatings material w	is the width of the removed coating and t is its thickness	7260.095504768884
3233. if the cutting force f is plotted against film thickness	a straight line should result passing through the origin and having slope	f	2336.5201341595407
3234. however in the actual assessment of the cutting force by instrumental	methods for any thickness of coating a number of spurious effects	occur which must be taken into account and which make the measured	value larger than the true cutting force indicated by eqn	6761.241906374022
3235. one of these is the fact that the knife employed no	matter how well sharpened will have a slightly rounded cutting edge	2186.1806118071154
3236. this signifies that |a the rake angle is no longer a constant	to zero film thickness	1888.8607921460982
3237. the curvature of this bluntness is in the	case of the carboloy knife employed in the hesiometer determined by	the grain sizes of the polished grit and the tungsten carbide crystals	cemented together in the knife body and is in the order of 0	4535.742001655124
3238. the force vector concept of fig 6 can readily be	applied to this condition also	1640.4118299100446
3239. because the rake angle f at the tip	of the knife is very much smaller when compared	to the value of |a for the major portion of the knife a very rapid	increase in cutting force with thickness will result	4227.859189923139
3240. this reduces	to the relationship: f where f is the intercept at zero thickness	of the extrapolation of the slope indicated in eqn f is the	thickness of the coating equivalent to the rounding off of the knife	tip f is a straight line first approximation of this roundness and	the other symbols are equivalent to those of eqn	8190.019606489058
3241. it can be	seen that f is a constant and is determined for the most part by the	geometry of the knife	2184.2925646452104
3242. the blunter the knife the higher is the value	of f	754.8894086429284
3243. the importance of a hard abrasion resistant knife material	like the carboloy employed in the hesiometer immediately becomes	apparent	1727.6482158475465
3244. softer knives would blunt very rapidly making the value of	f inexact	960.5116589370436
3245. in extreme cases of very soft knives this value may even	change during the course of a measurement	1578.1204756114187
3246. a second	factor which enters into the practical measurement of the instrumentally	determined cutting force is the frictional resistance caused	by the bottom of the knife against the substrate	4667.922270471232
3247. this is not a constant	value like f but varies with the thickness of the coating and the	direction and magnitude of the resultants r and f of fig	6	3229.4516830822863
3248. under equilibrium conditions of cutting the chip exerts a thrust	f against the knife which tends to push it into the substrate or	lift it away from the substrate depending on the vector direction of f	5791.3257228155335
3249. the resultant friction force f is thus directly proportional to	f and consequently also to film thickness	1418.2583964344833
3250. the value of f	can readily be assessed by determining the frictional force exerted	on the knife while running over the previously stripped coating track	under various external loadings	4644.122143988033
3251. a straight line relationship is usually	observed in a plot of f against load l having slope k	and f since the load l under actual cutting conditions	is caused by f it can be seen that f   the measured force	h in cutting removal of coatings from their substrates consequently	can be seen to be the sum of that force required to cut the	coating f that due to the bluntness of the knife f and that due	to the friction between the bottom of the knife and the substrate f	or f the first two forces are directly interrelated and depend	upon film thickness whereas f is independent of these two and is a	constant for a given knifecoating combination	0.20124717349522497
3252. these theoretical	relationships are more clearly illustrated in fig 7 and their	sum can be seen to correlate in form with practical measurements made	with the hesiometer as illustrated in the first portion of fig 5	for the cutting mechanism	6335.26592137206
3253. although a large number of coatings systems	particularly at low thicknesses fail cohesively by the cutting mechanism	frequently a second type of cohesive failure may also take place	2958.734588710938
3254. this is a chipping dynamic type failure encountered with very brittle	coatings resins or very highly pigmented films	2373.979390597572
3255. this is shown in	the photomicrograph of fig 8	260.6069777971084
3256. the basic difference between	the continuous cutting mechanism and that of the chipping mechanism	is that instead of shear occurring in the coating ahead of the knife continuously	without fracture rupture intermittently occurs along the	shear plane	5911.947231997777
3257. the detailed mechanisms of this type of failure have been	studied extensively by merchant for metal cutting and the principles	found can be directly applied to coatings	2854.2986142262475
3258. by studying	high speed movies made of this type of failure the sequence of relationships	as schematically illustrated in fig 9 could be observed	3698.1198750901335
3259. in the first picture the knife is just beginning to advance	into the inclined surface which was left from the previous chip	formation	2340.276250713976
3260. in the next the shear plane angle is high and extends to	the inclined work surface	1903.9590774962599
3261. with increasing advance of the knife into	the coating the shear plane extends to the coatings surface and the shear	angle rapidly decreases	2338.1585312229045
3262. eventually rupture occurs along the shear	plane and the cycle repeats itself	964.9798768085377
3263. merchant	has found that the same basic relationships which describe the geometry	and force systems in the case of the cutting mechanism can also be	applied to the discontinuous chip formation provided the proper values	of instantaneous shear angle and instantaneous chip thickness or cross-sectional	area are used	4823.059501240268
3264. consequently if the shear angle |f	is replaced by the rupture angle f the relationships as described in	eqns will directly apply	3299.412767962242
3265. mechanism	under equilibrium cutting conditions the chip exerts a	force f against the coating and an equal opposite force f against	the knife in the plane of the substrate as shown in fig 6	3681.142556809892
3266. if the	rake angle |a of the knife is high enough and the friction angle	|t between the front of the knife and the back of the chip is low	enough to give a positive value for f the resultant vector r	will lie above the plane of the substrate	7450.1073158789195
3267. within only a few years foamed plastics materials have managed	to grow into an integral and important phase of the plastics industry-	and the end is still not yet in sight	3333.9320574943204
3268. urethane foam as only	one example was only introduced commercially in this country in 1955	1643.5868350207475
3269. yet last year's volume probably topped 100 million lb and expectations	are for a market of 275 million lb by 1964	2023.546269241558
3270. many of the other	foamed plastics particularly the styrenes show similar growth potential	1183.3732003565515
3271. and there are even newer foamed plastics that are yet to be	evaluated	786.8478362843347
3272. as this issue goes to press for example one manufacturer	has announced an epoxy foam with outstanding buoyancy and impact strength;	another reports that a cellular polypropylene primarily for use	in wire coating applications is being investigated	5905.836355766884
3273. on the	following pages each of the major commercial foamed plastics is described	in detail as to properties applications and methods of processing	2327.761488550667
3274. it might be well to point out however some of the newer	developments that have taken place within the past few months which	might have a bearing on the future of the various foamed plastics involved	5754.378660486764
3275. in urethane foams for example there has been a definite trend	toward the polyether-type materials	and the emphasis is definitely on one-shot	molding	2336.529813504383
3276. most manufacturers also seem to be concentrating on formulating	fire-resistant or self-extinguishing grades of urethane foam that	are aimed specifically at the burgeoning building markets	3897.498051960919
3277. urethane	foam as an insulator is also coming in for a good deal of attention	1101.8671663252553
3278. in one outstanding example whirlpool corp found that by switching	to urethane foam insulation they could increase the storage capacity	of gas refrigerators to make them competitive with electric models	4823.872502773056
3279. much interest has also been expressed in new techniques for processing	the urethane foams including spraying frothing and molding		1099.4703755794699
3280. and in meeting the demands for urethane	foam as a garment interlining new adhesives and new methods of laminating	foam to a substrate have been developed	4093.808023053997
3281. new techniques	for automatic molding of expandable styrene beads have helped boost	that particular material into a number of new consumer applications including	picnic chests beverage coolers flower pots and flotation-type	swimming toys	3555.255924702587
3282. two other end-use areas which contributed to expandable	styrene's growth during the year were packaging	and foamed-core building panels	2573.7501926552723
3283. extruded expandable styrene film or sheet- claimed to be competitive	price-wise with paper- also showed much potential particularly	for packaging	1882.768111957205
3284. sandwich panels for building utility shelters that	consist of kraft paper skins and rigid styrene foam cores also aroused	interest in the construction field	3690.8933338526963
3285. in vinyl foam the big news	was the development of techniques for coating fabrics with the material		864.8345663463995
3286. better hand a more luxurious	feel and better insulating properties were claimed to be the result	1885.859857874398
3287. several companies also saw possibilities in using the technique for	extruding or molding vinyl products with a slight cellular core that	would reduce costs yet would not affect physical properties of the end	product to any great extent	4053.957166944239
3288. readers interested in additional	information on foams are referred to the foamed plastics chart appearing	in the technical data section and to the list of references which	appears below	4650.367314829081
3289. since the mid 1950s when	urethane foam first made its appearance in the american market growth	has been little short of fantastic	2160.954400172114
3290. present estimates are that production	topped the 100-million-lb mark in 1960	; by 1965 production	may range from 200 to 350 million lb for flexible and from 115	to 150 million lb for rigid	3993.2251516612932
3291. the markets that have started to open	up for the foam in the past year or so seem to justify the expectations	2179.2190654669953
3292. furniture upholstery as just one example can easily take millions	of pounds; foamed refrigerator insulation is under intensive evaluation	by every major manufacturer; and use of the foam for garment	interlining is only now getting off the ground with volume potential	in the offing	6815.714525647085
3293. urethane foams are basically	reaction products of hydroxyl-rich materials and polyisocyanates		262.20477179890025
3294. blowing can be either one of two types-	carbon dioxide gas generated by the reaction of water on the polyisocyanate	or mechanical blowing through the use of a low-boiling liquid	such as a fluorinated hydrocarbon	5643.035906999552
3295. the most important factor	in determining what properties the end-product will have is quite naturally	the type of hydroxyl-rich compound that is used in its production	2726.4398663590314
3296. originally the main types used were various compositions of polyesters	557.0542666169724
3297. these are still in wide use today particularly in semi-rigid	formulations for such applications as cores for sandwich-type structural	panels foamed-in-place insulation automotive safety padding arm	rests etc	2991.0667808476833
3298. more recently polyethers- again in varied compositions	molecular weights and branching- have come into use at first	for the flexible foams just lately for the rigids	4099.835189363528
3299. the polyether glycols	are claimed to give flexible urethanes a spring-back action which	is much desired in cushioning	1571.1891359447977
3300. although the first polyether foams	on the market had to be produced by the two-step prepolymer method	today thanks to new catalysts they can be produced by a one-shot	technique	4836.8661551058885
3301. it is possible that the polyether foams may soon be molded	on a production basis in low-cost molds with more intricate contours	and with superior properties to latex foam	3106.9100071056428
3302. the polyester urethane	foam is generally produced with adipic acid polyesters; the polyether	group generally consists of foams produced with polypropylene glycol	one shot vs	prepolymer the isocyanate and resin are	mixed anhydrously and no foaming occurs	5922.786321218986
3303. the foaming can be accomplished	at some future time at a different location by the addition of the	correct proportion of catalyst in solution	2452.4995656522688
3304. in one-shot the isocyanate	polyester or polyether resin catalyst and other additives are	mixed directly and a foam is produced immediately	3061.6690014266487
3305. basically this means	that simpler processing equipment	and less external heat	are required in one-shot foaming although	at the same time the problems of controlling the conditions of	one-shot foaming are critical ones	3559.452001424477
3306. most commercial	uses of urethane foams require densities between 2 and 30 lbcu	ft for rigid foams between 1 and 3 lbcu ft for flexible	foams	4079.7562040491525
3307. this latter figure compares with latex foam rubber at an average	of 5	787.7337254846177
3308. 5 lbcu ft in commercial grades	64.77139859736022
3309. graph in fig 1 p 392 indicates how the ratio of	compressive strength to density varies as the latter is increased or	decreased	2325.3720246351404
3310. the single curve line represents a specific formulation in	a test example	962.6942639990463
3311. by varying the formula this curve may be moved forward	or backward along the coordinates to produce any desired compression	strengthdensity ratio	2173.1217996320966
3312. in flexible urethane foams we are referring to the range	between the highest and lowest temperatures under which the materials'	primary performance remains functionally useful	3897.651745253246
3313. in temperature	resistance this quality is usually related to specific properties	eg flexural tensile strengths etc	1261.9906346927487
3314. thermal conductivity is	directly traceable to the material's porous air-cell construction	which effectively traps air or a gas in the maze of minute bubbles which	forms its composition	4475.99238581603
3315. these air or gas bubbles make highly functional	thermal barriers	372.42721163585736
3316. the k factor a term used to denote the rate	of heat transmission through a material	ranges from 0	2602.6658951272734
3317. 28	for flexible urethane foams and from 0	168.0853246874097
3318. 16 for rigid urethane	foams depending upon the formulation density cell size and nature	of blowing agents used	2348.4043529923833
3319. table 1 p 394 shows a comparison of	k factor ratings of a number of commercial insulating materials	flexural	this term refers to the ability of a material	to resist bending stress and is determined by measuring the load required	to cause failure by bending	4602.18826933092
3320. the higher-density urethane semi-rigid	foams usually have stronger flex fatigue resistance ie the	12 lbcu ft foam has 8 times the flexural strength of the	3 lbcu ft density	4647.3268429972695
3321. note that flexural strength is not always	improved by simply increasing the density nor is the change always	proportional from one formulation to another	2462.380572860974
3322. where flexural strength	is an important factor be sure that your urethane foam processor is	aware of it	2350.5532967555196
3323. this property refers to the greatest	longitudinal stress or tension a material can endure without tearing	apart	1418.0326622524485
3324. like compression strength of urethane foams it has a direct	relationship to formulation	1178.2756689212736
3325. exceptional tensile strength is another	of urethane foam's strong features	371.5195292841855
3326. figure 2 above shows the	aging properties of urethane foams as determined by the percent of change	processing	there are many ways of producing a foamed urethane	product	4483.913079241711
3327. the foam can be made into slab stock and cut to shape it	can be molded it can be poured-in-place it can be applied by spray	guns etc	2980.0815799802976
3328. slab stock is still one of the most important forms	of urethane end-product in use today	1867.6570968879023
3329. basically the foam machines	that produce such stock consist of two or more pumping units a variable	mixer a nozzle carriage assembly and in many cases a conveyor	belt to transport and contain the liquid during the reaction process	and until it solidifies into foam	4620.594753844556
3330. the ingredients are fed from tanks	through a hose and into the mixer at a predetermined rate	2133.024427819885
3331. the mixing	head moves back and forth slowly across the width of the receptacle	944.0825475207039
3332. it only takes a few minutes for the foaming action to be completed	and after a short cure the material can be cut into lengths as desired	4304.628647052309
3333. much has been done in the way of ingenious slitters to fabricate	the slab stock into finished products	1575.6730865104728
3334. profile cutting machines	are available which can split foam to any desired thickness and produce	sine triangle trapezoid and other profiles in variable heights	dimensions etc	4094.8440923584553
3335. the convoluted sheets can be combined to attain	certain cushioning effects mechanically rather than chemically	1099.715549880882
3336. also	available is a slitter which peels the inside of a folded block	of foam and can be used to slit continuous sheets up to 300 yd in	length down to 116 in thick	5473.86284259477
3337. the low cost and ease of fabrication	of the dies for three-dimensional foam cutting plus the wide	variety of shapes dimensions and contours that can be tailor-made to	customer requirements has made the technique useful for producing case	liners materials handling containers packaging and cushioning devices	and such novelties as soap dishes toys head rests arch supports	and gas pedal covers	5568.279104684163
3338. although slab stock appeared	first it soon became apparent that for the production of cushions with	irregular shapes crowned contours or rounded edges the cutting of	slab stock is a wasteful and uneconomical process	5478.116636166611
3339. only by resorting	to molding techniques can the cushion manufacturer hope to compete satisfactorily	in the established cushion market	1736.8170164878534
3340. the closed molding	of flexible urethane foams has been a problem ever since the introduction	of the material	2362.835290146081
3341. satisfactory methods for polyester foams and even prepolymer polyether	foams were never fully achieved	943.0706419048095
3342. closed molding generally resulted	in parts weighing more than parts fabricated	from free-blown foams	1412.3179143175898
3343. this counteracted the gain from having no scrap	loss	263.3742115539084
3344. in addition there were difficulties with the flow and spreading	of the foam mixture over the mold surface trouble with lack of	gel strength in the rising foam and problems of splits	5166.688972439237
3345. the introduction	of one-shot polyether foam systems aided by the development of	new catalysts helped to alleviate some of the problems of closed molding	2460.329162998263
3346. while there are still many bugs to be ironed out the technique	is fast developing	1636.9705130340076
3347. simple systems are available	that make it possible for urethane foam components to be poured pumped	etc into a void where they foam up to fill the void	2969.7798611475164
3348. in a	typical application- the making of rigid urethane foam sandwich panels-	an amount of foam mixture calculated to expand 10 to 20% more	than the volume of the panel is poured into the panel void and the top	of the panel is locked in place by a jig	7373.871911753519
3349. temperature of the wash and rinse waters is maintained at 85-90`f		262.42391946780714
3350. the top rolls are loaded with 40 lbs	249.48929693774485
3351. sixty	lbs loading is possible but 40 lbs is adequate	375.20057017307545
3352. the suds	box drain is arranged at the start to deliver into the raised main drain	pipe and the machine is started	3292.9901477343687
3353. the 160-ml bath containing the calculated amount of detergent is	applied slowly and directly to the running specimen	1569.7856711934835
3354. washing is continued	for 30 minutes or for a period of time sufficient to allow 100 nips	or passes through the squeeze rolls	3478.3044149101197
3355. at the conclusion of the washing	8 liters of water at 90`f are automatically metered	from the rinse reservoir to the washing tubs 4 liters to each tub	2976.4750199624364
3356. this operation requires from 10 to 12 minutes	252.21534992588303
3357. during the rinsing	operation the volume in the tubs gradually increases until overflow	from the main drain begins	1573.136286850849
3358. at this point the drains are readjusted so	that the suds box drain will discharge directly into the waste line	and the main tub drain is set at the 2-12 mark on the drain gauge	5646.075457822031
3359. when	all of the rinse water has passed from the reservoir to the tubs the	main drains are lowered to permit complete draining of the tubs	2736.1518170465024
3360. the	run is complete when all the water has drained off into the waste line	1647.641836557912
3361. by this procedure rinsing progresses in two stages first	by dilution until the time when the drains are separated and thereafter	by displacement of the soil-bearing liquor by clean rinse water since	soiled liquor squeezed from the specimens at the nip passes directly	to waste from the suds box drains	4946.371672664473
3362. this method of rinsing appears	to produce maximum cleansing with minimum soil redeposition	1185.4096009015466
3363. evaluation and classification	evaluation may be made on	either a soil-removal or a grease-removal basis as desired	1417.560980056323
3364. a	reflectance-measuring	instrument may be desirable to measure cleaning whereas	soxhlet extraction is necessary to measure grease removal	2352.264502759785
3365. this test method is intended for determining	the dimensional changes of woven or knitted fabrics made of fibers other	than wool to be expected when the cloth is subjected to laundering	procedures commonly used in the commercial laundry and the home	4306.550303460326
3366. four	washing test procedures are established varying in severity from very	severe to very mild and are intended to cover the range of practical	washing from commercial procedure to hand washing	4999.583836016454
3367. five drying test	procedures are established to cover the range of drying techniques	used in the home and commercial laundry	1882.3217582241036
3368. three methods for determining	the dimensional restorability characteristics are established for those	textiles which require restoration by ironing or wearing after laundering	3278.676138619502
3369. these tests are not accelerated and must be repeated to evaluate	dimensional changes after repeated launderings	1260.622954729335
3370. table 1	summarizes all of the various washing drying and restoration procedures	available	1181.132538147132
3371. the person using these tests must determine which combination	of procedures is practical for any specific item in order to	evaluate the dimensional changes of textile fabrics or garments after	laundering procedures commonly used in the home or commercial laundry	4214.646491088464
3372. it is possible to identify the test procedure completely with a code	consisting of a roman numeral a letter and an arabic number	3498.6965896977754
3373. for	example test 3 e 1 refers to a specimen which has been washed	by procedure 3	in the machine has been dried in a tumble dryer by procedure e	and has been subjected to restorative forces on the tension	presser by procedure 1	4551.5711888680125
3374. a specimen or garment	is washed in a cylindrical reversing wash wheel dried and subjected	to restorative forces where necessary	2830.7388875197753
3375. temperature and time of agitation	in the wash wheel are varied to obtain different degrees of severity	1403.4525354120588
3376. drying procedures and application of restorative force procedures	are varied to conform with end-use handling during home or commercial	laundering	2812.5160049047345
3377. distances marked on the specimen in warp and filling	directions are measured before	and after laundering	1258.960853774161
3378. _wash wheel-	the wheel	is 20 to 24 inches inside diameter and 20 to 24 inches inside length	2341.7551088242567
3379. there	are three fins each approximately three inches wide extending the full	length of the inside of the wheel	1717.2237143773905
3380. one fin is located every 120`	around the inside diameter of the wheel	1182.27555971434
3381. the wash wheel rotates at a	speed of 30 revolutions per minute making five to ten revolutions before	reversing	1725.837763817639
3382. the water inlets are large enough to permit filling the	wheel to an eight-inch level in less than two minutes and the outlet	is large enough to permit discharge of this same amount of water in	less than two minutes	6276.5930845815665
3383. the machine is equipped with a pipe for injecting	live steam that is capable of raising the temperature of water at	an eight-inch level from 110` to 140`f in	less than two minutes	3540.784732792331
3384. the machine shall contain an opening for the	insertion of a thermometer or other equivalent equipment for determining	the temperature of the water during the washing and rinsing procedures	4657.527626792287
3385. it is equipped with an outside water gauge that will indicate the	level of the water in the wheel	1729.3089560702713
3386. a domestic automatic washer	that will give equivalent results may be used	960.1653655582679
3387. the wash wheel is the	pressing equipment- flat-bed	any flat-bed press	capable of pressing a specimen 22 inches square may be used as an	alternative	2588.2597380907127
3388. the flat-bed press is maintained at a temperature not less	dryer- dryer of the rotary tumble	type having a cylindrical basket approximately 30 inches in diameter	the dryer is provided with a means of maintaining a drying temperature	of 120`-160`f measured in the exhaust	screen drying	racks- 16-mesh screening	7341.856389934287
3389. drying room-facilities	for drip- or line-drying	43.889024697884686
3390. extractor- centrifugal extractor	of the laundry-type with a perforated basket approximately 11	inches deep by 17 inches in diameter with an operating speed of approximately	1500 rpm	4268.242019471249
3391. pen and ink indelible- or other	suitable marking device	262.4079536064921
3392. soap neutral	_softener- eg sodium metaphosphate or sodium hexametaphosphate		191.7626613357421
3393. flatiron electric- approximately	3 lbtension presser- consisting of a padded ironing board	two of the	clamps are fixed to the edges of the board whereas two clamps travel on	guide rails opposite the fixed clamps	3769.585274963252
3394. the movable clamps travel on	carriages which ride the rails and are drawn by dead-weight loading	1880.658045359952
3395. sets of weights are provided so that the load can be selected in the	range of 12 to 4 pounds	1878.3919489479492
3396. a perforated aluminum plate used to provide	the drying surface is heated by means of a flatiron	2128.5019721751855
3397. a special template	is furnished with the apparatus to enable marking a specimen for	a central measuring area and the fabric extensions to the clamps	knit shrinkage gauge- consisting of a set of 20 mounting	each pin is individually	sprung to a tensioning member which is driven outwardly in	the slot	5038.642424733304
3398. the springs have an extension of 1 inch at f tension	753.9007024797303
3399. the	tensioning members have a common drive so that the application of restorative	force takes place simultaneously in all directions in the plane	of the test specimen	2854.631669262712
3400. the minimum diameter of the pin frame in the	collapsed state is 11 inches and the maximum diameter in the freely	extended state is 14 inches	4092.735836943967
3401. the surface of the apparatus	in contact with the test specimen is uncluttered and polished so as	to be as friction-free as possible	2338.9803402627663
3402. the preparation	of test specimens will vary depending upon the type of dimensional	restorability procedure to be used	2357.8463037146494
3403. three specimens	for each sample to be tested are required in order to arrive at a satisfactory	average of performance	1871.0321676728386
3404. this is especially true for knitted	fabrics	140.40705136257674
3405. specimens are allowed to reach moisture equilibrium with	a standard atmosphere of f and f and then laid out without tension	on a flat polished surface care being taken that the fabric is	free from wrinkles or creases	4049.1746233695267
3406. fabrics that are badly distorted in their	unlaundered state due to faulty finishing may give deceptive dimensional	change results when laundered by any procedure	3691.4651314921052
3407. this also holds	true	if restorative forces are applied	262.9494025777704
3408. therefore it is recommended that	in such cases the sample be replaced or if used the results of dimensional	change or dimensional restorability tests be considered as indicative	only	4666.610754334574
3409. generally it is necessary to mark distances on	a specimen in both lengthwise and widthwise directions and	to measure before and after laundering	2322.530361810668
3410. the distances may be marked	with indelible ink and a fine-point pen by sewing fine threads into	the fabric or by a specially designed stamping machine	4131.01936004295
3411. the marked distances	are parallel to the respective yarns	262.85085275523244
3412. usually the greater the	original distances marked the greater will be the accuracy of the	woven	fabrics to be dried by procedure b or restored by	the specimen of fabric is a rectangle	at least 22 by 22 inches except for cloth narrower than 22 inches	in which case the specimen is the entire width of the fabric	8126.073126460224
3413. three	distances each at least 18 inches are measured and marked off parallel	to each of the warp and filling directions	2032.9571350573483
3414. the distances are at	woven or warp knitted	each specimen is at least 25 inches by 25 inches	2358.832875588708
3415. place the template	on the fabric so that the sides of the 10 inch square	cut out of the template are parallel to the warp and filling for woven	fabrics or the wales and courses for knitted fabrics and so that the	same amount of fabric extends beyond the edges of the template on all	sides	5323.668189174834
3416. mark the specimen at the outer edges of the template with pen	and indelible ink; also place three dots on the specimen at each	side of the 10 inch square one dot at midpoint and one at approximately	circular knitted	fabrics to be subjected to restorative procedure 2	each specimen is approximately 16 inches square	7882.2448748258885
3417. the markings	consist of a centrally located 10 inch diameter measuring circle	and a 14 inch diameter circle of 20 dots equidistantly spaced		1582.6759590367933
3418. critical measurements in length and width	directions should be taken before and after washing drying and restorative	procedures	2365.0279953210893
3419. the washing	procedures are summarized in table 2	165.90031724924967
3420. place the specimen	in the wash wheel with sufficient other similar fabric to make a dry	load of f pounds	2812.737894784847
3421. start the wash wheel and note the time	167.4125737919611
3422. immediately	add water at 100-105`f to the wheel to a level	of f inches; this level will be increased by condensed steam	3244.7960876555817
3423. when this water level has been reached inject steam into the wheel until	the temperature reaches that shown in column b of table 2	2450.1116494845023
3424. add sufficient soap	to furnish a good running suds or if desired use a synthetic detergent	1888.7946231975761
3425. stop the wash wheel at the end of the	time	shown in column a of table 2 and drain	1720.9598132995138
3426. refill the machine	to a level of f inches with water at 100-109` f	and start the machine	2351.971703130096
3427. inject steam if necessary to reach the	temperature shown in column d of table 2	1093.23350216845
3428. again stop the machine	at the end of the time shown in column c of table 2	2116.069734120424
3429. this procedure is repeated for the second rinse using the temperatures	tests	2 3	- run the machine continuously until completion	of the test	1571.9683678717315
3430. drain off the soap solution of the suds cycle at such	a time that the wheel has become substantially empty of soap and water	at the end of the time shown in column a of table 2 measured	from the time the wash wheel was started	7003.701999676698
3431. refill the machine to a	level of f inches with water at 100-109` f	933.0338202312562
3432. when this water level has been reached inject steam until the temperature	is that shown in column d	2344.1573522130225
3433. drain off the water at such a time	that the wheel has become substantially empty of water at the end	of the sum of the times shown in columns a and c measured from	the time the wash wheel was started	4292.439830152197
3434. immediately refill to a level	of f inches with water at 100-109` f	1172.2978066390533
3435. when	this water level has been reached inject steam until the temperature is	that shown in column f	1561.45670853561
3436. drain off the water at such a time that	the wheel has become substantially empty of water at the end of the	sum of the times shown in columns a c and e measured from	the time the wash wheel was started	6554.178444687753
3437. high-gain photoelectronic image intensification is applied under	conditions of low incident light levels whenever the integration time	required by a sensor or recording instrument exceeds the limits of	practicability	3105.9775567914235
3438. examples of such situations are night reconnaissance	the recording of radioactive tracers in live body tissues	special radiography in medical or industrial applications track recording	of high energy particles etc	4852.284822932639
3439. high-gain photoelectronic	image intensification may be achieved by several methods; some of	cascading single stages by coupling	lens systems	image intensifier based upon the multipactor	transmission secondary electron multiplication	cascading of single	stages enclosed in one common envelope	4015.4181935064867
3440. cascading single stages	by coupling lens systems is rather inefficient as the lens systems	limit the obtainable gain quite severely	2815.676285497821
3441. channel-type image intensifiers	are capable of achieving high-gain values; suffer however	from an inherently low resolution	1260.5481379112973
3442. image intensifiers based upon	the multipactor principle appear to hold promise as far as obtainable	resolution is concerned	2373.6850089779537
3443. however the unavoidable low-duty cycle restricts	the effective gain	262.0083248568577
3444. tsem tubes have been constructed showing	high gain and resolution	561.948702000668
3445. however electrostatic focus important	for many applications has not been realized for these devices	946.0123415071488
3446. resolution	limitations with electrostatic focus might be anticipated due to	chromatic aberrations	955.650540807459
3447. furthermore the thin film dynodes appear to	have a natural diameter limitation wherever a mesh support cannot be	tolerated	1734.874658416132
3448. cascaded single stages enclosed by a common envelope	have been constructed with high gain and high resolution	2122.2383250665257
3449. these	tubes may differ both in the choice of the electron optical system	and in the design of the coupling members	2034.7693768799422
3450. the electron optical system	may be either a magnetic or electrostatic one	962.481480676964
3451. the magnification	may be smaller equal or larger than unity	373.2242759755395
3452. an electrostatic	system suffers generally from image plane curvature leading to defocusing	in the peripheral image region if a flat viewing screen	is utilized while a magnetic system requires accurate	adjustment of the solenoid which is heavy and bulky	6197.272546531287
3453. as it will be discussed	later peripheral defocusing can be improved on by utilizing	curved fiber couplers	1411.5414408969593
3454. it should be noted however that the paraxial	resolution is quite similar for both electron optical systems	2112.273106415394
3455. it is felt that fiber-coupled double- stage image intensifiers	will gain considerable importance in the future	1250.6844719111218
3456. therefore we	shall consider in this paper the theoretical gain and resolution capabilities	of such tubes	1893.4778640897869
3457. the luminous efficiency and resolution of single	stages fiber couplers and finally of the composite tube will be	computed	1729.6541965139136
3458. it will be shown theoretically that the high image	intensification obtainable with such a tube and contact photography permits	the utilization of extremely low incident light levels	4301.838879253586
3459. the effect	of device and quantum noise associated with such low input levels	will be described	1268.398813322274
3460. after these theoretical considerations constructional	details of a fiber-coupled double-stage x-ray image	intensifier will be discussed	1871.7949138711126
3461. measured performance characteristics	for this experimental tube will be listed	371.27003584927644
3462. the conclusion shall	be reached that fiber-coupled double-stage tubes represent a sensible	and practical approach to high-gain image intensification	2577.692228225519
3463. design of a fiber-coupled double-stage image intensifier	the tube	design which forms the basis of the theoretical discussion shall	be described now	2177.5100669109725
3464. the electron optical system is	based in principle on the focusing action of concentric spherical cathode	and anode surfaces	2582.886899487288
3465. the inner anode sphere is pierced elongated	into a cup and terminated by the phosphor screen	1267.6688654717982
3466. the photoelectrons	emitted from a circular segment of the cathode sphere are focused	by the positive lens action of the two concentric spheres pass through	the negative lens formed by the anode aperture and impinge	upon the cathodoluminescent viewing screen	6356.663006582339
3467. the cylindrical focusing	electrode permits adjustment of the positive lens part by varying the	focusing potential	1259.587682824836
3468. the anode potential codetermines the gain g	and magnification m of the stage	1197.4780651874119
3469. both the photocathode	and the image plane of such an electrode configuration are curved	concave as seen from the anode aperture	2044.1252520046048
3470. the field-flattening property	of the biconcave fiber coupler can be utilized to alleviate the	peripheral resolution losses resulting with a flat phosphor-screen or	coupling member	3909.0918076432076
3471. for the same reason the output fiber plate is planoconcave	its exposed flat side permitting contact photography if a permanent	record is desired	2321.2550186265125
3472. as it will be shown later the field-flattening	properties of the interstage and output fiber coupler comprise indeed	the main advantage of such a design	3911.492568017359
3473. the second photocathode	and both phosphor surfaces are deposited on the fiber plate substrates	945.6510774469203
3474. the photocathode sensitivities s phosphor efficiencies	p and anode potentials v of the individual stages shall	be distinguished by means of subscripts 1 and 2 in the text	where required	4829.371001820692
3475. both stages are assumed to have unity magnification	166.94555831577276

3494. the internal losses are due to absorption and the small but	finite losses suffered in the numerous internal reflections due to	deviations from the prescribed cylindrical fiber cross-section and minute	imperfections of the core-jacket interface	5620.661944694152

3498. this relatively high value is probably due to the small fiber	diameters increasing the number of internal reflections	2356.4649340124197
3499. since we are	considering here relatively small diameter fiber plates	their average thickness can be kept below 14 inch and their internal	losses may be assumed as 15 percent	3110.1602444780906

3512. we have evaluated the matching integrals for two types	of photocathodes and three types of light input	2122.081993660825
3513. the input light distributions considered are p-11 and p-20	phosphor emission and the so-called night light	as given by hw babcock and j j johnson	2614.9911925022507
3514. the integrals	are listed in table 14-1 below:	discussion of paraxial device resolution	_resolution limitations	the resolution limitations for a single stage are	given by the inherent resolution of the electron optical system as	well as the resolution capabilities of the cathodoluminescent viewing	screen	6816.416819568409
3515. the resolution capabilities of an electrostatic system	depend on both the choice of magnification and chromatic aberrations	1413.9200078741685
3516. it has been stated previously that a minifying electrostatic system yields	a lower resolution than a magnifying system or a system with unity	magnification	3699.803333428588
3517. furthermore the chromatic aberrations depend	on the chosen high voltage	377.21436705233083
3518. in general a high anode voltage reduces	chromatic aberrations and thus increases the obtainable resolution	1651.4161234208646
