3521. the following efficiencies obtained from jedec	and rca specifications were used: f   the following	table gain values computed according	to eq with f:   the possibility of a space charge	blowup of the screen crossover of the elementary electron bundles has	been pointed out	4451.0027319909905
3522. it is obvious that such an influence can only be	expected in the final stage of an image intensifier at rather high output	levels	3694.5380458204695
3523. space charge influences will also decrease at increased	voltages	262.8227395878899
3524. electrostatic systems of the pseudo-symmetric type have	been tested for resolution capabilities by applying electronography	1653.7489570065638
3525. a resolution of 70-80 line-pairs per millimeter appears to be feasible	502.57326399851
3526. the inherent resolution of a cathodoluminescent phosphor	screen decreases with increasingly aggregate thickness	decreases with decreasing porosity	and might be impaired by the	normally used aluminum mirror	4306.548133433664
3527. thus in general elementary light	optical effects light scatter and electron scatter determine the obtainable	resolution limit	1419.9023837926284
3528. it should be noted that photoluminescence	due to bremsstrahlung generated within the viewing screen by electron	impact appears to be important only if anode voltages in excess	of 30 kv are utilized	5160.233548338258
3529. it has been stated that settled cathodoluminescent	phosphor screens may have a limiting resolution of 60 f	at high voltage values of approximately 20 kv	2591.7407686002034
3530. for the further discussion	we shall thus assume an electron optical resolution of 80 f	and phosphor screen resolution of 60 f	3275.780828543552
3531. the set of all decisions is called the operating policy or more simply	the policy	1101.7564466882432
3532. an optimal policy is one which in some sense gets the	best out of the process as a whole by maximizing the value of the product	4117.4593066857005
3533. there are thus three components to an optimal design problem:	the specification of the operating variables and the transformation	the specification of the objective function	of which the optimization is desired	3355.1897074176704
3534. for a chemical process	the	first of these might involve the concentrations of the different chemical	species and the temperature or pressure of the stream	3913.540696101408
3535. for the	second we might have to choose the volume of reactor or amount of cooling	to be supplied; the way in which the transformation of state depends	on the operating variables for the main types of reactors is discussed	in the next chapter	4543.553557647632
3536. the objective function is some measure of	the increase in value of the stream by processing; it is the subject	of chapter 4	3486.0039382746
3537. the essential characteristic of an optimal policy	when the state of the stream is transformed in a sequence of stages	with no feedback was first isolated by bellman	2986.3281244839586
3538. he recognized that	whatever transformation may be effected in the first stage of an r-stage	process the remaining stages must use an optimal f-stage policy	with respect to the state resulting from the first stage if there	is to be any chance of optimizing the complete process	7136.523361151181
3539. moreover by	systematically varying the operating conditions in the first stage and	always using the optimal f-stage policy for the remaining stages	we shall eventually find the optimal policy for all r stages	3565.432076815123
3540. proceeding	in this way from one to two and from two to three stages we	may gradually build up the policy for any number	3677.0350888625
3541. at each step of the	calculation the operating variables of only one stage need be varied	1264.8786961098883
3542. to see how important this economy is let us suppose that there	are m operating variables at each stage and that the state	is specified by n variables; then the search for the maximum	at any one stage will require a number of operations of order f		5771.124544794349
3543. to proceed from	one stage to the next a sufficient number of feed states must be investigated	to allow of interpolation; this number will be of the order	of f	3200.1667125971544
3544. if however we are seeking the optimal r-stage policy	for a given feed state only one search for a maximum is required at	the final step	4127.006639661246
3545. thus a number of operations of the order of f are	required	635.4935416047136
3546. if all the operating variables were varied simultaneously	f operations would be required to do the same job and as r	increases this increases very much more rapidly than the number of operations	required by the dynamic program	6052.781664366366
3547. but even more important than	this is the fact that the direct search by simultaneously varying all	operating conditions has produced only one optimal policy namely that	for the given feed state and r stages	3762.013797453267
3548. in contrast the dynamic	program produces this policy and a whole family of policies for	any smaller number of stages	2800.9787947981017
3549. if the problem is enlarged to require	a complete coverage of feed states f operations are needed by the dynamic	program and f by the direct search	2869.3926069881973
3550. but f is vastly larger	than r	140.600915328309
3551. no optimism is more baseless than that which believes	that the high speed of modern digital computers allows for use of the	crudest of methods in searching out a result	3211.676226947802
3552. suppose that f and	that the average operation requires only f sec	963.7092723341966
3553. then the dynamic	program would require about a minute whereas the direct search would	take	more than three millennia!   the principle of optimality thus	brings a vital organization into the search for the optimal policy of	a multistage decision process	4231.929179188154
3554. bellman has annunciated in the	following terms:   an optimal policy has the property that	whatever the initial state and initial decision are the remaining decisions	must constitute an optimal policy with respect to the state resulting	from the first decision	6358.853532432278
3555. this is the principle which	we will invoke in every case to set up a functional equation	1405.7078627285273
3556. it appears	in a form that is admirably suited to the powers of the digital	computer	1882.4184276318363
3557. at the same time every device that can be employed to reduce	the number of variables is of the greatest value and it is one of	the attractive features of dynamic programming that room is left for	ingenuity in using the special features of the problem to this end	4883.893985381574
3558. the discrete deterministic process	consider the process illustrated	in fig 2	755.1447030712418
3559. 1 consisting of r distinct stages	43.509713280282305
3560. these	will be numbered in the direction opposite to the flow of the process	stream so that stage r is the rth stage from the end	4097.462293987219
3561. let the state of the stream leaving stage r be denoted by a vector	f and the operating variables of stage r by f	2466.858697110805
3562. thus	f denotes the state of the feed to the r-stage process and	f the state of the product from the last stage	3509.1012348661766
3563. each stage transforms	the state f of its feed to the state f in a way that depends on	the operating variables f	2327.676570432408
3564. this transformation	is uniquely determined by f and we therefore speak of the process	as deterministic	1876.8683921741242
3565. in practical situations there will be restrictions	on the admissible operating conditions and we regard the vectors as belonging	to a fixed and bounded set s	2747.4729002414724
3566. the set of vectors f	constitutes the operating policy or more briefly the policy and a	policy is admissible if all the f belong to s	4105.7876395618205
3567. when the policy	has been chosen the state of the product can be obtained from the	state of the feed by repeated application of the transformation;	thus f	3006.7735159304543
3568. the objective function which is to be maximized is some	function usually piecewise continuous of the product state	2358.4831228696075
3569. let this	be denoted by f	43.22620241596131
3570. an optimal policy is an admissible policy	f which maximizes the objective function p	1411.8692387943638
3571. the policy may	not be unique but the maximum value of p certainly is and once	the policy is specified this maximum can be calculated by	as a function of the feed state f	3656.9117436517977
3572. let f where the maximization	is over all admissible policies f	752.6710733519213
3573. when it is necessary to be specific	we say that the optimal policy is an optimal r-stage policy	with respect to the feed state f	2601.6469223460886
3574. for any choice of admissible	policy f in the first stage the state of the stream leaving	this stage is given by f	3478.089308711062
3575. this is the feed state of the subsequent	f stages which according to the principle of optimality must use an	optimal f-stage policy with respect to this state	2981.6782212450303
3576. this will result	in a value f of the objective function and when f is chosen correctly	this will give f the maximum of the objective function	4286.122167350608
3577. thus	f	where the maximization is over all admissible policies f and f	is related to f by can be solved	for f when f is known and clearly f the maximization being	over all admissible f	3947.0060329489816
3578. the set of equations and the	starting equation is of a recursive type well suited to programming	on the digital computer	3045.2195372642786
3579. in finding the optimal r-stage policy	from that of f stages only the function f is needed	1416.0562726471762
3580. when	f has been found it may be transferred into the storage location of	f and the whole calculation repeated	2823.307470142472
3581. we also see how the results	may be presented although if n the number of state variables	is large any tabulation will become cumbersome	2450.224035591179
3582. a table or set of tables	may be set out as in table 2	1396.2129203410602
3583. to extract the optimal	r-stage policy with respect to the feed state f we enter section	r of this table at the state f and find immediately	from the last column the maximum value of the objective function	4036.1625243175645
3584. in	the third column is given the optimal policy for stage r and	in the fourth the resulting state of the stream when this policy is used	4304.2396341749445
3585. since by the principle of optimality the remaining stages use an	optimal f-stage policy with respect to f we may enter section f	of the table at this state f and read off the optimal policy for stage	f and the resulting state f	4520.41617467241
3586. proceeding in this way up the table	we extract the complete optimal policy and if it is desired we	can check on f by evaluating f at the last stage	4822.083331947906
3587. it may be	that the objective function depends not only on f but also on f	as when the cost of the operating policy is considered	2736.1750880651725
3588. a moment's	reflection shows that the above algorithm and presentation work equally	well in this case	1871.462702462733
3589. a form of objective function that we shall often	have occasion to consider is f	1099.1918112181916
3590. here v represents	the	the cost	of operating the stage with conditions 	519.2508925479597
3591. hence p	is the increase in value of the stream minus the cost of operation that	is the net profit	1885.2176398400309
3592. if f denotes the net profit from stage r	and f then the principle of optimality gives f this sequence	of equations may be started with the remark that with no process f there	is no profit ie f	6182.028726947398
3593. the process in which the outcome of any one stage is known only	statistically is also of interest although for chemical reactor design	it is not as important as the deterministic process	3456.20262622268
3594. in this case	the stage r operating with conditions f transforms the state	of the stream from f to f but only the probability distribution of	f is known	4663.524760174346
3595. this is specified by a distribution function f such	that the probability that f lies in some region d of the stage	space is f	2588.6768211458843
3596. we cannot now speak of maximizing the value	of the objective function since this function is now known only in a	probabilistic sense	3492.0484175563083
3597. we can however maximize its expected value	93.66339278563835
3598. for	a single stage we may define f where the maximization is by choice	of f	1883.0857085278926
3599. we thus have an optimal policy which maximizes the expected	value of the objective function for a given f	1735.0403689280297
3600. if we consider a process	in which the outcome of one stage is known before passage to the	next then the principle of optimality shows that the policy in subsequent	stages should be optimal with respect to the outcome of the first	6579.6031241180335
3601. then f the maximization being over all admissible f and the integration	over the whole of stage space	1579.1812691737891
3602. the type of presentation	of results used in the deterministic process may be used here except	that now the fourth column is redundant	3474.4862666792096
3603. the third column gives	the optimal policy but we must wait to see the outcome of stage r	and enter the preceding section of the table at this state	3102.575279644764
3604. the	discussion of the optimal policy when the outcome of one stage is not	known before passing to the next is a very much more difficult matter	4295.7742500036675
3605. in many cases it is not	possible to divide the process into a finite number of discrete stages	since the state of the stream is transformed in a continuous manner	through the process	3553.8662472670467
3606. we replace r the number of the stage	from the end of the process by t a continuous variable which	measures the distance of the point considered from the end of the	process	5327.964058362418
3607. the word distance is used here in a rather general sense;	it may in fact be the time that will elapse before the end of the	process	2853.753642497323
3608. if t is the total length of the process its	feed state may be denoted by a vector  and the product	state by  denotes the state at	any point t and  the vector of operating variables	there	5921.62702649653
3609. a gyro-stabilized platform system using restrained gyros is	well suited for automatic leveling because of the characteristics of the	gyro-platform-servo combination	2029.9016328752525
3610. the restrained gyro-stabilized platform	with reasonable response characteristics operates with an approximate	equation of motion neglecting transient effects as follows:	f where u is a torque applied about the output axis of the	controlling gyro	5641.216661526452
3611. the platform angle |f is the angle about	which the gyro is controlling	792.4536324644312
3612. this is normally termed the gyro input	axis 90` away from the gyro output or |j axis	2142.782481378239
3613. the gyro angular	momentum is defined by h	167.61121651183154
3614. thus if the gyro and platform-controller	combination maintains the platform with zero angular	deviation about the |f axis the system can be rotated with an	angular velocity f if a torque is supplied to the gyro output axis |j	6212.713045443233
3615. it is assumed that the gyros are designed with electrical torquers	so that a torque can be applied about their output axes	2179.095270556616
3616. in the system shown in fig 7-1 the accelerometer output is amplified	and the resulting voltage is applied to the gyro output-axis torquer	3499.3607106955133
3617. this torque causes the entire system to rotate about the |f	axis since the response to f	1409.7398333176366
3618. if the polarities are correct the	platform rotates in such a direction as to reduce the accelerometer output	to zero	2827.333661131329
3619. as the accelerometer output is decreasing the torque applied	to the gyro output axis decreases and therefore the rate decreases	1895.706875819676
3620. finally when the accelerometer output is zero the entire system	remains stationary and the platform is by definition leveled	2595.261878538349
3621. a mathematical block diagram for the leveling system is shown in	fig 7-2	786.1652452275091
3622. the platform is initially off level by the angle |f	563.8501380186337
3623. the angle generated by the platform servo |f multiplied by g	is the effective acceleration acting on the accelerometer	1739.3738843671485
3624. f	is the scale factor of the accelerometer	250.761010605751
3625. the voltage f is amplified	by f and applied to the gyro torquer with scale factor f	1412.6134753120932
3626. finally the gyro-stabilized platform characteristic is represented	by f the system as indicated in fig 7-2 is fundamental and simple	because the transient effects of both the platform servo and the	accelerometer have been neglected	5640.74673844391
3627. with these factors included an upper	limit is placed on the allowable loop gain by stability considerations	1413.326932767523
3628. in this type of system a high loop gain is desirable because it	provides a fast response time	2349.595350812478
3629. when the frequency response characteristics	of practical components are considered their effect on	stability does not present the most serious limit on the system loop	gain	2717.763985689359
3630. the time required for the system to reach a level position is approximately	inversely proportional to the servo loop gain	2816.045477436194
3631. in addition	the cutoff frequency for input accelerations is approximately proportional	to the servo loop gain; ie high loop gain causes the	system to respond to horizontal components of accelerations	3219.0643863725627
3632. this problem	usually determines the lower limit of loop gain rather than response	time	1402.4622581978385
3633. it must be noticed in fig 7-1 that the accelerometer	responds to any input acceleration	1100.986612792105
3634. the equation relating input	acceleration to output platform angle is f in practice the preflight	leveling process takes place with the system mounted in the airframe	4113.6081239744735
3635. when the system is arranged for automatic leveling the platform	angles respond to any horizontal components of acceleration acting on	the accelerometers	2176.4758940125203
3636. there are many such components of acceleration present	due to the effect of wind gusts engine noise turbulence around	the vehicle etc	3257.0201803102486
3637. one of the greatest problems associated with automatic	leveling is establishing a true level in the presence of high-level	acceleration noise	2040.642776798421
3638. one solution to the problem is to operate	with a low loop gain and to include low-pass filters	2371.6314608479406
3639. this technique	causes the system to respond only to low frequency acceleration components	such as the platform tilt	1572.6145233538778
3640. since a lower loop gain and low-pass filtering	increases the response time a practical compromise must be reached	2356.6899169979824
3641. one of the most desirable solutions is achieved by the	use of a non-linear amplifier for f	1417.6523672500182
3642. the amplifier is designed so	that its gain is large for accelerometer signals above a certain threshold	level	2352.8867582538583
3643. below this level the amplifier gain f is proportional	and is of small value in order to provide adequate noise filtering	2038.918819694313
3644. the	effect is that the platform returns from an off-level position at	a rapid rate until it is nearly level at which point the platform is	controlled by a proportional servo with low enough frequency response	so that the noise has little effect on the leveling process	7105.643303111932
3645. when	the system is on automatic leveling the gyro drift is canceled by	the output of the leveling system	1731.1059959611928
3646. the platform actually	tilts off level so that the accelerometer output when amplified	by f will supply the correct current to the gyro torquer to cancel	the gyro drift	4663.197475040549
3647. the amount of platform dip required depends upon the	scale factors of the system	942.0665996492673
3648. the automatic leveling system described in this section is readily	adaptable to a gyro-stabilized platform consisting of three integrating	gyros	2804.010410098974
3649. the system requires some switching of flight equipment circuits	260.17573718372523
3650. however the leveling operation can be maintained and controlled	remotely with no mechanical or optical contact with the platform	2605.4824375403305
3651. this leveling system will hold the platform on-level automatically	as long as the system is actuated	1265.9930965549822
3652. a useful by-product of this	system is that the information necessary to set the gyro drift biases	is available from the currents necessary to hold the system in level	4650.020694776354
3653. the leveling process can be accomplished manually and the results	are as satisfactory as those obtained with automatic equipment	1738.7869321239618
3654. the	process consists in turning the platform manually until the outputs	of both accelerometers are zero	1879.8594050013485
3655. the turning is accomplished by applying	voltage to the gyro torquers described above	788.4157286736333
3656. in brief the human	replaces amplifier f in figs 7-1 and 7-2	959.3730186360342
3657. manual leveling	requires an appropriate display of the accelerometer outputs	374.5546346674796
3658. if	high accuracy is required in preflight leveling it is usually necessary	to integrate or doubly integrate the accelerometer outputs		1812.1216611076875
3659. with integration the effect of a small	acceleration can be seen after a time	945.7892343706748
3660. however skill is required on the part of an operator to level a	platform to any degree of accuracy	2584.3606790864983
3661. also it requires more time as	compared to the automatic approach	503.83476627019354
3662. manual leveling is inconvenient	if the platform must be maintained accurately level for any prolonged	period of time	2352.884045338224
3663. the operator must continually supply the correct	amount of turning current to the gyro torquers so that the effect of	gyro drift is canceled	2458.489498007708
3664. this process is especially difficult since gyro	drifting is typically random	750.2435951500535
3665. platform	heading consists of orienting the sensitive axis of the accelerometers	parallel to the desired coordinate system of the navigator	1876.4919569178924
3666. in simpler	terms it amounts to pointing the platform in the proper direction	1178.275880944478
3667. for purely inertial navigators two techniques are available	to accomplish the platform heading:  use of external or	surveying equipment to establish proper heading	2311.348524374447
3668. use of the	characteristics of the platform components for an indication of true	heading the choice of the heading technique is dependent upon the accuracy	requirements field conditions and the time available to accomplish	the heading	5790.774388654503
3669. with the gyro-stabilized platform leveled it can be	headed in the proper direction by using surveying techniques	1412.2978955341696
3670. the platform	accelerometers must be slightly modified for this procedure	558.0708051888674
3671. before	the accelerometers are mounted on the platform the direction of	their sensitive axis must be accurately determined	1578.765036667686
3672. a mirror is mounted	on each accelerometer so that the plane of the mirror is perpendicular	to the sensitive axis of the unit	3502.0325073897175
3673. a precision transit	is set up so that it is aligned with respect to true north	1248.956427063708
3674. this	can be done to a high degree of accuracy by existing surveying techniques	1423.9176690179886
3675. with the transit set up a mirror on one of the accelerometers	is sighted and the platform is turned until it is aligned	2333.2829871800272
3676. the	sighting procedure includes the use of a fixture for the transit to	project a beam of light which is darkened by crossed hairs on the accelerometer	mirror	4473.114257509356
3677. when the platform is aligned the reflected image	of the crossed hairs can be seen exactly superimposed upon the original	crossed hairs	2168.2967386046557
3678. the images can easily be aligned with a high degree	of accuracy	963.3303027513837
3679. the platform is turned as required by supplying currents	to the appropriate gyro torquers	939.1076187461495
3680. although this technique is	simple and satisfactory one practical difficulty does exist: the direction	of true north must be known for each launch point	3675.853308854365
3681. however	this difficulty is not too serious if it is realized that a surveying	team can establish a true north base line with a few days' work	2859.555238706025
3682. in many installations the inertial platform is raised off the ground	a considerable height when it is mounted in the vehicle before flight	3496.7190495017726
3683. with this situation it is difficult to sight in on the platform with	surveying equipment	1094.0793945102555
3684. if the platform is not too high off the ground	a transit can be mounted on a stand to raise it up to the platform	3907.783772500197
3685. obviously the heading accuracy is lessened by such techniques since	errors are introduced because of motion of the stand	1729.4276331931844
3686. the transit can be replaced by an autocollimator	249.6669025075772
3687. this instrument	provides an electrical signal proportional to the angular deviations	of the platform and can be used to automatically hold the platform	on true heading	2736.8323507169994
3688. the electrical signal from the autocollimator is amplified	and supplied to the z-gyro torquer	1423.3043846538285
3689. if the polarity is	correct the platform will turn until the heading error angle is zero	1262.0790973116675
3690. information is also available from this autocollimator system to set	the drift bias for the z-axis gyro	2117.6697559860972
3691. if the z gyro	is drifting a current generated by the autocollimator is delivered to	the gyro torquer to cancel the drift	2183.251719856088
3692. if the drift error is systematic	it can be canceled with a bias circuit which can be arranged and adjusted	to supply the required compensating current	4090.493528339667
3693. it is possible to locate an angular electrical pickoff which	will indicate the angular deviation between the true heading direction	and the platform	2324.167826295543
3694. essentially the stator or reference portion of	the pickoff is established with respect to the true heading direction	and the platform is turned either manually or automatically until the	angular electrical pickoff signal is reduced to zero	5950.238382759566
3695. gyrocompass alignment is an automatic heading system	which depends upon the characteristic of one gyro to establish true	heading	1721.7417427047542
3696. for the case of a purely inertial autonavigator consisting of	three restrained gyros a coordinate system is used where the sensitive	axis of the x accelerometer is parallel to the east-west direction	at the base point and the y accelerometer sensitive	axis is parallel to the north-south direction at the base point	7622.074110970044
3697. the	accelerometers are mounted rigidly on the platform	168.07680146691456
3698. thus if one accelerometer	is properly aligned the other is also	757.5033796602581
3699. the input axis of the	appropriate gyros are parallel to the sensitive direction of the accelerometers	1258.346410050583
3700. figure 7-3 shows a platform system with the gyro	vectors arranged as described above	1416.0479934020445
3701. the platform is leveled and properly	headed so that the x-gyro input axis is parallel to the	east-west direction and the y-gyro input axis is parallel to	the north-south direction	3232.642072525558
3702. the input axis of the x gyro	when pointing in the east-west direction is always perpendicular to	the spin axis of earth	3270.763189781353
3703. if the platform is not properly headed the	x-gyro input axis will see a component of the earth's rotation	1738.00565810944
3704. the sensing of this rotation by the x gyro can be utilized	to direct the platform into proper heading	2593.9290709094143
3705. in fig 7-4	the input axis of the three-axis platform is shown at some point on the	earth	1581.0575861001143
3706. the point is at a latitude |l and the platform is at	an error in heading east	2134.378705273134
3707. the earth is spinning at an angular velocity	\q equal to one revolution per 24 hr	1263.788788157243
3708. when the platform is	level |e is a rotation about the z axis of the platform	f	2127.6540589722053
3709. since the earth is rotating and the unleveled gyro-stabilized platform	is fixed with respect to a reference in space an observer on	the earth will see the platform rotating	3132.6128576370043
3710. scotty did not go back to school	141.15004314326472
3711. his parents	talked seriously and lengthily to their own doctor and to a specialist	at the university hospital- mr mckinley was entitled to a	discount for members of his family- and it was decided it would be	best for him to take the remainder of the term off spend a lot of time	in bed and for the rest do pretty much as he chose- provided of	course he chose to do nothing too exciting or too debilitating	0.20124717349522497
3712. his	teacher and his school principal were conferred with and everyone agreed	that if he kept up with a certain amount of work at home there was	little danger of his losing a term	5479.94320387579
3713. scotty accepted the decision	with indifference and did not enter the arguments	636.6270438066405
3714. he was	discharged from the hospital after a two-day checkup and he and his	parents had what mr mckinley described as a celebration lunch	at the cafeteria on the campus	4883.5652913641325
3715. rachel wore a smart hat and because	she had been warned recently about smoking puffed at her cigarettes	through a long ivory holder stained with lipstick	2750.2209052603457
3716. scotty's father	sat sprawled in his chair angular alert as a cricket looking about	at the huge stainless-steel appointments of the room with an expression	of proprietorship	4289.501646233653
3717. teachers- men who wore brown suits and	had gray hair and pleasant smiles- came to their table to talk shop	and to be introduced to scotty and rachel	2987.0295505830677
3718. rachel was polite scotty	indifferent	22.156357233284396
3719. they ate the cafeteria food with its orange sauces	and scotty gazed without interest at his food the teachers the heroic	baronial windows and the bright ranks of college banners	3233.757431872489
3720. his father	tried to make the food a topic	390.9150937942729
3721. the blueberry pie is good	scotty	43.37594111719706
3722. he looked at his son his face worried	249.39625100121435
3723. scotty murmured no thanks so softly his father had to	bend his gaunt height across the table and turn a round brown ear to him	2595.2997886076914
3724. scotty regarded the ear and the grizzled hair around it with a moment	of interest	1649.0222560995182
3725. he said more loudly i'm full old pop	167.24712295774077
3726. he	had eaten almost nothing on the crested three-sectioned plate and	had drunk about half the milk in its paper container	3071.7913431562947
3727. he's	all right craig rachel said	43.45031429104257
3728. i can fix him something later	in the afternoon when we get home	1173.672529237493
3729. since his seizure scotty	had had little appetite; yet his changed appearance surprisingly	was one of plumpness	1409.7286148574478
3730. his face was fuller; his lips and the usually	sharp lines of his jaw had become swollen-looking	2109.019187009317
3731. he breathed now	with his mouth open showing a whitely curving section of lower teeth;	he kept his eyes with their puffed blurred lids always lowered	though not apparently focusing	3232.0139247174952
3732. even his neck seemed thicker and	therefore shorter	251.21685842010947
3733. his hands which had been as quick as a pair of fluttering	birds were now neither active nor really relaxed	1891.2787418921064
3734. they lay	on his lap palms up stiffly motionless the tapered fingers a little	thick at the joints	2349.080225550416
3735. altogether he had since the seizure the appearance	of a boy who overindulged in food and took no exercise	1729.220133421608
3736. he looked	lazy spoiled a little querulous	141.19341501700592
3737. rachel had little to say	14.783956782517075
3738. she greeted her husband's colleagues with smiling politeness offering	nothing	558.4552809447288
3739. mr mckinley for all his sprawling and his easy familiarity	was completely alert to his son eyes always on the still	face jumping to anticipate scotty's desires	2864.9082354145617
3740. it was a strained silent	lunch	65.25364293051997
3741. rachel said i'd better get him to bed	166.03130400913975
3742. the doctors had suggested scotty remain most of every afternoon	in bed until he was stronger	1861.31792991465
3743. since mr mckinley had to	give a lecture rachel and scotty drove home alone in the plymouth	1424.4850955934112
3744. they did not speak much	22.053336983848887
3745. scotty gazed out at ugly gray slums and	said softly look at those stupid kids	1096.482424684312
3746. it was a negro section	of peeling row houses store-front churches and ragged children	1410.795534363493
3747. rachel	had to bend toward scotty and ask him to repeat	502.5948125915008
3748. and then: there are lots of kids around here	391.0469561232073
3749. scotty looked at the children his mouth slightly opened his eyes	dull	643.2367532995977
3750. he felt tired and full and calm	140.8296989026276
3751. the	days seemed short perhaps because his routine was each day almost	the same	939.2389646495242
3752. he rose late and went down in his bathrobe and slippers to	have breakfast either alone or with rachel	2597.359564153599
3753. virginia treated him with	attention and tried to tempt his appetite with special food: biscuits	cookies candies- the result of devoted hours in the tiled kitchen	2730.4446740344124
3754. she would hover over him and looking like her brother anxiously	watch the progress of scotty's fork or spoon	2586.9483818148915
3755. you don't	eat enough honey	14.770521660809374

3762. he was able now to sit for hours	in a chair in the living room and stare out at the bleak yard without	moving	3689.3642793219187
3763. his hands lay loosely yet stiffly- they were like wax hands:	almost lifelike not quite- folded in his lap; his mouth hung	slightly open	2448.3296716151353
3764. when he was asked a question or addressed in such a way	that some response was inescapable he would answer; if as often	happened he had to repeat because he had spoken too softly he would	repeat his words in the same way without emphasis or impatience only	a little louder	7543.034168209435
3765. he had not mentioned kate	14.765686333522703
3766. he had not even	thought about her much except once or twice at night in bed when his	slowly ranging thoughts would abruptly almost accidentally encounter	her	4284.317844376678
3767. at these times he felt a kind of pain in his upper chest but	it was an objective pain in no way different from others in intensity	and not different in kind; it was like the bandaged wound on the back	of his head which occasionally throbbed; it was merely another part	of his weakness	5228.28781191063
3768. he was calm drugged and lazy	65.24261555662703
3769. rachel mentioned kate	0.20041515
3770. she said i notice the girl from	across the street hasn't bothered to phone or visit	1900.7714135690117
3771. scotty	said that's all right	14.799367857029358
3772. he thought	about it briefly then deliberately turned the talk to something else	1182.2906261137882
3773. once sitting at the front window in his parents' room he	saw kate come out of her house	1569.5423541086836
3774. they were	far off and looked tiny	141.2229255946881
3775. the heavy branches in his front yard would hide	and then reveal them	783.1011979586766

3777. he thought he saw- it	awakened and for a moment interested him- that elizabeth held a	leash in her hand and that a round fuzzy puppy was on the end of the leash	3550.6871518441685

3847. where their sharp edges seemed restless as sea waves thrusting themselves	upward in angry motion papa-san sat glacier-like his smooth solidity	his very immobility defying all the turmoil about him	3225.2597860386477
3848. our	objective the colonel had said that day of the briefing is papa-san	1181.5663004429787
3849. there the objective sat brooding over all	93.67207273033196
3850. gouge burn	blast insult it as they would could anyone really take papa-san	1181.7167576114775
3851. between the ponderous hulk and himself in the valley over which	papa-san reigned men had hidden high explosives booby traps and	mines	2184.325718172715
3852. the raped valley was a pregnant womb awaiting abortion	389.22746114546464
3853. on	the forward slope in front of his own post stretched two rows of barbed	wire	1251.2391468468677

3855. closer still regular barricades of barbed	wire hung on timber supports	496.47410465265705
3856. was it all vain labor	22.16834463313299

3858. smiling at his quixotic	thoughts warren turned back from the opening and lit a cigarette before	sitting down	2381.89060308205

3873. he had come because he could not live out	his life feeling that he had been a coward	1572.2488114794442
3874. there were ten men	on the patrol which sergeant prevot led out that next night	1637.8282875998411
3875. the	beaming rok was carrying a thirty-caliber machine gun; another	man lugged the tripod and a box of ammunition	1734.1943837883687
3876. warren and white each	carried in addition to their own weapons and ammo a box of ammo for	the rok's machine gun	3261.6188905158033
3877. others carried extra clips for the	browning automatic rifle which was in the hands of a little mexican	named martinez	1879.5798553881305
3878. prevot had briefed the two new men that afternoon	389.8894986707979
