3885. that still holds	0.20041515
3886. we bring back all dead and wounded	141.00135214802276
3887. at 2130 hours they had passed through the barbed wire at the	point of departure	1090.7718577143346
3888. then began the journey through their own mine fields	391.7243744976438
3889. ours were kinder than theirs some said	93.64187175256298
3890. they set bouncing	betties to jump and explode at testicle level while we more mercifully	had them go off at the head	3286.930776524439
3891. the crude	wooden boxes of the enemy our nicely turned gray metal disks	791.4408110893794
3892. but	theirs defied the detectors	22.397426898254196
3893. a foot misplaced a leg missing	43.95497399288234
3894. all sizes: big ones some wired to set off a whole field	little ones hand grenade size	2125.088116496354
3895. booby traps to fill the head with	chunks of metal	375.96001984373777
3896. warren tried to shake off the jumble of his fears by	looking at the sky	1650.2582312134055
3897. prevot had said that the searchlights	would be bounced off the clouds at 2230 hours which gives us time	to get settled in position	2458.4225237176483
3898. because they were new men and	to be sure that they didn't get lost prevot had placed warren	and white in the center of the patrol as it filed out	4799.611371725661
3899. his eyes now	fixed on white's solid figure warren could hear behind him the tread	of another	1421.335923157342
3900. he could also hear the stream which he had seen from	his position	1192.4245237092944
3901. they were going to follow it for part of their journey	494.483336766749
3902. it's safe prevot had said and it provides cover for our	noise	963.7883322688015
3903. soon they were picking their way along the edge of	the stream which glowed in the night	1419.84486483916
3904. on their right rose the embankment	covered with brush and trees	754.3126019439957
3905. if a branch extended out too far	each man held it back for the next and if they met a low overhang each	warned the other	2727.194426108563
3906. thus stealthily they advanced upstream; then	they turned to the right climbed the embankment and walked into the	valley again	2830.2117792920017
3907. there was no cover here only grass sighing against	pant-legs	376.51882804917864
3908. and with each sigh like a whip in the hand of an expert	the grass stripped something from warren	2599.918970680346
3909. the gentle whir of each footstep	left him more naked than before until he felt his unprotected	flesh tremble chilled by each new sound	2455.813119528045
3910. the shapes of the men ahead	of him lacked solidity as if the whip had stripped them of their very	flesh	3059.42348940744
3911. the dark forms moved like mourners on some nocturnal pilgrimage	their dirge unsung for want of vocal chords	1565.380824352674
3912. the warped broken	trees in the valley assumed wraith-like shapes	559.9038528583849
3913. clumps of brush that	they passed were so many enchained demons straining	in anger to tear and gnaw on his bones	2020.0442622183655
3914. looming over all papa-san	leered down at him threatening a hundred hidden malevolencies	1185.2559020339888
3915. off in	the distance a searchlight flashed on its beam slashing the sky	792.5220646017814
3916. the	sharp ray was absorbed by a cloud then reflected to the earth in a	softer diffused radiance	2363.2196695920366
3917. somewhere over there another patrol had need	of light	261.51154925887835
3918. warren thought of all the men out that night who like	himself had left their protective ridge and- fear working at their	guts- picked their way into the area beyond	4840.812773988421
3919. from the east to the west	coast of the korean peninsula was a strip of land in which fear-filled	men were at that same moment furtively crawling through the night	sitting in sweaty anticipation of any movement or sound or shouting	amidst confused rifle flashes and muzzle blasts	4825.585535796061
3920. white's arm went	up and warren raised his own	392.2889404416791
3921. prevot	came up take that spot over there he whispered pointing to	a small clump of blackness	1406.7498524077228
3922. give me your machine gun ammo	65.37120046783483
3923. warren	handed him the metal box and prevot quietly disappeared down the	line	789.8842088642705
3924. lying in the grass behind the brush clump warren looked	about	753.7228080708749
3925. the others likewise had hidden themselves in the grass and	the brush	645.258728610303
3926. over his shoulder he could see prevot with the machine gun	crew	968.0540342762272
3927. even at this short distance they were only vague shapes setting	up the machine gun on a small knoll so that it could fire above the	heads of the rest of the patrol	3550.152571438731
3928. warren eased his rifle's	safety off and gently slowly sneaked another clip of ammunition from	one of the cloth bandoleers that marked the upper part of his body with	an x	5005.376995724207
3929. this he placed within quick reach	43.77312158312019
3930. the walk and his fears	had served to overheat him and his sweaty armpits cooled at the touch	of the night air	3291.7686230830177
3931. although the armored vest fitted the upper part	of his body snugly he felt no security	1254.7140452630308
3932. figures seemed to crouch in	the surrounding dark; in the distance he saw a band of men who seemed	to advance and retreat even as he watched	4287.321756462714
3933. certain this menace was	only imaginary he yet stared in fascinated horror his hand sticky against	the stock of his weapon	2031.874503468763
3934. he was aware of insistent inner beatings	as if prisoners within sought release from his rigid body	2118.7920159159667
3935. above the glowing ivory baton of their searchlight pointed at the clouds	diluting the valley's dark to a pallid light	1890.9231748091795
3936. then the figures	which held his attention became a group of shattered trees standing	like the grotesques of a medieval damnation scene	3251.5294439726044
3937. even so he could	not ease the tension of his body; the rough surface of the earth itself	seemed to resist every attempt on his part to relax	2982.3839624743646
3938. sensing the	unseen presence of the other men in the patrol he felt mutely united	to these nine near-strangers sharing this pinpoint of being with him	4095.8731411606727
3939. he sensed something precious in the perilous moment something akin	to the knowledge gained on his bicycle trip through the french countryside	a knowledge imprisoned in speechlessness	2869.690270862164
3940. in france	he had puzzled the meaning of the great stone monuments men had thrown	up to the sky and always as he wandered he felt a stranger to their	exultation	5041.737384906151
3941. they were poems in a strange language of which he could	barely touch a meaning- enough to make his being ache with the desire	for the fullness he sensed there	3218.925707078261
3942. brittany that stone-gray mystery	through which he traveled for thirty days sleeping in the barns of	farmers or alongside roads had worked some subtle change in him he	knew and it was in brittany that he had met pierre	6180.472442385921
3943. pierre	had no hands; they had been severed at the wrists	502.39863558507193
3944. with leather cups	fitted in his handlebars he steered his bicycle	747.5582653623972
3945. he and warren had	traveled together for four days	261.135326981528
3946. they visited the shipyards at brest	and pierre had to sign the register vouching for the integrity of	the visiting foreigner	3049.4359288380974
3947. he took the pen in his stumps and began to	write	502.97334588087386
3948. wait! wait! cried the guard who ran from the	hut to shout to other men standing about outside	2364.09254320928
3949. they crowded the small	room and peered over one another's shoulders to watch the handless	man write his name in the book	2193.5998520432045
3950. c'est merveilleux	0.30041514999999996
3951. and then the questions came eager interested questions and many compliments	on his having overcome his infirmity	1418.6308998392199
3952. doesn't it	ever bother you warren had asked to have people always asking	you about your hands	2126.3304706020263
3953. oh the french are a very curious	people pierre had laughed	509.3622669719551
3954. they are also honest seekers	after truth	141.47141095273443
3955. now the english are painfully silent about my missing	hands	376.6195516349836
3956. they refuse to mention or to notice that they are not there	954.216085626042
3957. the	americans like yourself take the fact for granted try to be helpful	but don't ask questions	1406.0389565573278
3958. i'm used to all three but i think	the french have the healthiest attitude	1411.3699244610455
3959. that was the day	that pierre had told warren about the abbey of solesmes	942.7674350046843
3960. you	are looking tired and there you can rest	392.1661770714669
3961. it will be good for you	43.59617795933257
3962. i think too he said his dark eyes mischievous that you will	find there some clue to the secret of the cathedrals about which you	have spoken	4288.417342699418
3963. within two weeks warren was ringing the bell	at the abbey gate	645.6139295539813
3964. the monk who opened the door immediately calmed his	worries about his reception: i speak english the old man	said but i do not hear it very well	4464.549184807709
3965. he smiled and stuck a large	finger with white hairs sprouting on it into his ear as though that	might help	2030.4959875593352
3966. smiling at warren's protestations the old monk took	his grip from him and led him down a corridor to a small parlor	3289.6666094884204
3967. will	you please wait in here	43.59879657399479
3968. mickie sat over his second whisky-on-the-rocks in a little bar next	to the funeral parlor on pennsylvania avenue	2351.3972029858974
3969. al's little cafe	was small dark narrow and filled with the mingled scent of beer	tobacco smoke and italian cooking	1878.2692711243246
3970. hanging over the bar was an oil	painting of a nude al had accepted from a student at the corcoran	gallery who needed to eat and drink and was broke	4852.827150992622
3971. the nude was small	and black-haired and elfin and was called eloise	637.2463596671371
3972. this	was one place where moonan could go for a drink in a back booth without	anyone noticing him or at least coming up and hanging around and	wanting to know all the low-down	5513.038844268548
3973. the other patrons were taxi drivers	and art students and small shopkeepers	638.0449585502478
3974. the reporters had not yet	discovered that this was his hideaway	743.5880513192958
3975. his friend jane was with	him	43.48837530367403
3976. she was wise enough to realize a man could be good company even	if he did weigh too much and didn't own the mint	3689.2088859790974
3977. she was the widow	of a writer who had died in an airplane crash and mickie had found	her a job as head of the historical section of the treasury	3225.8213632228453
3978. this	meant sorting out press clippings and the like	392.4261947238341
3979. jane sat receptive	and interested	14.87835937743508
3980. mickie had a pleasant glow as he said you see	both of them i mean the president and jeff lawrence are romantics	3279.3824369155946
3981. a romantic is one who thinks the world is divinely inspired and	all he has to do is find the right key and then divine justice and	altruism will appear	3238.820906683168
3982. it's like focusing a camera; the distant ship	isn't there until you get the focus	1650.2005667772087
3983. you know what i'm talking	about	43.59653991241649
3984. i'm sure all girls feel this way about men until they live	with them	1406.1525663272657
3985. but when it comes to war the colonel knows what	it is and jeff doesn't	1094.8958092113921
3986. mr christiansen knows that a soldier	will get the distinguished service medal for conduct that would land	him in prison for life or the electric chair as a civilian	4663.383018063614
3987. he had	a mean unbroken sheer bastard in his outfit and someone invented the	name trig for him	1572.5488337735064
3988. that's to say he was trigger happy	140.46253577735743
3989. he'd	shoot at anything if it was the rear end of a horse or his own sentry	1421.0139943351849
3990. he was a wiry inscrutable silent country boy from the red clay of	rural alabama and he spoke with the broad drawl that others normally	make fun of	4477.743066952077
3991. but not in front of trig	43.23441172899141
3992. i heard of some that tried	it back in the states and he'd knock them clear across the room	2580.097895862365
3993. there'd been a pretty bad incident back at the marine base	504.11637248471516
3994. a new	york kid a refugee from one of the harlem gangs made fun of trig's	accent and drew a knife	3062.0827392528995
3995. before the fight was over the harlem	boy had a concussion and trig was cut up badly	1417.4478167065258
3996. they caught trig	stealing liquor from the officers' mess and he got a couple of girls	in trouble	2375.406643434782
3997. the fear of punishment just didn't bother him	167.11198340846644
3998. it was left out of him at birth	248.65470213913414
3999. this is why he made such	a magnificent soldier	262.3808652279844
4000. he wasn't troubled with the ordinary rank-and-file	fear that overcomes and paralyzes and sends individual soldiers	and whole companies under fire running in panic	3684.781408877624
4001. it just didn't	occur to trig that anything serious would happen to him	782.9153396900942
4002. do you get	the picture of the kind of fellow he was	954.949992897716
4003. jane nodded	with a pleasant smile	43.86464986767821
4004. there was a sniper's nest	in a mountain cave and it was picking off our men with devilish accuracy	2591.0827601301203
4005. the colonel ordered that it be wiped out and i suggested	'you ask for volunteers and promise each man on the patrol a quart	of whisky ten dollars and a week-end pass to davao'	3647.6117426994724
4006. trig was	one of the five volunteers	140.78681466004466
4007. the patrol snaked around in back of the cave	approached it from above and dropped in suddenly with wild howls	1871.4050642197133
4008. you could hear them from our outpost	140.40279727416322
4009. there was a lot of shooting	42.937204616875476
4010. we knew the enemy was subdued because a flare was fired as the signal	1420.1382307337485
4011. two of our men were killed a third was wounded	373.6139182490398
4012. trig and a very black colored boy from detroit had killed or put	out of action ten guerrillas by grenades and hand-to-hand fighting	3487.3079647989384
4013. when	we got there trig and the negro were quarreling over possession	of a gold crucifix around the neck of a wounded filipino	2319.547216415603
4014. the colored	boy had it and trig lunged at him with a knife and said 'give	that to me you black bastard	3263.453881923675
4015. we don't 'low nigras to walk on	the same sidewalk with white men where i come from'	1420.1513219114254
4016. the	negro got a bad slice on his chest from the knife wound	1188.9863254449149
4017. what	did the colonel do about the men	168.41309089836233
4018. jane asked in her placid	interested way	140.15958888396125
4019. he recommended both of	them for the dsm and the detroit fellow for the purple heart	too for a combat-inflicted wound	2028.5115353909223
4020. so you see mr christiansen	knows what it's all about	560.3509906679659
4021. when he was in	the war he was in law or supplies or something like that and an	old buddy of his told me he would come down on sundays to the pentagon	and read the citations for medals- just like the one we sent in for	trig- and go away with a real glow	5274.9281551172535
4022. these were heroes nine feet	tall to him	249.4168238850496
4023. jefferson lawrence was alone at the small perfectly	appointed table by the window looking out over the river	1571.6523336754683
4024. he	had dinner and sat there over his coffee watching the winding pattern	of traffic as it crossed the bridge and spread out like a serpent with	two heads	4640.400309800616
4025. open beside him was mrs dalloway	43.64879779205496
4026. he thought how	this dainty fragile older woman threading her way through the streets	of westminster on a day in june enjoying the flowers in the shops	the greetings from old friends but never really drawing a deep passionate	breath was so like himself	6812.1169884508245
4027. he and mrs dalloway too	had never permitted themselves the luxury of joys that dug into the	bone marrow of the spirit	2194.876026900013
4028. he had not because he was both poor	and ambitious	562.4938814765012
4029. poverty imposes a kind of chastity on the ambitious	261.3406893735895
4030. they cannot stop to grasp and embrace and sit in the back seat of cars	along a dark country lane	2830.2460847818215
4031. no they must look the other way and climb	one more painful step up the ladder	1267.2559080440847
4032. he made the decision with his	eyes open or so he thought	963.742335091911
4033. at any cost he must leave the dreary pennsylvania	mining town where his father was a pharmacist	1415.737698309563
4034. and so he	had so he had	142.47286084565607
4035. at state college he had no time to walk among the	violets on the water's edge	1261.3041033899888
4036. from his room he could look out in springtime	and see the couples hand in hand walking slowly deliciously	across the campus and he could smell the sweet vernal winds	4829.3148566369855
4037. he was not unmoved	2.9419253025379386
4038. he had to teach himself patiently that	these traps were not for him	1179.1608724170496
4039. he must mentally pull the blinds and	close the window so that all that existed was in the books before him	2036.2532695358957
4040. at law school the same	22.284262123929846
4041. more of this stamping down of human emotion	as a young lawyer in new york	1101.5689566744616
4042. by the time he was prosperous enough-	his goals were high- he was bald and afraid of women	2354.4304814428506
4043. the only	one who would have him was his cripple the strange unhappy woman	who became his wife	1564.433533333162
4044. perhaps it was right; perhaps it was just	249.380099187195
4045. he	had dared to defy nature to turn his back to the lorelei and he was	punished	1414.1257977018552
4046. like mrs dalloway with her regrets about peter walsh	he had his moments of melancholy over a youth too well spent	3058.2111044693957
4047. if	he had had a son he would tell him gather ye rosebuds while ye	may h this same flower that smiles today tomorrow will be dying	2850.373681998732
4048. but then his son could afford it	140.4258850428789
4049. lawrence was waiting for bill	boxell	43.36115462932496
4050. the vice president had called and asked if he could see	the secretary at his home	1891.314936465726
4051. he said the matter was urgent	43.814041390667136
4052. the secretary	was uneasy about the visit	141.81943543490408
4053. he did not like boxell	14.954189908890797
4054. he suspected	something underhanded and furtive about him	253.2605618776664
4055. lawrence could not	put his finger on it precisely and this worried him	787.8885265823026
4056. when you disliked	or distrusted a man you should have a reason	966.8016639010559
4057. human nature was	not a piece of meat you could tell was bad by its smell	1249.2824784034933
4058. lawrence stared	a minute at the lighted ribbon of traffic hoping that a clue to his	dislike of the vice president would appear	3474.6189778590806
4059. therefore	he decided he was unfair to the young man and should make an effort	to understand and sympathize with his point of view	2467.7008455474615
4060. a half	hour later the vice president arrived	249.94944357574872
4061. he looked very carefully at	every piece of furnishing as though hoping to store this information	carefully in his mind	1886.0200530514044
4062. he observed the florentine vase in the hall	the renoir painting in the library as well as the long shelves of well-bound	volumes; the pattern of the oriental rug the delicate cut-glass	chandelier	5324.520873389428
4063. he said to the secretary i understand	you came from a little pennsylvania town near wilkes-barre	1265.097863256932
4064. how did	you find out about this	139.8084380321614
4065. he waved his arm around at the furnishings	167.93123574385885
4066. it was not a discourteous question lawrence decided	250.09833850819004
4067. this young man had so little time to learn he had to be curious;	he had to find out	1730.4722703491036
4068. the secretary did not tell him at what cost at	what loneliness he learned these things	1881.3613490406733
4069. he merely said any good	decorator these days can make you a tasteful home	946.7689611897638
4070. the vice	president said if you hear of any names that would fix me cheap	in return for advertising they decorated the vice president's	home let me know	4451.372985510955
4071. i can do business with that kind	93.40939416405237
4072. again	lawrence thought a little sadly these were the fees of poverty and	ambition	1417.3090667806014
4073. boxell did not have the chance to grow up graciously	373.7504977199323
4074. he	had to acquire everything he was going to get in four years	1177.2658890143712
4075. they	had brandy in the library	43.35051012967843
4076. boxell looked at lawrence with a searching	glance the kind that a prosecuting attorney would give a man on trial	2831.713845197356
4077. what are your weaknesses	2.948539694277348
4078. where will you break	4.396286820867516
4079. how best to	destroy your peace	43.47482507938982
4080. the vice president said with a slight	bluster there isn't anyone who loves the president more than	i do	2607.308356338061
4081. old chris is my ideal	14.82786549130957
4082. at the same time you have to face facts	and realize that a man who's been in the marine corps all his	life doesn't understand much about politics	4469.45507689888
4083. what does a monk know	about sex	94.97440836715906
4084. lawrence listened with the practiced deceptive	calm of the lawyer but his face was in the shadow	2124.150935943869
4085. so	we have to protect the old man for his own good	642.6820450644166
4086. you see what i mean	22.250996032930217
4087. congress is full of politicians and if you want to get along with	them you have to be politic	1719.0622005818102
4088. this is why i say we just can't go ahead	and disarm the germans and pull down our own defenses	2832.962513397959
4089. let me tell	you what happened to me today	259.9763307114498
4090. a fellow came up to me a senator	i don't have to tell you his name and he told me 'i love the	president like a brother but god damn it he's crucifying me	5479.487532807927
4091. i've	got a quarter of a million germans in my state and those krautheads	tune in on father werther every night and if he tells them to	go out and piss in the public square that's what they do	4141.614706952708
4092. he's	telling them now to write letters to their congressmen opposing the disarmament	of germany'	1638.1451351816972
4093. and another one comes to me and he says 'look	here there's a mill in my state employs five thousand people	making uniforms for the navy	2733.260888206335
4094. the bishop looked at him coldly and said take it or leave it!	literally there was nothing else to do	2800.878231242121
4095. he was caught in	a machine	43.78326066868041
4096. but sojourner was not easily excited or upset and said quite	calmly: let's go and see what it's like	2597.831230405633
4097. annisberg	was about seventy-five miles west of birmingham near the georgia	border and on the tallahoosa river a small and dirty stream	2184.041369915219
4098. the	city was a center of manufacture especially in textiles and also	because of the beauty of some of its surroundings a residence for many	owners of the great industries in north alabama	5307.935020763913
4099. but it had as was	usual in southern cities of this sort a black bottom a low region	near the river where the negroes lived- servants and laborers huddled	together in a region with no sewage save the river where streets	and sidewalks were neglected and where there was much poverty and crime	5134.288296662242
4100. wilson came by train from birmingham and looked the city	over; the rather pleasant white city was on the hill where the chief	stores were	3905.3277218654534
4101. beyond were industries and factories	14.868011142981436
4102. then they went down	to black bottom	140.57907608090633
4103. in the midst of this crowded region was the allen	african methodist episcopal church	939.9755768034578
4104. it was an old and dirty	wooden structure sadly in need of repair	1180.283818626858
4105. but it was a landmark	14.869789657694117
4106. it	had been there 50 years or more and everybody in town black and white	knew of it	2355.390679962417
4107. it had just suffered a calamity the final crisis in a	long series of calamities	1100.6195925223547
4108. for the old preacher who had been there twenty-five	years was dead and the city mourned him	2125.3926527760514
4109. he was a	loud-voiced man once vigorous but for many years now declining in strength	and ability	1415.7147721291685
4110. he was stern and overbearing with his flock but obsequious	and conciliatory with the whites especially the rich who partly	supported the church	3494.71941228821
4111. the deacon board headed by a black man	named carlson had practically taken over as the pastor grew old and	had its way with the support of the amen corner	3234.989358660677
4112. the characteristic	thing about this church was its amen corner and the weekly religious	orgy	1648.713596731827
4113. a knot of old worshippers chiefly women listened weekly to a	sermon	646.844043195151
4114. it began invariably in low tones almost conversational and	then gradually worked up to high shrill appeals to god and man	3030.70902363553
4115. and	then the amen corner took hold re-enacting a form of group participation	in worship that stemmed from years before the greek chorus spreading	down through the african forest overseas to the west indies	and then here in alabama	4144.818693397458
4116. with shout and slow dance with tears and	song with scream and contortion the corner group was beset by hysteria	and shivering wailing shouting possession of something that seemed	like an alien and outside force	5640.218613297927
4117. it spread to most of the audience	and was often viewed by visiting whites who snickered behind handkerchief	and afterward discussed negro religion	2312.045026557506
4118. it sometimes ended in	death-like trances with many lying exhausted and panting on chair and	floor	1882.9811411661801
4119. to most of those who composed the amen corner it was a magnificent	and beautiful experience something for which they lived from week	to week	2591.3703896218462
4120. it was often re-enacted in less wild form at the wednesday	night prayer meeting	1413.989241025514
4121. wilson on his first sunday witnessed	this with something like disgust	502.5161098283482
4122. he had preached a short sermon	trying to talk man-to-man to the audience to tell them who he was what	he had done in macon and birmingham and what he proposed to do here	5477.554148887446
4123. he sympathized with them on the loss of their old pastor	502.94598380293866
4124. but then	at mention of that name the amen corner broke loose	959.0106829229251
4125. he had no	chance to say another word	165.98835174597053
4126. at the very end when the audience was silent	and breathless a collection was taken and then slowly everyone	filed out	3027.640632165544
4127. the audience did not think much of the new pastor and what	the new pastor thought of the audience he did not dare at the time to	say	2970.9915832491074
4128. during the next weeks he looked over the situation	392.63822304915266
4129. first	of all there was the parsonage an utterly impossible place for civilized	people to live in originally poorly conceived apparently not	repaired for years with no plumbing or sewage with rat-holes and rot	3659.8485356448728
4130. it was arranged that he would board in the home of one of the old	members of the church a woman named catt who as wilson afterward found	was briefly referred to as the cat because of her sharp tongue	and fierce initiative	6686.59823825011
4131. ann catt was a lonely devoted soul	never married conducting a spotless home and devoted to her church but	a perpetual dissenter and born critic	2600.9826281196883
4132. she soared over the new pastor	like an avenging angel lest he stray from the path and not know all	the truth and gossip of which she was chief repository	4858.428477345107
4133. then	wilson looked over the church and studied its condition	377.0783660644542
4134. the salary	of the pastor had for years been $500 annually and even this was in arrears	2125.2600683700134
4135. wilson made up his mind that he must receive at least $2500	but when he mentioned this to the deacons they said nothing	2314.560954609101
4136. the church	itself must be repaired	64.68438119499095
4137. it was dirty and neglected	14.963097712553093
4138. it really	ought to be rebuilt and he determined to go up and talk to the city banks	about this	2821.2235704640243
4139. meanwhile the city itself should be talked to	166.76652466620496
4140. the	streets in the colored section were dirty	249.30107089229585
4141. there was typhoid and malaria	14.857648375212396
4142. the children had nowhere to go and no place to play not even sidewalks	1418.2728454415287
4143. the school was small dark and ill-equipped	93.70828176637158
4144. the teacher was	a pliant fool	65.52856587485621
4145. there were two liquor saloons not very far from the	church one white that is conducted for white people with a side entrance	for negroes; the other exclusively negro	3117.728310869771
4146. undoubtedly there	was a good deal of gambling in both	560.5629935969998
4147. on the other side of the	church	was a quiet well-kept house with shutters and recently painted	1424.8678120415852
4148. it was called kent house	22.21711825909112
4149. the deacon of the	church carlson was its janitor	260.9586316663315
4150. one of the leading members of the	amen corner was cook; there were two or three colored maids employed	there	2795.103594612636
4151. wilson was told that it was a sort of hotel for white people	which seemed to him rather queer	1717.0945559077252
4152. why should a white hotel be set	down in the center of black bottom	1412.56203546603
4153. but nevertheless it looked respectable	14.933306545908627
4154. he was glad to have it there	139.20816012011443
4155. the rest of black	bottom was a rabbit warren of homes in every condition of neglect disrepair	and careful upkeep	1874.4390432720404
4156. dives carefully repaired huts and nicely	painted and ornamented cottages were jumbled together cheek by jowl	with little distinction	2586.65319953487
4157. the best could not escape from the worst and	the worst nestled cosily beside the better	1264.2452044629765
4158. the yards front and back	were narrow; some were trash dumps some had flower gardens	1644.763419883679
4159. behind	were privies for there was no sewage system	259.7759036433243
4160. after looking	about a bit wilson discovered beyond black bottom across the river	and far removed from the white city a considerable tract of land	and it occurred to him that the church and the better negro homes might	gradually be moved to this plot	6908.035343043426
4161. he talked about it to the presiding	elder	167.06030496318675
4162. the presiding elder looked him over rather carefully	252.25451091060944
4163. he was not sure what kind of a man he had in hand	782.7122204696867
4164. but there was one	thing that he had to stress and that was that the contribution to the	general church expenses the dollar money had been seriously falling	behind in this church and that must be looked after immediately	6213.872460209538
4165. in	fact he intimated clearly that that was the reason that wilson had	been sent here- to make a larger contribution of dollar money	2451.048658591322
4166. wilson stressed the fact that clear as this was they must have a	better church a more business-like conduct of the church organization	and an effort to get this religious center out of its rut of wild worship	into a modern church organization	6677.798052396414
4167. he emphasized to the presiding	elder the plan of giving up the old church and moving across the	river	1734.919160550847
4168. the presiding elder was sure that that would be impossible	557.3981739852413
4169. but he told wilson to go ahead and try	260.7931608332169
4170. it did seem impossible	4.428939018104305
4171. the bank which held the mortgage on the	old church declared that the interest was considerably in arrears and	the real estate people said flatly that the land across the river was	being held for an eventual development for white working people who	were coming in and that none would be sold to colored folk	5244.427660617629
4172. when it	was proposed to rebuild the church wilson found that the terms for	a new mortgage were very high	2819.004218962202
4173. he was sure that he could do better if	he went to atlanta to get the deal financed	1577.1062257644444
4174. but when this proposal	was made to his deacon board he met unanimous opposition	1408.7561675272032
4175. the	church certainly would not be removed	93.66106425156629
4176. the very proposition was sacrilege	22.1874889909711
4177. it had been here fifty years	43.886279081435276
4178. it was going to stay forever	64.68811566154203
4179. it was hardly possible to get any argument on the subject	500.67751332165847
4180. as for	rebuilding well that might be looked into but there was no hurry no	hurry at all	2348.3334851887525
4181. wilson again went downtown to a different banker	an intelligent young white man who seemed rather sympathetic but	he shook his head	2164.945303033398
4182. reverend he said i think you don't	quite understand the situation here	965.7957187265526
4183. don't you see the amount	of money that has been invested by whites around that church	1254.8342081780097
4184. tenements	stores saloons some gambling i hope not too much	561.1090797256196
4185. the colored	people are getting employment at kent house and other places and	they are near their places of employment	1875.271654449471
4186. when a city has arranged	things like this you cannot easily change them	1187.7501068997462
4187. now if i were you i	would just plan to repair the old church so it would last for five or	ten years	2344.432089958951
4188. by that time perhaps something better can be done	391.9185639528956
4189. then wilson asked what about this kent house which you	mention	501.02806764305933
4190. i don't understand why a white hotel should be down here	757.294747976169
4191. the young banker looked at him with a certain surprise and	then he said flatly: i'm afraid i can't tell you anything	in particular about kent house	2870.2908043144967
4192. you'll have to find out about it	on your own	559.143433294076
4193. hope to see you again	14.910901904999895
4194. and he dismissed the colored	pastor	65.62734595772912
4195. it was next day that sojourner came and sat beside	him and took his hand	1099.1554387976623
4196. she said my dear do you know what kent	house is	755.5948388625719
4197. no said wilson i don't	14.802631964138005
4198. i was	just asking about it	65.49046872789472
4199. what is it	0.20041515
4200. it's a house of prostitution	for white men with white girls as inmates	1184.8926777432494
4201. they hire	a good deal of local labor including two members of our trustee board	1090.2685884994212
4202. they buy some supplies from our colored grocers and they are patronized	by some of the best white gentlemen in town	3063.163013618654
4203. my dear you must be mistaken	43.49900348750211
4204. talk to	mrs catt she said	65.28609690362185
4205. and after wilson had talked to mrs	catt and to others he was absolutely amazed	1099.6104628361388
4206. this of course was	the sort of thing that used to take place in southern cities- putting	white houses of prostitution with colored girls in colored neighborhoods	and carrying them on openly	5157.973929777489
4207. but it had largely disappeared on	account of protest by the whites and through growing resentment on the	part of the negroes as they became more educated and got better wages	3340.545722201006
4208. but this situation of kent house was more subtle	388.7034991626668
4209. the wages	involved were larger and more regular	165.89048410800862
4210. the inmates were white and	from out of town avoiding local friction	958.9048772937655
4211. the backing from the white	town was greater and there was little publicity	785.6723991671543
4212. good wages patronage	and subscription of various kinds stopped open protest from negroes	1180.2601545568978
4213. and yet wilson knew that this place must go or he must go	791.8909763708687
4214. and	for him to leave this job now without accomplishing anything would mean	practically the end of his career in the methodist church if not	in all churches	4469.527093807533
4215. payne dismounted in madison place and handed the reins to herold	508.65948970541666
4216. there was a fog which increased the darkness of the night	760.0816002373946
4217. two gas	lamps were no more than a misleading glow	374.2456968365624
4218. he might have been anywhere	or nowhere	140.91611702010968
4219. the pretence was that he was delivering a prescription	from dr verdi	642.5697491902595
4220. secretary of state seward was a sick man	251.0010253327263
4221. the idea had come from herold who had once been a chemist's clerk	792.571030970634
4222. the sick were always receiving medicines	65.22909905776417
4223. no one would question	such an errand	93.90429881168906
4224. the bottle was filled up with flour	140.32131955667538
4225. before payne	loomed the old clubhouse seward's home where key had once	been killed	946.588218663248
4226. now it would have another death	64.76618386971205
4227. from the outside it	was an ordinary enough house of the gentry	637.4838833711344
4228. he clomped heavily up the	stoop and rang the bell	565.988795297169
4229. like the bell at mass the doorbell was pitched	too high	501.97615142106287
4230. it was still good friday after all	140.86675027803315
4231. a nigger	boy opened the door	43.283501540828354
4232. payne did not notice him	22.306962832459117
4233. he was thinking chiefly	of cap	43.52384748819204
4234. if their schedules were to synchronize there was no point	in wasting time	1171.7722221363924
4235. he pushed his way inside	14.711168319520038
4236. for a moment	the hall confused him	142.06709359806248
4237. this was the largest house he had ever been in	almost the largest building except for a hotel	1572.8445105841754
4238. he had no idea where	seward's room would be	392.7222370537355
4239. in the half darkness the banisters gleamed	and the hall seemed enormous	646.0835509676873
4240. above him somewhere were the bedrooms	65.25630770022102
4241. seward would be up there	14.748048281420159
4242. he explained his errand but without	bothering much to make it plausible for he felt something well	up in him which was the reason why he had fled the army	4807.284128996746
4243. he did not	really want to kill but as in the sexual act there was a moment when	the impulse took over and could not be downed even while you watched	yourself giving way to it	3855.670114488365
4244. he was no longer worried	22.167307505625338
4245. everything would	be all right	14.799367857029358
4246. he knew that in this mood he could not be stopped	748.1724282631685
4247. still the sensation always surprised him	43.41478489528401
4248. it was a thrill he	felt no part in	390.25746179415466
4249. he could only watch with a sort of gentle dismay while	his body did these quick appalling and efficient things	1884.9039365022848
4250. he	brushed by the idiotic boy and lumbered heavily up the stairs	964.2472558402163
4251. they	were carpeted but made for pumps and congress gaiters not the great	clodhoppers he wore	1269.7569640760046
4252. the sound of his footsteps was like a muffled	drum	561.0812945381189
4253. at the top of the stairs he ran into somebody standing there	angrily in a dressing gown	1417.7771709110752
4254. he stopped and whispered his errand	65.00041631790323
4255. young frederick seward held out his hand	92.4046563776414
4256. panting a little payne	shook his head	140.7127373212693
4257. dr verdi had told him to deliver his package in	person	497.7242405290002
4258. frederick seward said his father was sleeping and then	went through a pantomime at his father's door to prove the statement	3032.407710468723
4259. i will go	0.20041515
4260. he smiled	but now that he knew where the elder seward was he did not intend	to go	2355.3265464238784
4261. he pulled out his pistol and fired it	166.98279664545692
4262. it	had misfired	0.30041514999999996
4263. reversing it he smashed the butt down on frederick	seward's head over and over again	1104.7907773558466
4264. it was the first blow	that was always difficult	389.0652393824697
4265. after that violence was exultantly easy	43.813386405950766
4266. he got caught up into it and became a different person	752.9927720401745
4267. only afterwards	did an act like that become meaningless so that he would puzzle over	it for days whereas at the time it had seemed quite real	2856.7701449761494
4268. the nigger boy fled down the stairs screaming murder	396.9490346754523
4269. it was not murder at all	43.515507639020214
4270. payne was more methodical than that	65.11726496195512
4271. he	was merely clearing a way to what he had to do	642.0872161347818
4272. he ran for the	sick room found his pistol was broken and threw it away	1650.7317449316029
4273. from childhood he had known all about knives	168.37015654329412
4274. someone blocked	the door from inside	65.10267484713766
4275. he smashed it in and tumbled into darkness	167.23441354924472
4276. he saw only dimly moving figures but when he slashed them they yelled	and fled	1631.2090870111956
4277. he went for the bed jumped on it and struck where he could	repeatedly	947.6917921799698
4278. it was like finally getting into one's own nightmares	to punish one's dreams	1178.8304584599914
4279. two men pulled him off	14.9357448301664
4280. payne hacked at their arms	22.214534064195398
4281. there was a lady there in	a nightdress	167.23168511157425
4282. he would not have wanted to hurt a lady	393.40240529678965
4283. another man	approached this one fully dressed	93.57561678562261
4284. when the knife went into his chest	he went down at once	963.2872574306757
4285. i'm mad shouted payne as	he ran out into the hall	505.24361368531515
4286. i'm mad and only wished he had been	253.12266767017385
4287. that would have made things so much easier	167.64622863030294
4288. but he was not mad	22.198137256540452
4289. he clattered down the stairs and out of	the door	373.2449131690081
4290. somewhere in the fog the nigger boy was still yelling murder	755.6051499547375
4291. one always wakes up even from one's own dreams	263.65951794500495
4292. the clammy air	revived him	22.40957208272112
4293. herold he saw had fled	14.893469099551169
4294. well one did not expect	much of people like herold	558.79898050572
4295. he unhitched his horse walked	it away mounted and spurred it on	644.4222574925705
4296. the nigger boy was close	behind him	140.56729279543933
4297. then the nigger boy turned back and he was alone	376.3439522460988
4298. he rode	on and on	22.309672719227997
4299. he had no idea where he was	93.62953853587913
4300. after some time he came to	an open field	395.3280384361486
4301. an open field was better than a building that was for	sure so he dismounted turned off the horse and plunged through the	grass	2471.818454143416
4302. he felt curiously sleepy the world seemed far away;	he knew he should get to cap but he didn't know how	3041.777277959501
4303. he was sure	for he had done as he was told hadn't he	789.9474436408974
4304. cap would find him	and take care of him	392.1439935528203
4305. so choosing a good tree he clambered up into it	found a comfortable notch and curled up in it to sleep like the tousled	bear he was with his hands across his chest as though surfeited	with honey	4039.172470684389
4306. violence always made him tired but he was not	frightened	559.7151744566083
4307. in boston edwin booth was winding up a performance	of a new way to pay old debts	1409.4504174462145
4308. it was a part so familiar	to him that he did not bother to think about it any more	2574.9727335586454
4309. on a stage he always knew what to do and tonight to judge	by the applause he must be doing it better than usual	2459.0592335922966
4310. as	sir giles overreach	he raised his arm and declaimed: where	is my honour now	1648.452102883095
4311. that was one of the high spots of the	play	372.82291574526596
4312. the audience as usual loved it	65.01347780547117
4313. he was delighted to see them	so happy	167.6513328360391
4314. if he had any worries it was only the small ones about	mother in new york and his daughter edwina and what she might be	doing at this hour with her aunt asia in philadelphia	5618.7074810365775
4315. everyone	is ambivalent about his profession if he has practised it long	enough but there were still moments when he loved the stage and all	those unseen people out there who might cheer you or boo you but that	was largely though not entirely up to you	4754.395229359036
4316. they made the	world seem friendly somehow though he knew it was not	1183.5993013947655
4317. wilkes	was quite right about one thing	94.83432188796027
4318. laura keene had been in the	green room	251.1561888062719
4319. the commotion had brought her into the wings	167.607211404075
4320. since she	could not act one part suited her as well as any other and so she was	the first person to offer mr lincoln a glass of water holding	it	up to the box high above her head to miss harris who had asked for	it	7093.508493020328
4321. she had been one of the first to collect her wits	499.1828233518763
4322. it was not so much that the shot had stunned the audience as that	they had been stunned already	2606.143390105043
4323. most of them had seen our american	cousin before and unless miss keene was on stage there was not	much to it	2167.0497219574777
4324. the theatre was hot and they were drugged with boredom	557.6698768630038
4325. the stage had been empty except for harry hawk doing his star	monologue	791.3282525180213
4326. the audience was fond of harry hawk he was a dear	in or out of character but he was not particularly funny	3248.321890075217
4327. at the end	of the monologue the audience would applaud	377.22512613540624
4328. meanwhile it looked at	the scenery	65.63880933701259
4329. well i guess i know enough to turn you inside	out you sockdologizing old mantrap! said trenchard otherwise	hawk	1726.3953440075663
4330. there was always a pause here before the next line	561.3166787227877
4331. that was when the gun went off	94.55328323227111
4332. yet even that explosion did not mean	much	248.46247722652416
4333. guns were going off all over washington city these days because	of the celebrations and the theatre was not soundproof	1886.0409682671245
4334. then	the audience saw a small dim figure appear at the edge of the presidential	box	1887.9528356003389
4335. sic semper tyrannis it said mildly	43.27533846238485
4336. booth	had delivered his line	22.074100981777853
4337. behind him billowed a small pungent cloud	of smoke	261.55716303861027
4338. they had not heard what had	been said	249.7356591633023
4339. they had been sitting too long to be able to stand up easily	782.8907390534112
4340. the figure leapt from the box almost lost its balance the flag	draped there tore in the air the figure landed on its left leg fell	on its hands and pressed itself up	5312.148652550527
4341. harry hawk still had his	arm raised towards the wings	375.7874094334664
4342. he did not lower	his arm	64.97002500421895
4343. the figure was so theatrically dressed that it was	as though	a character from some other play had blundered into this one	2188.1781979224606
4344. the	play for saturday night was to be a benefit performance of the octoroon	1410.9901304207178
4345. this figure looked like the slave dealer from that	262.86826396279287
4346. but it	also looked like a toad hopping away from the light	973.3781906248972
4347. there was something	maimed and crazy about its motion that disturbed them	639.2818977700197
4348. then	it disappeared into the wings	65.67750842098724
4349. harry hawk had not shifted	position but he at last lowered his arm	785.1814348269819
4350. there was no mistaking that scream	65.10462716020285
4351. it was what anyone who had ever	seen her had always expected her to do	1096.4474443937697
4352. yet this scream had a different	note in it	392.45637815995
4353. that absence of an urgent self-indulgence dashed them	awake like a pail of water	947.8241955923288
4354. clara harris one of the guests	in the box stood up and demanded water	1407.3102030970717
4355. when something unexpected happened one always asked for water if	one were a woman brandy if one were a man	1883.0698530837813
4356. in the presidential box someone leaned over the	balustrade and yelled: he has shot the president!   that	got everybody up	2832.9686907947603
4357. on the stage harry hawk began to weep	166.56049495725142
4358. laura	keene	brushed by him with the glass of water	559.4229948781865
4359. the crowd began to move	14.716362165858646
4360. in washington city everyone lived in a bubble of plots and one death	might attract another	1875.3768404583734
4361. it was not exactly panic they gave way to	but they could not just sit there	1250.5318452919926
4362. the beehive voices for no one could	bear silence drowned out the sound of mrs lincoln's weeping	2125.2030338601317
4363. at the rear of the auditorium upstairs some men tried to	push open the door to the box corridor	1729.8877854903244
4364. a	dr charles taft clambered up on the stage and got the actors to	hoist him up to the box	2833.787800258629
4365. in the audience a man named ferguson lost	his head and tried to rescue a little girl from the mob on the same principle	which had led miss harris to demand water	3446.8449720124436
4366. someone	opened the corridor door from the inside and called for a doctor	1181.319808950481
4367. somehow	dr charles leale was forced through the mob and squeezed out	into the dingy corridor	1249.8457007625589
4368. he went straight to the presidential box	140.9455562088047
4369. as usual mrs lincoln had lost her head but nobody blamed	her for doing so now	1259.5592943759198
4370. there was a little blood on the hem of her dress	for the assassin had slashed miss harris's companion major	rathbone with a knife	3688.8887923707343
4371. rathbone said he was bleeding to death	93.46971504680081
4372. by	the look of him he wasn't that far gone	556.598888853282
4373. with a sneer the man spread his legs and a third time confronted them	944.8391285877091
4374. once more katie reared and whinnied in fear	251.10325265556108
4375. for a moment	boy and mount hung in midair	261.1467210750342
4376. stevie twisted and frantically	commanded the mare to leap straight ahead	756.5903698251783
4377. but the stranger was nimbler	still	43.38550072195254
4378. with a bold arm he dared once more to obstruct them	753.5633473701457
4379. katie	reared a third time then trembling descended	166.5264104785353
4380. seizing the bridle he tugged with all his might and forced	katie to her knees	1636.105885368938
4381. stevie could feel himself toppling	14.872584300770493
4382. he saw the ground coming up- and the stranger's head	563.157038910492
4383. with	incredible ferocity he brought his fists together and struck	374.88142447974434
4384. the blow	encountered silky hair and hard bone	250.94809103061985
4385. the man uttered a weird cry	spun about and collapsed in the sand	794.8186617286817
4386. katie scrambled to her	feet stevie agilely retaining his seat	558.9109161500586

4388. he could feel his own feet	iron-shod striking repeatedly until the body was limp	1410.3193988845435
4389. he gloated	and his lips slavered	43.01902067759094
4390. they rode	around and around to trample the figure into the sand	969.9379145968869
4391. only the top	of the head with a spot bare and white as a clamshell remained visible	1427.297770206533
4392. a train hooted	0.30041514999999996
4393. they were pursuing him	2.963959524299196
4394. he was frightened; his fists	clutched so tightly that his knuckles hurt	954.2238119524748
4395. then katie stumbled	and again he was falling falling!   stevie! stevie!	his mother was nudging him but he was still falling	2021.424513146873
4396. his head hung	over the boards of katie's stall; before it was sprawled the	mangled corpse of the bearded stranger	2814.0628910300743
4397. stevie wake up now!	we're nearly there	93.22815719774016
4398. he was safe	in his mama's arms	140.26399115860858
4399. houses winked	as the cars rolled beside a little depot	374.77589277913046
4400. po' chavis! the	trainman	called	22.1770643535592
4401. he came by and repeated po' chavis!	6	bong! bong! startled him awake	794.3953589972205
4402. the room vibrated as	if a giant hand had rocked it	759.5060845833316
4403. bong! a dull boom and a throbbing	echo	166.94732232752796
4404. the walls bulged the floor trembled the windowpanes rattled	395.2182783705069
4405. he stared at the far morning expecting a pendulum to swing across the	horizon	940.8644022140732
4406. bong! he raced to the window and yanked at the sash	756.4975101185723
4407. bong! the wood was old the paint alligatored	167.53113521670932
4408. bong! a	fresh breeze saluted him	65.92998840310167
4409. six o'clock!   he put his his	head out	166.96914688673002
4410. there was the slate roof of the church; ivy climbed the	red brick walls like a green-scaled monster	2376.070234648628
4411. the clock which had struck	presented an innocent face	263.0610998195888
4412. in the kitchen mama was wiping	the cupboards	249.70265148907401
4413. there's a tower and a steeple on the church	a million feet high	799.402102782119
4414. and the loudest clock in the whole world!	i know stephen she smiled	1187.2398385620206
4415. they say that our	steeple is one hundred and sixty-two feet high	646.9660373533106
4416. the clock you heard strike-	it's really the town clock- was installed last april by	mrs shorter on her birthday	2801.5107543217678
4417. he dressed and sped outdoors	14.813881029711544
4418. he crossed broome street to orange square	141.40610531798922
4419. the steeple leaned	backward while the church advanced like a headless creature in a	long shapeless coat	1414.939406076232
