4680. the chief annoyed by these questions knocks voltaire down and shouts	at him that he not only never went to any school but never even	learned how to read	4647.735970068499
4681. when finally the two bedraggled men reach	their friend's home voltaire's fears are once again aroused	1261.1108050807377
4682. for it is such a distinguished place with such fine works of art and	such a big library that there can be little doubt but that the owner	has become depraved by all this culture	5608.160416879268
4683. to voltaire's surprise	however their host gives them fresh clothes to put on opens his	purse to lend them money and sits them down before a good dinner	2977.524195088475
4684. immediately after dinner however rousseau asks for still another	favor	556.8686244458596
4685. could he have pen and paper please	94.68583543715624
4686. he is in a hurry	to write another essay against culture	750.5326667362215
4687. such was the impromptu	that voltaire gave to howls of laughter at sans souci and that was	soon circulated in manuscript throughout the literary circles of europe	to be printed sometime later but with the name of timon of athens	the famous misanthrope substituted for that of rousseau	4773.692131207318
4688. how cruel!   but at the same time how understandable	389.74329685031387
4689. how could	the rich for whom life was made so simple ever understand the subterfuges	the lies the frauds the errors sins and even crimes to	which the poor were driven in their efforts to overcome the great advantages	the rich had in the race of life	4761.376845317882
4690. how for example	could a voltaire understand the strange predicament in which a rousseau	would find himself when soon after the furor of his first discourse	he acquired still another title to fame	5309.723055918206
4691. this time	as a musician	14.978882438680012
4692. ever since he had first begun	to study music and to teach it rousseau had dreamed of piercing through	to fame as the result of a successful opera	4473.027850760294
4693. but his facility in	this genre was not great	260.2053260146445
4694. and his efforts to get a performance for his	gallant muses invariably failed	1179.8300079670214
4695. his	operatic music had little merit	43.65420998112129
4696. but then one day while on a	week's visit to the country home of a retired swiss jeweler rousseau	amused the company with a few little melodies he had written to which	he attached no great importance	5922.073448795321
4697. he was really amazed to discover	the other guests so excited about these delicate little songs	1262.3018046606835
4698. put a few such songs together they urged him	388.20244307469454
4699. string them	onto some sort of little plot and you'll have a delightful operetta	941.7112590071807
4700. nonsense he said	0.30041514999999996
4701. this	is the sort of stuff i write and then throw away!   heaven	forbid! cried the ladies enchanted by his music	2038.5873748458562
4702. you	must make an opera out of this material	388.97109985103714
4703. and they wouldn't	leave off arguing and pleading until he had promised	640.500597574196
4704. oh	the irony and the bitterness of it! that after all his years of effort	to become a composer he should now now when he was still stoutly	replying to the critics of his discourse on the arts and sciences	be so close to a success in music and have to reject it	7680.591412063756
4705. or at least appear to reject it!   but what else could he do	785.5662512040886
4706. you couldn't on the one hand decry the arts and at the same time	practice them could you	2364.75597686351
4707. well yes perhaps in literature since	you could argue that you couldn't keep silent about your feelings against	literature and so were involved in spite of yourself	2864.416856652465
4708. but now music	too	4.4335918607354206
4709. no	0.20041515
4710. that would be too much!   and the fault of	course was rameau's	959.1453226117625
4711. the fault was rameau's and that of the whole	culture of this parisian age	938.6917740418783
4712. for it was rameau's type of music	that he had been trying to write and that he couldn't write	2582.404157837568
4713. these	little songs however were sweet nothings from the heart tender	memories of his childhood little melodies that anyone could hum and	that would make one want to weep	3085.7081460245618
4714. he couldn't appear	as a composer now	142.16938893236826
4715. that glory craved for so long was now forbidden	to him	501.9642030635972
4716. still just for the ladies and just for this once for this	one weekend in the country he would make a little piece out of his	melodies	4291.1726994084365
4717. the ladies were delighted and jean jacques was applauded	260.66489397919594
4718. and everyone went to work to learn the parts which he wrote	965.5655688416751
4719. but then after the little operetta had been given its feeble	amateur rendering everyone insisted that it was too good to be lost	forever and that the royal academy of music must now have the manuscript	in order to give it the really first-rate performance it merited	4735.010662031206
4720. rousseau was aware that he must seem like a hypocrite standing	there and arguing that he could not possibly permit a public performance	3495.1965123703244
4721. the ladies especially couldn't understand what troubled him	166.99865963976265
4722. a contradiction	0.30041514999999996
4723. bah what was a contradiction in one's life	167.54943350899504
4724. every woman has had the experience of saying no when she meant yes	and saying yes when she meant no	2819.5844878548805
4725. rousseau had to admit that	though he couldn't agree to a public performance he would indeed	just for his own private satisfaction dearly love to know how his work	would sound when done by professional musicians and by trained voices	4249.211809968852
4726. i'd simply like to know if it is as good as you kind people	seem to think he said	2596.95928099676
4727. duclos the historian pointed	out to jean jacques that this was impossible	633.5741248256932
4728. the musicians of the	royal opera would not rehearse a work merely to see how it would sound	2366.428027109694
4729. merely to satisfy the author's curiosity	43.47110874464789
4730. but he recalled that rameau had once had a private performance	of his opera armide behind closed doors just for himself alone	3279.289707328403
4731. duclos understood what was bothering rousseau: that the writer	of the prosopopoeia of fabricius should now become known as the	writer of an amusing little operetta	2732.4695056067585
4732. that would certainly be paradoxical	22.103572504373012
4733. but duclos thought he saw a way out	166.80312715832753
4734. let me do the	submitting to the royal academy he suggested	750.0135157549216
4735. your name will	never appear	14.787723884136568
4736. no one will even suspect that it is your work	561.5152136109792
4737. to that rousseau could agree	14.966187628602507
4738. but now what crazy twists	and turns of his emotions!   afraid at one and the same time	that his work might be turned down- which would be a blow to his pride	even though no one knew he was the author- and that the work would	be accepted and then that his violent feelings in the matter would	certainly betray how deeply concerned he was in spite of himself	0.30166232349522504
4739. and	how anxious this lover of obscurity was for applause! and thus torn	between his desire to be known as the composer of a successful opera	and the necessity of remaining true to his proclaimed desire for anonymity	rousseau suffered through several painful weeks	4527.807211029643
4740. all these	emotions were screwed up to new heights when after acceptance and	the first rehearsals there ensued such a buzz of excitement among parisian	music lovers that duclos had to come running to rousseau to	inform him that the news had reached the superintendent of the king's	amusements and that he was now demanding that the work be offered	first at the royal summer palace of fontainebleau	8811.629639854254
4741. imagine the honor	of it!   what was your answer	257.6519396193347
4742. jean jacques asked	striving to appear unimpressed	139.86223851210596
4743. what else could i do	14.933086423405303
4744. monsieur de cury was incensed of course	140.3152871010462
4745. but i said i would first have to get the author's permission	639.9651167523507
4746. and i was certain he would refuse	142.41624801390648
4747. how infuriating all	this was! why had not this success come to him before he had plunged	into his discourse and before he had committed himself to a life	of austerity and denial	3559.4868577217326
4748. now when everything was opening up to	him- even the court of louis 15!- he had to play a role of	self-effacement	3273.34163325794
4749. back and forth duclos had to go between m	de cury and jean jacques and between the duke d'aumont and jean	jacques again as his little operetta the village soothsayer	though still unperformed took on ever more importance	4041.290204991291
4750. and	of course the news of who the composer was did finally begin to get	around among his closest friends	2802.7086427653517
4751. but they naturally kept his secret	well and the public at large knew only of a great excitement in musical	and court circles	2320.047951133891
4752. how titillating it was to go among people	who did not know him as the composer but who talked in the most	glowing terms of the promise of the piece after having heard the first	rehearsals	5758.718932486505
4753. the furor was such that people who could not possibly have	squirmed their way into the rehearsals were pretending that they were	intimate with the whole affair and that it would be sensational	3543.810562835994
4754. and	listening to such a conversation one morning while taking a cup of	chocolate in a cafe rousseau found himself bathed in perspiration	trembling lest his authorship become known and at the same time dreaming	of the startling effect he would make if he should proclaim himself	suddenly as the composer	7552.228737328241
4755. he felt himself now as he himself	says in his confessions at a crucial point of his life	1570.8491747199282
4756. and that	was why on the day of the performance when a carriage from the royal	stables called to take him to the palace he did not bother to shave	4824.86310551318
4757. on the contrary he was pleased that his face showed a neglect of	several days	1096.9358148320462
4758. seeing him in that condition and about to enter	the hall where the king the queen the whole royal family and all	the members of the highest aristocracy would be present grimm and the	abbe raynal and others tried to stop him	6585.509109215837
4759. you can't	go in that way! they cried	165.6658998716989
4760. why not	0.30041514999999996
4761. jean jacques	asked	0.20041515
4762. who is going to stop me	64.61510277689536
4763. you haven't dressed	for the occasion! they pointed out to him	499.88165066509754
4764. i'm	dressed as i always am rousseau said	248.02086738253288
4765. at home yes they argued	14.75494331567867
4766. but here you are	in the palace	141.21704577907093
4767. and madame de pompadour	2.965979176822349
4768. if they are here then surely i have the right to be here	rousseau said	1639.3377072571134
4769. since i am the composer!	but in such a slovenly condition	501.4692777201564
4770. what	is slovenly about me	22.188725495883418
4771. rousseau asked	0.20041515
4772. is it because of my slovenliness	that hair grows on my face	954.4371737392405
4773. surely it would grow there	whether	i washed myself or not	502.76035585742466
4774. a hundred years ago i would have worn	a beard with pride	969.8675344652627
4775. and those without beards would have stood out as	not dressed for the occasion	939.1710149167662
4776. now times have changed and i must pretend	that hair doesn't grow on my face	1640.7212530356614
4777. and	fashion is the real king here	94.56510234886221
4778. not louis 15 since even he obeys	141.0034614386834
4779. now if you don't mind i should like to hear my own piece performed	946.3578921355744
4780. but of course behind his boldness he didn't feel bold	at all	957.7573441597658
4781. he trembled lest his piece should fail	93.71634567315571
4782. and this in addition	to his usual fear of being among people of high society	1636.871907444481
4783. his fear	of making some inane or inappropriate remark	265.6941367774476
4784. and even deeper than	that: his fear lest in this closed hall he should suddenly itch to	relieve himself	2577.461622892804
4785. could he walk out in the midst of his piece	372.3700934136957
4786. here	before the court	4.432041953051857
4787. before the king	0.20041515
4788. it was the first time any of us had laughed since the morning began	1411.1231857527946
4789. the rider from concord was as good as his word	377.3167697782256
4790. he came spurring	and whooping down the road his horse kicking up clouds of dust	shouting:   they're a-coming! by god they're a-coming	they are!   we heard him before he ever showed and we	heard him yelling after he was out of sight	6585.923302534378
4791. solomon chandler hadn't	misjudged the strength of his lungs not at all	636.2866888710353
4792. i think you could	have heard him a mile away and he was bursting at every seam with	importance	2587.2998219386927
4793. i have observed that being up on a horse changes the whole	character of a man and when a very small man is up on a saddle he'd	like as not prefer to eat his meals there	3960.9015824536714
4794. that's understandable	and i appreciate the sentiment	140.12372692851852
4795. as for this rider i never saw	him before or afterwards and never saw him dismounted so whether he stood	tall or short in his shoes i can't say; but i do know that	he gave the day tone and distinction	4329.793017662283
4796. the last thing in the world that	resembled a war was our line of farmers and storekeepers and mechanics	perched on top of a stone wall and this dashing rider made us feel	a good deal sharper and more alert to the situation	6700.996775191548
4797. we came	down off the wall as if he had toppled all of us and we crouched behind	it	1730.7317522604594
4798. i have heard people talk with contempt about the british regulars	but that only proves that a lot of people talk about things of	which they are deplorably ignorant	4643.325039068828
4799. whatever we felt about the redcoats	we respected them in terms of their trade which was killing; and	i know that i myself was nauseated with apprehension and fear and	that my hands were soaking wet where they held my gun	4277.199902581504
4800. i wanted to wipe	my flint but i didn't dare to the state my hands were in just	as i didn't dare to do anything about the priming	4484.6070751232055
4801. the gun would	fire or not just as chance willed	375.1191731491248
4802. i put a lot more trust in my two	legs than in the gun because the most important thing i had learned	about war was that you could run away and survive to talk about it	5789.527055315671
4803. the gunfire which was so near that it seemed just a piece up the	road now stopped for long enough to count to twenty; and in that	brief	interval a redcoat officer came tearing down the road whipping	his horse fit to kill	4470.145053127939
4804. i don't know whether he was after our rider	who had gone by a minute before or whether he was simply scouting conditions;	but when he passed us by a musket roared and he reared his	horse swung it around and began to whip it back in the direction	from which he had come	7797.658894291169
4805. he was a fine and showy rider but his skill	was wasted on us	940.5047175791993
4806. from above me and somewhere behind me a rifle cracked	561.5933085327725
4807. the redcoat officer collapsed like a punctured bolster and the	horse reared and threw him from the saddle except that one booted foot	caught in the stirrup	2883.424962171004
4808. half crazed by the weight dragging the dust	and the heat the horse leaped our wall dashing out the rider's brains	against it and leaving him lying there among us- while the horse	crashed away through the brush	6090.317416359332
4809. it was my initiation to war	and the insane symphony war plays; for what had happened on the common	was only terror and flight; but this grinning broken head not	ten feet away from me was the sharp definition of what my reality had	become	4594.8845328736215
4810. and now the redcoats were coming and the gunfire was	a part of the dust cloud on the road to the west of us	3702.8339593318897
4811. i must state	that the faster things happened the slower they happened; the passage	and rhythm of time changed and when i remember back to what happened	then each event is a separate and frozen incident	3858.0312803972097
4812. in my recollection	there was a long interval between the death of the officer and	the appearance of the first of the retreating redcoats and in that interval	the dust cloud over the road seems to hover indefinitely	6087.868203109805
4813. yet	it could not have been more than a matter of seconds and then the front	of the british army came into view	2329.5821926049057
4814. it was only hours since	i had last seen them but they had changed and i had changed	2362.9923398965116
4815. in	the very front rank two men were wounded and staggered along trailing	blood behind them	1254.3768548728644
4816. no drummers here no pipers and the red coats	were covered with a fine film of dust	2131.3816362327316
4817. they marched with bayonets fixed	and as fixed on their faces was anger fear and torment	1265.2023808251963
4818. rank after	rank of them came down the road and the faces were all the same	and they walked in a sea of dust	3696.9630651182183
4819. committeemen hold your fire!	hold your fire! a voice called and what made it even more	terrible	and unreal was that the redcoat ranks never paused for an instant	only some of them glancing toward the stone wall from behind which	the voice came	4560.019389238625
4820. the front of their column had already passed	us when another officer came riding down the side of the road not	five paces from where we were	4288.815008951007
4821. my cousin simmons carried a musket	but he had loaded it with bird shot and as the officer came opposite	him he rose up behind the wall and fired	3120.3210959817034
4822. one moment there was a man	in the saddle; the next a headless horror on a horse that bolted through	the redcoat ranks and during the next second or two we all of	us fired into the suddenly disorganized column of soldiers	6560.044211282491
4823. one moment	the road was filled with disciplined troops marching four by four	with a purpose as implacable as death; the next a cloud of gun smoke	covered a screaming fury of sound out of which the redcoat soldiers	emerged with their bayonets and their cursing fury	4761.388214024614
4824. in the course	of this they had fired on us; but i have no memory of that	2103.5553012683527
4825. i	had squeezed the trigger of my own gun and to my amazement it had	fired and kicked back into my shoulder with the force of an angry mule;	and then i was adding my own voice to the crescendo of sound hurling	more vile language than i ever thought i knew sobbing and shouting	and aware that if i had passed water before it was not enough	for my pants were soaking wet	0.20124717349522497
4826. i would have stood there and died	there if left to myself but cousin simmons grabbed my arm in his	viselike grip and fairly plucked me out of there; and then i came	to some sanity and plunged away with such extraordinary speed that i	outdistanced cousin simmons by far	7393.62096357322
4827. later	we realized that the redcoats had stopped their charge at the wall	790.232628310552
4828. their only hope of survival was to hold to the road and keep marching	1412.0994743483168
4829. we tumbled to a stop in deacon gordon's cow hole a low-lying	bit of pasture with a muddy pool of water in its middle	2457.49509468735
4830. a dozen	cows mooed sadly and regarded us as if we were insane as perhaps	we were at that moment with the crazy excitement of our first encounter	the yelling and shooting still continuing up at the road and the	thirst of some of the men which was so great that they waded into the	muddy water and scooped up handfuls of it	8457.327482499091
4831. isaac pitt one of the	men from lincoln had taken a musket ball in his belly; and though	he had found the strength to run with us now he collapsed and lay on	the ground dying the reverend holding his head and wiping his hot brow	4715.896834128332
4832. it may appear that we were cruel and callous but no one had time	to spend sympathizing with poor isaac- except the reverend	3473.672940224204
4833. i know	that i myself felt that it was a mortal shame for a man to be torn	open by a british musket ball as isaac had been yet i also felt	relieved and lucky that it had been him and not myself	4460.729061201995
4834. i was drunk	with excitement and the smell of gunpowder that came floating down from	the road and the fact that i was not afraid now but only waiting	to know what to do next	5636.156195595784
4835. meanwhile i reloaded my gun as the	other men were doing	503.9309469105586
4836. we were less than a quarter of a mile from the	road and we could trace its shape from the ribbon of powder smoke and	dust that hung over it	4858.248698561645
4837. wherever you looked you saw committeemen	running across the meadows some away from the road some toward it some	parallel to it; and about a mile to the west a cluster of at least	fifty militia were making their way in our direction	4469.493159130239
4838. cousin	joshua and some others felt that we should march toward lexington	and take up new positions ahead of the slow-moving british column but	another group maintained that we should stick to this spot and this	section of road	6181.353521185289
4839. i didn't offer any advice but i certainly did not	want to go back to where the officer lay with his brains dashed out	2454.581865576625
4840. someone said that while we were standing here and arguing about it	the british would be gone; but cousin simmons said he had watched	them marching west early in the morning and moving at a much brisker	pace it had still taken half an hour for their column to pass what with	the narrowness of the road and their baggage and ammunition carts	8487.198553902006
4841. while this was being discussed we saw the militia to the west	of us fanning out and breaking into little clusters of two and three	men as they approached the road	3334.3479076115896
4842. it was the opinion of some of us that	these must be part of the committeemen who had been in the battle	of the north bridge which entitled them to a sort of veteran status	and we felt that if they employed this tactic it was likely enough	the best one	7476.012380328629
4843. mattathias dover said:   it makes sense	43.56402315684751
4844. if	we cluster together the redcoats can make an advantage out of it	but there's not a blessed thing they can do with two or three of	us except chase us and we can outrun them	5770.977892053326
4845. that settled it	and we broke into parties of two and three	641.742927681706
4846. cousin joshua dover	decided	to remain with the reverend and poor isaac pitt until life passed away-	and he was hurt so badly he did not seem for long in this world	5149.017795494243
4847. i went off with cousin simmons who maintained that if he didn't	see to me he didn't know who would	1877.1970469351702
4848. good heavens adam	he said i thought one thing you'd have no trouble learning	is when to get out of a place	3260.1857224982928
4849. i learned that now	i said	43.512988970438286
4850. we ran east for about half a mile before we turned back	to the road panting from the effort and soaked with sweat	3503.103403377578
4851. there	was a clump of trees that appeared to provide cover right up to the road	and the shouting and gunfire never slackened	2327.6792979291313
4852. under the trees	there was a dead redcoat a young boy with a pasty white skin and	a face full of pimples who had taken a rifle ball directly between the	eyes	5186.363852437205
4853. three men were around him	14.942531828686265
4854. they had stripped him of his musket	and equipment and now they were pulling his boots and jacket off	2588.152013098793
4855. cousin simmons grabbed one of them by the shoulder and flung him away	793.7239128347603
4856. god's name what are you to rob the dead with the fight	going on! cousin simmons roared	2124.6984199110757
4857. they tried to outface	him but joseph simmons was as wide as two average men and it would	have taken braver men than these were to outface him	2984.0686667352525
4858. that summer the gambling houses were closed despite the threats	of pierre ameaux a gaming-card manufacturer	1888.9168294629512
4859. dancing was no longer	permitted in the streets	166.87744943492254
4860. the bordel and other places of prostitution	were emptied	388.5289436919462
4861. the slit breeches had to go	43.90667896425704
4862. drunkenness was no	longer tolerated	22.159909992419365
4863. in defiance a chinless reprobate jake camaret	marched down the aisle in st peter's one sunday morning followed	by one of the women from the bordel whose dress and walk plainly	showed the lack of any shame	3959.435645684881
4864. plunking themselves down on the front	bench they turned to smirk at those around them	1646.0848928336
4865. john's first	impulse was to denounce their blasphemy	166.40300858081983
4866. but the thought occurred	that god would want this opportunity used to tell them about him	1880.1403918078922
4867. calmly	he opened the bible and read of the woman at the well	790.8149396171643
4868. he finished	the worship service as if there had been no brazen attempt to dishonor	god and man	2370.611544406354
4869. the next morning as the clock struck nine	he appeared at the council meeting in the town hall and insisted	that the couple would have to be punished if the church was to be respected	3764.7907206391837
4870. i have told you before and i tell you again monsieur	favre said rudely	1410.9722325885818
4871. stick to the preaching of the gospel!	john stiffened in anger	499.3970065018505
4872. that is the answer the ungodly	will always make when the church points its fingers at their sins	2355.1612484225907
4873. i say to you that the church will ever decry evil!   john's	reply was like a declaration of war	1724.6772813388984
4874. monsieur favre sat down	in his high-backed stall lips compressed eyes glinting	960.7157925452696
4875. ablard corne	a short man with a rotunda of stomach rose	500.1356224169713
4876. every eye was on him	as he began to speak	563.0825713244475
4877. what master calvin says is true	43.504812275580505
4878. how can we have a good city unless we respect morality	751.1546549913395
4879. abel	poupin a tall man with sunken cheeks and deep-set eyes got to	his feet	1096.459252539227
4880. we all know that jake camaret and the woman are brazenly	living together	1188.94797971602
4881. it would be well to show the populace how we deal	with adulterers	789.6175742591876
4882. philibert berthelier the son of the famous	patriot disagreed	391.05761520528966
4883. do not listen to that frenchman	43.394597993807
4884. he is throttling	the liberty my father gave his life to win!   john	was quietly insistent	1865.202280022623
4885. there can be no compromise when souls are	in jeopardy	376.14330997101627
4886. a week later the sentence of the council was	carried out: jake camaret and the woman were marched naked through	the streets past a mocking populace	4096.345912600152
4887. before them stalked the beadle	proclaiming as he went thus the council deals with those who break	its laws- adulterers thieves murderers and lewd persons	2602.05422923284
4888. let	evildoers contemplate their ways and let every man beware!	john's thoughts raced painfully into the past as he read the letter	he had just received from his sister mary	4872.59632005085
4889. charles had died two	weeks before in early november without being reconciled to the church	1093.0276925593985
4890. the canons in a body had tried to force him on his deathbed to	let them give him the last rites of the church but he had died still	proclaiming salvation by faith	5330.147993642805
4891. burial had taken place at night in	the ground at the public crossroads under the gibbet so that his enemies	could not find his body and have it dug up and burned	3456.7714983691453
4892. the abbot	of st eloi claude de mommor had been a good friend but not	even he thought charles deserved burial in hallowed ground	3684.6466683732374
4893. john	closed his eyes and saw once again the little niche in his mother's	bedroom where she had knelt to tell the good virgin of her needs	2853.915395797637
4894. the blue-draped virgin was still there but no one knelt before her	now	1174.302009104911
4895. not even varnessa; she too prayed only to god	263.5818202510307
4896. for an	instant john longed for the sound of the bells of noyon-la-sainte	the touch of his mother's hand the lilt of charles's voice in the	square raftered rooms his father's bass tones rumbling to the canons	and the sight of the beloved bishop	6833.982826814155
4897. but he had to follow the light	93.88005932446225
4898. unless god expected a man to believe the holy scriptures why	had he given them to him	2122.510512963569
4899. the white-clad trees stood like	specters in the february night	375.8336116032632
4900. snow buried the streets and covered	the slanting rooftops as john trudged toward st peter's	1654.2751105207044
4901. a carriage	crunched by its dim lights filtering through the gloom	502.9409653155869
4902. the	sharp wind slapped at him and his feet felt like ice as the snow penetrated	the holes of his shoes his only ones now patched with folded parchment	4664.587908308089
4903. the city had recently given him a small salary but it was not	enough to supply even necessities	1573.3980860786455
4904. as he neared the square a	round figure muffled in a long black cape whisked by	1888.5468057857681
4905. john recognized	ablard corne and called out a greeting	261.89806344006024
4906. how grateful he was to such	men! there were several on the council who tried to live like christians	2575.549702239247
4907. despite their efforts the problems seemed to grow graver	all the time	641.7610997125631
4908. quickening his steps john entered the vast church and	climbed the tower steps to the bells	1900.6643770480655
4909. underneath the big one in the	silent moonlight lay a dead pigeon and on the smaller bell the clemence	two gray and white birds slept huddled together in the cold	winter air	3463.5660827465645
4910. john leaned upon the stone balustrade	64.61188250911538
4911. he brushed	back his black hair shoving it under his pastor's cap to keep it	from blowing in his eyes	1882.3791551238926
4912. below the moon-splashed world rolled away	to insurmountable white peaks; above him the deep blue sky glittered	with stars	2599.946681710796
4913. he stood very still his arms at his sides staring up	at the heavens then down at the blinking lights below	2031.1983881769822
4914. how	long my lord	4.426998305697107
4915. how long	0.20041515
4916. i have never asked for an easy task	but i am weary of the strife	1641.8746767358448
4917. sleep was difficult these days	14.888399645950036
4918. severe headaches were frequent	4.413381650745372
4919. loneliness	tore through him like a physical pain whenever he thought of peter	robert nerien nicholas cop martin bucer and even the compromising	louis du tillet	2733.4975953555945
4920. an occasional traveler from italy brought	news of peter robert who was now distributing his bible among the	waldensian peasants	2825.2831866247707
4921. letters came regularly from nerien nicholas	and martin	167.5656497395838
4922. he had anthony and william to confide in and consult	560.7011667180456
4923. but william continued to find a bitter joy in smashing images and	tearing down symbols sacred to the old church	1888.0245224264775
4924. john found it difficult	but he held him in check	558.2854829326982
4925. and anthony was busy most of the time	courting this girl and that	788.1733890390003
4926. his easy good looks made him a favorite	with the ladies	762.687481864097
4927. geneva instead of becoming the city of god	as john had dreamed had in the two years since he had been there	continued to be a godless place where all manner of vice flourished	3681.9078577129862
4928. refugees poured in signing the confession and rules in order to remain	and then disregarding them	1877.0438586848045
4929. dice rolled prostitutes plied their	trade thieves stole murderers stabbed and the ungodly blasphemed	946.4086615121308
4930. catholics who were truly christians longed for the simple penance of	days gone by	1406.0831505188305
4931. libertines recalled the heroism of the past and demanded:	are we going to allow the protestant pope master calvin	to curtail our liberty	2323.893398476005
4932. h why oh why doesn't he stick to preaching	the gospel instead of meddling in civic affairs politics	economics and social issues that are no concern of the church	4644.833846086318
4933. and john's reply was always the same: anything that affects	souls is the concern of the church! we will have righteousness!	tears burned behind his eyes as he prayed and meditated tonight	3465.4206349030947
4934. unless the confusion cleared he would not be coming here much	longer	962.046135864498

4940. john	0.30041514999999996

4951. anger	and fear fused in john	43.30025914286835

4954. peter	caroli had come to geneva saying that he had been a bishop of the	church of rome and had been persecuted in paris for his reformed faith	4458.079436092939
4955. he asked to be appointed a preacher	94.05018390455947
4956. but michael sept had unmasked	him revealing he had never been a bishop but was an anabaptist	afraid to state his faith because he knew john calvin had written	a book against their belief that the soul slept after death	6351.518404677817
4957. so john	had refused to agree to his appointment as a preacher and now caroli	sought revenge	1423.4897698944733
4958. if william agrees we should	insist on a public debate he said at length	1417.4763965528539

4988. standing in the shelter of the tent- a rejected hospital tent	on which the rain now dripped no longer drumming- adam watched his	own hands touch the objects on the improvised counter of boards laid	across two beef barrels	6188.031319102828
4989. there was of course no real need to rearrange	everything	376.2467698165985
4990. a quarter inch this way or that for the hardbake or	the toffee or the barley sugar or the sardines or the bitters or	the condensed milk or the stationery or the needles- what could it	mean	5971.303876672331
4991. adam watched his own hands make the caressing anxious movement	that when rain falls and nobody comes and ruin draws close like	a cat rubbing against the ankles has been the ritual of stall	vendors forever	3864.3213462376916
4992. he knew its meaning	4.441186333131229
4993. he had seen a dry old yellowing hand reach out with that painful	solicitude to touch to rearrange to shift aimlessly some object	worth a pfennig	2740.870348301908
4994. back in bavaria he had seen that gesture and at	that sight his heart had always died within him	2596.3945716232047
4995. on such occasions he	had not had the courage to look at the face above the hand whatever	face it might be	2178.9093266732148
4996. now the face was his own	65.27456383909025
4997. he wondered what	expression as he made that gesture was on his face	786.5838314697228
4998. he wondered if	it wore the old anxiety or the old taut stoicism	1193.0995148049487
4999. but there was no	need he remembered for his hand to reach out for his face to show	concern or stoicism	2029.0554959695637
5000. it was nothing to him if rain fell and nobody came	753.9382853203608

5004. he looked out of the tent at the	company street	560.8193353530062

5006. beyond that misty gray of the rain he saw the stretching hutment	low diminutive log cabins chinked with mud with doorways a man would	have to crouch to get through with roofs of tenting laid over boughs	or boards from hardtack boxes or fence rails with cranky chimneys	of sticks and dried mud	7695.33500869719

5011. this was the hut of simms purdew the hero	260.8308385351094
5012. the men were huddled in those lairs	139.70020404106225

5135. some liar's logic a wisp of optimism	as fragile as the scent of tropical blossoms that came through the	window	consoled her for a moment	2595.1515553726967
5136. amy had to be safe had to	come back to them- if only to reap that share of life's experiences	that were her due if only to give her parents another chance to do	better by her	5884.000088902585

5361. and in any case answers may	clarify but they do not change anything	783.5281491821489
5362. h he brought with him a mixture of myrrh and aloes of about a hundred	pounds' weight	2127.498990623778
5363. they took jesus's body then and wrapped it	in winding-clothes with the spices; that is how the jews prepare a	body for burial	2324.2623701963444
5364. listed as present at the descent were mary	mary's sister mary magdalene john joseph of arimathea nicodemus	2131.332652847489
5365. search as he might he could find no place where the bible	spoke of a moment when mary could have been alone with jesus	2473.0575752522504
5366. mostly	the scene was crowded with mourners such as the dramatic dell'arca	lamentation in bologna where the grief-stricken spectators had	usurped mary's last poignant moment	3899.7474859991407
5367. in his concept there could	be no one else present	374.6309205117772
5368. his first desire was to create a	mother and son alone in the universe	1415.3802114852076
5369. when might mary have had that	moment to hold her child on her lap	934.778932146434
5370. perhaps after the soldiers had	laid him on the ground while joseph of arimathea was at pontius pilate's	asking for christ's body nicodemus was gathering his mixture	of myrrh and aloes and the others had gone home to mourn	6186.068842932015
5371. those	who saw his finished pieta would take the place of the biblical witnesses	945.1249915436023
5372. they would feel what mary was undergoing	141.01806419229672
5373. there would be no	halos no angels	93.50115035279933
5374. these would be two human beings whom god had chosen	563.8668163971131
5375. he felt close to mary having spent so long concentrating	on the beginning of her journey	1250.797807541005
5376. now she was intensely alive anguished;	her son was dead	560.5506016567022
5377. even though he would later be resurrected	he was at this moment dead indeed the expression on his face reflecting	what he had gone through on the cross	2983.2119140416426
5378. in his sculpture therefore	it would not be possible for him to project anything of what jesus felt	for his mother; only what mary felt for her son	4447.675455157385
5379. jesus' inert	body would be passive his eyes closed	262.72576057370213
5380. mary would have to carry the	human communication	251.01603022273292
5381. this seemed right to him	14.82386879315662
5382. it was a relief	to shift in his mind to technical problems	966.9872713058119
5383. since his christ was	to be life size how was mary to hold him on her lap without the relationship	seeming ungainly	2168.0864964725197
5384. his mary would be slender of limb and	delicate of proportion yet she must hold this full-grown man as securely	and convincingly as she would a child	4275.914143417248
5385. there was only one	way to accomplish this: by design by drawing diagrams and sketches	in which he probed the remotest corner of his mind for creative ideas	to carry his concept	3437.1902740605774
5386. he started by making free sketches to loosen	up his thinking so that images would appear on paper	2366.397880251671
5387. visually	these approximated what he was feeling within himself	260.9417471133321
5388. at the same time	he started walking the streets peering at the people passing or shopping	at the stalls storing up fresh impressions of what they looked	like how they moved	4990.51295756418
5389. in particular he sought the gentle sweet-faced	nuns with head coverings and veils coming to the middle of their foreheads	remembering their expressions until he reached home and set them	down on paper	3547.3395521351135
5390. discovering that draperies could be designed	to serve structural purposes he began a study of the anatomy of folds	2593.0290576321063
5391. he improvised as he went along completing a life-size clay figure	then bought yards of an inexpensive material from a draper wet the	lightweight cloth in a basin and covered it over with clay that argiento	brought from the bank of the tiber to the consistency of thick	mud	4913.538501075536
5392. no fold could be accidental each turn of the drapery had to serve	organically to cover the madonna's slender legs and feet so that	they would give substantive support to christ's body to intensify	her inner turmoil	5926.226042920643
5393. when the cloth dried and stiffened he saw what	adjustments had to be made	947.4010042593975
5394. so that's sculpture commented	argiento wryly when he had sluiced down the floor for a week making	mud pies	2616.450675074074
5395. see argiento	if you control the way these folds are bunched like this or made to	flow you can enrich the body attitudes	2340.5646682475626
5396. they can have as much tactile	appeal as flesh and bone	758.6550351874542
5397. he went into the jewish quarter	wanting to draw hebraic faces so that he could reach a visual understanding	of how christ might have looked	2593.476233291996
5398. the jewish section was	in trastevere near the tiber at the church of san francesco a ripa	2124.9487565420777
5399. the colony had been small until the spanish inquisition of 1492	drove many jews into rome	1256.8267486702327
5400. here for the most part they were well	treated as a reminder of the old testament heritage of christianity;	many of their gifted members were prominent in the vatican	as physicians musicians bankers	5296.865211481001
5401. the men did not object to	his sketching them while they went about their work but no one could	be persuaded to come to his studio to pose	2975.6703524165277
5402. he was told to ask for	rabbi melzi at the synagogue on saturday afternoon	1401.1250165456354
5403. michelangelo found	the rabbi in the room of study a gentle old man with a white beard	and luminous grey eyes robed in black gabardine with a skullcap on	his head	3350.224757775965
5404. he was reading from the talmud with a group of men from his	congregation	1417.492681030227
5405. when michelangelo explained why he had come rabbi	melzi replied gravely:   the bible forbids us to bow down	to or to make graven images	2456.7341880995455
5406. that is why our creative people give their	time to literature not to painting or sculpture	1887.423795649535
5407. but	rabbi melzi you don't object to others creating works of art	641.8026760699099
5408. not at all	0.30041514999999996
5409. each religion has its own tenets	43.79201052982313
5410. i am carving a pieta from white carrara marble	395.5912911540951
5411. i wish to make	jesus an authentic jew	166.48535152085503
5412. i cannot accomplish this if you will not	help me	561.4539880910704
5413. the rabbi said thoughtfully i would not want	my people to get in trouble with the church	1409.6482918942845
5414. i am working	for the cardinal of san dionigi	389.21589340366114
5415. i'm sure he would approve	14.869490069022214
5416. what kind of models would you prefer	141.68117676938752
5417. workmen	0.20041515
5418. not bulky laborers but sinewy men	65.17903061701955
5419. rabbi melzi smiled at	him with infinitely old but merry eyes	504.9966180411225
5420. i will send you the best the quarter has to offer	760.1348006197046
5421. michelangelo	hurried to sangallo's solitary bachelor room with his sketches	asked the architect to design a stand which would simulate the	seated madonna	2322.1039692900767
5422. sangallo studied the drawings and improvised a trestle	couch	395.39843270920943
5423. michelangelo bought some scrap lumber	14.899610428101397
5424. together he and argiento	built the stand covering it with blankets	749.6260380611159
5425. his first	model arrived at dusk	43.48745412815026
5426. he hesitated for a moment when michelangelo asked	him to disrobe so michelangelo gave him a piece of toweling to	wrap around his loins led him to the kitchen to take off his clothes	5472.916860748166
5427. he then draped him over the rough stand explained that he was supposed	to be recently dead and was being held on his mother's lap	2593.287593171356
5428. the	model quite plainly thought michelangelo crazy; only the instructions	from his rabbi kept him from bolting	2140.9454195293347
5429. but at the end of the sitting	when michelangelo showed him the quick free drawings with the	mother roughed in holding her son the model grasped what michelangelo	was after and promised to speak to his friends h	4053.8674870150157
5430. he worked for	two hours a day with each model sent by the rabbi	1418.4669739360613
5431. mary presented	quite a different problem	43.718850997519986
5432. though this sculpture must take place	thirty-three	years after her moment of decision he could not conceive	of her as a woman in her mid-fifties old wrinkled broken in body and	face by labor or worry	5762.765888635108
5433. his image of the virgin had always been that	of a young woman even as had his memory of his mother	2045.4735496329772
5434. jacopo	galli introduced him into several roman homes	252.24654101749735
5435. here he sketched	sitting in their flowing gowns of linen and silk young girls not yet	twenty some about to be married some married a year or two	2997.111609926803
5436. since	the santo spirito hospital had taken only men he had had no experience	in the study of female anatomy; but he had sketched the women of	tuscany in their fields and homes	5343.825761976004
5437. he was able to discern the body	lines of the roman women under their robes	1100.2368033628727
5438. he spent concentrated	weeks putting his two figures together: a mary who would be young	and sensitive yet strong enough to hold her son on her lap; and	a jesus who though lean was strong even in death h a look he remembered	well from his experience in the dead room of santo spirito	7789.247368892114
5439. he drew toward the composite design from his meticulously accurate memory	without need to consult his sketches	1414.1787237492688
5440. soon he was ready	to go into a three-dimensional figure in clay	964.5673667798828
5441. here he would have free	expression because the material could be moved to distort forms	1100.7781701458384
5442. when	he wanted to emphasize or get greater intensity he added or subtracted	clay	1417.3875252905343
5443. next he turned to wax because there was a similarity of	wax to marble in tactile quality and translucence	1717.4757581510707
5444. he respected each	of these approach techniques and kept them in character: his quill	drawings had a scratchiness suggesting skin texture; the clay he used	plastically to suggest soft moving flesh as in an abdomen in a reclining	torso; the wax he smoothed over to give the body surface an	elastic pull	7657.649332075208
5445. yet he never allowed these models to become fixed in his	mind; they remained rough starting points	1417.616663520712
5446. when carving he was charged	with spontaneous energy; too careful or detailed studies in clay	and wax would have glued him down to a mere enlarging of his model	4672.220312305581
5447. the true surge had to be inside the marble itself	373.29033202390576
5448. drawing and	models were his thinking	64.85273977777584
5449. the arrangement	with argiento was working well except that sometimes michelangelo	could not figure who was master and who apprentice	1874.3899741281869
5450. argiento had	been trained so rigorously by the jesuits that michelangelo was unable	to change his habits: up before dawn to scrub the floors whether	they were dirty or not; water boiling on the fire for washing laundry	every day the pots scoured with river sand after each meal	7333.269003742324
5451. argiento this is senseless he complained not liking to work	on the wet floors particularly in cold weather	1573.0482467617478
5452. scrub the studio once a week	65.66538068193685
5453. before dawn	0.20041515
5454. and god help anyone who tries to unteach you!	grumbled michelangelo; yet he knew that he had nothing to grumble	about for argiento made few demands on him	4476.59875902981
5455. the boy was becoming acquainted	with the contadini families that brought produce into rome	945.8056539509492
5456. on sundays he would walk miles into the campagna to visit with	them and in particular to see their horses	2832.0693633945143
5457. the one thing he missed	from his farm in the po valley was the animals; frequently he would	take his leave of michelangelo by announcing:   today	i go see the horses	3358.2588418831356
5458. it took a piece of bad luck to show	michelangelo that the boy was devoted to him	2115.870754199795
5459. he was crouched over his	anvil in the courtyard getting his chisels into trim when a splinter	of steel flew into his eye and imbedded itself in his pupil	3097.038899791878
5460. he stumbled	into the house eyes burning like fire	392.7648102719945
5461. argiento made him lie	down on the bed brought a pan of hot water dipped some clean white linen	cloth and applied it to extract the splinter	2863.0494246650533
5462. though the pain was	considerable michelangelo was not too concerned	561.2162151743927
5463. he assumed he could	blink the splinter out	167.70335617358924
5464. but it would not come	22.174670475993317
5465. argiento never left	his side keeping the water boiled applying hot compresses throughout	the night	1108.9417356237664
5466. by the second day michelangelo began to worry;	and by the second night he was in a state of panic: he could see nothing	out of the afflicted eye	4664.092054351549
5467. at dawn argiento went to jacopo galli	93.25841312714165
5468. galli arrived with his family surgeon maestro lippi	251.06074046124468
5469. the surgeon	carried a cage of live pigeons	167.90736609823105
5470. he told argiento to take a bird	out of the cage cut a large vein under its wing let the blood gush	into michelangelo's injured eye	4078.6146287382194
5471. the surgeon came back at	dusk cut the vein of a second pigeon again washed out the eye	1568.1337620980598
5472. beth was very still and her breath came in small jerking gasps	952.5104203988394
5473. the thin legs twitched convulsively once then kate felt the little	body stiffening in her arms and heard one strangled sound	2027.010457312493
5474. the scant	flesh grew cool beneath her frantic hands	391.6206961898091
5475. when juanita awoke kate was still rocking the dead child still	crooning in disbelief no no oh no!   they put	kate to bed and wired jonathan and sent for the young presbyterian	minister	3537.49640843069
5476. he sat beside kate's bed with the others throughout the	morning talking talking of god's will while kate lay staring angrily	at him	3481.2543824362083
5477. when he told her god had called the child to him she	rejected his words rebelliously	1261.8209477711368
5478. few of the neighbors came but	mrs tussle came called by tragedy	963.0733413509595
5479. it always comes in	threes she sighed heavily	165.74516009808116
5480. trouble never comes but in threes	64.93891128887833
5481. they held the funeral the next morning from the crossroads	church and buried the little box in the quiet family plot	2039.546379007273
5482. kate moved	through all the preparations and services in a state of bewilderment	1184.4691285462823
5483. she would not accept the death of such a little child	502.1017590276165
5484. god called	her to him the minister had said	393.27549718679586
5485. god would not do that	kate thought stubbornly	165.98695288119296
5486. jonathan's letter came as she knew	it would and he had accepted their child's death as another judgment	from god against both kate and himself	3915.7140876198296
5487. in blind panic of grief	she accepted jonathan's dictum and believed in her desperation that	she had been cursed by god	2028.6684344424325
5488. she held jonathan's letter his words	burning like a brand and knew suddenly that the bonds between them	were severed	2807.500420295487
5489. she had nothing left but her duty to his land and his	son	786.2435510851615
5490. joel came and sat mutely with her sharing her pain and anguish	averting his eyes from the ice packs on her bosom	3259.7575736890467
5491. juanita and	mrs tussle kept kate in bed a week until her milk dried	942.4336886501709
5492. when	she returned to life in the big house she felt shriveled of all emotion	save dedication to duty	2580.9022515572465
5493. she disciplined herself daily to do what	must be done	373.1540508796336
5494. she had even steeled herself to keep juanita upstairs	in the nurse's room off the empty nursery although the girl tried	to insist on moving back to the quarters to spare kate remembrance of	the baby's death	5939.941338563817
5495. juanita drooped about the place wearing	a haunted brooding look which kate attributed to the baby's death	until the day a letter came for her addressed to miss juanita fitzroy	bearing a grafton postmark	3671.2071407305493
5496. seeing the slanting hand kate	knew uneasily that it was from the yankee colonel	1404.1634341015658
5497. the federal	forces had taken parkersburg and grafton from the rebels and were moving	to take all the mountains	1729.053656245554
5498. kate tried to contain her curiosity	and foreboding at what the letter portended at what involvement existed	for juanita	2587.487406503971
5499. uncle randolph and joel had replanted the bottom	lands with difficulty for more of the slaves including annie	had sneaked off when the soldiers broke camp	2752.7541663802585
5500. joel worked like a field	hand in the afternoons after school	756.1326315760765
5501. he had been at lessons in the	schoolhouse since they returned from harpers ferry	938.4815692955439
5502. kate felt she	had deserted the boy in her own loss	754.6526561485367
5503. she loved him and missed his company	94.06032693626271
5504. uncle randolph had been riding out every evening on some	secret business of his own	1649.8155464946078
5505. what it was kate could not fathom	93.90856291239714
5506. he	claimed to be visiting the waterfront saloon at the crossroads to play	cards and drink with his cronies but kate had not smelled brandy	on him since mrs lattimer's funeral	5005.385306497953
5507. joel knew what he was about	however	93.4915584952695
5508. you're gonna get caught she heard joel	say to uncle randolph by the pump one morning	1897.8922408435333
5509. not this old	fox chuckled uncle randolph	94.15513806887745
5510. everybody knows i'm just	a harmless deaf old man who takes to drink	1181.6407372669162
5511. i aim to keep a little whisky	still back in the ridge for my pleasure	1098.417818720342
5512. whisky still	my foot said joel	65.12488921929295
5513. you're back there riding with the	guerrillas the moccasin rangers	374.77123422965616
5514. hush said uncle	randolph smiling or i'll give you another black eye	960.1207406949663
5515. he	patted the eye joel had had blackened in a fight over being rebel at	the crossroads some days back	1891.8133259740011
5516. kate had no idea what they were	talking of although she had seen the blue lights and strange fires	burning and winking on the ridges at night had heard horsemen on the	river road and hill trails through the nights till dawn	6589.041541441225
5517. stranger	uncle randolph began riding home nights with a jug strapped to his saddle	drunkenly singing old dan tucker at the top of his voice	2600.0536518814147
5518. hearing his voice ring raucously up from the road kate would await	him anxiously and watch perplexed as he walked into the house cold	sober	3927.8492257582816
5519. what he was about became clear to her with the circulation of	another broadside proclamation by general mcclellan threatening	reprisals against rebel guerrillas	2318.7717264125595
5520. she was taken up in worry for the	reckless old man	749.993276541457
5521. kate drew more and more on her affection for	joel through the hot days of summer work	1418.916973193623
5522. she had taken him out of	the schoolhouse and closed the school for the summer after she saw	miss snow crack joel across the face with a ruler for letting a snake	loose in the schoolroom	5787.8007533273585
5523. kate had walked past the school on her morning	chores and had seen the whole incident had seen joel's burning	humiliation before miss snow's cold bespectacled wrath	2865.411983194816
5524. he had	the hardest pains of growing before him now as he approached twelve	1410.995284681891
5525. these would be his hardest years she knew and he missed his father	desperately	939.3863201806198
5526. she tried to find some way to draw him out to	help him	1179.5987381796435
5527. whenever she found time she went blackberry picking with	him and they would come home together mouths purple arms and faces	scratched tired enough to forget grief for another day	3216.787305645731
5528. he tended the	new	colts beau had sired	250.78946848393585
5529. he helped kate and juanita enlarge the flower	garden in the side yard where they sometimes sat in the still evenings	watching the last fat bees working against the summer's purple dusk	3449.5380122561
5530. no one went much to the crossroads now except uncle randolph	754.0993872902962
5531. they stayed in their own world on the bluff waiting for letters	and the peddler bringing	the news	1585.6592233998535
5532. jonathan wrote grimly of the destruction	of harpers ferry before they abandoned it; of their first	engagement at falling waters after old jack's first brigade	had destroyed all the rolling stock of the b+o railroad	5626.328570389922
5533. the men	were restive he wrote ready to take the battle to the enemy as jackson	wished	1422.413180169558
5534. the peddler came bawling his wares and told them	of the convention in wheeling which had formed a new state government	by declaring the government at richmond in the east illegal because	they were traitors	5635.002948760063
5535. dangling his gaudy trinkets before them he told	of the rebel losses in the mountains at cheat and rich mountains	both and the federal march on beverly	2872.1556787898426
5536. cleaned all them	rebs out'n the hills they did! they won't never git over inter	loyal western virginia them traitors! the federals is making	everybody take the oath of loyalty around these parts too he crowed	5780.313572963619
5537. after he had gone kate asked uncle randolph proudly would	you take their oath	942.6832358567244
5538. and the old man had given a	sly and wicked laugh and said hell yes! i think i've taken	it about fifty times already! winking at joel's look of shock	4842.742328229957
5539. her mother wrote kate of her grief at the death of kate's	baby and at jonathan's decision to go with the south and dear	kate she wrote poor dr breckenridge's son robert	is now organizing a militia company to go south to his good father's	sorrow	4675.228634898931
5540. maj anderson of fort sumter is home and recruiting volunteers	for the us army	1412.8190275093093
5541. in spite of the fact that the state	legislature voted us neutral john hunt morgan is openly flying	the confederate flag over his woolen factory!   rumor of a	big battle spread like a grassfire up the valley	3963.7341865775284
5542. accounts were garbled	at the telegraph office when they sent old george down to parkersburg	for the news	2364.0337906876766
5543. all dey know down dere is it were at manassas	junction and it were a big fight the old man told them	2168.4861149690396
5544. in the next few days they had cause to rejoice	556.7429771147107
5545. it had been	a big battle and the confederate forces had won	647.0441447007535
5546. jonathan and ben	were not on the lists of the dead or on that of the missing	2117.0538658685637
5547. kate and	mrs tussle waited for letters anxiously	166.45951719877047
5548. joel went to the crest	of a hill behind the house and lit an enormous victory bonfire to celebrate	2596.8298274711506
5549. when kate hurried in alarm to tell him to put it out she	saw other dots of flames among the western virginia hills from the few	scattered fires of the faithful	3333.3761158491457
5550. they all prayed now that the north	would realize that peace must come for virginia had defended her land	victoriously	2813.05086059299
5551. the week after manassas the sound of horses	in the yard brought kate up in shock from an afternoon's rest when	she saw the federal soldiers from her upstairs window	3235.769354575409
5552. they had already	lost most of their corn she thought	558.4416239264406
5553. were they to be insulted again	because of the south's great victory	642.0207207357889
5554. she remembered mcclellan's	last proclamation as she hurried fearfully down the stairs	969.4652910628147
5555. at the landing she saw juanita her face flushed pink with excitement	run down the hall from the kitchen to the front door	2335.6354335612614
5556. juanita	stopped just inside the open door her hand to her mouth	952.2023475865519
5557. as kate	came swiftly down the stairs to the hall she saw colonel marsh framed	in the doorway his face set in the same vulnerable look juanita wore	2990.76223631782
5558. kate greeted him gravely uneasy with misgivings at his visit	558.0490747556124
5559. what brings you here again colonel marsh	93.67661750024662
5560. she asked	taking him and juanita into the parlor where the shutters were closed	against the afternoon sun	2365.551555787123
5561. i stopped to say goodbye mrs	lattimer and to tell you how sorry i was to hear about your baby	1875.4778877265096
5562. i wish our doctor could have saved her	249.56407041446428
5563. it was a terrible	loss to me said kate quietly feeling the pain twist again	at the mention knowing now that juanita must have written to him at	grafton	3090.7037604683856
5564. where will you go now that you're leaving parkersburg	391.5101626390598
5565. she asked him seeing juanita's eyes grow bleak	166.97201379753568

5568. i am to go to washington to serve with him	560.7389253629547
5569. when are you to leave	14.678263946765705
5570. kate asked watching them both	now anxiously	140.8035006711033
5571. their eyes betrayed too much of their emotions she	thought sadly	499.4675257236604

5574. it would be better for joel and uncle randolph and	mrs tussle not to see them	1888.1912746982337
5575. kate went back and reminded	the kitchen women of the supper preparations	644.1403799543534

5578. she sought kate out upstairs	her lips trembling	248.11252065180116
5579. he wants me to go with him tomorrow	she told kate	499.96137284099103
5580. what do you want to do	65.0841553533678
5581. kate asked	uneasy at the gravity of the girl's dilemma	376.78987432126803

6793. there was never a doubt	any more how his structures would be received; it was always the same	unqualified success now	2022.9075374362678

6795. stowey rummel was internationally famous a crafter of a genuine	americana in foreign eyes an original designer whose inventive	childishness with steel and concrete was made even more believably sincere	by his personality	3561.7177917140752
6796. he had lived for almost thirty years in this	same stone farmhouse with the same wife a remarkably childish thing	in itself; he rose at half-past six every morning made himself some	french coffee had his corn flakes and more coffee smoked four cigarettes	while reading last sunday's herald tribune and yesterday's	pittsburgh gazette then put on his high-topped farmer's	shoes and walked under a vine bower to his workshop	0.30166232349522504
6797. this was an enormously	long building whose walls were made of rocks some of them brought	home from every continent during his six years as an oil geologist	2982.381406383694
6798. the debris of his other careers was piled everywhere; a pile of	wire cages for mice from his time as a geneticist and a microscope lying	on its side on the window sill vertical steel columns wired for support	to the open ceiling beams with spidery steel cantilevers jutting	out into the air masonry constructions on the floor from the time he	was inventing his disastrous fireplace whose smoke would pass through	a whole house visible all the way up through wire gratings on each	floor	0.30166232349522504
6799. his files desk drafting board and a high stool formed the only	clean island in the chaos	1426.655108135087
6800. everywhere else his ideas lay or hung in	visible form: his models drawings ten-foot canvases in monochromes	from his painting days and underfoot a windfall of broken-backed books	that looked as though their insides had been ransacked by a maniac	6360.681146463752
6801. bicycle gear-sets he had once used as the basis of the design for	the camden cycly company plant hung on a rope in one corner and over	his desk next to several old and dusty hats was a clean pair of roller	skates which he occasionally used up and down in front of his house	5279.000470411507
6802. he worked standing with his left hand in his pocket as though he	were merely stopping for a moment sketching with the surprised stare	of one who was watching another person's hand	5120.83627489398

6816. he had a deep	voice which was full of good food she had cooked and good humor;	an explosive laugh which always carried everything before it	4081.846770981293
6817. he would	settle himself into his seat to laugh	260.50073403553415
6818. whenever he laughed it was	all he was doing	390.02833197118485
6819. and she was made to fall in love with him again there	in the rutted dirt driveway standing in the cold fog mad as she was	at his going away when he really didn't have to mad at their both	having got older in a life that seemed to have taken no more than a	week to go by	5470.818740987875
6820. she was forty-nine at this time a lanky woman of breeding	with an austere narrow face which had the distinction of a steeple	or some architecture that had been designed long ago for a stubborn	sort of prayer	6093.982722251886
6821. her eyebrows were definite and heavy and formed two	lines moving upward toward a high forehead and a great head of brown hair	that fell to her shoulders	2982.3073241574843
6822. there was an air of blindness in her	gray eyes the startled-horse look that ultimately comes to some women	who are born at the end of an ancestral line long since divorced from	money-making and which besides has kept its estate intact	6570.332826618513
6823. she was	personally sloppy and when she had colds would blow her nose in the	same handkerchief all day and keep it soaking wet dangling from her	waist and when she gardened she would eat dinner with dirt on her calves	4289.341087849114
6824. but just when she seemed to have sunk into some depravity of peasanthood	she would disappear and come down bathed brushed and taking	breaths of air and even with her broken nails her hands would come to	rest on a table or a leaf with a thoughtless delicacy a grace of history	so to speak and for an instant one saw how ferociously proud she	was and adamant on certain questions of personal value	0.30166232349522504
6825. she even spoke	differently when she was clean and she was clean now for his departure	and her voice clear and rather sharp	2321.1284454445527
6826. now drive carefully	for god's sake! she called trying to attain a half humorous	resentment at his departure	2344.677358693759
6827. but he did not notice and was already	backing the car down to the road saying toot-toot! to the	stump of a tree as he passed it the same stump which had impaled the	car of many a guest in the past thirty years and which he refused to	have removed	5041.71780447699
6828. she stood clutching her shawl around her shoulders until	he had swung the car onto the road	2127.31663248095
6829. then when he had it pointed	down the hill he stopped to gaze at her through the window	1574.0444352712252
6830. she had	begun to turn back toward the house but his look caught her and she stood	still waiting there for what his expression indicated would be	a	serious word of farewell	5143.297448778507
6831. he looked at her out of himself she thought	as he did only for an instant at a time the look which always surprised	her even now when his uncombable hair was yellowing a little and	his breath came hard through his nicotine-choked lungs the look of the	gaunt youth she had suddenly found herself staring at in the tate	gallery on a thursday once	5740.24711998999
6832. now she kept herself protectively ready	to laugh again and sure enough he pointed at her with his index finger	and said toot! once more and roared off into the fog his foot	evidently surprising him with the suddenness with which it pressed	the accelerator just as his hand did when he worked	7707.008811461106
6833. she walked back	to the house and entered feeling herself returning sensing some kind	of opportunity in the empty building	1880.5113569146718
6834. there is a death in all partings	she knew and promptly put it out of her mind	2105.987639875476
6835. she enjoyed	great parties when she would sit up talking and dancing and drinking	all night but it always seemed to her that being alone especially	alone in her house was the realest part of life	3853.2509286491345
6836. now she could let out	the three parakeets without fear they would be stepped on or that stowey	would let them out one of the doors; she could dust the plants	then break off suddenly and pick up an old novel and read from the	middle	on; improvise cha-chas on the harp; and finally the best part of	all simply sit at the plank table in the kitchen with a bottle of wine	and the newspapers reading the ads as well as the news registering	nothing on her mind but letting her soul suspend itself above all wishing	and desire	0.30166232349522504
6837. she did this now comfortably aware of the mist running	down the windows of the silence outside of the dark afternoon	it was getting to be	2731.502092706923
6838. she fell asleep leaning on her hand hearing the	house creaking as though it were a living a private life of its own	these two hundred years hearing the birds rustling in their cages and	the occasional whirring of wings as one of them landed on the table and	walked across the newspaper to perch in the crook of her arm	8364.870757352885
6839. every	few minutes she would awaken for a moment to review things: stowey	yes was on his way south and the two boys were away in school and	nothing was burning on the stove and lucretia was coming for dinner	and bringing three guests of hers	4678.946294815653
6840. then she fell asleep again as soddenly	as a person with fever and when she awoke it was dark outside	and the clarity was back in her eyes	4471.945060931581
6841. she stood up smoothing her hair	down straightening her clothes feeling a thankfulness for the enveloping	darkness outside and above everything else for the absence of	the need to answer to respond to be aware even of stowey coming in	or going out and yet now that she was beginning to cook she glimpsed	a future without him a future alone like this and the pain made her	head writhe and in a moment she found it hard to wait for lucretia	to come with her guests	0.20124717349522497
6842. she went into the living room and turned on	three lamps then back into the kitchen where she turned on the ceiling	light and the switch that lit the floods on the barn illuminating	the driveway	5845.954726141042
6843. she knew she was feeling afraid and inwardly laughed at	herself	505.18019065315656
6844. they were both so young after all so unready for any final	parting	1183.065400922322
6845. how could it have been thirty years already she wondered	374.27414390507084
6846. but yes nineteen plus thirty was forty-nine and she was forty-nine	and she had been married at nineteen	2346.617321696708
6847. she stood still over the leg	of lamb rubbing herbs into it quite suddenly conscious of a nausea	in her stomach and a feeling of wrath a sensation of violence that started	her shivering	3638.7604532111204
6848. but they all said no your time will come	391.5786976595904
6849. enjoy being a	bride while you can	94.41170669697021
6850. there was no room for company in the	tiny weaning house		390.92054963485623
6851. so when the	big house filled up and ran over the sisters-in-law found beds for	everyone in their own homes	1888.1129178429383
6852. and there was still not anything that linda	kay could do	749.5214803310794
6853. so linda kay gave up asking and accepted	her reprieve	374.1711431777061
6854. without saying so she was really grateful; for to	attend the dying was something she had never experienced and certainly	had not imagined when she thought of the duties she would have as bobby	joe's wife	5779.7138112909915
6855. she had made curtains for all the windows of her	little house and she had kept it spotless and neat shabby as it was	and cooked good meals for bobby joe	3327.957999331539
6856. she had done all the things she	had promised herself she would do but she had not thought of this	2821.688399114985
6857. people died she would have said in hospitals or in cars on the highway	at night	1262.5480136715819
6858. bobby joe was gone all day now not coming in	for dinner and sometimes not for supper	2110.5176657959473
6859. when they first married he	had been working in the fields all day and she would get in the car and	drive to wherever he was working to take him a fresh hot meal	3664.198326233699
6860. now	there was no work in the fields nor would there be till it rained	and she did not know where he went	3483.9429038880344
6861. not that she complained or had any	cause to	262.44966884620527
6862. four or five of the cousins from east texas were about	his age so naturally they ran around together	2592.190488346459
6863. there was no reason	for her to ask what they did	494.1966220598523
6864. thus a new pattern of days began	to develop for granny albright did not die	1631.1854338186226
6865. she lay still on the	bed her head hardly denting the pillow; sometimes she opened her eyes	and looked around and sometimes she took a little milk or soup	3123.320868593907
6866. they	stopped expecting her to die the next minute but only in the next	day or two	2121.1978168043092
6867. those who had driven hundreds of miles for the burial would	not go home for she might die any time; but they might as well	unpack their suitcases for she might linger on	3549.7697033972167
6868. so the pattern	was established	22.223822033046776
6869. when linda kay had put up her breakfast dishes	and mopped her linoleum rugs she would go to the big house	2047.4872526896477
6870. there	was not anything she could do there but that was where everyone was	or would be	2121.0675225513287
6871. bobby joe and the boys would come by say how's granny	502.24222027779024
6872. and sit on the porch a while	141.24241832462752
6873. the older men would be there	at noon and maybe rest for a time before they took their guns off	to the creek or drove down the road towards town	3231.43830367922
6874. the women and	children stayed at the albrights'	251.60767032077166
6875. the women keeping their voices	low as they worked around the house or sat in the living room sounded	like chickens shut up in a coop for the night	3126.5358091208536
6876. the children had to	play away from the house	to maintain a proper quietness	1407.2848374711286
6877. off and on all day someone	would be wiping at the powdery gray dust that settled over everything	1577.2440615718044
6878. the evaporative cooler had been moved to granny's room and	her door was kept shut; so that the rest of the house stayed open	though there was a question as to whether it was hotter or cooler that	way	6181.571430508137
6879. the dust clogged their throats and the heat parched them	so that the women were always making ice water	1729.7673345074315
6880. they had cleaned	up an old ice box and begun to buy fifty-pound blocks of ice in town	as the electric refrigerator came nowhere near providing enough ice for	the crowds who ate and drank there	5754.403259576963
6881. one afternoon as the women	sat clucking softly a new carload of people pulled up at the gate	1573.303903920319
6882. it was a cadillac black grayed with the dust of the road its windows	closed tight so you knew that the people who climbed out of it would	be cool and unwrinkled	5175.6550822165345
6883. they were an old fat couple	a thick middle-aged man and a girl about	ten or twelve	1423.0805015015737
6884. there was much embracing much exclaiming	64.9426127250234
6885. cousin	ada! cousin john! cousin lura! cousin	howard! and how is she	642.3464430169338
6886. about the same john	about	the same	141.50745270039718
6887. all the women got up and offered their chairs and	when they were all seated again the guests made their inquiries and	their explanations	2466.729801162874
6888. we were on our vacation in canada	howard explained in a muffled voice that must have been used to booming	and the news didn't catch up with us till we were nearly home	5310.354499427136
6889. we came on as soon as we could	167.86970545061766
6890. there was the suggestion	of ice water and- in spite of the protest we're not really	thirsty- linda kay to escape the stuffy air and the smothering	soft voices hurried to the kitchen	5303.526541049911
6891. she filled a big pitcher	and set it with glasses on a tray	789.7522882249583
6892. carrying it to the living room	she imagined the picture she made: tall and roundly slim a bit sophisticated	in her yellow sheath with a graceful swingy walk that she	had learned as a twirler with the school band	6231.758358216597
6893. almost immediately she	was ashamed of herself for feeling vain at such a time in such a	place and she tossed back her long yellow hair smiling shyly as she	entered the room	3542.16496294654
6894. howard was looking	at her	22.071585985653865
6895. she felt the look and looked back because she could not help	it seeing that he was neither as old nor as thick as she had at first	believed	3120.832710338583
6896. and who is this	4.409196561168942

6898. oh that's linda kay mama albright	said fondly	249.8325622332195
