6900. let's see cousin ada said	22.110905902964888
6901. he's a right smart	younger than the rest	168.22528803707056
6902. oh yes mama laughed	4.444178073004935
6903. he's	ten years younger than ernest	43.59999641706428
6904. we didn't expect him to come	along; thought for the longest he was a tumor	1648.7181180878154
6905. this joke	was not funny to linda kay and she blushed as she always did;	then hearing the muffled boom of howard's laughter blushed redder	2594.3703220379616
6906. who is howard anyway	4.4586896282693935
6907. she asked bobby joe that	night	43.50813581910553
6908. oh he's a second	cousin or something	141.01619344574388
6909. he got in the oil business out at odessa and	lucked into some money	945.5932389553451
6910. how old is he	4.433244068775883
6911. gosh	i don't know	2.962337103120379
6912. he's been married and	got this half-grown kid	250.5610561867755
6913. if he bothers you don't pay him any mind	262.57430570402346
6914. he's just a big windbag	22.316542201267517
6915. bobby joe was thinking about something	else	94.14160620020554
6916. say did you know they're fixing to have a two-day antelope	season on the double x	1884.8825132461527
6917. he was talking about antelope	again when they woke up	372.7854637471947
6918. listen i never had a chance to	kill an antelope	563.7558706336051
6919. there never was a season before but now they want	to thin 'em out on account of the drouth	1714.1187438927573
6920. did he ever	visit here when he was a kid	562.8566712248903
6921. linda kay asked	0.20041515
6922. when he	was a kid i wasn't around	252.39189568015303
6923. bobby joe took a gun from behind	the door and with a quick bye now was gone for the day	1889.5706719282894
6924. almost immediately howard and his daughter debora drove up in	the cadillac	961.0600935322784
6925. we're going after ice howard said	and	thought maybe you'd go along and keep us company	1256.3453659989807
6926. there	was really no reason to refuse and linda kay had never ridden in	a cadillac	1877.9350176276944
6927. driving along the caliche-topped road to town howard	talked	261.6286733243218
6928. finally he said tell me about yourself and linda	kay told him because she thought herself that she had had an interesting	life	3478.978031294093
6929. she was such a well-rounded teenager having been a twirler	future farmers sweetheart and secretary of future homemakers	1574.112452536423
6930. in her sophomore year she had started going steady with bobby joe	who was a football player future homemakers sweetheart and president	of future farmers	3871.7781552270744
6931. it was easy to see that they were made for	each other and they knew what they wanted	1556.6485863648968
6932. bobby joe would be a senior	this year and he planned to graduate	1187.1748215624732
6933. but there was no need for	linda kay to go on since all she wanted in life was to make a home	for bobby joe and raise his children	3095.478326116863
6934. you lucky kids he said	22.189643826883902

6936. then he told linda kay about himself	140.19429592624073
6937. of course he couldn't say much really because of debora but	linda kay could imagine what kind of woman his wife had been and	what a raw deal he had got	3337.0714613858736
6938. it made her feel different about howard	140.89923440669546
6939. she was going to tell bobby joe about how mistaken she had	been but he brought one of the cousins home for supper and all they	did was talk about antelope	3318.880192908114

6941. cook	a whole antelope	2.942393411437914
6942. she exclaimed	0.30041514999999996
6943. why i couldn't even cook	a piece of antelope steak; i never even saw any	1098.2655072307318
6944. i want to roast the whole thing and have it for the boys	1189.6528486068992
6945. linda kay told him he couldn't do anything like that	with his grandma dying and he said well they had to eat didn't	they they weren't all dying	2978.6537819205137
6946. linda kay felt like going off to the	bedroom to cry; but they were going up to the big house after supper	and she had to put on a clean dress and fix her hair a little	5925.356974558765
6947. every night they all went to mama and papa albright's and	sat on the open front porch where they could get the breeze	2332.193109654658
6948. it was	full-of-the-moon and nearly light as day	253.33914128283897

6952. bobby joe and two or three of the	other boys declared they had never been possum-hunting and uncle bill	farnworth said he would	just get	up from there and take them right then	5333.538674390539
6953. after they	had left some of the people moved around to find more comfortable places	to sit	1417.155090664238
6954. there were not many chairs so that some preferred to sit	on the edge of the porch resting their feet on the ground and others	liked to sit where they could lean back against the wall	5813.977695314219

6961. he had become the center of the	company such stories he had to tell	941.3382217665991

6963. but tell me doctor where do you plan to conduct the hatching	646.2200853622342
6964. alex asked	0.30041514999999996
6965. that will have to be in the hotel	the doctor retorted confirming alex's anticipations	941.5665927475229
6966. what i	want you to do is to go to the market with me early tomorrow morning	and help smuggle the hen back into the hotel	4116.348536241342
6967. the doctor paid	the bill and they repaired to the hotel room number nine to initiate	alex further into these undertakings	2029.4028546668644
6968. the doctor opened	the smallest of his cases an unimposing straw bag and exposed the contents	for alex's inspection	2599.1766408621243
6969. inside carefully packed in straw	were six eggs but the eye of a poultry psychologist was required to detect	what scientifically valuable specimentalia lay inside; to alex	they were merely six not unusual hens' eggs	3732.329292956917
6970. there was little enough	time to contemplate them however; in an instant the doctor was stalking	across the room with an antique ledger in his hands thoroughly	eared and big as a table top	5452.10578523615
6971. he placed it on alex's lap	43.442200874056326
6972. this is my hen ledger he informed him in an absorbed way	962.8650287597578
6973. it's	been going since 1908 when i was a junior in college	639.2754519624949
6974. that first	entry there is the vermont flumenophobe the earliest and one of	the most successful of my eighty-three varieties- great big scapulars	and hardly any primaries at all	4652.764254470936
6975. couldn't take them near a river	though or they'd squawk like a turkey cock the day before thanksgiving	1581.369367243839
6976. the ledger was full of most precise information:	date of laying length of incubation period number of chicks reaching	the first week second week fifth week weight of hen size of rooster's	wattles and so on all scrawled out in a hand that looked more	chinese than english the most jagged and sprawling alex had ever seen	8011.1901705260625
6977. below these particulars was a series of alpha-beta-gammas connected	by arrows and crosses which denoted the lineage of the breed	1879.6481943312604
6978. alex's	instruction was rapid for the doctor had to go off to the rue	ecole de medecine to hear more speeches with only time for one sip	of wine to sustain him through them all	5632.940016744851
6979. but after the doctor's return	that night alex could see from the high window in his own room	the now familiar figure crouched on a truly impressive heap of towels	apparently giving its egg-hatching powers one final chance before it	was replaced in its office by a sure-enough hen	4917.600276980147
6980. a knocking at	alex's door roused him at six o'clock the following morning	1185.6536154230437
6981. it	was the doctor dressed and ready for the expedition to the market and	alex was obliged to prepare himself in haste	2171.5988610709737
6982. the doctor stood about	waiting for alex to dress with a show of impatience and soon they	were moving as quietly as could be through the still-dark hallways	past the bedroom of the patronne and so into the street	6202.6648465902545
6983. the	market was not far and once there the doctor's sense of immediacy	left him and he fell into a state of harmony with the birds around him	2992.622109812125
6984. he stroked the hens and they responded with delighted clucks he gobbled	with the turkeys and they at once were all attention he quacked	with the ducks and cackled with a pair of exceedingly flattered geese	5777.504677434141
6985. the dawn progressed and it seemed that the doctor would never be	done with his ministrations when quite abruptly something broke his revery	2312.420212229585
6986. it was a fine broody hen white with a maternal eye and a striking	abundance of feathers in the under region of the abdomen	3705.7783081129396
6987. the doctor	with the air of a man whose professional interests have found scope	drew alex's attention to those excellences which might otherwise	have escaped him: the fine color in comb and wattles the length and	quality of neck and saddle hackles the firm wide spread of the	toes and a rare justness in the formation of the ear lappets	5515.481084091215
6988. all search	was ended; he had found his fowl	392.2801461106943

6998. their hostess enquired	0.30041514999999996
6999. alex told her that	there was no hurry for their breakfasts trying at the same time to	effect a speedy separation of the persons before and behind him	2983.9008174021983
7000. the	doctor he noticed was attempting a transverse movement towards the stairs	but before the movement could be completed a distinct and audible	cluck ruffled the air in the hollow of the stair-well	5349.178264249042
7001. eyes swerved	in the patronne's head alex coughed loudly and the doctor	with a sforzando of chicken noises floating behind him took to the stairs	in long-shanked leaps	2989.3770695148773

7009. the spectacle progressed towards a denouement which	was obviously still remote; the audience attended	943.7424408028488

7013. it was giselle the fille de	chambre come to clean the room and while she stood before him with	ears pricked up and regard all curiosity explaining her errand alex	could see from the corner of his eye the doctor doing all he could	to calm the displeased bird	4903.002808306585
7014. giselle was reluctant but alex succeeded	in persuading her to come back in five minutes and the door was shut	again	3029.4457826301914
7015. who was that young feller	15.01332911070688
7016. the doctor instantly	asked	4.407785960195587
7017. that was the fille de chambre the one you thought	couldn't get the eggs out	1101.6645124852132
7018. she looked mighty interested though	22.334602956661094
7019. anyhow she's coming back in five minutes to do the room	504.99671063891503
7020. the doctor's mind was working at a great speed; he rose to put	his greatcoat on and addressed alex in a muted voice	3498.0771451727
7021. have	you got our keys handy	43.19273815212365
7022. right in my pocket	4.4433774786859646
7023. now you go outside and beckon me when it's safe	371.2799657693812
7024. the hall was empty and alex beckoned; they climbed the stairs	which creaked very loudly to their sensitive ears and reached the next	floor	3715.2827398849413
7025. a guest was locking his room; they passed behind him and	got to alex's room unnoticed	1255.9709359380668
7026. the doctor sat down rather wearily	caressing the hen and remarking that the city was not the place for a	poultry-loving man but no sooner was the remark out than a knock at this	door obliged him to cover the hen with his greatcoat once more	7038.382123564617
7027. at	the door alex managed to persuade the increasingly astonished fille	de chambre to return in ten minutes	1567.445930163951
7028. it was evident that a second	transfer had to be effected and that it had to take place between the	time the fille finished the doctor's room and the time she began	alex's	5338.374750004547
7029. they waited three minutes and then crept out on tip-toe;	the halls were empty and they passed down the stairs to number nine	and listened at the door	2978.2285130886103
7030. a bustle of sheets being smoothed and pillows	being arranged indicated the fille de chambre's presence inside;	they listened and suddenly a step towards the door announced	another important fact	4828.471316126534
7031. the doctor shot down to the lavatory and turned	the doorknob but to no effect: the lavatory was occupied	1740.3729208422858
7032. although	a look of alarm passed over his face he did not arrest his movements	but disappeared into the shower room just as the chambermaid emerged	from number nine	4662.4821422822015
7033. alex suppressed those expressions of relief which	offered to prevail in his face and escape from his throat; unwarranted	they were in any case for as he stood facing the fille de chambre	his ears were assailed by new sounds from the interior of the shower	room	4735.424572511095
7034. the events of the last quarter of an hour mysterious to	any bird accustomed only to the predictable life of coop and barnyard	had overcome the doctor's hen and she gave out a series of cackly wails	perhaps mourning her nest but briefly enjoyed	6802.975770734131
7035. the doctor's	wits had not left him however for all his sixty-eight years and the	wails were almost immediately lost in the sound of water rushing out	from the showerhead	3214.877865053809
7036. alex nodded to the maid as though nothing unusual	were taking place and entered the doctor's room	2133.621354145304
7037. shortly the doctor	himself entered his hair somewhat wet from the shower but evidently	satisfied with the outcome of their adventures	2031.1479066958716
7038. without comment he	opened the closet and from its shelves constructed a highboard around	the egg case which he had placed on the floor inside	3909.3158717801184
7039. next the hen	was nested and all seemed well	260.2754600268154
7040. the two men sat for some time savoring	the pleasure of escape from peril and the relief such escape brings	before they got up and left the hotel the doctor to go to the conference	house and alex to go to the main post office	6932.510599378504
7041. alex returned	to the hotel rather weary and with no new prospects of a role	in the late afternoon but found the doctor in an ebullient mood	2856.862615573019
7042. at	the time alex arrived he was engaged in some sort of intimate communication	with the hen who had settled herself on the nest most peacefully	after the occurrences of the morning	5175.982989329281
7043. chickens have short	memories the doctor remarked that's why they are better company	than most people i know and he went on to break some important	news to alex	3093.4576170934515
7044. well he began it seems like some people	in paris want to hear more from me than those fellers over at the conference	house do	3904.022549390029
7045. they've got a big vulture from tanganika at the	zoo here with a wife for him too very rare birds both of them the	only vulturidae of their species outside africa	3345.576673834797
7046. seems like	she's	willing but the male just flops around all day like the bashful boy	who took jeannie may behind the barn and then didn't know what to	do and the people at the zoo haven't got any vulture chicks to show	for their trouble	7046.2757768054
7047. going downstairs with the tray winston wished he could have	given in to miss ada but he knew better than to do what she said when	she had that little-girl look	3335.9925876161665
7048. there were times it wasn't right	to make a person happy like the times she came in the kitchen and asked	for a peanut butter sandwich	4105.593112261921
7049. you know we don't keep peanut butter	in this house he always told her	935.0354195955395
7050. why winston she'd	cry i just now saw you eating it out of the jar! but he	knew how important it was for her to keep her figure	4436.120393409362
7051. in the	kitchen leona his little young wife was reading the morning paper	790.7600252716186
7052. her legs hung down long and thin as she sat on the high stool	1419.734989627364
7053. here winston said gently what's these dishes doing not	washed	375.53852823502103
7054. the enormous plates which had held mr jack's four	fried eggs and five strips of bacon were still stacked in the sink	3259.9081189571234
7055. leave me alone leona said	14.775868206819037

7061. she had an alley cat's manners	43.96498073457536

7071. she turned and	put her arms around his neck	261.8047235702206
7072. i don't want to leave here winston	139.88399052044363

7098. winston!   it was mr	jack bellowing out in the hall	559.0438490366739

7120. for the first time he	let himself be sad about the move	958.884279987981
7121. that house was ten years off his life	167.5886642422678
7122. each brass handle and hinge shone for his reward and he knew how	to get at the dust in the china flowers and how to take down the long	glass drops which hung from the chandelier	5771.254759396632
7123. he knew the house like	a blind man through his fingers and he did not like to think of all	the time and rags and polishes he had spent on keeping it up	3545.020326022389
7124. ten years	ago he had come to the house to be interviewed	959.4693859868272
7125. the tulips and the	big pink peonies had been blooming along the drive and he had walked	up from the bus almost singing	2355.76061079551

7198. was it love	0.30041514999999996
7199. i had no doubt that it was	92.5637570650282
7200. during the rest of the summer	my scholarly mania for making plaster casts and spatter prints of	catskill flowers and leaves was all but surpassed by the constantly	renewed impressions of jessica that my mind served up to me for contemplation	and delight	6672.444697184171
7201. nothing in all the preceding years had	had the power to bring me closer to a knowledge of profound sorrow than	the breakup of camp the packing away of my camp uniforms the severing	of ties with the six or ten people i had grown most to love in the	world	5037.802823194528
7202. in final separation from them in the railroad terminal across	the river from new york i would nearly cry	2598.3905646124117
7203. my parents' welcoming	arms would seem woeful inadequate unwanted	263.42078983326587
7204. but that year was	different for just as the city in the form of my street clothes had	intruded upon my mountain nights so an essential part of the summer	gave promise of continuing into the fall: jessica and i about to	be separated not by a mere footbridge or messhall kitchen but by the	immense obstacle of residing in cruelly distant boroughs had agreed	to correspond	8747.133462707028
7205. these letters became the center of my existence	166.3059304345796
7206. i lived to see an envelope of hers in the morning mail and to lock	myself in my room in the afternoon to reread her letter for the tenth	time and finally prepare an answer	5625.543025070073
7207. my memory has catalogued for easy	reference and withdrawal the image of her pink scented stationery and	the unsloped almost printed configurations of her neat studious handwriting	with which she invited me to recall our summer so many sentences	beginning with remember when h; and others concerning	camp friends who resided in her suburban neighborhood and news of her	commencing again her piano lessons her private school a visit to	boston to see her grandparents and an uncle who was a surgeon returned	on furlough wounded from the war in europe	0.20124717349522497
7208. in my letters	i took on a personality that differed from the self i knew in real	life	2359.0660474037613
7209. then epistolatory me was a foreign correspondent dispatching exciting	cables and communiques full of dash and wit and glamor quoting	from the books i read imitating the grand styles of the authors recommended	by a teacher in whose special after-school class i was enrolled	4546.9468510036
7210. the letters took their source from a stream of my imagination	in which i was transformed into a young man not unlike my bunkmate eliot	sands- he of the porch steps anecdotes- who smoked cigarettes	performed the tango wore fifty dollar suits and sneaked off into	the dark with girls to do unimaginable things with them	8000.949971791039
7211. like eliot	in my fantasies i had a proud bearing and with a skill that was vaguely	continental i would lead jessica through an evening of dancing	and handsome descriptions of my newest exploits would guide her gently	to the night's climax which in my dreams was always represented	by our almost suffocating one another to death with deep moist kisses	burning with love	5709.733259608654
7212. the night after reading her letter about her surgeon	uncle- it must have been late in september- i had a vision	of myself returned in ragged uniform from the front nearly dying	my head bandaged and blooded and jessica bending over me the power	of her love bringing me back to life	7611.568009374818
7213. for many nights afterward the	idea of her having been so close to me in that imagined bed would return	and fill me with obscure and painful desires would cause me to lie	awake in shame tossing with irresolution longing to fall into a deep	sleep	4665.030303886613
7214. the weeks went by and the longer our separation grew	the more unbounded and almost unbearable my fantasies became	2600.7079582094248
7215. they	caused my love for jessica to become warmer and at the same time more	hopeless as if my adolescent self knew that only torment would ever	bring me the courage to ask to see her again	3944.8751616467684
7216. as it turned out	jessica took matters	into her own hands	749.4038337750908
7217. having received permission	to give a camp reunion-halloween party she asked that i come and	be her date	1565.9502199591802
7218. i went and mum and nervous all but made a fool of myself	1183.1443395562944
7219. again among those jubilantly reunited bunkmates i was shy with	jessie and acted as i had during those early saturday mornings when	we all seemed to be playing for effect to be detached and unconcerned	with the girls who were properly our dates but about whom later in	the privacy of our bunks we would think in terms of the most elaborate	romance	5632.5198971970085
7220. i remember standing in a corner watching jessica act the	hostess serving soft drinks to her guests	2119.646078151254
7221. she was wearing her dark	hair in two thick braids to attain an american girl effect	she thought was appropriate to halloween	2170.6347011493094
7222. it made her look sweet and	schoolgirlish i was excited to be with her but i did not know how	to express it	3452.252125319038
7223. yet a moment did come that night when the adventurous	letter writer and fantasist seemed to stride off my flashy pages out	of my mind and plant himself in reality	3223.8788248404303
7224. it was late we were playing	kissing games and jessica and i were called on to kiss in front	of the others	3248.7578308283805
7225. we blushed and were flustered and it turned out to	be the fleetest brush of lips upon cheek	1556.8750688470964
7226. the kiss outraged our friends	but it was done and meanwhile had released in me all the remote exciting	premonitions of lust all the mysterious sensations that i had	imagined a truly consummated kiss would convey to me	6052.918273474405
7227. it was	at that party that finally overcoming my timidity inspired by tales	only half-understood and overheard among older boys i asked jessie	to spend new year's eve with me	3204.6112604766
7228. lovingly she accepted and so	great was my emotion that all i could think of saying was you're	amazing you know	3038.0818002756105
7229. later we agreed to think of how we wished	to spend that night	784.7981710375735
7230. we would write to one another and make a definite	plan	756.0284211295436
7231. among my school and neighborhood	friends during the next months i bragged and swaggered and	pompously described my impending date	1885.5649652283275
7232. but though i boasted and gave	off a dapper front i was beneath it all frightened	1884.5434350764176
7233. it would be the	first time i had ever been completely alone with a girl i loved	1427.0472590981697
7234. i had no idea of what subjects one discussed when alone with a girl	or how one behaved: should i hold her hand while walking or only	when crossing the street	5012.133196058453
7235. should i bring along a corsage or send	one to her	504.4563597628069
7236. was it preferable to meet her at home or in the city	960.3999121109607
7237. should i accompany her to the door of her home or should i ask to	be invited in	1564.129436825528
7238. in or out should i kiss her goodnight	250.56427928262048
7239. all this	was unknown to me and yet i had dared to ask her out for the most	important night of the year!   when in one letter jessica informed	me that her father did not like the idea of her going out alone	on new year's eve i knew for a moment an immense relief; but	the letter went on: she had cried she had implored she had been miserable	at his refusal and finally he had relented- and now how happy	she was how expectant!   her optimism gave me heart	0.20124717349522497

7766. a foolish thought came into	his head	141.94868580318877
7767. he remembered a story he had read as a youth	375.58129249225595
7768. it was probably	one of kipling's tales of the british army	756.6636448314432
7769. it concerned an officer	who had been disgraced and drummed out	502.02688655814734
7770. the steady roll of the drums	had sounded behind him as he walked between the endless ranks of	the men he had commanded and each man about-faced and turned his back	as the officer approached	5682.32737485912
7771. marty wished these poor farm people would	turn their backs	373.8028435582934
7772. the fencing by the roadside ended	65.28981279969466
7773. now the	dirt highway was bordered on either side by a fairly deep drainage ditch	too broad to leap over unless you were an olympic star	2724.7987998651124
7774. the day's	rain had been added to the stagnant water	563.3008745261351
7775. he was trapped on the	road when he heard the sound of an approaching car	1105.3423002722784
7776. it was coming toward	him	22.40933720130241
7777. the car was now in sight	43.66924804319654
7778. marty's heart skipped a beat when	he recognized it	390.1570887685964
7779. it was the station wagon that had passed his cab	on the road the station wagon that had been parked at the burch farm	2462.561071378007
7780. it had headed back toward jarrodsville	65.21681495053288
7781. that had only been a ruse to lure him out on the deserted road	946.2093330578131
7782. now acey and his friends were returning to seek him out	749.4178336742772
7783. the station wagon came to a stop a couple of hundred feet in front of	him beside a fenced field	1883.8291813595254
7784. then there was another sound	22.179848504908808
7785. a second	car was coming from the west from the direction of sanford's run	949.8774889306624
7786. it was the ford that had been outside burch's farm	559.3575742358727
7787. marty	looked helplessly in both directions	43.62608183255509
7788. it was a narrow road barely	wide enough for two cars to pass	1179.3211795011175
7789. he could not leave the road because	of the water-filled drainage ditch	641.1075046934614
7790. when the two cars were equidistant	from him the station wagon started up again and the ford gathered	speed	2595.9436607673674
7791. they bore down on him	14.897944004184541
7792. there was nothing he could do except	jump into the ditch	761.6234080675097
7793. he jumped and sank to his knees in muddy	water	372.848080676525
7794. as the two cars roared by there was a high-pitched eerie	nerve-shattering sound	1181.6032143157922
7795. marty knew how the union soldiers must	have felt at chancellorsville and antietam and gettysburg when the	ragged gray ranks charged at them screaming the wild banshee howl they	called the rebel yell	3544.0482865549434
7796. for moments he stood in water shivering	and gasping for breath	748.6991221879878
7797. he had turned his ankle slightly and it	pained him	373.797290922355
7798. the cars with their load of howling men had disappeared	in the distance	1184.0159496045842
7799. there had been two more cars parked at the farm	a plymouth and a pickup truck	1267.028346543054
7800. they would be coming for him next bearing	down on him from both directions	1423.8754719098542
7801. and then the station wagon and	the ford would seek him out again	787.7333489113514
7802. he would be harassed repeatedly	and would escape death by inches time after time all the way to jarrodsville	2574.0317448464675
7803. he still had three miles to go	94.00293209027038
7804. back east the more affluent	juvenile delinquents who could afford hyped-up autos instead of	switch blades as lethal weapons played this same game and called it	chicken	4283.429868198645
7805. he could not go through the fields	94.3736565248899
7806. that way	was barred on both sides of the road by a high barbed-wire fence	1660.2804968357734
7807. he	had to make for the section of road just ahead that was bordered by the	rail fence the section by the farmhouse	2321.2695273358195
7808. at least he could climb	up on the fence when his tormenters roared by again	1647.081656708266
7809. the admassy place	could not be far now	166.71413201036475
7810. he would go in there climb through the window	and at least be safe for a little while and able to rest	3252.7666573972374
7811. there	was even a bare chance that the phone had not been disconnected	788.8710568796189
7812. he did not dare climb back up to the road	564.4880912173313
7813. he was deep in water but	at least they could not reach him there	936.7011222678626
7814. he splashed on mud sucking	at his feet with each step until he reached the end of the drainage	ditch and the beginning of the fence that enclosed the farm	4832.416193025404
7815. he climbed	back to the road and he felt utterly exhausted	505.3153805746862
7816. he stood panting	for a moment	65.03222192496638
7817. and then he saw something that he had not seen before	and panic gripped him again	1260.4323400497074
7818. the fence his only refuge when	the metal death came roaring at him was made of rails all right	but the rails were protected by a thick screening of barbed wire that	would rip his flesh if he pressed against it	6423.298623748752
7819. he lurched on down the	road despairingly because there was no place else to go	1104.5711814540498
7820. he lost	all sense of dignity	65.33301992566922
7821. you could not stand on dignity when you were	soaked and muddied and your life was at stake	1566.9467526899568
7822. probably people were	watching him from the porch or from behind the windows of this farmhouse	too but he did not bother to look	3703.2985925455746
7823. he broke into a dogtrot breathing	heavily streaming with sweat	378.8144343906768
7824. he had to reach admassy's place	65.66634242929817
7825. it was his only sanctuary	14.97525878174432
7826. the fences on both sides of the road	bristled with the barbed wire	1179.7288211340879

7831. they had timed it better this time	92.95443084072427
7832. they would reach him at almost	exactly the same instant	560.0215604442545
7833. if he backed	against the fence one of the cars would brush him as it passed and he	would be cruelly lacerated by the wire	2606.621720201065
7834. he stumbled to the middle	of the road and simply stood there waiting for them a perfect	target	2355.619021512833
7835. the cars must have had their gas pedals pushed down to	the floor boards	944.2044608569659
7836. they were coming on at reckless speed for such old	vehicles	750.2906147220872
7837. he held his arms close to his sides	and made himself as small as possible	1099.3049524531868
7838. when the plymouth neared it	veered toward him and seemed about to run him down	1650.1764144660665
7839. he forced himself	to stay frozen there	93.59317838357597
7840. if he moved he would be in the path of the	other car	1187.3423395104514
7841. he thought the fender of the plymouth brushed his jacket	as it went by	935.0135290112536
7842. in a fraction of a second the pickup truck hurtled by	on the other side	1650.2660191434675

7844. he did not	leave the middle of the road	393.54863858512306

8023. after a moment he extended one	hand the fingers curled	374.03245294108643
8024. you want	to be that big a fool- i was hoping for this	1178.3488932324944
8025. roberts	brushed at his eyes with his free hand and started down the steps	946.3860962862512
8026. he	held the razor well out to one side	390.5135854046033
8027. he was invulnerable to attack	but he could be handled mickey knew if he could be brought to make	the first move	2170.0967616233793
8028. they were eight feet apart when roberts cleared	the last step	757.1422002022788
8029. mickey waited with slack arms	14.79742879302039
8030. any time	roberts he said	22.189643826883902
8031. or would it be easier if i put my hands in	my pockets	789.0393627995401
8032. the taunt was lost on roberts	64.85091351824576
8033. he advanced	slowly directly giving no hint of a feint to either side	785.5099754571985
8034. he was	just short of arm's reach when he stopped	557.2403830220568
8035. mickey backed off two steps	forcing him to come on again	502.98341649385327
8036. there was a fixed grin on roberts'	face made hideous by the swollen nose and the smeared blood	2360.672919917365
8037. mickey backed off again and roberts hesitated then came along	373.91427764174
8038. they moved in a series of rhythmic fits and starts a macabre dance-	two steps back two steps forward two steps back	3293.67342387798
8039. mickey felt his shoulders	come up against the wall beside the heavy slab front door	1097.1887901385594
8040. this	was going to be it now any second and what he had to remember was	to keep his eye on the razor no matter what even if roberts should	feint with a kick to the groin the deadly hand was his exclusive concern	6807.605806354104
8041. the kick came sudden and vicious but short	166.37392751119359
8042. mickey's	guts twisted with the effort but he kept his eye on the weapon	1421.0553564765926
8043. it	moved in a silver arc toward his throat then veered downward	641.466578277268
8044. he hunched	his left shoulder into it and slashed at roberts' forearm with	his own felt the blade slide off his sleeve	3265.7466002279807
8045. before roberts could	move inside to cut upward toward his face he slammed his right fist into	roberts' belly	1721.464007643942
8046. roberts sagged and slashed at him wildly	141.14825305309225
8047. ducking	mickey tripped and fell to one side landing heavily on the wood	floor	944.2793902426052
8048. then roberts was on him gasping for breath and for a couple	of seconds mickey lost sight of the blade	2809.1618629962604
8049. he felt it rip at the side	of his jacket and a momentary sting under his left ribs	1573.1624980201846
8050. he got a	knee up into roberts' belly used both hands and heaved him clear	then scrambled to his feet	2826.7162060401038
8051. they were in the center of the lobby now	262.275269244628
8052. still clutching the razor roberts came up into a crouch shaking	his head	1184.056533328204
8053. when he charged mickey was ready	43.23276433014474
8054. he hit roberts with his	left fist in the ribs and the razor cut toward him feebly then wobbled	in mid-air	3051.98281160436
8055. with his right fist and nearly all his weight behind	it he smashed at the bloodstained face	1415.321460093217
8056. roberts careened backward	his back arched fought for balance and failing stumbled against	the newel post at the foot of the stairs	3275.0032822116927
8057. the sound of his head striking	the solid wood was an ultimate sudden-end sound	947.1871237939922
8058. he fell on	his side across the lowest step rolled over once then lay still	1641.1252842050471
8059. mickey found himself leaning against the desk with stiff hands	panting for breath	785.9853550197628
8060. after a minute he went to roberts looked at one	of his eyes and felt for a pulse	2362.275463291274
8061. roberts appeared	to be dead; if not yet then soon very soon	637.4860935162926
8062. suddenly it was	cold in the lobby	140.07885309433115
8063. it seemed to him that a long time	had passed before he decided what to do	1255.933533642726
8064. actually it was no more than	eight or ten minutes and the sum of his reasoning came to this:	there's no way to take him in now and keep those other two-	wister and the one who hired the two of them- from finding out about	roberts and lamming out	7411.502044528572
8065. the local law here would hold me till they	check clear back home and maybe more than that	1576.516088551279
8066. by then they could never catch up with the others	565.4363342455641
8067. there's no other	way; i'll have to do it myself	373.8617494609238
8068. he looked at where roberts	lay sprawled on the step	564.1924915985219
8069. mickey was sure now he was dead	94.06579812693693
8070. one thing he thought nobody knows about it yet	391.33288695257943
8071. he climbed the stairs went into roberts' room found a suitcase	and	packed as much into it as he could	1893.1839019123968
8072. he left a few things	22.13575877935976
8073. it didn't	have to be perfect	43.17817743660429
8074. walking away on impulse	he might logically leave behind what it was inconvenient to carry	1631.1408467860267
8075. when he had closed the suitcase he found a rag and moved about	the room wiping carefully everything he might have touched	2192.5976161943486
8076. it took	him nearly an hour	65.84160782355637
8077. he went to the room he had rented and got into	his overcoat	794.4712381542046
8078. he left the rest of his things and returned to the lobby	955.3818253869509
8079. he set roberts' suitcase near the front door went outside and	walked back to the garage	1261.591381850629
8080. he was mildly surprised to find it was snowing	388.52891221095024
8081. it snowed softly silently an undulating interruption of his vision	against the night sky	947.2260052231732
8082. he could feel it on his face and in his	hair	751.932055027801
8083. he found the key to the jeep got it started and warmed	it up for five minutes	1411.1497921793518
8084. then he backed out and swung around to the front	drive	756.9154708523462
8085. he went into the hotel and searched till he found the razor	647.0020762838558
8086. he put it in his own pocket for safekeeping	394.4498048764931
8087. he took the suitcase	out to the jeep and put it in the front seat	1096.0585848825826
8088. then he went back for	roberts	65.24002864212801
8089. the body was heavier than he had anticipated	168.6328001014636
8090. he	got it onto his shoulder after some work and carried it outside and down	to the jeep	2367.035004079536
8091. he dumped it into the back and made sure it wouldn't	roll out then returned to the porch and closed the front door making	sure it was unlocked	2981.989772250569
8092. he drove carefully in the direction	of the brief tour they had taken earlier	1412.9292866111562
8093. it snowed continuously but	quietly evenly	43.36196704104675
8094. when he reached the dip in the woods he saw that	already the earlier ruts were barely discernible	2354.2272033874997
8095. the jeep fought its	way through the low spot and got onto higher ground	939.4665416745056
8096. he drove in low	gear to the fork in the road and swung as close as possible to the entrance	to the abandoned mine	3708.6314660922594
8097. he parked facing it and left the headlights	on but when he started into the tunnel with the suitcase he found	the illumination extended no farther than half a dozen feet into the	passage	3673.8204925328328
8098. he went back and got the flashlight returned to the tunnel	and carried the suitcase to the edge of the pit he had found earlier	3911.282188514914
8099. he tossed the bag into the pit and watched dry dust spray up around	it	1111.021208021022
8100. when the dust settled he went back to the jeep and carefully	worked roberts' body onto his shoulder	2367.6047460451573
8101. it wasn't like carrying	the suitcase	43.83489250491936
8102. the soft snow was deceitful underfoot	64.81033167660966
8103. inside the passage he had to work his way over the fallen	timber and nearly collapsed under his clumsy burden	1887.3030570448796
8104. by the time	he reached the edge of the pit he was panting and his shoulder and back	ached under the drag of the dead weight	4114.435609964368
8105. he stood looking down	for a few seconds then backed up two or three paces from the edge	1573.207389499212
8106. there was too much weight casually to toss it away	559.6210418620587
8107. he could feel	himself falling in with it and being unable to get out	931.1881674514214

8113. he was shaking with tension	and it took him a couple of minutes to get his breath and settle down	1871.734596949429

8115. it hung momentarily on the point of dropping off	261.21017532436974

8117. he got	to his feet and threw the flashlight beam into the pit	793.3460641685348

8119. there was little chance	anyone would enter this shaft during the winter	636.5704101298495
8120. the external signs of	his approach to it would be covered by the snow probably by the next	day	2588.5281425275166
8121. it wasn't cold enough in the tunnel to preserve the body intact	639.3570506572192

8123. he made his way back to	the jeep	166.93699114745806

8144. gulf springs was ten miles inland- more of a quaint old	coast town than those along the beach made garish by tourist attractions	3481.1373462224137

9319. garth was prepared to be helpful in what he referred to with	fastidious distaste as this unfortunate johnston affair which would	not he said more than once have ever come about if mrs meeker	had only seen fit to consult mr hohlbein or him about it	4689.932392424132
9320. madden regretted not being able to find fault with so true a statement	1178.8048992568617
9321. he asked to see a copy of mrs meeker's will	376.57020972572326
9322. the date october 8 1957 immediately caught	the inspector's eye	563.1820533006661
9323. was she	in the habit of making new wills	259.9148039201981
9324. oh no	0.30041514999999996
9325. she had reason	to change the one she made right after mr meeker's death	946.9592685707746
9326. her	estate had grown considerably	22.114026753558754
9327. she wanted to make a more equitable	distribution of it among the groups that would benefit the most; particularly	the scholarship fund	2183.327401810954

10067. diana beauclerk was a second-rate actress living	in new york	375.87731557679973

10069. daniel forbes her divorced husband lived there	93.10710603488685

10074. according to stacy	she told him she was planning to remarry and she wanted him to ask forbes	for the lump sum	3261.6837627671152

10871. another	obstacle was the grammatical construction of siddo	167.73286618592266
10872. instead of inflecting a verb or using an unattached	particle to indicate the past or future siddo used an entirely different	word	3295.440977401014
10873. thus the masculine animate infinitive dabhumaksanigalu'ahai	meaning to live was in the perfect tense ksu'u'peli'afo	and in the future mai'teipa	1879.6030222426896
10874. the same use of	an entirely different word applied for all the other tenses	1403.6577064987991

10876. fortunately gender was inflected though the expression	of it would be difficult for anybody not born in siddo	2353.1107452210094
10877. the system	of indicating gender varied according to tense	263.7070509661849
10878. all the other	parts of speech: nouns pronouns adjectives adverbs and conjunctions	operated under the same system as the verbs	2821.5272033484407

11352. we all know what the dummies	will do- he gestured at the hummocks in which the decorticated	men were cradled- and we all know what the new people will ask	4824.145413298296
11353. but we never know how long a scene is going to take	639.4856021755679
11354. what's	a 'scene'	0.30041514999999996
11355. asked mercer	0.20041515
11356. is that the name for the	needle	141.1351761759207
11357. the half-man laughed with something close to real	humor	262.8884591735289
11358. you've got the lovelies on the brain	141.00716968454782
11359. a	scene is just a part of a play	262.50598113612904
11360. i mean we know the order in which things	happen but we have no clocks and nobody cares enough to count days	or to make calendars and there's not much climate here so none of	us know how long anything takes	6429.069423562663
11361. the pain seems short and the pleasure	seems long	261.3351602696821
11362. i'm inclined to think that they are about two earth-weeks	each	750.7401940068008
11363. mercer did not know what an earth-week	was since he had not been a well-read man before his conviction but	he got nothing more from the half-man at that time	3228.848302250742
11364. the half-man received	a dromozootic implant turned red in the face shouted senselessly	at mercer take it out you fool! take it out of me!	when mercer looked on helplessly the half-man twisted over on	his side his pink dusty back turned to mercer and wept hoarsely and	quietly to himself	7514.792619518892
11365. mercer himself could not tell how long it	was before b'dikkat came back	782.5478528507981
11366. it might have been several days	65.08849704656268
11367. it might have been several months	43.428410607617465
11368. once again b'dikkat moved	among them like a father; once again they clustered like children	1652.2514979569482
11369. this time b'dikkat smiled pleasantly at the little head which had	grown out of mercer's thigh- a sleeping child's head covered	with light hair on top and with dainty eyebrows over the resting eyes	3656.5419385777327
11370. mercer got the blissful needle	22.07547270716756
11371. when b'dikkat cut the head	from mercer's thigh he felt the knife grinding against the cartilage	which held the head	to his own body	2477.8691025021544
11372. he saw the child-face grimace	as the head was cut; he felt the far cool flash of unimportant pain	as b'dikkat dabbed the wound with a corrosive antiseptic which	stopped all bleeding immediately	5324.681367504016
11373. the next time it was two legs	growing from his chest	501.9049765393852
11374. then there had been another head beside	his own	392.7651879456572
11375. or was that after the torso and legs waist to toe-tips	of the little girl which had grown from his side	2039.9799659695443
11376. he	forgot the order	4.436636673283453
11377. he did not count time	14.80815603070466
11378. lady da smiled	at him often but there was no love in this place	1408.0046920462607
11379. she had lost	the extra torsos	43.86726160442693
11380. in between teratologies she was a pretty and shapely	woman; but the nicest thing about their relationship was her whisper	to him repeated some thousands of time repeated with smiles and	hope people never live forever	5762.56518942796
11381. she found this immensely	comforting even though mercer did not make much sense out of it	1250.2244359626159
11382. thus events occurred and victims changed in appearance and	new ones arrived	959.7006111266592
11383. sometimes b'dikkat took the new ones resting in	the everlasting sleep of their burned-out brains in a ground-truck	to be added to other herds	2464.5945888561896
11384. the bodies in the truck threshed and bawled	without human speech when the dromozoa struck them	1892.1475629292308
11385. finally	mercer did manage to follow b'dikkat to the door of the cabin	786.099918815688
11386. he	had to fight the bliss of super-condamine to do it	751.6648530383534
11387. only the memory	of previous hurt bewilderment and perplexity made him sure that if	he did not ask b'dikkat when he mercer was happy the answer would	no longer be available when he needed it	3751.5437576837735
11388. fighting pleasure itself	he begged b'dikkat to check the records and to tell him how long	he had been there	2820.805414280273
11389. b'dikkat grudgingly agreed but he did not	come out of the doorway	637.0476671273987
11390. he spoke through the public address box built	into the cabin and his gigantic voice roared out over the empty plain	so that the pink herd of talking people stirred gently in their	happiness and wondered what their friend b'dikkat might be wanting	to tell them	7018.4752746440545
11391. when he said it they thought it exceedingly profound	though none of them understood it since it was simply the amount of time	that mercer had been on shayol:   standard years- eighty-four	years seven months three days two hours eleven and one	half minutes	4509.090274275029
11392. mercer turned away	0.30041514999999996
11393. the secret little corner of his mind which stayed sane through happiness	and pain made him wonder about b'dikkat	1737.300328309031
11394. what persuaded the	cow-man to remain on shayol	249.77715688790636
11395. what kept him happy without super-condamine	43.68571623906656
11396. was b'dikkat a crazy slave to his own duty or was he a	man who had hopes of going back to his own planet some day surrounded	by a family of little cow-people resembling himself	5637.2563811748
11397. mercer despite	his happiness wept a little at the strange fate of b'dikkat	789.8949433340559

11399. he remembered the last time he had eaten-	actual eggs from an actual pan	951.1437280250078
11400. the dromozoa kept him alive	but he did not know how they did it	1399.0160493069975
11401. he staggered back to the	group	43.58024827005669

11404. the years if they were years went by	248.3686461084962
11405. the land of shayol did not	change	93.19641975646397
11406. sometimes the bubbling sound of geysers came faintly across	the plain to the herd of men; those who could talk declared it	to be the breathing of captain alvarez	4622.434516266711
11407. there was night and day but	no setting of crops no change of	season no generations of men	1563.7806278017492
11408. time	stood still for these people and their load of pleasure was so commingled	with the shocks and pains of the dromozoa that the words of the	lady da took on very remote meaning	5492.875674489275
11409. her statement was a hope not a truth in which they	could believe	793.0154709577446
11410. they did not have the wit to follow the stars in their	courses to exchange names with each other to harvest the experience	of each for the wisdom of all	4820.716606892985
11411. there was no dream of escape for these	people	260.4170253177891

11413. far long ago some	other prisoner than one of these had tried to write a letter	1260.6187471490246
11414. his	handwriting was on a rock	65.88040761476839
11415. mercer read it and so had a few of the others	but they could not tell which man had done it	2031.3090441108084
11416. the letter scraped on stone had been a message home	562.8305851613407
11417. they	could still read the opening: once i was like you stepping	out of my window at the end of day and letting the winds blow me gently	toward the place i lived in	3667.486721941373

11421. dan morgan told himself he would forget ann turner	262.2490413705252

11423. he certainly didn't want a wife who was fickle	as ann	498.9070524953884

11431. each day he found	himself thinking less often of ann; each day the hurt was a little	duller a little less poignant	2170.488362509506
11432. he had plenty of work to do	141.22760503216728
11433. because the summer was unusually dry and hot the spring produced a	smaller stream than in ordinary years	1582.653834417139
11434. the grass in the meadows came	fast now that the warm weather was here	1405.4103902463844
11435. he could not afford to lose	a drop of the precious water so he spent most of his waking hours along	the ditches in his meadows	2734.5195087409775
11436. he had no idea how much time	budd would give him	748.5624264214827

11438. he stopped	every few minutes and leaned on his shovel as he studied the horizon	but nothing happened each day dragging out with monotonous calm	3891.4890203377713
11439. when in late afternoon on the last day in june he saw two	people top the ridge to the south and walk toward the house he quit work	immediately and strode to his rifle	3688.4715398662556
11440. it could be some kind of trick	budd had thought up	748.9846297835651
11441. no one walked in this country least of all	ed dow or dutch renfro or any of the rest of the bar b crew	2454.786871619496

11616. when he had finished he led him and	the mare to the porch	1187.8499933395235
11617. the stallion had smelled the mare coming into	heat and began to paw the turf shaking his head	1578.1872464847606
11618. clayton looped the	reins in a	knot over the veranda post and patted the warm flesh of his	neck	2592.542522744297
11619. the mare had backed away	14.75298362575442
11620. you take it easy boy clayton	whispered	141.11276521604537
11621. she doesn't want you now	14.959922767102602
11622. you take it easy your time	will come	251.01779842433538
11623. gavin stood on the porch a thin figure	168.09693202999716
11624. he	had taken a carbine down from the wall and it trailed from his hand	the stock bumping on the wood floor	3281.4581678374825
11625. clayton called to him and he came	slowly down the steps	507.69338634261595
11626. clay he said where are we	goin	140.51219820512
11627. to a ranch in the valley	43.41732141093761
11628. there's someone there	i have to see	140.48752791706391
11629. we may take her with us- to california	166.19618983293222
11630. i don't	know yet it's crazy; i have to think about it	956.3820022413247
11631. but california	is where we're goin	43.21463875599242
11632. that's a new land	4.450326513144499
11633. a man could make a mark there	93.21841496495645
11634. two men	together like us we could do somethin fine out there maybe find a	place where no one's ever been	3052.456814234594
11635. start out fresh the two of us like	nothin had ever happened	639.6704376038583
11636. yes like a father and son	64.99014273216046
11637. i made you what you are gavin whispered	167.4067509671708
11638. i made	you so you could stand up	251.9818375561437
11639. i made you a man	14.854067151527255
11640. he approached the horse and laid a hand on the	stallion's quivering neck	1189.5439448881298
11641. help me up i	feel kind of stiff	166.81573100817099
11642. clayton lifted him gently into the saddle like	a child	568.0911673744351
11643. i hate to leave my garden gavin said	167.10487090135214
11644. i loved my garden	4.451057009743788
11645. it will grow again-	in california	43.500200282261105
11646. i loved this valley he whispered	huskily	139.62180456148033
11647. lived alone here for three years before any man came	371.9568792962579
11648. lived	alone by the river	22.212171852432036
11649. it was nice then so peaceful and quiet	167.56149755907592
11650. there	was no one but me	65.14350185890633
11651. i don't want to leave it	42.96231910514444
11652. clayton	swung into the saddle and whacked the stallion's rump	564.913581571838
11653. the two horses	broke from the yard from the circle of light cast by the lamp still	burning in the house into the darkness	2473.223526305416
11654. they	rode at a measured pace through the valley	392.4685009925341
11655. dawn would come soon	and the night was at its coldest	502.0432514164546
11656. the moon had sunk below the black crest	of the mountains and the land seen through eyes that had grown accustomed	to the absence of light looked primeval as if no man had ever	trespassed before	5788.89938906396
11657. it looked as gavin had first seen it years ago	on those nights when he slept alone by his campfire and waked suddenly	to the hoot of an owl or the rustle of a blade of grass in the moon's	wind- a savage land untenanted and brooding too strong to be	broken by the will of men	5372.6652636822255
11658. in that inert landscape	the caravan of his desires passed before his mind	1183.1309434838731
11659. he saw them	ambushed strewn in the postures of the broken and the dying	947.8491275661647
11660. in vain	his mind groped to reassemble the bones of the relationships he had	sought so desperately but they would not come to life	3691.1560699828246
11661. the silence oppressed	him made him bend low over the horse's neck as if to hide	from a wind that had begun to blow far away and was twisting slowly through	the darkness in its slow search	3966.2362973175213
11662. they passed ranches that	were framed dark gray against the black hills	956.7177780824471
11663. then at last the darkness	began to dissolve	167.2797225871008
11664. a bold line of violet broke loose from the	high ridge of the mountains followed by feathers of red that swept the	last stars from the sky	4295.938228701688
11665. the wan light spread over the ground and the	valley revealed in the first glimmer the contours of trees and fences	and palely shadowed gullies	2606.6550691418042
11666. they had been seen as soon	as they left the ranch picked out of the darkness by the weary though	watchful eyes of two men posted a few hundred yards away in the windless	shelter of the trees	6048.721360393769
11667. the two men whipped their horses into town	and flung themselves up the steps of the saloon crying their intelligence	1895.8358174745092
11668. the men in pettigrew's were tired from a night's	drinking their faces red and baggy	1644.423643140982
11669. but the liquor had flushed their	courage	94.78899556687932
11670. they greeted the news angrily as though they had been cheated	of purpose	1184.3468175523412
11671. lester heard their muttering saw their eyes reveal their	desire	375.2332191956444
11672. he worked his tongue round and round in the hollow of his	cheek and his voice came out of his throat dry and cracked	3700.342992650564
11673. that's what you wanted isn't it	43.53832356786456
11674. clayton is with	him takin him out of the valley	559.4039628807528
11675. you can't-   keep out	of this purvis snarled	164.60054711083188
11676. he's not your brother he's gavin's	son	139.46137312881984
11677. you see he lied to us when he said he was leavin alone	786.1133536467117
11678. joe purvis was thinking back many years	141.97324240417547
11679. first he thought of	the time he had ridden to gavin and told him how his cattle were being	rustled at the far end of the valley	2848.9441473751062
11680. he remembered gavin's smirk	his own cringing feeling his impotence	563.1257504821641
11681. then he thought of a time	when clayton's horse had fallen lame in the gap	1102.4227013300394
11682. his wife had	said to him: nellie is in love with clayton roy	1185.2015660836373
11683. he wouldn't	even dance with her at gavin's party	259.24731617452494
11684. he treats her like she was	dirt	140.8734957797141
11685. and you stand by like a fool and let him do it h   he	remembered clayton's mocking smile in the saloon when he had asked	him what he would do if they brought their cattle to water	3978.1662781975406
11686. it was	the night clayton had tricked them in the poker game	964.2630752052246
11687. you're gavin's	son joe purvis had said	93.48184517750308
11688. you brought him back to this valley thinkin he would help you find	your boy	1643.0732508488131
11689. he meant to help gavin all the time	167.35043623097405
11690. he made a fool of	you lester	140.2203069241512
11691. he swung round to the other men- we can catch	him easy! there are plenty of fresh horses halfway at my place	2185.093225130834
11692. if	we let them go they won't stay away they'll find men to ride with	them and they'll be back	2813.654068198963
11693. there's only one way they can get out	now and that's through the gap- if we ride hard we can take them	2165.492043403515
11694. lester's hand fluttered to cabot's shoulder	65.17525574518707
11695. he killed tom- do you understand that	94.61668441500113
11696. cabot turned back to the men and he was drunk with the thing they	would do wild to break from the cloying warmth of the saloon into the	cold of the ebbing night	5354.963943158524
11697. he fled through the door and down the steps	running and the men grunted and followed pushing lester to one	side where he backed against the wall with the sleeve of his jacket raised	before his eyes to shut out the light	4389.909966707099
11698. purvis and silas pettigrew	were the last to leave	388.3299662123367
11699. they mounted up and rode slowly behind the	others at a safe distance	791.9840137904608
11700. in the cold dawn	the mist swirled low to the ground then rose with a gust of sudden wind	to leave the valley clear	3684.7534466033967
11701. the clouds parted and hard gashes of sunlight	swooped down to stain the earth with streaks of white and gold	light so that the shadows of the running horses flowed like dark streams	over the dazzling snow	3965.650502080681
11702. when they turned in the saddle they could	see the men behind them strung out on the prairie in a flat black line	3469.462803213355
11703. the wind of their running was cold and wild the horses were lathered	and their manes streamed like stiff black pennants in the wind	2462.2967159768846
11704. the mare began to tire and clayton felt the spray of snow from	the hoofs of gavin's stallion	2355.467617664829
11705. he looked over his shoulder at the	thin dotting of pursuers	503.65512529172776
11706. they neither gained nor fell back	65.10120164186847
11707. he rode	low on the mare's neck	94.60941934741047
11708. ahead of him gavin turned slightly off the	trail and pointed for the gap no more than a mile away	2842.964379214056
11709. gavin's	face was bloodless with excitement	43.23409838825624
11710. he did not look back; he	could feel more than hear the staccato beat of hoofs that fanned out	across the prairie to the north	3884.383710267768
11711. he knew who was riding after him-	the men he had known all his life the men who had worked for him sworn	their loyalty to him	2860.6889533392687
11712. now they were riding to kill him	141.35072667459778
11713. and he was	fleeing running- fleeing his death and his life at the same time	1097.9321196081323
11714. the land over which he sped was the land he had created and lived in:	his valley	2124.398108449457
11715. with every leaping stride of the horse beneath him he	crossed one more patch of earth that had been his that he would never	see again	2732.217154465952
11716. the gap looming before him- the place where had confronted	jack english on that day so many years ago- was his exit from	all that had meaning to him	4675.129537336996
11717. california is too far he thought	43.270142541759206
11718. he would never reach california	22.33959266126975
11719. he was too old- when he passed	up and through the corridor of pines that lined the trail he could	see ahead he was passing from life	2860.2260444673398
11720. the sentry was not dead	22.2332633649981
11721. he was in fact showing signs of	reviving	166.2185170079115
11722. he had been carrying an enfield rifle and a holstered navy cap-and-ball	pistol	1197.2944642804368
11723. a bayonet hung in a belt scabbard	93.98997214981405
11724. he was partially	uniformed in a cavalry tunic and hat	565.1651848096195
11725. mike stripped these from him	and donned them	168.30902619700433
11726. he and dean tied and gagged the man using his belt	and shirt for the purpose	1888.0474230485997
11727. they dragged him inside the building	43.44928379632955
11728. fiske joined them unsteady on his feet	139.81040243114916
11729. julia seeing the bandage	rushed to him	94.07939243884091
11730. you are hurt! she breathed	22.27917993128893
11731. i	never felt better in my life fiske blustered	261.82865274904384
11732. he turned	to susan and kissed her on the cheek	559.1279791654076
11733. thank you my dear	he	said	43.22245645246005
11734. mike silenced them	0.30041514999999996
11735. first we've got to get out of here	164.796390479737
11736. we'll	grab horses dean said	22.203461769834433
11737. the main bunch is outside but	there are some over there inside the wall	941.645615458483
11738. mike debated it	trying to decide whether fiske was strong enough to ride	1170.4645335396901
11739. but it at	least offered him a chance for living	376.0122149381158
11740. and for	the sake of julia and susan it had to be tried	1180.413716038223
11741. the guerrilla	bivouac	remained silent	14.857738567864283
11742. light showed in the orderly room across the	parade ground	562.6159508058581
11743. someone evidently was on duty there	43.414846928079434
11744. no doubt there	would be men guarding the horses	393.9535499869175
11745. about a dozen animals were	held inside the stockade as best mike could make out in the moonlight	1571.6022018157046
11746. evidently this was a precaution so that mounts would be available	in an emergency	1409.4981797627206
11747. he handed the guard's rifle to fiske	93.87604667747162
11748. dean	and myself will try to cut out horses to ride he said	1171.542602570448
11749. you stay with the ladies	14.971003892012567
11750. all of you be ready	to ride hell for leather	556.7676119908261
11751. he added if this doesn't	work out the three of you barricade yourself in the house and talk	terms with them	2026.2885487357057
11752. he handed the bayonet to dean and kept the	pistol	565.2782577361593
11753. susan halted dean and kissed him	43.685901670738836
11754. she clung to him talking	to him and dabbing at her eyes	964.6206763252374
11755. he was	thinking that the way she had responded to his own kiss hadn't meant	what he had believed it had	2038.7291807942845
11756. dean	turned from susan and took julia fortune in his arms	751.7012173806291
11757. he kissed her	also and with deep tenderness	168.27033865403035
11758. she too began to weep	22.084543883123807
11759. he released	her and joined mike	43.70804830566834
11760. mike only said	later	4.392943454241879
11761. be careful mclish! susan said	fiercely	43.37238709879877
11762. the way you were careful	22.202036419792478
11763. he snorted	0.20041515
11764. running	around in the moonlight almost naked and slugging a man with a rock	1411.651615454616
11765. he kept going	0.20041515
11766. he wanted no more sentimental scenes with	her	248.83438355784156
11767. he might say or do something foolish	94.72781442482146
11768. something all of them	would regret	65.50700533346578
11769. he might tell her how sorry a spectacle she was making	of herself pretending to be blind to the way julia fortune had taken	dean's affections from her	2971.47001589264
11770. and using him mike mclish as a	sop to her pride	757.176241155769
11771. he handed the bayonet to dean and kept the	pistol	377.1125617863514
11772. stay well back of me he said	139.26001300480135
11773. i'm going to walk	up to the horses bold as brass pretending i'm one of the guerrillas	1419.4953840165504
11774. there's bound to be someone on guard but the hat might fool them	long enough for me to get close	2804.778983359664
11775. holding the pistol concealed	he walked to the rear wall of the stockade	791.3236910548442
11776. it was pierced by	a wagon gate built of two wings	751.0442653246408
11777. mike passed through	it and moved toward the dark mass of horses	640.3673926722244
11778. they were tethered	army style on stable lines	248.58023637465794
11779. who's	thet	0.20041515
11780. just me mike said	4.41411768167019
11781. is that you	bill	2.9301032784560186
11782. he located his man	4.405484280274534
11783. the guard stood in the shadow	of the stockade wall just out of reach of the moonlight	1409.129526704361
11784. mike kept	walking and got within arm's reach before the man became suspicious	and straightened from his lax slouch	2598.693068848058
11785. mike struck with the muzzle	of the pistol	168.35739227405332
11786. but the luck that had been running their way left	him	751.1817528208558
11787. the guard instinctively parried the blow with his rifle	262.18415893750296
11788. he tried	to veer the rifle around to fire into mike's body	965.7799408446914
11789. mike	off balance managed to bat the muzzle away a moment before it exploded	940.8004776456098
11790. mike swung the pistol in a savage backlash	251.00356772237242
11791. this time it connected solidly on the man's temple felling	him	505.30365827984724
11792. the explosion of the rifle had crashed against the walls	of the stockade and the deep echoes were still rolling in the hills	3493.490129658637
11793. the	startled horses began rearing on their tethers	168.4183188535393
11794. are you hit	0.30041514999999996
11795. he demanded	0.20041515
11796. no but the	fat's in the fire! mike said	391.63975604140535
11797. there's no chance now of all	of us getting away	370.4331152246883
11798. you'll have to try it alone	64.9660273142392
11799. the	sentry's saddled horse stood picketed nearby having been kept handy	in case of need	1091.098428170953
11800. mike took the bayonet from dean's hand and	slashed the picket line	962.3667360388415
11801. up you go! he said	14.803317329407358
11802. ride!	dean resisted mike's attempt to push him toward the horse	757.4188016145781
11803. why not you	0.20041515
11804. he protested	0.30041514999999996
11805. you're lighter than me	2.9297641017805476
11806. it's our only chance now	22.17459640300057
11807. try to find these feds	14.922044817975586
11808. the rest of us can fort up in the house	and hang on until you get back	2124.388950821351
11809. you're the one that's taking the	big chance	168.63832794202366
11810. dean still hesitated but mike lifted him almost	bodily into the saddle and thrust the reins in his hand	2608.483123616843
11811. no	telling how good this horse is mike panted	262.23529898922607
11812. favor him and	save something in case you hit trouble	557.9156960285203
11813. watch out for apaches when	it comes daylight	166.30311373544905
11814. you might need it	4.39894529706599
11815. we'll still	have the rifle and i might be able to round up some more	1103.2617804622625
11816. i'll	stampede the rest of these horses so they can't chase you	966.8878895405154
11817. dean leaned from the saddle and gave him a mighty whack on the back	949.7530435146269
11818. mclish he said as he kicked the horse into motion i'd	be a mighty sad man if we never met again	3058.123690251427
11819. then he was on	his way at a gallop	261.8110731280236
11820. mike ran down the line slashing picket ropes	with the bayonet	753.8332053277691
11821. he lifted a screeching war whoop	43.503565035366435
11822. that touched off	a total stampede	65.69553421414649
11823. he darted inside the stockade and freed the horses	there	378.24980355127525
11824. these poured through the gate and joined the flight	395.6022028412898
11825. the animals	thundered away into the moonlight heading for the ridges	503.99491729255385
11826. the guerrillas were swarming from their bivouac at the west end of the	enclosure	1423.8356785693593
11827. they're	stealin'	the stock!   he scuttled in shadow along the east wall	of the stockade and then followed the south wall until he was at the	rear of the two frame buildings	3447.6936093745157
11828. his shout	had been taken up and repeated	249.39917271470614
11829. the guerrillas were running across	the parade ground and through the rear gate in the wake of the departing	horses	1880.2083316769754
11830. all were carrying guns they had seized up but they were	half-clad or hardly clad at all	2098.937919285271
11831. durkin and calhoun came running	from the post	168.41872805532427
11832. they had pistols in their hands	64.9509928287367
11833. they bawled questions	that were not answered in the uproar	372.3701866729011
11834. they followed the others	toward the east gate	252.579059213853
11835. beyond the stockade rifles began to explode as	some of the guerrillas	fired at shadows that they imagined were apaches	1873.6733311530309
11836. mike made a dash to the rear of the frame buildings	751.2530682733716
11837. he crawled beneath	the two supply wagons which stood between the buildings and peered	around a corner	1427.059501000055
11838. a man was standing in the	open door of the lighted orderly room a few yards to mike's left	but he too suddenly made up his mind and went racing to join the	confused activity at the east end of the stockade	6565.107691261711
11839. mike crawled	to the door and peered in	167.5124037132456
11840. the orderly room seemed to be deserted	139.6515418561593
11841. a lantern hung from a peg giving light	169.11293819075175
11842. ducking inside he found that	three rifles were stacked in a corner	957.3795957255813
11843. a brace of pistols holstered	on belts hung from a peg along with ammunition pouches	1102.9812751881082
11844. an ammunition	case stood open containing canisters which contained powder cartridges	756.5562332329317
11845. mike seized a blanket from a pallet in a corner spread	it on the floor and used it to form a bag in which he placed his booty	2999.029856429209
11846. shouldering the load he peered from the door	252.59142185683604
11847. his looting	of the orderly room had taken only a minute or two and the vicinity	was still clear of guerrillas	2041.6291136114687
11848. he looked at the looming hoods	of the supply wagons struck by a new inspiration	1647.6942889865663
11849. he set his bundle	down	14.833708117922418
11850. snatching the lantern from its peg he shattered its globe with	a blow against a post	1888.8503474137458
11851. he picked up the powder canister and ran out	262.00821242932113
11852. bursting paper cartridges he scattered powder beneath the nearest wagon	and dumped the contents of the canister upon it	2596.815815213468
11853. he shouldered	the blanket again backed off and tossed the lantern with its open	wick beneath the wagon	1573.7673835163084
11854. he turned and raced across the parade ground	toward the rock house	962.3618208109953
11855. powder flame gushed beneath the wagon	43.676587231924984
11856. the stockade was brilliantly lighted and the guerrillas sighted him	563.323807840213
11857. bullets began to snap past him	43.71001134948584
11858. one struck	the muzzle of one of the rifles that projected from the shoulder	pack	1656.1320448681931
11859. its force spun him around but he recovered and got into stride	again	791.1065339471795
11860. a bullet tore the earth from beneath his foot when he	was a stride or two from safety	2370.895385984016
11861. another struck him heavily in the thigh	and he went down	503.79874613356424
11862. guerrillas were racing toward him	22.40933720130241
11863. susan	and julia came from the door and dragged him with them	643.2958447239773
11864. the three	of them floundered through the door into the interior and fell in a heap	1890.1163136093492
11865. susan bounced to her feet and slammed the door	260.1488650353958
11866. she crouched	aside as bullets beat at the portal chewing into the planks	1189.1906199685436
11867. some	tore entirely through the whipsawed post oak	167.15264869345444
11868. the iron hinges held	but the planks were in danger of being torn from the crossbars	1885.8202212725198
11869. mike rolled to susan grasped her around the knees dragging her off	her feet	937.0125234335161
11870. he hovered over her to shield her for spent bullets were	thudding against the rear walls	1856.7625172478697
11871. he peered from a loophole	14.854946520908129
11872. guerrillas	were only a dozen yards away charging the house	565.9026813609585
11873. mike snatched	a pistol from the heap of scattered booty and fired	645.6122587221413
11874. he dropped	a man with the first bullet	251.6205826792347
11875. at the same moment wheeler fiske fired	the rifle mike had given him and another guerrilla was hit	1578.8642917077827
11876. the guerrillas scattered for cover	22.231183439053687
11877. the wagons	were burning fiercely	14.73177047615226
11878. the mudwagon had caught fire also	65.5000850823852
11879. the blaze	was spreading to the frame buildings	167.05333326838516
11880. the guerrillas realized	they faced a new problem	250.71407423277066
11881. there	goes our grub an' ammunition!   get a bucket line	going! calhoun shouted	791.2156743649791
11882. hurry! hurry!   the guerrillas	began a frantic search for pails in which to bring water from	the spring	2363.1777512405497
11883. but what few containers they found were inadequate	165.78067939525482
11884. many	of them in increasing panic came running with water in their hats	in a ludicrous effort	2122.0147547697807
11885. both buildings were in flames	14.813203975723649
11886. the heat drove	the guerrillas back	65.91120327366852
11887. the roof of the command post began to buckle	261.9464375496115
11888. drag the wagons to the spring! lew durkin yelled	390.77872118573737
11889. run	'em right into the spring! hustle!   one of the	wagons erupted a massive pillar of flame	1419.3702778354568
11890. a sizable supply of powder	had been touched off	391.46638805390825
11891. the wagons and the coach were beyond saving and	so were the buildings	790.5526979185213
11892. the glow of the fire reached through the	openings in the windows giving light enough to examine mike's wound	2586.347281179903
11893. the bullet had torn through the flesh just above the knee inflicting	an ugly gash that was forming a pool of blood on the floor	2604.4081749769466
11894. but	it had missed the bone and had passed on through	757.2817812807597
11895. susan and julia	ripped strips from their clothing and bound the injury	645.708829361868
11896. mike tested	the leg and found that he was able to hobble around on it	1639.233948436553

11900. reverend jason looking worried hurried toward us	141.21087571001317
11901. anything	wrong cap'n	0.20041515
11902. the men seem to think so	65.203317475427
11903. dirion found	a large war party south of us	258.7564886546983
11904. they'll probably attack at dawn	montero said	139.80327121936352

11908. they	all flew into action	22.44683502626715
11909. that was a terrible thing to do	i	said to oso	503.0806344054101

11911. and here all	the time you knew the sioux would be using our rifles on them! god	what a world you people live in	2472.357472971037

11917. mr	manuel did that in the war	93.35960009424653
11918. that's why the british never got the	tribes to fight for the king	1188.7655278546238

11921. he did that with all the nations	94.13392683439477

11924. he carried it in a little wallet made	of fish skin	750.0258922669714

11928. first it was	the nations against themselves then it was them against the whites	1410.923208801067

11935. well	talkin' ain't goin' to help- let's fort up!   as	i dug in behind one of the bales we were using as protection i grudgingly	found myself agreeing with oso's logic especially when i imagined	what would have happened to missy if old knife's large party	of screeching warriors had overrun our company	5121.646528562063
11936. for unlike	the sioux and the crows the aricaras are not great horsemen nor	are they aggressive like the savage blackfeet	3052.9011601483185
11937. more of an agricultural	nation they have relied on their warriors only for defense and for	survival in the endless wars of the plains	2471.207304456138

11946. gray eyes attacked our camp just as the first	pink threads stitched together the hills and the sky	2394.373406752619
11947. our camp was	in the center of a wide valley	374.07695994671616
11948. montero had set up a strong position	using every bale and box we had in addition to barricades of logs and	brush	3260.208363962503
11949. he had ordered the ponies brought inside the fortified circle	and had assigned pierre and a band of picked engages the job of trying	to keep them steady under fire	3234.1235344450242
11950. the pony herd was the one	flaw in our defense; the rees undoubtedly would try to cut down as	many of the animals as possible	3914.505817560084
