12174. six hundred and forty acres the old man back in st louis	had said; good grass good water	2354.855671280526
12175. well the grass was there though	in some places the ground was too steep for a cow to get to it	2023.6096837960297
12176. the	water was there so much of it that it spread all through	the dead orchard	1869.2533815758325
12177. and there was a house; livable perhaps but	badly in need of repairs	786.2873351932686
12178. in the last analysis though wilson	had little cause to complain	751.6824375779919
12179. the place had been cheap- just the	little he had left after amelia's burial- and it would serve its	purpose	1883.4496042866322
12180. there was only one place where jake carwood's description	had gone badly awry: the peace and quiet	2139.631410071188
12181. it hadn't started out	that way	42.98289769238595
12182. and he had a feeling- thanks to the girl- that things	would get worse before they got better	2367.568359629316
12183. they had the house cleaned	up by noon and wilson sent the boy out to the meadow to bring	in the horses	2170.914613635216
12184. he stood on the porch and watched him struggling with	the heavy harness and finally went over to help him	2839.351086502837
12185. kathy was already	in the wagon	43.492465613825374
12186. they were going to town and they were both excited	557.7875502086468
12187. wilson backed the team into the traces and wished they weren't	going to town at all	1253.5553856141346
12188. he had an uneasy feeling about it	141.33118953084758
12189. that girl	last night what was her name	166.90273466706668
12190. judith pierce	0.30041514999999996
12191. it was the only	thing about her that was the least bit hard to remember	1093.4891455920622
12192. he finished	with the team and filled his pipe and stood looking about him	1420.5099443980878
12193. he had spent two hours riding around the ranch that morning and in	broad daylight it was even less inviting than judith pierce had made	it seem	2867.593704273963
12194. there was brush and stands of pine that no grass could grow	under and places so steep that cattle wouldn't stop to graze	3474.4985539500326
12195. there was an artificial lake just out of sight in	the first stand of trees fed by a half dozen springs that popped out	of the ground above the hillside orchard	3330.6972097989005
12196. yes there was plenty of water	too much and that was probably the trouble	1407.0163739561074
12197. there were tracks	of cattle all over his six hundred and forty acres	783.2925639943098
12198. the first	part of the road was steep but it leveled off after the second bend and	curled gradually into the valley	3271.9607581588457
12199. it was hotter once they reached	the flat and drier but the grass was better	1092.8901893353748
12200. a warm breeze played across	it moving it like waves	557.8433480369597
12201. a red-tailed hawk flew in behind them	and stayed there watching for any snakes or rabbits that they might	stir up from the side of the road	2846.6497076942546
12202. it took them an hour before they came	to the first houses of kelseyville	1414.72160165167
12203. the town was about what	wilson expected: one main street with its rows of false-fronted	buildings a water tower a few warehouses a single hotel; all dusty	and sunbaked	3105.6323009550065
12204. such was my state of mind that i did not question the possibility	of	this; under the circumstances i was only too willing to confess all	4078.873708036731
12205. i was nearly thirty at the time	93.76141516152909
12206. i went to the hall in the	afternoons only on these preliminary matters	1194.2984392537564
12207. it was dark and i sensed	very large; only the counter at one end was lighted by a long	fluorescent tube suspended directly above it	2586.9103403359486
12208. sometimes i was aware	of people moving about in the darkness	754.1899325360529
12209. i would turn away from my	writing	in the hope of getting a good look at them but i never quite succeeded	2173.2466605768627
12210. a glimpse of three of four vague figures at the most	747.9792996012101
12211. squatting as if waiting	2.9431563073300806
12212. the pulsing glow of	a cigarette	65.18996508279426
12213. since they could see me but i not them their presence	in the hall disturbed me	1252.6971292376845
12214. the clerk paid them no attention	64.95756276286141
12215. this impressed	me until i realized how limited was his sphere of influence	787.7131735514412
12216. his job simply consisted in registering new men	248.89720137509343
12217. when the phone rang	he answered it	93.485112101944
12218. his authority extended to the far edge of the counter	no further	962.8493470579758
12219. none of the men hanging around the hall bothered to speak	to him	791.9784513101023
12220. baldness was attacking his pate	22.088422928200227
12221. he spoke to me in a gruff	voice an affectation which quite belied his personality	1095.5664289746933
12222. he wore	his white shirt open at the neck revealing a bit of scrawny pale chest	underneath	2127.6751727152086
12223. it was obvious that he wished himself different from the	sort of person he thought he was	1413.2892333865661
12224. but it was not easy for him and he	often slipped	754.807404688446
12225. when one of the men in the hall behind us spat on the	floor and scraped his boot over the gob of spittle i noticed how the	clerk winced	3101.2298907540235
12226. i felt certain he was really a spineless little man	561.2002876936543
12227. his hat hung on a hook on the wall and	underneath it i could see his tie knotted ready to be slipped over	his head a black badge of frayed respectability that ought never to	have left his neck	4137.58996536515
12228. the morning's tabloids were on the counter and	a stack of dog-eared men's magazines	1407.4121483982112
12229. on a shelf in the office behind	the counter was a small radio dialed permanently on a station which	broadcast only vulgar commercials and cheap popular music	2867.588893624239
12230. everything	about the clerk was trivial	64.76415693953626
12231. once pressing him i learned that his	job was only part-time in the afternoons when nothing went on in the	hall	2034.044940207835
12232. noticing my disappointment he attempted to salvage what scraps	and shreds of authority he felt might still be clinging to his person	3251.524210248099

12239. they and the two large fans which i could dimly see as	daylight filtered through their vents down at the far end of the hall	could be turned on by a master switch situated inside the office	3961.4961614346503

12679. mcbride gave him his opportunity when he showed up in town with	a pistol on his hip	1414.1669639281397
12680. he had a legitimate reason for wearing it	249.87221515076098
12681. it	was payday for highlands and he was packing a lot of money back into	the oil fields	1581.4190057865
12682. moreover as long as the weapon was carried openly	the sheriff's office had made no previous issue of it	2602.9933256004397
12683. so	what's this all about	14.844062574785625
12684. he demanded when lord confronted him	65.32097252114679
12685. i'm not the only man in town with a gun or the only one without	a permit	1427.2244207919225
12686. it was the wrong thing to say	141.26655320044972
12687. by failing to do	as he was told instantly- to take out a permit or return the gun to	his car- he had played into lord's hands	2866.8542746937733
12688. the trouble was	that he had virtually had to protest	560.9025229207673

12690. so how about it	4.39894529706599
12691. he	said	0.20041515
12692. why single me out on this permit deal	249.93368377838542
12693. well	i'll tell you about that lord told him	262.02016653680084
12694. we aim t' be see-lective	y'know	65.13677914682481

12697. he himself had heard that there was gangster money in the company	but that had nothing to do with him	1874.9675383106514
12698. he was an honest man doing a hard	job and the implication that he was anything else was unbearable	2587.253977705438

12716. it was strictly the deputy's game but mcbride had gone	too far to throw in	1642.4820985536248
12717. now he could only play the last card in what was	probably the world's coldest deck	1254.7455180879474
12718. he flung off lord's	hand and attempted to push past him inadvertently shoving him into a	storefront	2136.111929535111

12720. lord slugged him in the stomach so hard	that the organ almost pressed against his spine	1874.3730554638364

12723. and then	there was a numbing blow to the heart and another gut-flattening blow	to the stomach h   but he couldn't keep up with them	2590.505208500375
12724. no	more could he defend himself against them	249.71440375417177
12725. he seemed to be fighting	not one man but a dozen	504.67928137041815

12733. he mcbride would be cited	as in the wrong and he lord would go scot-free an officer who had	only done his duty though perhaps too energetically	2882.2548922702326

12739. he hated them too much to	understand- the people of this isolated law-unto-itself world that	was lord's world	1569.263076118098
12740. this he was sure was the way they would	act;	laughing at a dying man laughing as a man was beaten to death	3477.1059364326525

12746. the brannon outfit- known as the slash-b because of its brand-	reached hondo creek before sundown	1882.0509858776754
12747. the herd was watered and	then thrown onto a broad grass flat which was to be the first night's	bedground	1875.373299925101
12748. two of the new hands a mexican named jose amado and	a kid known only as laredo were picked for the first trick of riding	night herd	4300.244729293652
12749. the rest of the crew offsaddled their mounts and	turned them into the remuda	945.5075220051901
12750. they got tin cups of coffee from the big	pot on the coosie's fire rolled and lighted brown-paper cigarettes	lounged about	3047.583965831457
12751. there was some idle talk a listless discussion of	this or that small happening during the day's drive	1567.7985887051318

12764. he'd come alone	without his wife and child	249.29550130771105

12918. they brought	to it all the odors that clung to men like themselves that of their	own sweat of campfire smoke of horses and cattle	3885.0345197702723

12922. the author of the anonymous notes seemed to be all-knowing	560.9600160375918
12923. for	men who had left cattle alone after getting their first notices had	received no second	1262.2070043521453
12924. but the day of the deadline came and passed and	the men who had scoffed at the warnings laughed with satisfaction	3057.6499893829628
12925. for	with a single exception nothing had happened to them	373.4976530981231
12926. the	exception was an iron mountain settler named william lewis	562.6463041941939
12927. after	walking out to his corral that morning he'd been amazed to see the	dust puff up in front of his feet	2172.942375180869
12928. a split second later the distant	crack of a rifle had sounded	966.4291863656803
12929. he'd mounted up immediately and raced	with a revolver ready toward the spot from which he'd estimated the	shot had come	2040.2280112704707
12930. but he had found all of the thickets and points of	cover deserted	1178.3040023926148
12931. there had been no sign of a rifleman and no track or	trace to show that anyone had been near	1882.9067582108837
12932. lewis was a man who had	made a full-time job of cow stealing	1181.0062639456644
12933. he hadn't even pretended to	be farming his spread	259.5174918030763
12934. his land had never been plowed	64.75698844054169
12935. he had done	his rustling openly and boasted about it	375.58801305020086

12937. he had cursed at them and threatened them	166.47585842592065
12938. he was	a man those neighbors testified later who didn't have a friend	in the world	1878.5303586239993
12939. william lewis made the rounds of all who lived	near him again that august morning after a bullet landed at his feet	and once more he accused and threatened everyone	3217.8477057630726
12940. i'll	be ready next time! he raged	141.02347188237178
12941. i'll be shootin' right back	14.898658947621135
12942. he had his chance the very next morning for exactly the	same thing happened again	1644.4561906458653
12943. this time lewis had his own rifle in his	hands and he threw some answering fire back at the mysterious far-off	shot then spent most of the day searching out the area	3451.22272249483
12944. he found nothing	but he still refused to give up and move out	1174.9431381229033
12945. just	let me meet up with that damned bushwhackin' coward face-to-face!	he exploded	788.1216205589283
12946. that's all i ask!   he never got that	chance	390.6025900956047
12947. for the unseen ghostlike rifleman aimed a little higher the	third time	643.901038018422
12948. 30-30 bullet smashed directly into the center of william	lewis' chest	758.0542670966158
12949. he slumped against a log fence rail then tried	to lift himself	641.752631833228
12950. two more shots followed in quick succession dropping	him limp and huddled on the ground	1649.165376828839
12951. an inquest was held and	after a good deal of testimony about the anonymous notes the county	coroner estimated that the shooting had been done from a distance of	300 yards	3351.1684370398243
12952. rumors of the offer tom horn had made at the stockgrowers'	association meeting had leaked out by then and as a grand jury	investigation of the murder got underway the prosecuting attorney	a colonel baird ordered that the tall stock detective be summoned for	questioning	6935.765161958135
12953. it took some time to locate horn	93.09418719067993
12954. he was finally	found in the bates hole region of natrona county two counties	away	1649.8511222371562
12955. prosecutor baird immediately assumed he was hiding out there	after the shooting and began preparing an indictment	1422.3660074319446
12956. but that indictment	was never made	65.26389016759497
12957. for tom horn it turned out had a number of	rancher and cowboy witnesses ready and willing to swear with straight	faces that he had been in bates hole the day of the killing	3659.4951295781343
12958. the former scout's alibi couldn't be shaken	140.5527826691413
12959. the authorities had	to release him	43.41430238477949
12960. he immediately rode on to cheyenne threw a ten-day	drinking spree and dropped some very strong hints among friends	2584.2927442030273
12961. dead center at three hundred yards that coroner said! he'd	grin	496.6969339869967
12962. three shots in that fella 'fore he hit the ground! you	reckon there's two men in this state can shoot like that	3276.5497964100387
12963. publicly he denied everything	2.9388093648120863
12964. privately he created and magnified	an image of himself as a hired assassin	1182.992935123589
12965. for a blood-chilling ring	of terror to the very sound of his name was the tool he needed for	the job he'd promised to do	2601.756907971368
12966. tom horn was soon back at work	giving his secret employers their money's worth	1407.1830302797794
12967. a good many beef-hungry	settlers were accepting the death of william lewis as proof	that the warning notes were not idle threats	2178.570158042866
12968. the company herds were	being raided less often and cabins and soddies all over the range were	standing deserted	2564.578921887865
12969. but there were other homesteaders who passed the	lewis murder off as a personal grudge killing the work of one of his	neighbors	2321.6743746687075
12970. the rustling problem was by no means solved	250.88237415892678
12971. even	in the very area where the shooting had been done cattle were still	disappearing	1098.6364714821054
12972. for less than a dozen miles from the unplowed land of	the dead man lived another settler who had ignored the warnings that his	existence might be foreclosed on- a blatant and defiant rustler named	fred powell	5923.22800073826
12973. fred was mighty crude about the way he	took in cattle his own hired man andy ross mentioned later	1724.8283006213574
12974. everyone knew it but he sort of acted like he didn't care	who knew it- even after them notes came even after he'd heard about	lewis even after he'd been shot at a couple o' times hisself!	on the morning of september 10 1895 powell and ross	rose at dawn and began their day's work	7884.40674481045
12975. haying time was close at	hand and they needed some strong branches to repair a hay rack	1415.456624453363
12976. harnessing	a team to a buckboard they drove out to a willow-lined creek	about a half-mile off then climbed down and began chopping	3503.9485991758165
12977. andy	ross had just started swinging an ax at his second willow when the	distant blast of a rifle sounded	1880.1754982464936
12978. he looked around in surprise then	noticed that fred powell was clutching his chest	1397.980676795303
12979. the hired man	ran over to help his boss	262.262991911209
12980. my god i'm shot! powell	gasped	65.47440308533098
12981. and he collapsed and died instantly	43.73071335304491
12982. ross had no	intention of searching for the assassin	392.19939319203866
12983. he heaved the dead man onto	the buckboard yelled and lashed at the team and got out of there fast	1880.1365734590993
12984. but he brought back the sheriff and several deputies and to the lawmen	the entire affair seemed a repetition of the lewis killing	3497.0169238148287
12985. a detailed scouring of the entire area revealed nothing beyond a	ledge of rocks that might have been the rifleman's hiding place	2172.440609435611
12986. there	were no tracks of either hoofs or boots	394.5616436913768
12987. not even an empty cartridge	case could be found	261.9632262718998
12988. once again tom horn was the first	and most likely suspect and he was brought in for questioning immediately	2581.6673851479045
12989. once again he shook his head kept his face expressionless and	his voice very calm and had a strongly supported alibi ready	2188.777234761832
12990. later	riding in for some lusty enjoyment of the liquor and professional ladies	of cheyenne he laid claim to the killing with the vague insinuations	he made	4293.4420208929205
12991. exterminatin' cow thieves is just a business	proposition with me he'd blandly announce	794.0014453393131
12992. and i sort o'	got a corner on the market	564.4095204663928
12993. tom a friend asked him	once how come you bushwhacked them rustlers	640.3207155346569
12994. they wouldn't	o' stood no chance with you in a plain straight-out shoot-down	1181.0092716548397
12995. he had lots of friends then as always	167.2706809785009
12996. even as he became widely	known as a professional killer nearly every cowboy and rancher in	wyoming seemed proud to call him a friend	3704.9367395867425
12997. no man's name brought	more cheers when it was announced in a rodeo	790.201502563003
12998. well he	explained	s'posin' you was a nester swingin' the long rope	962.243134342971
12999. which would you be most scairt of- a dry-gulchin' or a shoot-down	644.2866755799631
13000. yeah i can see that the friend was forced to	agree	751.0488479237457
13001. but h well it just don't seem sportin' somehow!	sportin'! the tall sunburnt rustler-hunter stared	in amazement	1414.4999284904254
13002. sportin'! he echoed again in soft wonder	141.354721192715
13003. i	seen a lot o' things in my time	259.42353576169046
13004. i found a trooper once the apache	had spread-eagled on an ant hill and another time we ran across	some teamsters they'd caught tied upside down on their own wagon wheels	over little fires until their brains was exploded right out o'	their skulls	6824.133745220091
13005. i heard o' texas cattlemen wrappin' a cow thief up	in green hides and lettin' the sun shrink 'em and squeeze him to	death	2461.659714259659
13006. but there's one thing i never seen or heard of one thing	i just don't think there is and that's a sportin' way o' killin'	a man!   after the first two murders the warning notes	were rarely ignored	6077.836809501656
13007. the lesson had been learned	14.887315419870683
13008. when fred powell's brother-in-law charlie keane moved	into the dead man's home the anonymous letter writer took no chances	on charlie taking up where fred had left off and wasted no time	on a first notice:   if you don't leave this country	within 3 days your life will be taken the same as powell's was	7909.213976596511
13009. this was the message found tacked to the cabin door	373.2137254571769
13010. keane	left within three days	22.049231325178106
13011. all through albany and laramie counties	other men were doing the same	641.1851278252916
13012. houses of settlers who'd treated	the company herds as a natural resource free for the taking were	sitting empty with weeds growing high in their yards	4126.449229483137
13013. the small half-heartedly	tended fields of men who'd spent more time rustling cattle	than farming were lying fallow	1557.805611652608
13014. no cow thief could count on a jury	of his sympathetic peers to free him any longer	2124.0511389024796
13015. jury judge and executioner	were riding the range in the form of a single unknown figure	that could materialize anywhere at any time to dispense an ancient	brand of justice the men of the new west had believed long outdated	4221.399657277109
13016. for three straight years tom horn patrolled the southern wyoming	pastures and how many men he killed after lewis and powell	will never be known	3896.370475532463
13017. it is possible	although highly doubtful that he killed none at all but merely let	his reputation work for him by privately claiming every unsolved murder	in the state	3107.1254692973444
13018. it is also possible but equally doubtful that he actually	shot down the hundreds of men with which his legend credits him	3264.8201230142336
13019. for that legend was growing explosively rumor was insisting	he received a price of $600 a man	1409.0369230587316
13020. a monthly wage of about $125 very good money in an era when top	rumor had it he slipped two small	rocks under each victim's head as a sort of trademark	5019.418454183277
13021. one thing was certain- his method was effective so	effective that after a time even the warning notices were often unnecessary	2046.300431708
13022. the mere fact that the tall figure with the rifle and field	glasses had been seen riding that way was enough to frighten three rustling	homesteaders out of the upper laramie country in a single week	5767.231529188023
13023. my reputation's my stock in trade tom mentioned more	than once	501.1109331121782
13024. he evidently couldn't foresee that it might be his downfall	in the end	1175.4610511919923
13025. he had made himself the personification of the	devil to the homesteaders	636.8360035244626
13026. but to the cattlemen who had been facing	bankruptcy from rustling losses and to the cowboys who had been faced	with lay-offs a few years earlier he was becoming a vastly different	type of legendary figure	5790.668756269538
13027. such ranchers as coble and clay and the	bosler brothers carried him on their books as a cowhand even while	he was receiving a much larger salary from parties unknown	3229.2355100614495
13028. he made their	spreads his headquarters and he helped out in their roundups	1172.9495795682355
13029. in the cow camps tom horn was regarded as a hero as the same	kind of champion he was when he entered and invariably won the local	rodeos	2979.4124315209224
13030. the hands and their bosses saw him as a lone knight of the range	waging a dedicated crusade against a lawless new society that was	threatening a beloved way of life	5002.7486046553695
13031. the wailing guitar-strumming minstrels	of the cattle kingdom made up songs about him	791.3871815538513
13032. by 1898	rustling losses had been driven down to the lowest level ever seen in	wyoming	1882.8446511715078
13033. when several minutes had passed and curt hadn't emerged from	the livery stable brenner reentered the hotel and faced summers across	the counter	2330.7947476125028
13034. i have a little job for you charlie	250.04349964114581
13035. i'm	sure you won't mind doing me a small favor	377.56473273189476
13036. brenner's	voice was oily but summers wasn't fooled	249.91840711268247
13037. he moistened his lips	uneasily	14.832806837847897
13038. what is it you want me to do mr brenner	560.1075885034713
13039. brenner shrugged carelessly	0.20041515
13040. i just want you to take a message to diane molinari	754.1526416983078
13041. tell her	to come here to the hotel	167.71299978307738
13042. vastly relieved summers nodded	and started toward the door	393.2839693621125
13043. one thing summers brenner	said	14.783470142260416
13044. you're not to mention my name	65.36221245973562
13045. tell her curt adams	wants to see her	166.68687516447662
13046. summers pulled up short and turned around	141.50461560934173
13047. i don't know mr brenner he said haltingly	beginning to get an inkling of brenner's plans	1259.9835388703086
13048. it doesn't seem	quite right telling her a thing like that	756.5690399586698
13049. couldn't i just-	his voice trailed off into silence	263.6062863386156
13050. brenner continued to smile	but his eyes were cold	390.2264662789166
13051. he turned and looked around at the lobby	as though seeing things he hadn't before noticed	1259.845030915467
13052. you know	summers he said thoughtfully	65.10365422012771
13053. eagle's nest ought to have	a fire company	166.7955195543293
13054. if someone were to drop a match in here this place	would go up like a haystack	2137.654873544092
13055. he started toward the stairway then	turned to add tell her to come to adams's room that adams	is in trouble	2027.1955707437169
13056. yes sir	0.30041514999999996
13057. his face	pale summers headed for the street	167.10798660769473
13058. curt's visit to the	livery stable had been merely a precaution in case anyone should be watching	2116.879873370841
13059. he paused only long enough to ascertain that jess's buckskin	was still missing and that his own gray was all right then climbed	through a back window and dropped to the ground outside	3545.578730745588
13060. the	fact that jess's horse had not been returned to its stall could indicate	that diane's information had been wrong but curt didn't interpret	it this way	4277.078036731129
13061. a man like jess would want to have a ready means	of escape in case it was needed	1558.1182393486117
13062. probably his horse would be close	to where he was hiding	756.0648795756038
13063. from the back of the barn it was a simple	matter to reach black's house without using the street	1730.4429334064687
13064. curt	approached the place cautiously and watched it several minutes from the	protection of a grove of trees	2362.804820449877
13065. there was a light in black's	front room but drawn curtains prevented any view of the interior	1415.3615675587305
13066. curt circled the house and located a barn out back	562.8939134800158
13067. he could hear	horses moving around inside and nothing else	374.60608123665247
13068. there was no lock on the	door only an iron hook which he unfastened	1417.0644885310387
13069. he opened the door and	went in pulling it shut behind him	639.0337744100325
13070. again he stood in the darkness	listening but there was only the scrape of a shod hoof on a plank	floor	3058.154180677414
13071. he moved ahead carefully his left hand in front of him	and came to a wooden partition	1410.8869488700675
13072. horse smell was very strong and he could	hear the crunch of grain being ground between strong jaws	2359.1892541455754
13073. he found	a match in his pocket and lit it	374.76276287838834
13074. there were two horses in	the barn a sway-backed dun and jess crouch's buckskin	1413.967616974032
13075. curt snuffed	out the match	14.932260468522623
13076. it was certain now that jess was in the house	but also presumably was stacey black	1880.0605690775205
13077. curt wanted to get jess	alone without interference from anyone even as spineless a person	as the store owner	1737.227427401791
13078. he studied the problem for a few seconds	and thought of a means by which it might be solved	2582.9597374359746
13079. reaching across	the side of the stall he slapped the buckskin on the rump	942.4854910221087
13080. the startled	animal let out a terrified squeal and thrashed around in the stall	1420.758328600269
13081. as curt had hoped the house door banged open	261.6628065078558
13082. he slapped	the buckskin again and it kicked wildly its hoofs rattling the side of	the stall	2125.7323201681784
13083. curt moved over beside the door and waited	166.68175776533084
13084. presently	he heard footsteps crossing the yard and jess's smothered curses	756.9839457410219
13085. the door swung open and jess said sourly what the hell's	the matter with you	1102.1612641596107
13086. the horse continued to snort	22.17275656026785
13087. curt doubted that any animal belonging to jess would find much reassurance	in its owner's voice	1246.6595558764552
13088. jess cursed again and entered	the barn	141.3531187586746
13089. a match flared and he reached above his head to light a lantern	which hung from a wire loop	1727.7641139525545
13090. as he crossed to the side of the	stall curt drew his gun and clicked back the hammer	2371.5216938589697
13091. before	you try anything he said	43.41194134653702
13092. remember what happened to gruller	22.029571067730377
13093. jess caught his breath in surprise	43.37913711562707
13094. he started to reach	for his gun but apparently thought better of it	1175.735208131546
13095. that's	the stuff curt said	14.83741758936117
13096. just hold it that way	22.041443811640406
13097. he reached out	to pull the door shut and fasten it with a sliding bolt	1095.7850841590125
13098. you and	i have a little talking to do jess	562.942217719656

13100. he moved up and lifted jess's pistol out of its holster	756.4493374706389

13107. there was raw fury in his eyes and the veins of his	neck were swollen	1100.4885266188583

13112. no	0.30041514999999996

13114. curt's fingers put a little more pressure on the trigger of his gun	1185.1142786591076

13119. he drew back his	arm to slash the gunbarrel across jess's face but didn't finish	the motion	1414.2535151447628
13120. pistol-whipping an unarmed man might come easy to someone	like jess but curt couldn't bring himself to do it	2591.752051038681

13138. somewhere in	the distance a woman screamed	141.04707086852866

13204. what a spectacle he was	caked with dirt and sweat and blood filthy as a pig and naked as an	indian kissing the finest the sweetest the bravest and absolutely	the prettiest girl in this whole wonderful world	6090.1688818190805
13205. he released her reluctantly	for her enthusiastic reunion with old hap	505.68392654578764
13206. got a lot	to tend to but i'll get back quick as i can he assured her	2110.86739128645
13207. dan could hear clayton burnside and eben jackson summing up	their final reckoning for rental on the oxen	1576.5372808800005
13208. jackson was doing most	of the talking	140.8987174050962
13209. so long as sally's pa was coming out best on the	haggle dan didn't feel the need of putting in his two-bits'	worth	2310.0845577433583
13210. soon as the burnsides moved on he'd lead rex down by the	river; there he could shave and scrub himself up for the evening	3686.869713157112
13211. damn	it he thought bitterly picking up his shirt and staring at the fresh	bullet hole in the sleeve	1730.48414344217
13212. if i hadn't got nate stopped when	i did my duds'd all be shot plumb to hell!   he stooped	picked up his ruined hat and pursed his lips thoughtfully	4651.432679038742
13213. from the	way the wound in his head was itching dan knew that it would heal	1246.3858976322938
13214. but his only	hat was something else again	250.40800316154164
13215. the burnsides now ready to roll were purposefully deaf to his	cry	636.3666731399221
13216. nate! he bellowed to the retreating back directly	in front of him	963.8442350990166
13217. i ain't going to fight you no more	167.41149435036368
13218. nate turned his head attempting to speak in a soothing voice	754.74850336093
13219. i know you ain't! dan affirmed feeling ten feet tall	370.83314347196864
13220. he moved in close jerked the handsome broad-brimmed beaver hat from	nate's head and clamped it on his own	2608.1386413172854
13221. here's a present for	you he said shoving his bullet-riddled hat down over nate's purpling	forehead	1259.8518721880423
13222. me and you's trading hats so's you'll have	something permanent to remember me by!   sally left her choring	to stand beside dan	3247.183074572042
13223. slipping her hand in his they silently watched	the burnsides make the bend in the road and disappear from sight	1890.1726494684822
13224. much as they had to look forward to they didn't begrudge a moment	of the time they spent seeing them go	3029.44062323805
13225. at first matilda	could not believe her own eyes	263.33441672859675
13226. she had spent too many hours looking	ahead hoping and longing to catch even a glimpse of dan and finding	nothing but emptiness	3492.443977504748
13227. and now she could see him looking uncommon	handsome standing there beside sally jackson and her folks in front	of their trail-worn wagon	2316.254373488334
13228. seeing them waiting there at the	foot of emigrant rock was so overwhelming that for a good minute	after they rounded the bend and started down the grade leading toward	them matilda could not speak at all	5902.90397011013
13229. then with a glory that almost	wiped out the deep downward sags in her careworn face matilda leaned	over the wheel and shouted to hez who was stumbling along in the	heat and the dust on the opposite side of the wagon pa! pa!	i can see dan	4810.583362546301
13230. and he's with the jacksons!   what	about burnsides	251.55639663716724
13231. hez asked who still believed they'd have them	to lick	372.1313435344195
13232. they ain't even in sight! she replied	141.1777385506414
13233. by then hez could see for himself and so could the others	647.6168061840236
13234. soon they were all shouting greetings exchanging smiles and rejoicing	to think that they were all back together again	2567.3181491637497
13235. but even a reunion	as joyous as this one did not make a break in the routines of the day	1885.3651541385545
13236. nor could they stop and find out about all that had happened until	they made circle tended the cattle tethered the horses gathered fuel	carried water and started their cooking fires	4994.841106508006
13237. then and only then	with the jacksons and dan as their true guests of honor did the	harrows take time to catch up on the news	2730.3319823024003
13238. no sooner did they hear	of dan's injury than both gran and matilda went into immediate action	2120.6666849346047
13239. the wound in his scalp was examined pronounced healing and well	doctored with simples before they dished up the victuals	1879.4704726621526
13240. from then	on in keeping with the traditions they had followed since childhood	the whole group settled down to relish their food	3272.7668742120873
13241. even sally in	spite of her gaiety and obvious welcome followed the old taboo of quitting	the gab when wearing the nosebag	2174.2772227817586
13242. after their supper	the evening turned into a regular hoe-down	566.7743596245775
13243. only they	carefully	substituted old country folk dances for the virginia reels and	square dances that were so popular among more worldly trains in the	great westward migration	2986.2645077229804
13244. but with bill o'connor on the fiddle	and gran harrow exuberantly shouting glory be and hallelujah	above their united chant of the lilting old ballads they played	their quaint folk games with all the fervor and abandon of a real	celebration	6446.435160122894
13245. golly rod exclaimed to harmony as he dutifully	stood by her side among the ringed spectators don't that	fiddle make you wish the bible didn't say us baptists can't dance	3225.2144804564864
13246. nor methodists neither she replied	22.28283278333786
13247. not	that	it matters to me being this far along	372.38229643359307
13248. rod gave her a warm	pat on the shoulder before he replied	964.7185694208149
13249. come spring you'll be	kicking up your heels and feeling coltish again too gal	940.7292180536427
13250. at these words of sympathy and understanding harmony said generously	i don't mind setting here along with gran while you go out and	join in the games	4285.438137689947
13251. rod shifted his eager eyes from the milling	group out in the circle long enough to reply i ain't much	of a hand for dare-base and farmer-in-the-dell but i'd sure	like to get in on the handhold and wrestles	4118.864445521789
13252. he looked down at his	big hands and slowly flexed his long fingers	1176.943693656771
13253. don't reckon there's	nobody out there 'cept maybe dan who can outgrip me harmony	934.7502637391065
13254. with rod on his way and matilda visiting with mrs	jackson while they searched out familiar names on the face of the cliff	harmony settled on the edge of the grub box to ease the pressure	of her swollen body on her bone-weary legs and worried about all that	might have happened to sally	7765.504959928468
13255. and she was deeply thankful that she	could see her now out there in the midst of a gay youthful circle	skipping and singing farmer in the dell farmer in the dell heigh-ho	the dairy-oh the farmer in the dell	4234.037911236896
13256. at the sight	of sally's happy face and carefree expression harmony's dark brooding	eyes quickly brightened with unshed tears	2587.521953000256
13257. she was glad completely	and unselfishly glad to see that things were working out the right	way for both sally and dan	2169.65871168061
13258. h and she really tried to go a step	further and say she hoped they'd be just as right as they now were	for her and for rod	4481.56890453321
13259. but she couldn't not yet	14.708275345261109
13260. not with the memory	of her folks and the lost conestoga still holding her close h	1868.8033649879185
13261. out in the center of the circle the farmer who was dan wasted	no time when they came to the line the farmer choose his wife	2715.9828294274516
13262. with a swift swoop of his big arms he grabbed sally out of the	circle surrounding him and then kissed her soundly before setting her	down so she could stand by his side while they jointly chose the rest	of their outfit	6541.208571098052
13263. soon the child the dog the cat h and even	the cheese all joined them out there in the circle	1884.62143320246
13264. by now	harmony could see that most of the adults in the train were winded and	resting or else siphoned off from the games by the challenging lure	of the great cliff towering above them	5637.538381162139
13265. no matter how many registry	rocks they came to on this journey each one exerted its own appeal	1567.7512441188903
13266. even strange names seemed to make them feel closer to some kind of civilization	when stumbled across out here in this wilderness	3241.066239174751
13267. already	a few hardy folk from their own train were zealously chipping away at	the register rocks leaving their own records along with those made by	the earlier trains	3113.768830074588
13268. soon she saw rod and hez moving over to join them	747.2566850283578
13269. no sooner were they through and the guards posted than the	whole camp turned in for a night of sound sleep	2039.3832923303532
13270. for matilda it	was the first she had known in many a night	1192.4704358516751
13271. even the knowledge that	she was losing another boy as a mother always does when a marriage is	made did not prevent her from having the first carefree dreamless sleep	that she had known since they dropped down the canyon and into bear	valley way way back there when they were crossing those other mountains	5254.708874051661
13272. next morning they moved on again	65.32235017509183
13273. my souls'	a-gracious! gran harrow exclaimed watching their rippling	muscles as rod and dan swung her up into the load	1868.4656470221823
13274. a body would	swear i floated right up here on a cloud!   rod and dan	released their holds on the arms of her hickory rocker and exchanged	embarrassed grins	4647.455437493732
13275. shucks gran they said almost in unison	92.71002462105237
13276. that	wasn't nothing at all!   leaning forward in her chair	gran nearsightedly scrutinized dan's face	1626.052118623834
13277. how's sally	like rubbin' agin that thar little ticklebrush ye're a-raising	501.8150056736321
13278. quit ragging him gran rod protested	64.78093522146062
13279. i	ain't ragging him! gran peered again at the week-old blond	mustache shadowing dan's upper lip	1255.6873006500107
13280. but honest-to-betsy i've	seed more hair than that on a piece o' bacon	1180.5209579621549
13281. the two	tall	brothers waited silently while their mother handed gran her cold	snack and water jug placed the chamber pot beside her feet and returned	to her place at the front of the wagon with alice	3922.0589841881642
13282. rheumatics	worse pa	0.30041514999999996
13283. dan asked hez who had limped back from his	team to hold the notched-stick chair braces in place while his boys swung	up the tailgate and tied it tight at the ends	3447.7358199251494
13284. my right	leg's stiff as a board this morning he replied	759.371146889878

13286. the three	men stepped out to the side to wait for captain clemens' signal	1409.5666172545716

13290. from	now on sally and me and her folks aim to give you our turn when it	comes up and fall in behind you and rod's outfit	4270.334896003669

13292. sally	and her ma want to trade off on account of harmony being so far along	dan explained	2352.8350814201303
13293. jackson recruited his critters and him and	me fixed up his wagon while we was waiting for you to catch up	2027.914993080045
13294. he's	got the tightest running gear in the train now	557.3171083684124
13295. besides 'tain't	no more'n right for me to follow with my black oxen so's i can	unhook and pull up fast if either of you get in a pinch	3092.793740320504

13301. like enough we'll all be up on top by	sundown	372.58968722781185
13302. out of the corner of his eye he could see his father's	wheels beginning to turn	1889.6406059328856
13303. before harmony had a chance	to reply rod cracked his long whip over his thin oxen's backs h	1576.640891725968
13304. while no larger than dutch springs this mining supply town had	the	appearance of being far busier and more prosperous	2831.9018155562035
13305. men crowded the streets	and freight rigs and teams were moving about	641.58934651898
13306. although they were	forced to maintain a sharper watch this activity enabled them to ride	in and rack their broncs without any particular attention being paid	them	4259.0720643940185
13307. gyp'll be holdin' forth in some bar if he's	here at all cobb declared glancing along the street as they stretched	their legs	2338.297611044957
13308. there were no less than six or seven saloons	in ganado not counting the lower class dives all vying for the trade	of celebrating miners and teamsters	4270.188087515775
13309. take one	side of the street and i'll take the other he proposed	791.4459406758359

13314. russ visited two places without result	and his blood pressure was down to zero	1404.7473611911628

13316. he tramped out of the miners rest with his	hopes plummeting and headed doggedly for the palace saloon the	last place of any consequence on this side of the street	4825.333195589827
13317. the	palace was an elaborate establishment built practically on stilts in	front with long flights of wooden steps running up to the porch	2313.4071717592988
13318. behind	its ornate facade the notorious dive clung like a bird's nest	to the rocky ribs of the canyonside	2598.145343516603

13321. heading for the batwings cobb glanced perfunctorily	through the nearest window and suddenly dodged aside	1104.1838755366261
13322. nerves tight as	a bowstring he paused to gather his wits	755.7240401388115
13323. against all expectation	carmer was inside clearly enjoying himself to the hilt and already	so tipsy that it seemed unlikely he was bothering to note anything	or anyone about him	3220.600469102318
13324. fierce anger surged through russ	22.25649861227876
13325. he fought	down the impulse to rush in and collar the vicious puncher on the spot	1254.4305790559051

13331. he said swiftly	0.20041515

13341. where yuh	goin'	0.20041515
13342. it was the barkeep	4.430033659733095
13343. halting pat turned to	survey him deliberately	93.60676048018544

13422. he knew now what he was	up against	248.60635094900402
13423. whoever was out there hiding in the brushy cover was besieging	the antler house and having spotted his approach was determined	to drive him off before he could get into the fight	3460.1090129879294
13424. cursing	himself for having ridden out the last few days without a rifle in	his saddle boot russ drew his colt and examined it briefly	3884.2637075237485

13428. the would-be assassin had his position figured	pretty close	392.1170650622364

13438. jumping jerusalem! let's get out of here!	at the first shot russ had hurled his mount to the left toward	the side of the winding draw	4095.6601963910834
13439. the long minute before he reached effective	cover seemed endless	374.26694299839227
13440. sweeping a look around he saw that he	was safe for the moment	1178.7426069651742
13441. he heard cries from behind him but he could	make out no words	790.4494847742759
13442. he dashed madly for the next elbow turn in	the draw and made it	1409.603216611698

13444. gradually	the wash climbed upward forcing him toward open range	560.8710466352376

13447. early in november the clouds lifted enough to carry out the assigned	missions	788.8476984594442
13448. and sweeney squadron put its first marks on the combat	record	753.3959361841279
13449. every plane that could fly was sent into the air	376.0548144392282

13451. anything the enemy flew	or floated was his target	259.9150155201911

13454. each plane carried two five-hundred	pound bombs	141.30902322919752
13455. a weapons carrier took greg todman belton	banjo ferguson and walters and the others the two miles from the	bivouac area to the strip	2472.644853411672
13456. it was a rough long ride through the mud	and pot holes	959.0539496286747

13458. the sky glowered down at them	65.09975181716649

13483. he possessed the fighter pilot's	horror of bad weather and instrument flying and he wondered if	the ceiling did drop whether he and the other flights would be able to	find their way back in this unfamiliar territory	4055.6814447215684

14170. the soaking will put life back in the wagon too	564.666273172736
14171. his wife didn't give a sign she'd heard	167.61834527966795
14172. she was watching a	tree ride wildly down that roiling current	753.7311509965256
14173. somebody was riding the	tree	14.966927543006339
14174. it raced closer and they could see a woman with white hair sitting	astride an upright branch	2131.095690397455
14175. she did not call out	14.703671734009186
14176. but as	the tree passed she lifted an arm in gesture of better luck and farewell	1878.5777078696708
14177. they watched the tree until it twisted sharply on a bend	500.6555606146886
14178. it speared	up into the air then sinking back the up-jutting branch turned	slowly	1426.0662324602968
14179. the pale blob of the woman disappeared	94.24799126691761
14180. there's	the one who's lucky! the girl murmured harshly	395.0062857745349
14181. ben's	eyes strained with the bitter hurt his homely face slashed with gray	and crimson	1098.9478275163624
14182. then he took off his wet boots and dropped down into	the water to talk with the beasts needing their comfort more than they	needed his	4108.209771535809
14183. it was nearly sundown and he went to the back of	the wagon half-swimming his way for he was not a tall man	2322.0706701636345
14184. he let	down the tailgate and was knocked over by the sluice of water	1411.6694867346064
14185. he sputtered back to his feet and scrambled madly to pull his bags of	seed grain forward	1407.5059252113795
14186. they were already swollen to bursting	64.85914761171253
14187. of all	their worldly	belongings next to the oxen and his gun the seed grain had been	the most treasured	1890.39982642732
14188. it was spoiled now for seed and it would sour	and mold in three days if they failed to find a place and fuel to dry	it	4280.968724096679
14189. the oxen might as well enjoy it	94.10899509927688
14190. he examined the water marks	on the iron tires when the animals were finished	1409.853842575449
14191. the waters lay	muddy but placid without a ripple of movement against the wheels; there	was not a match-width of damp mark to show they were receding	2843.2191838526933
14192. he doubted if a man could wade as far as the desolate dry hills	that rimmed the valley	2368.5178403753043
14193. a terrible numbing sense of futility swept	over him	261.8892047595767
14194. he gripped the wheel hard to fight the despondency of	defeat	746.0252842905272
14195. then he noticed that the dry wood of the wheels had swollen	642.859874376543
14196. the spokes were tight again the iron tires gripped onto the wheels	as if of one piece	2129.9051261081395
14197. he swung toward	the front	to give the news to hettie then stopped barred from her by	the vehemence of her blame and hate	2460.1494810497525
14198. a tight	wagon meant so much	65.18416838810619
14199. he got a small fire started and put on bacon	and coffee	639.4773143006894
14200. he poured the water off the sourdough and off the flour	salvaging the chunky watery messes for biscuits of a sort	3055.90817148425
14201. their	jams and jellies had not suffered	93.89108211233172
14202. he found a jar of preserved tomatoes	and one of eggs that they had meant to save	2109.3560215800344
14203. now he broke them open	hoping a good meal might lessen this depression crushing hettie	1093.7367602959894
14204. his long nose wiggled at the smells of frizzling bacon and heating	java but the fire was low and he wanted to waste no time	3889.3647401076314
14205. he	furled the slashed sides of the canvas tarpaulins leaving the ribs and	wagon open	1103.0477385704035
14206. he looked thoughtfully at his wife's trunk holding	her meager treasures	752.4217364270997
14207. he said hesitantly hettie i don't	figure your things got wet too much	786.2095091642207
14208. if you	want to get them aired h   she said without turning her head	after that rain beating in atop the dust there isn't a thing	that won't be streaked	4816.148846089998
14209. he drew a long breath and opened	the trunk and hung out her clothes and spoilables upon the wagon ribs	1878.6504683671526
14210. sulphur oil and copra make the kind of tinder any firebug dreams	of	1170.0695082764998
14211. i suppose a lascar sailor had sneaked a cigarette in the hold	and touched off the blaze	1425.1052368927462
14212. now roaring up in great oily clouds of	smoke and flames the fierce heat quickly drove us to the stern where	we huddled like suffocating sheep not knowing what to do h	5164.6599230080255
14213. the lifeboats were stuck fast	14.76425393303999
14214. i heard a	cry from a stoker as a pillar of flame leaped from a hatch and tongued	the man's bare back	3305.756761799671
14215. he sprinted to the rail and leaped overboard	into the shark-infested waters	647.4763856560187
14216. one especially bad detonation	shook lifeboat no 3 which trembled violently in the davits	1414.2391621111824
14217. brassnose	yelled: come on sommers max h step on it we got	a chance now	1100.5076132686986
14218. heave on those ropes; the boat's come unstuck	249.75469884573778
14219. we pulled and swore and yanked and wept scraping our hands until	they bled profusely	1090.1956320565255
14220. the bonaventure was quivering and lurching	like an old spavined mare	758.078606035
14221. her stern was down and a sharp list helped	us to cut loose the lifeboat which dropped heavily into the water	2037.6427165148184
14222. brassnose max and i leaped into the sea and swam to the	boat	1190.1439836047443
14223. let's get away fast said brassnose shaking water from	his mop of bleached hair	938.5192827680401
14224. that tub is going to explode all at once	388.40060131679104
14225. then the bonaventure seemed to disintegrate with a	roar of live steam geysers of sparks and flames and a dense cloud of	black-and-orange smoke	2458.351703858169
14226. dimly we heard the voices of men in mortal	agony but we couldn't go back into that inferno	2351.282809566035
14227. already our	leaky lifeboat was filled with five inches of water	499.6710919757411
14228. sommers you	bale while we row brassnose commanded	250.30807906881438
14229. as best as i could	determine we were some 700 miles west of new guinea in the bismark	archipelago	1726.7090672010727
14230. three days previously we had steamed past barren	rennell island in the distance	1196.040441715972
14231. now we peered anxiously for any speck	of land in the pacific for this interminable bailing would have	to stop soon	2019.284491155257
14232. there were gigantic blisters and rope burns on our hands;	our muscles were hot wires of pain	2107.1548502962482
14233. the big man with the whitened hair murmured something: his	words sounded as if they were in the manu tongue which i recognized	having studied the dialect in my anthropology 6 class at the	university of chicago	3957.1819984178037
14234. he then said something which struck	a chord in my memory	754.068032666397
14235. god help us if we're near the island	of eromonga	375.25945978536635
14236. we'd be in real trouble then	65.01945864562597
14237. i'd rather keep bailing-	or sink	43.42085846822171
14238. i was puzzled by the remark then i recalled	the voice of mild professor howard griggs three years ago in a	university lecture on primitive societies	4097.975283255661
14239. he had been speaking of this	archipelago:   even when the islands were under german	mandate before world war 1 europeans gave eromonga a wide berth	2598.200008944072
14240. the place is inhabited by several hundred warlike women who are	anachronisms of the twentieth century- stone age amazons who live	in an all-female matriarchal society which is self-sufficient	4644.929032301831
14241. i remembered too the jesting voice of a classmate bobby pauson:	but how do they reproduce dr griggs	1571.0086693409037
14242. i'm sure that	males have something to do with that process!   there had	been classroom guffaws which quickly subsided as professor griggs said	dryly: i see your point pauson	4652.914411959304
14243. of course males play a role	there but believe me when i say you wouldn't enjoy yourself one	bit on eromonga	2039.8101551413079
14244. indeed you wouldn't live long for the females	either drive the men they've seized from neighboring islands back	to their boats after exploiting them for amatory purposes or they destroy	them by revolting but ingenious methods	5787.647985584916
14245. in fact one important	aspect of their very religion is the annihilation of men	943.7122285500058
14246. i	think i know what you mean brassnose i said	561.7959990549058
14247. i know something	about eromonga	15.012378901455998
14248. let's hope we come to a safer place	250.81019555589873
14249. three hours later while we were bailing desperately	a dot of land came into view	1091.9014516942113
14250. foster lukuklu frayne made a	sign over his heart with his two linked thumbs: i recognized it as	an ancient manu gesture intended to propitiate the devil	4298.475226863129
14251. a	half-hour passed; we had drifted closer	94.26959971483613
14252. in a voice so frightened as	to seem not his own the big bo'sun's mate quavered:   tchalo!	it is eromonga- look hard you can see with your	naked eye the wooden scaffolding on the cliff	5663.4824887192535
14253. i squinted	at the looming shoreline	43.497313961383995
14254. there was a wooden tower or derrick there	something like a ski jump; it was perhaps 80 feet high and had	been artfully constructed of logs	4094.0170203172565
14255. a fine example of engineering in	a primitive society	261.2560221350826
14256. what is the scaffolding for brassnose	65.15421151945637
14257. he made a sound of despair deep in his throat	373.18673482038696
14258. it was	embarrassing to see strapping blonde brassnose comport himself like	a child who talks about bogeymen	2114.9591585375733
14259. aaa-ee! it is their	tultul the 'jumping platform' of death	373.71232182074493
14260. it is the last of the	three tests of manhood which the women impose to discover if a male	in worthy of survival there	3671.17161083861
14261. often i heard my uncles and cousins speak	of it when i was a small boy growing up in rabaul	1864.909388341496
14262. they had never	seen a tultul but they had heard about it from their fathers	1652.8385359105282
14263. our lifeboat was filling rapidly and despite what i had	heard of the inhabitants of eromonga i was glad to see a long and	graceful outrigger manned by three bronzed girls glide out of a lagoon	into the open sea and toward our craft	4553.7050414761925
14264. i expected brassnose-	as a man with a strain of melanesian in his blood- to speak to	them	2351.4332467816457
14265. but he had turned a sickly green and appeared tongue-tied or panicked	649.7287588484155
14266. so i mustered my few words of the manu dialect and	said we greet you in peace	2129.895524397738
14267. my friends and i	come from a ship which was destroyed by fire	786.9078242247226
14268. we are thirsty and hungry;	our sore and burned hands and arms need attention	1408.0117518194818
14269. the	girl in the prow of the outrigger turned a smile like a beacon on me	1266.8076645466874
14270. i noted that her full breasts were bare and that she wore a garland	of red pandanus fruit in her blue-black hair	3252.669167526774
14271. she said my	name is songau and these girls are ponkob and piwen	796.9104338965409
14272. you are welcome	to eromonga	22.30450598122368
14273. my people await you on the shore	94.58886302392973
14274. you shall have	food water and rest	140.39207113870913
14275. thirty minutes later the outrigger grated	on sand and other girls waiting on shore rushed forward to pull	it up on the beach and make it fast with vine ropes to a large boulder	3652.3473982618802
14276. i saw a dozen or so other outriggers moored there	564.427444293003
14277. all my rosy visions of rest and even pleasure on this island vanished	at the sight	1260.529589131535
14278. there was a mound of bleached human bones and skulls	at the base of the big wooden derrick	2349.647465308316
14279. some had been there for years;	others still had whitened shreds of decayed flesh sticking to them	1407.3361194157
14280. there was one object which sickened yet fascinated me	389.5680469348987
14281. this	was also a corpse- a male judging from the coral arm bands the	tribal scars still discernible on the maggoty face the painted bone of	the warrior caste which still pierced the septum of the rotting nose	4055.640803345768
14282. the body may have been two or three weeks' dead	560.5017659460127
14283. i looked	with revulsion at the legs	94.49480522882178
14284. many small bones protruded	crazily from the shreds of flesh	565.5733041975932
14285. the man must have leaped to	his death from the topmost rung of the tultul	1100.7863530725115
14286. as if divining	my thoughts the girl songau smiled warmly and said in the casual	tone an american woman might use in describing her rose garden:	this is our tultul a jumping platform maku	5489.934941186879
14287. later	you shall know it better	43.3704273517382
14288. is it not well-made	4.4347628477795915
14289. our old one blew	down in a storm at the time of the pokeneu festival fifteen moons	ago	1575.6567725434127
14290. it took thirty of our women almost six moons to build this one	which is higher and stronger than the old one	3266.8424766464263
14291. we are very proud of	it	43.285326481403665
14292. you have every right to be i replied gravely in	the manu dialect but my attention was fixed on brassnose the biggest	and strongest of us	4082.673541243482
14293. he looked as if he was going to keel over	374.4701823677368
14294. i	felt a queasiness in my own stomach but it wouldn't do to show these	girls that we were afraid	2827.9172053251373
14295. i clapped	the big man with the bleached hair on his shoulder and said heartily	hoping it would make an impression on the women: this one is the	maku frayne	3242.140081290236
14296. he speaks your language too for he is the grandson	of a chieftain on taui who made much magic and was strong and cunning	3691.8570232441625

14299. brassnose	turned a stricken face toward me and said brokenly sommers you	meddling yank you're a fool! they despise males who brag of	their strength; they destroy such men with their damned tests	3530.78247178368
14300. you've	ruined me blast you!   at first i thought he was out	of his head talking wildly like this	2590.5243944081303
14301. but a glance at songau and	the other women confirmed what brassnose had blurted out	1098.0673352302042
14302. the	women's faces had hardened after my statement	250.07591522395668
14303. at a nod from songau	four lithe and muscular girls darted to frayne's side and seized	him by the arms	1879.9559918777395
14304. the man was an ox and he put up a creditable struggle;	but four eromonga women are more than a match for the strongest	male that ever lived	4496.6946496033415
14305. besides terror had sapped some of frayne's	vitality and will	374.9600378144024
14306. my last impression as they led him off to	a stockade was of his pale face   in the manu tongue eromonga	means manhood- a quality which the women derisively toasted	in weekly feasts at which great quantities of a brew like kava were	imbibed	6796.988739971549
14307. in the hut to which i was assigned- max had his own quarters-	my food was brought to me by a wrinkled crone with bare drooping	breasts who seemed to enjoy conversing with me in rudimentary phrases	3932.1999756298
14308. her name was l'turu and she told me many things	560.0579005333716

14310. though i had a great dread of the island and felt i would never	leave it alive i eagerly wrote down everything she told me about its	women	4472.989813860402
14311. from l'turu	i heard that until about 1850 the people of this island- which	was about the size of guam or smaller- had been of both sexes	and that the normal family life of melanesian tribes was observed here	with minor variations	4379.467635695786
14312. but in the middle of the last century	an island woman named karipo seized a spear in the heat of an	inter-tribal	battle and rallied the women after their men had fled	5205.782535555498
14313. miraculously	karipo and her women had succeeded in driving a hundred invaders	from the isle of pamasu back to their war canoes after considerable	loss of life on both sides	3218.8458381573255
14314. karipo was something of a	politician as well as a militarist	761.347611375579
14315. she quickly exploited the exalted	position she now occupied by harassing the disorganized males and even	putting many of them to death	2174.1414838244077
14316. within a decade or less few men	were left and a feminist society had sprung up	1882.4979952855847
14317. karipo was	great goddess told our mothers that men were not necessary except to	father children the crone told me	1864.0913628408302
14318. all men went away from here	65.56821675925994
14319. those who stayed had to pass tests	93.86951407924248
14320. she cackled with	mirth showing the stumps of betel-stained teeth	564.2394186051968
14321. karipo's women	then named this place 'eromonga'- manhood- for just the strongest	men could stay here	1263.638234340431

14647. waddell turned to face him	14.897008905882917
14648. but that's what he told me	64.60659280092659
14649. why that's	his main reason for making the dive	261.25546153200474
14650. shaffner looked at	him altogether without guile and shrugged his shoulders making a	little spreading gesture with his two hands	2818.744419283446
14651. what do you mean	2.9582261493230706
14652. waddell asked frowning	0.30041514999999996
14653. please let me explain	the german said earnestly his face still devoid of deceit	932.5544954317127
14654. i have	in europe a gross business of seven million dollars the year	1186.3510206670258
14655. now	i wish to enter the american market where the competition is very	strong	940.8343221859368
14656. i must have a powerful representative here a firm with a national	distribution and ten twenty thousand dollars to advertise my	products	3280.370455211855
14657. with all respect to a fine young man mr roy is not able	to provide these necessaries	1420.4267723150483
14658. waddell was not an eminently	moral person but he did not like what he had just heard	2115.8973928344703
14659. did you	tell him all this	43.35166104833772
14660. he asked	0.30041514999999996
14661. perhaps not in so many	words the german said	263.52832059502873
14662. but surely you have misunderstood mr	roy	141.23264888978704
14663. never never did i offer him the exclusive rights	262.94328605521684
14664. we spoke	of the need for advertising and i agreed that the deep dive would	be most useful for publicity	2819.3345412358344
14665. he was most eager to make the dive;	of course i was willing	784.4350690572422
14666. but there was no definite agreement about	business arrangements	395.62841038677186
14667. there	was the end of his front-page feature story with byline	498.03972439564325
14668. he started	out the door	22.21708326592573
14669. one moment! herr schaffner said	14.8108353930161
14670. you	intend to speak with mr roy	140.45606601899004
14671. what else	0.20041515
14672. waddell asked	0.30041514999999996
14673. if you will pardon i think it would be	better if not	642.5133524672667
14674. mr roy is determined to make this dive	248.0513825626662
14675. whatever	you tell him he will dive	93.9965987362367
14676. i know this from my talks with him	252.03465625312703
14677. well let's let him make up his own mind ok	375.6004132890565
14678. waddell	said	0.30041514999999996
14679. on the basis of the facts	43.60984640649819
14680. you will make	him unhappy and anxious the german said	564.770983800627
14681. at 200 300 400 feet	under the water when he must be paying very much attention he will	be thinking about what you are telling him	2734.0763186704844
14682. it is not good mr	waddell: you will do him great harm	966.1270049330287
14683. there was no doubt	that herr schaffner meant every word of what he said	937.616390157742
14684. waddell came	back from the door and sat on a bunk	755.9597063275991
14685. i am an honest man	the german said with fervor	375.215555709145
14686. i will give mr roy his due for	this dive	558.4066336828823

14689. this will help him to get out	of his little tackle shop	635.0794987039751

14691. the german's words worked on the	newspaperman like a reprieve from an odious duty	952.737921302483
14692. he took a big swig	of his drink	251.06360588219664
14693. it would be a colossal shame to throw away a story like	this	793.3160942635074
14694. i think maybe you're right schaffner he said	249.6223515788106

14696. yes	the german said	4.41411768167019

14698. by	god waddell said we don't want to upset the boy at this	time of all times	2096.1000369810126
14699. he sloshed his drink	around and drained it in a few large gulps	785.3437138419091
14700. the story was shaping up	nicely in his mind: the young pioneer as of old altruistically braving	the unknown; the rewards prompt and juicy in modern big-business	america	4492.952333241325
14701. join me in another	2.931369208986516
14702. he had asked	0.30041514999999996
14703. thank	you the german had said courteously	94.16083084476267
14704. i do not drink so much	65.08144936282703
14705. now in that same cabin robinson fell to his knees beside	a bunk	789.0665280776391
14706. fear and relief mingled in his churning emotions	248.5403380016706
14707. he pressed	his palms together and addressed himself to the patron saint of divers	in a hurried and anxious whisper	1871.8872698057353
14708. blessed saint nicholas	i thank thee for getting me out of that mess and sending me up	instead of down when i was bewildered	3664.379637294539
14709. and when i make the dive again-	he paused; crossed himself; said a hail mary slowly and	with understanding	1727.6423717016237
14710. folding between his hands the cross that hung	from his neck he took his appeal direct to headquarters	2350.4790336660576
14711. holy mary	mother of god star of the sea stay thou with me on this next	dive	1402.2327053431898
14712. make it come off all right	65.212413088017
14713. let me set the record this time	and let me get back ok so the german will give me the exclusive	2030.078181386599
14714. and make my life different and better from this time on	751.7952575026171
14715. he crossed himself again and rose	43.51119739656364
14716. he felt a good deal less	shaky	140.16404723884608
14717. as he reached for the door there was a knock on it and when	he opened he found artie who came in and sat down on a bunk	2969.903249656713
14718. artie	had picked up a snorkle and was twirling it on his forefinger	1176.9479934873564
14719. he waited	awhile before he said roy you know your decompression table	don't you	942.7161859061041

14721. you came straight up from 275 without a stop	artie said	502.4432076194165

14723. anyway	i wasn't down long enough to matter	166.56338681247368
14724. you don't see me stretched	out	on the deck do you	755.5219468096573
14725. you know what they say about two	deep dives in one day artie went on still twirling the snorkle and	studying it intently	2315.788389722388
14726. i don't think you should go down again	253.73667559994774
14727. early that day matsuo saw a marine	94.84390880240238
14728. the enemy came looming	around a bend in the trail and matsuo took a hasty shot then fled	without knowing the result ran until breath was a pain in his chest	and his legs were rubbery	5785.8102489518615
14729. as his feet slowed he felt ashamed of the	panic and resolved to make a stand	1250.2370705494416
14730. he crossed the next meadow and	climbed a tree where the jungle trail resumed	1423.8969040923323
14731. in the leafiest	part of the tree straddling a broad horizontal limb he could see over	the meadow	1578.0551821730783
14732. for	a while he was content to let events develop in their	good time	1399.0721266674266
14733. he had no doubt the marine was the lead scout of a column	and while his shot had probably bred indecision they would soon come	hunting	2734.8550758517104
14734. his superiors had emphasized that marines tortured	others for the sheer pleasure	963.0283830814933
14735. yesterday; today; tomorrow: no	surrender	14.93557422400844
14736. his remembering the self-dictate brought no peace- only	a faint chill of doubt	1189.611602663396
14737. he murmured to himself with firmness: no	surrender	167.67284712204213
14738. it was best to die fighting the marines	251.90807306510715
14739. his superiors	had also preached this saying it was the way for eternal honor	932.1060799471259
14740. what if the marines never came	65.60928207006023
14741. his comrades were all dead	14.842845730651826
14742. then it would be a choice between starvation and suicide	563.011079401574
14743. whichever the way he would rot in this vast choking green	his wife never to receive an urn of his ashes	2030.7478347173633
14744. he sighed and leaned	for a moment against the trunk	564.2500946875605
14745. his fingers touched the bone handle	of a knife	263.2044540968552
14746. the knife an ammunition pouch and a half-filled bottle	of purified water hung on his belt	1884.5037183788845
14747. besides the belt he wore a loin	cloth	167.87734859099368
14748. as he looked up from picking at a leg ulcer he saw	a marine in the jungle across the clearing	2833.8777284353146
14749. the	marine came to the edge of the green jungle mist and stayed as though	debating whether to brave the sunlight	2048.110823741591
14750. his fatigues made a streak	of almost phosphorescent green in the mist	960.0755352317894
14751. come out come	out in the meadow matsuo said under his breath	640.7610193095738
14752. the man	leaned against a tree and wiped a sleeve across his face	1188.3242150917
14753. a signal	0.20041515
14754. matsuo lifted his rifle easing the sling under his left upper arm for	steadiness	1419.7995822883595
14755. fresh on his mind were events of the past day when	his whole regiment was destroyed in the hills	1727.1731909322698
14756. they had fought from	caves and the marines resorted to burning them out	1179.2595059036562
14757. even now like	a ringing in his ears he heard the wooooosh of flame-throwers squirting	great orange billows	1584.0372497671874
14758. a wave of flame rippling through their	cave had reached nagamo his friend and with a shriek the man bolted	through the entrance then slowed to the jerky walk of a puppet his	uniform blazing	5651.912028050225
14759. the marines let him advance	14.932750543991059
14760. when he sank on his knees	they had allowed him to char without administering the stroke of	mercy	2351.838628468525
14761. matsuo had faked death and was pitched on a stack of corpses	both the burned and the unburned the latter decomposing rapidly	under the tropical sun	2738.6121318703376
14762. the callous marines had laughed at each other's	retching while stacking bodies	961.915707286353
14763. matsuo repeatedly choked down	his own nausea	94.22270544534014
14764. at nightfall he had been able to sneak down a hillside	and into the jungle reeking of death	2363.6526893782084
14765. apprehensively he	peered	to the left to the right into the leafy vine-crisscrossed maze	946.6698205464027
14766. he decided that the marines must be deploying around the meadow with	the one left to distract him	2369.308502524402
14767. cautious feet	stepping on leafmold; faint creaking of belts and slings; whispers:	he heard none of these	1414.4247585411817
14768. only the hum of insects and the distant	fluttering call of a bird	1178.2656167744574
14769. because he couldn't hear them he was	more convinced they were there	637.5978523911175
14770. a spectacle occurred across the	meadow: the lone marine took a seat on the ground; leaning sidewise	on a tree trunk he embraced it	3721.298308035646
14771. while his comrades cocked the trap that one behaved as if it was some	dull maneuver	1258.279733026625
14772. taking aim at the man's face matsuo squeezed the	trigger up to the point of discharge and then he changed his mind	3260.690939225365
14773. he wanted the arrogant marine to know fear and so he aimed above the	head	1107.8809786946204
14774. the shot reverberated in diminishing whiplashes of sound	249.54708604432707
14775. like a mischievous boy expecting punishment matsuo	awaited reaction from the jungle	646.120408371608
14776. how stupid to give his position	away	140.2346668636206
14777. the jungle did not retort	14.799485730558349
14778. the sitter remained seated	hugging the tree	142.1610735295012
14779. before long the atmosphere reverted to its old normalcy	and insects hummed and birds occasionally called	1257.7168789714876
14780. matsuo puzzled	and grew anxious over the complete passiveness concluding that he	was the butt of a devilish joke	2597.5655521772264
14781. five or so minutes later the	marine abruptly pulled up and stepped into sunlight immediately throwing	his hands over his eyes	2040.3591292507267
14782. he went into a whirling dance a sort of	blind chasing of the tail	1419.2910944628552
14783. it ended when he tumbled; but jumping right	up he staggered in no particular direction	1097.3451988116817
14784. he wore no head cover	of any kind and more odd had no visible weapon	1652.1608735466064
14785. with a sudden	decisiveness he lurched in matsuo's direction crossing the meadow	in a zigzagging gallop	1259.2542097332102
14786. when he got closer to the tree matsuo	noted the wild look on his face	1650.327674630918
14787. the pockets of his jacket bulged	43.21276472981857
14788. the bobbing head was a poor target so matsuo shot	him in the upper trunk	1654.7353012098952
14789. the marine spun clapping a hand high	on his chest and dived forward	789.0652040024544
14790. in the hush that followed the echoes	matsuo was tense	561.8230949222906
14791. they could come on him now without difficulty	166.65529141189865
14792. gradually he reached a conclusion	22.287550031917267
14793. the marine was alone for they	were impatient people and by now would have vied to knock him from	the tree	2036.5867451854551
14794. down the tree he scrambled and knelt at the edge of	foliage	962.6287467625389
14795. the marine was sprawled some thirty yards away one arm extended	502.7128308665212
14796. matsuo jumped when the hidden arm flopped out	250.84949128002532
14797. reflex	0.20041515
14798. rifle leveled on the man he made a rush	393.8331998330888
14799. heat in the sunlight pressed	in like an invisible crowd	376.28538078927784
14800. he squatted by the head gently	placing the rifle	on the ground	970.5576045572465
14801. with a snakestrike motion he grasped the	hair and twisting pulled the marine over on his back	1427.5673614927405
14802. the bullet had penetrated in the area of the right collarbone;	around the hole blood glistened in a little patch	2810.8955607845583
14803. maintaining his	clutch on the hair matsuo watched the closed eyes while rummaging in	the jacket pockets	1422.0651311736867

14805. in the other: a	wristwatch with broken crystal wrapped in a dirty handkerchief	784.2162384545023

14807. he didn't smoke and could not light	fires with a flintless lighter; he had no use any longer for exact	time even had the watch been running	2873.5478413344727
14808. then there was no saying how	many times the marine had blown his nose on the handkerchief	2119.7011347574407

14810. from its holder he took his own canteen	251.79996170139708

14815. none	for you	0.20041515
14816. the marine blinked soon dropping his hand	138.85944785803753
14817. not only	had he no canteen but he lacked even the belt to hang one on	1268.54964902042

14822. drunk on sake he must have wandered off from his	bivouac	758.3168857911387
14823. the marine tried to roll on his right side and moaned	501.96769290702605
14824. when he rolled on the left side propping on his left elbow matsuo	seized his hair and pulled him back over	3051.4853392803307
14825. awkwardly with one hand matsuo got the cap back on the water	bottle	794.2543160376979
14826. the smell of sake had freshened yesterday's events in his	thoughts	755.4254213835926
14827. in the caves with other supplies they had kept cases of	sake	640.6811253607552
14828. the marine shut his eyes	22.286473788045306
14829. are you a thrower of	flame marine	94.05631771300474
14830. matsuo took the small knife from its scabbard and	laid it on the ground out of the marine's reach and away from their	shadows	3695.966895620707
14831. he waited in his squat gripping the hair	166.94182369382014

14833. its blade was dazzling in the intense sunlight	168.15849629048367
14834. the sun was noon high and matsuo perspired until his body was	dripping	1182.7997674878084

14836. the man had thrown the left hand over his eyes	563.2682269435769

14840. even the bone handle scorched and he retrieved	the marine's handkerchief to wrap it	1406.7600976473855
14841. first he barely touched the	blade on the hand which shaded the eyes	792.548269633548

14843. with a firm grip on the man's hair matsuo applied the	blade flat on a cheek	1261.0019725634133
14844. a shrill yelp kicked legs and groping hands	that circled matsuo's wrist	958.3401584452624
