14846. the marine commenced to weep and it blighted	the sense of enjoyment	961.0760713025566
14847. a small measure	of payment marine	43.33315209387482
14848. he dropped the knife in its scabbard hung the	rifle behind a shoulder	1185.2016899542027
14849. the marine hands on cheeks rolled	by his unwounded side onto his stomach	786.1231692643779
14850. matsuo	walked toward his tree once glancing back	253.2036358038471
14851. he would soon die	2.953677061016683
14852. as matsuo climbed by using the vines	and kicking his feet against the trunk a mood of gloom immersed him like	a jungle shadow	3714.5286145841455
14853. what now	0.20041515
14854. in the jungle birds were mute while	insects preserved only the monotony of living	1410.3664933370023
14855. it was the marine: head lifted he strained and called	377.1358942965375
14856. then he	astonished matsuo by pushing and dragging himself until he sat	958.0877408717273
14857. he	cupped his mouth and yelled	43.66686291645944
14858. matsuo hustled the rifle off his shoulder	141.7204633246892
14859. once and for all he'd finish this marine who would not die	637.6623034701927
14860. it sounded as if the man were calling him: hey	japanese h hey there japanese	1658.070531611966
14861. the man tilted back his	head and went through the pantomime of drinking from a container	1260.598548807923
14862. he	performed the act twice more and the begging in his tone grew more distinct	1652.3486934204188
14863. the marine nodded	vigorously	2.936976808759697
14864. matsuo laughed slung the rifle	22.401537196315523

14866. his superiors had said that all marines were depraved	389.29872867159025
14867. the marine slumped forward into a bow like a priest before	an idol	794.7555627947929
14868. remembering his own thirst matsuo took out his water bottle	558.664661069799
14869. one swallow was all he would have; he was very thirsty but he must	observe water discipline	1412.718008453558
14870. his years of campaigning had taught him	the value of water discipline	965.9984122188741
14871. he began to uncap the bottle	the rusty cap squealing on its threads	794.1028915540603
14872. popping upright the marine waved	both hands and shouted	395.2557123600195
14873. of course it was water he really	craved; down in the broil of the sun he was becoming dried out	1883.358121545559
14874. the	marine shouted for it until it seemed that his voice had to crack	1404.3878656613613
14875. he had no water for an enemy	94.32013926995378
14876. and when this was	gone he hadn't even a little bitter tablet to purify other water	if he were to discover some stagnant jungle pool	3897.7855573420943
14877. he capped the	bottle and replaced it	94.02683587181664
14878. after all he had less reason to desire it	than the marine	959.1691428088088
14879. before much longer the marine quieted down	95.24718878004151
14880. the upper part of his packet had stained dark	393.32518260296206
14881. there is nothing for you matsuo said	94.06844565992094

14883. from the convulsive quivers of	the man's shoulders it was plain he had resumed the weeping	1253.025349180417

14886. chairs scraped back and customers hastily vacated their tables	as the tall young buffalo hunter pushed open the swing doors and	walked towards the bar	3934.173129430675
14887. only blue throat and his gang stayed where	they were	373.4757186908032
14888. blue throat was slumped with his back against the bar elbows	supporting his massive frame	1653.050054651024
14889. he leered at the stranger as the	distance between them closed	504.71851849982374
14890. since when did they allow beardless	kids into the saloon bars of this town boys	1638.399986000527
14891. he asked	0.20041515
14892. seems	to me i don't remember altering any law about that	748.1936031756824
14893. he straightened up alert now as the buffalo hunter came closer	507.4882684888921
14894. stay	right here where you are kid he called	394.0865185934041
14895. i don't aim	to have minors breathing down my neck when i'm a-drinking:	the stranger ignored him	1418.56776042319
14896. he didn't stop till he was within three	feet of blue throat and by that time the gang leader's right	hand was on the butt of his revolver	4452.72957780694
14897. i'm billy tilghman	said the stranger and i've come for pat conyers' body	794.1505410779235

14899. because i'm asking	0.20041515
14900. most of the time i get	what i ask for	556.4281095741628
14901. blue throat winked at his six cronies	93.76186903097326
14902. the kid has no manners boys	65.7595098150874
14903. shall we teach him some	14.957112240872581
14904. his	gun was half drawn when he asked the question but the weapon never	left its holster	2117.260126243897
14905. tilghman's clenched fist swept over in a terrific	right cross and clipped the big gunfighter on the side of his chin	2036.874342044265
14906. his	head snapped round and he reeled back crashing into the table where	his buddies were sprawling	2130.2780183365667
14907. tilghman leapt on to him dragged	him upright and hit him again this time sending him careening against	the bar	1882.5426065182987
14908. a bullet gouged into the bar top an inch from tilghman's	stomach as blue throat's henchmen started shooting	2374.6073974433593
14909. tilghman	flung himself aside dropped on one knee and pulled his own gun	795.8966771318255
14910. the colt roared twice and two men dropped writhing	393.1538461240391
14911. a third shot	doused the light	44.026987641030495
14912. somewhere at the far end of the room a voice yelled	you all right billy	1653.8733139959154
14913. yes george but i ain't	got poor old pat's body yet	501.4446502434839
14914. and i aim to have it	64.67652443448478
14915. he fired	again and somewhere in the gloom a man screamed	500.3820882448484
14916. another took off	his gun belt and flung his weapons to the floor	1191.2364249314166
14917. and me said another blue throat	henchman	93.49017910710424
14918. tilghman and his partner	george rust herded the men into a corner	969.8466861270051
14919. and now said tilghman	with deadly calm i'll repeat what i said	642.0547621733134
14920. i've come	for pat conyers' body	65.32415426133498
14921. in two minutes the body of tilghman's	former comrade who had been killed by blue throat in a gambling	brawl the previous night was carried into the town's funeral	parlor to be prepared for decent burial	3854.3836039052003
14922. blue throat nursing an aching	jaw and a collosal dose of wounded pride rode out of town with the	survivors of the fight	3478.847558365071
14923. that critter will be back tomorrow	predicted george rust and he'll bring fifty of his kind	back with him	1729.7025289465714
14924. blue throat won't stand for this	64.67501193164387
14925. he'll shoot up	the town	14.842095524262536
14926. the reverend james	doran had scarcely completed pat conyers' last rites on boot	hill in the township of petrie when shots were heard in the distance	4086.597824684856
14927. amen said the reverend doran grabbing his rifle propped	up against a tombstone and now my brethren it would seem that	our presence is required elsewhere	2741.3151289481425
14928. billy tilghman and	his comrades rode off to the battle	562.8960433464958
14929. blue throat who had ruled the	town with his six-shooter for the last six months certainly had no intention	of relinquishing his profitable dictatorship	2469.917441774235
14930. it was essential	that he should restore his formidable reputation as a rip-roaring	ruthless gun-slinger and this was the time-honored wild west method	of doing it	4088.2181938613185
14931. he rode in at the head of sixty trigger-happy and	liquor-crazed desperadoes and took over a livery barn at the entrance	to main street	2480.3373074919464
14932. the entire length of the street could be raked with	rifle fire from this barn	1654.2938319359887
14933. any posse riding down the street to demand	blue throat's surrender would be wiped out with one deadly burst	of fire	2040.1379993699716
14934. the law-abiding citizens of petrie had gathered	inside kaster's store halfway down the street	1413.75337919382
14935. several were firing	into the barn when billy tilghman arrived	377.9925887038023
14936. he sized up the situation	and shook his head	392.75645220080264
14937. if blue throat has his way he'll	keep us all cooped up in here for days he said	1564.9934092724866
14938. there's only	one thing to move him fast and we have it right here in this very	store	2346.8217982974343
14939. he called the store owner and together they went into	the stockroom	639.6350223610323
14940. billy returned with six sticks of dynamite	140.3763089329954
14941. i'm	gonna drop these into blue throat's lap he announced and	i'd like every gun to be firing into that barn while i get near	enough to toss 'em through the window	3444.7029416484866
14942. he slipped outside	hugging the walls of buildings and dodging into doorways	959.1248263194162
14943. blue throat's	men spotted him and a hail of bullets splintered the store fronts	and board walk as he passed	1889.5390553612178
14944. fifty yards away from the barn	he dodged inside a barber's shop and came out at the back	2361.241363902441
14945. here he	couldn't be seen by blue throat and his gang	504.0143934783685
14946. all he had to do	was light the fuses of the dynamite sticks run to within ten yards of	an open window in the barn and hurl the sticks through	4852.635554757006
14947. billy	tilghman did just that	14.841185271089454
14948. within seconds the big barn was blasted into	smoking splinters with every outlaw either dead or injured inside	2361.1120969534163
14949. it was the abrupt end of blue throat's dictatorship in petrie	499.71811490115545
14950. though	only slightly injured himself the big hoodlum never returned to	those parts	1176.51118271799
14951. to tilghman the incident was just one of a long	list of hair-raising smash-'em-down adventures on the side of the	law which started in 1872 when he was only eighteen years old and did	not end till fifty years later when he was shot dead after warning	a drunk to be quiet	5089.399116109359
14952. of all the rip-roaring two-fisted tough boys	of the old west uncle billy tilghman stands out head and	shoulders	2610.6245853479313
14953. he was the lawman who survived more gunfights than any	other famous gun-slinging character in the book	1407.4029346498924
14954. he saw the most action	beat up more badmen with his bare fists broke up the most gangs and	sent more murderers to the gallows than any other us marshal	who lived before or after him	5782.281215284598
14955. for fifty years his guns and	ham-like fists shot holes through and battered the daylights out of the	enemies of law and order in the frontier towns of the west	3218.983092562354
14956. the deeds of countless western bandits and outlaws have been glorified	almost to the point of hero-worship but because billy tilghman remained	strictly on the side of the law throughout his action-packed career	his achievements and the appalling risks he took while taming the	west have remained almost unsung	7339.904204436067
14957. citizens took the view that	a lawman was expected to risk his life on the odd occasion anyway	but this fighting fury of a man risked it regularly over a period of	half a century	3760.173341029381
14958. he came within an ace of being riddled with bullets	during his long fight with the doolin gang which terrorized oklahoma	in the 1890's	3683.222336653328
14959. led by bill doolin these mobsters specialized	in train robberies but as a sideline they looted stores and robbed	banks making liberal use of their guns	2738.624380403647
14960. bill doolin's ambition	it appeared was to carve out his name with bullets alongside those of	jesse james and billy the kid and bill tilghman had sworn he would	stop him	5011.371905946902
14961. tilghman knew that some ranchers were hand-in-glove	with the doolin gang	501.9442783683655
14962. they bought rustled cattle from the outlaw	kept him supplied with guns and ammunition harbored his men in their	houses	2839.640629500032
14963. billy decided to set an example by arresting one of the ranchers	named ed dunn who lived at rock fort	1884.558335924624
14964. on a bitterly	cold day in january 1895 accompanied only by neal brown as his	deputy tilghman left the township of guthrie and headed for rock fort	and dunn's ranch	4846.30881822474
14965. it was snowing hard when they got there and	they saw no horses outside	936.9681074332959
14966. the only evidence of occupation came from	the chimney which was belching out thick smoke	1639.8161780927148
14967. the two lawmen	halted their wagon about twenty yards from the door	642.4171167728357
14968. wait here	neal said tilghman	22.329330195821523
14969. if i don't come out within half an	hour ride back to town and bring out a posse	1574.9115380602066
14970. leaving his rifle	in the wagon tilghman walked up to the door and hammered on it	1886.4083804543188
14971. there was no reply so he shoved it open with his foot and stepped inside	1099.3601265493958
14972. directly opposite the door was a roaring log fire a welcome sight	on that bitterly cold day	2115.5529012163697
14973. seated near it with his back to the door	was the rancher ed dunn	943.862997189279
14974. the rancher grunted an acknowledgement but didn't move	248.9736847357226
14975. tilghman	closed the door behind him and walked towards the fire	504.7362975537588
14976. suddenly	he saw something which made his big heart give a sickening lurch	and caused the hairs to bristle on the back of his neck	3892.916570161606
14977. along each side	of the room were six tiered bunks each one screened off with a curtain	1424.4550579469546
14978. and projecting wickedly through these curtains were the	gleaming muzzles of six rifles all trained on billy tilghman	2353.4553484001044
14979. the	fighting marshal had walked right into a trap and at any moment six slugs	might slam into his hide	1885.8535372256943
14980. thinking fast tilghman never	hesitated for one instant	250.05510084935548
14981. he walked right up to the fire as though blissfully	unaware of the guns covering him	1259.3714027983515
14982. the men behind them were	bill doolin and five of his gang- every man a killer	1872.331810916357
14983. cold	day said tilghman placing his hands behind him and casually	presenting his backside to the fire	1415.76680004274
14984. just dropped in to ask where	jed hawkins lives	391.19425550378406
14985. can't seem to locate landmarks in this snow	166.10108039617677
14986. he wouldn't look tilghman in	the face	141.45315140799846
14987. follow the river for five miles he said hoarsely	260.8025820955589
14988. jed's	homestead is on the south bank	142.08280759905747
14989. resisting the overwhelming	temptation to flng himself out of that bristling death-trap	tilghman deliberately engaged the nervous rancher in trivial conversation	for a good ten minutes	2717.660864093701
14990. all that time rifle barrels were pointing	unwaveringly at his head and body	1185.8971147184218
14991. one false move on his part and	he would be a dead man	791.100667934242
14992. well he announced guess i'll	be going now ed and thanks for the warmup	1416.7852274708976
14993. he strolled back	to the door whistling softly hands still clasped behind him	784.5797596847881
14994. he	left the house and almost certain death without even increasing his pace	and wondered by what remarkable stroke of providence he had been	allowed to come out alive	4658.0115795200845
14995. but he knew well enough that those	guns would still be trained on his back as he walked towards the wagon	2036.0782523195444
14996. if he showed signs of collecting his rifle and going back with his	deputy to the ranch he would be shot down instantly	3487.7815912306205
14997. leisurely	he climbed on to the wagon next to neal brown	499.9359573919026
14998. don't say or	do anything he said softly	250.72432032359157
14999. just get out of here without it looking	as though we're in a hurry	939.9348103175447
15000. that place is crawling with bill	doolin and his gang	559.7473440906717
15001. even as he spoke those words billy	tilghman's life hung on a thread	794.5853891779957
15002. back in the house a hoodlum named	red buck sore because billy had been allowed to leave unscathed	jumped from a bunk and swore he was going after him to kill him right	then	5492.698450840009
15003. you'll stay right here commanded bill doolin	covering red with his rifle	641.3492674482449
15004. billy tilghman is too good a man	to shoot in the back	962.486099170889
15005. but the fighting	marshal's fifty-year run of immunity from violent death came to a	full and final stop one night in a street at cromwell oklahoma where	he had been sent to clean up the gambling and vice rackets	4144.733799024098
15006. wiley lynn a self-styled prohibition officer had hit town the previous	day and had been drinking ever since	2356.552038042645
15007. that night he reeled out	of ma murphy's dance hall and proceeded to disturb the peace by shooting	off his revolver	2027.33697727557
15008. for several months now jack carter a big overgrown boy of fifteen	with a fuzzy pimpled face and greenish catlike eyes with a lot	of red in them had been haunted by a dream a vision of a woman	6218.867272241921
15009. this	woman had no distinct shape or size and no particular face but she	radiated warmth a sweet warmth; she would talk to him in a soothing	voice about things his mother would have said were not nice and put	her hands on him and kiss him passionately	4849.8490271007
15010. when she would do these	things he would turn blind for an instant and become sick at his stomach	2600.955495954192
15011. then he would run to the toilet behind the house	374.3233209030871
15012. sometimes he	did this three or four times a day for this woman was almost always	with him	2351.807428983775
15013. he would feel ashamed each time and wonder whether his mother	and father knew- thinking they might see it in his eyes or smell	it on him	2853.8489805447784
15014. but they never said anything so he figured it was all right	955.2872765571843
15015. and so when miss langford came to teach at the one-room	chestnut school where jack was a pupil in the eighth grade the woman	of jack's mind assumed the teacher's face and figure	3553.0200346624756
15016. he could	not keep his eyes off her when at school; when he went home at	night he took her with him in his mind and she did the things the anonymous	woman used to do and he did the thing afterwards each time as	he used to do	7348.091160862745
15017. when he awoke in the mornings she was in his mind and	he could hardly wait to get to school to be near her in the flesh	2849.245350237542
15018. miss langford was an attractive	girl	65.85882115840715
15019. tall blonde blue-eyes fair buxom without being heavy she cut	a fine figure of budding womanhood as she swished among the pupils	in her fresh starched summer dress	2976.816274393993
15020. something was beginning to stir	and come alive in her too	she was twenty now; but if it had been it had been smothered until	: you could tell it by the way she watched the older	bigger boys like jack	4962.625678767841
15021. she would look at jack with that hidden	something in her eyes and jack would see the woman and become breathless	and a little sick	2597.2568059831674
15022. school began in august the hottest	part of the year and for the first few days miss langford was very	lenient with the children letting them play a lot and the new ones sort	of get acquainted with one another	6317.779397547785
15023. the first two or three days they	went home early	372.62253570258997
15024. all that is except jack	22.146291489934967
15025. he hung around	the schoolhouse watching through a window from outside while miss	langford straightened desks and put the room in order	2178.7380025476346
15026. once	she kneeled down to pick up some books	where they'd dropped on the floor and jack looked up her dress-	at the bare expanse of incredibly white leg	4652.081461529841
15027. he thought for a moment	his heart had stopped beating	373.8555376831391
15028. about that time miss langford straightened	up and looked out the window directly at him he thought although	probably she didn't even see him	3698.2488709638324
15029. he jumped back ducked and ran	crouching down the hill away from the school	951.1054392998783
15030. he didn't	look back and he ran until he was out of sight of the schoolhouse and	out of breath; then he slowed to a walk	4075.3498381588774
15031. the vision became even stronger	now	43.79494645891705
15032. i'll get her yet	he muttered to himself	249.4626078425436
15033. i've got to get her	14.687664757787278
15034. that night he dreamed	a dream violent with passion in which he and the woman now the	teacher did everything except engage in the act	and when he	awoke the next morning his heart was afire	5786.359904529866
15035. he ate litle that	morning and his mother became concerned inasmuch as he usually ate	heartily	1256.1025087447558
15036. what's the matter honey	4.434704908105454
15037. she said with the	solicitude of a middle-aged woman for her only child	788.9281474819365
15038. aren't	you hungry	0.30041514999999996
15039. no i'm not hungry he said pushing	back the bacon and eggs	643.4304012687348
15040. outside it was already hot at 7:30 am	and it was getting hot in the kitchen	1876.8177194275443
15041. he felt a little sick at	his stomach	166.2266645213667
15042. are you sick	0.30041514999999996
15043. no he said	0.20041515
15044. i guess it's this hot weather	65.22857672901625
15045. don't you play hard today then	43.263671113528815
15046. and if you get sick ask the teacher	to let you come home early	1416.7336178937753
15047. daddy left the car for me and i'm	going to town this afternoon	780.5547468222976
15048. o k i won't	play hard he promised	249.3249719804121
15049. just then charles lever yelled hey	jack from the quarry road which ran behind the carter house	and jack grabbed the lunch from the table and darted out the kitchen	door yelling good-bye mom over his shoulder	3968.829618403951
15050. whaddya	say boy	0.30041514999999996
15051. charles said grinning showing his huge yellow	teeth	167.35506372736552
15052. charles also fifteen was tall and skinny scraggly with	straight black hair like an indian's and sharp brown eyes	2608.057860600385
15053. he considered	himself handsome and seemed to think all the girls were after him	942.7611446166254
15054. you know what i done last night	141.87389529141618
15055. charles said as	they picked their way over the rocky road which led up the hill away	from the dixie highway through a corn field and a patch of woods to	the school	3570.063525484236
15056. jack knew of course that the tale to be unfolded	would involve a girl and probably be dirty because girls were charles'	only apparent interest	3902.3545189401607
15057. but jack always derived vicarious sensual	thrills from charles' revelations	so he usually invited them as he	did now	1731.5279681902841
15058. what	0.30041514999999996
15059. i got margaret rider in one	of them old box cars down there by the quarry	1257.6205501620327
15060. a nude imaginary	picture of miss langford flashed across jack's mind	746.4270682363801
15061. hell you say	0.20041515
15062. he said lapsing into the profanity	he often used when away from his parents and especially when he	was with charles	3051.8299020202817
15063. how'd you do it	2.934656529649969
15064. hell i jist	got on top of-   no i mean how'd you get her to	do it	2118.7392493848506
15065. hell i jist ask her	14.744543639824409
15066. jist like	that	0.30041514999999996
15067. hell yes	0.20041515
15068. she's been hangin' around me	a lot here lately and i figgered i might as well's try it	2356.1025653928823
15069. besides	i heard her old uncle that stays there has been doin' it	786.2133699095249
15070. it's all over branchville	4.453583751067709
15071. if you'd get out of your back yard once in a while you might even	get her your ownself	1717.7353515425468
15072. i might try it one of these days	jack said wonderingly thinking of miss langford	1631.3649218987111
15073. when	they reached the school a gang of boys and girls were already	there playing crack the whip in front of the schoolhouse	2322.379538796319
15074. miss	langford in a fresh white dress and low-heeled white sandals without	socks was out there with them trying to get them inside	3452.998767532834
15075. time	for books she yelled jingling a little five-and-dime store	bell in her right hand	1090.8065022462229
15076. oh come	on miss langford play with us just onct one of the little girls	begged smiling wistfully	2353.5624963534938
15077. no not now said the teacher	43.799541162763504
15078. come inside now	0.30041514999999996
15079. the children	grudgingly stopped playing then and straggled into the schoolhouse	502.48316705531926
15080. jack watched miss langford all morning	64.78121859547188
15081. he could think of nothing	else save his mental image of her nude figure and what charles	had said that morning about margaret rider	2452.5632456294297
15082. occasionally he would	look across the aisle at margaret fourteen and demure in a fresh green	organdy dress sitting in the sixth-grade row and he coud hardly believe	she would do what charles had said she did	5947.602866646286
15083. at noontime	remembering what the teacher had said about maybe playing with the	kids jack stayed close to the schoolhouse while all the other big boys	except charles went off out the road to play ball	3861.290113230306
15084. why ain't	you playin' ball	22.143955564123015
15085. he asked charles suspiciously as they sat	in the well-house shade watching the girls congregate in front of the	schoolhouse	1878.3894084769515
15086. miss langford come out and play with us like you	promised several of the little girls called	2117.703193522964
15087. i'd druther	stay here and watch the girls charles grinned	376.0960904814851
15088. maybe some	of 'em will fall down and we'll see up their dress	1184.9099783028803
15089. maybe	jack said idly watching for miss langford	165.26963411521558
15090. presently	she came out of the schoolhouse	139.64949364784565
15091. when she appeared two or three	of the little girls jumped up and down yelling goody goody	1421.4848672574678
15092. let's play with 'em jack said rising from where	he sat on the ground and dusting off his overall pants	2829.3435777044897
15093. ok	charles rose also and the two of them moved over to join	the girls	1100.4088024440616
15094. they played crack the whip a few minutes without mishap	560.9842967443668
15095. then when miss langford was on the end of the line of girls	jack in the middle of the line gave an extra hard pull and the young	teacher sprawled backwards sitting down hard her dress flying over	her head	4205.970010223526
15096. while she was struggling to get her skirt down and get	on her feet again jack ran over offered her his hand and said gosh	i'm sorry miss langford	4607.453132959492
15097. i didn't mean to pull so hard	92.77686572943644
15098. that's all right she said tossing her head back	to get the hair out of her eyes	2109.713391152393
15099. with one hand	she held her skirt down while she took jack's extended hand with	the other	1403.3225786592907
15100. when her hand touched his fire went through jack and he	felt weak but he managed somehow to get her on her feet	3454.577688324578
15101. he thought	she gave him that look with the hidden something in it as he let her hand	go	1727.169421724921
15102. thank you she said dusting herself off	140.7784673880393
15103. will you play with us again miss langford	165.08132521147897
15104. one of the little	girls said	65.08547042953377
15105. maybe some other day	2.9644131047453928
15106. oh shucks the girl said	22.315831487065175
15107. i don't believe i'll	play any more neither	166.8559514047351
15108. me neither others said and soon	the game broke up the children going off in pairs in larger groups	and alone	3043.0831675217387
15109. jack walked off alone out the road in the searing	midday sun past robert allen's three-room tarpapered house toward	the field where the other boys were playing ball thinking of what	he would do in order to make miss langford have him stay in after	school- because this was the day he had decided when he thought he saw	the look in her eyes	5713.320149775548
15110. when he came back to the schoolhouse	his mind was made up	963.0032890922981
15111. he simply would not work his arithmetic problems	when the teacher held his class	941.0725491734099
15112. that should do it he thought because	miss langford had said she was going to be strict about school	work	2797.0943486674796
15113. he had considered throwing erasers or flipping paperwads at someone	or pulling the hair of the girl sitting in front of him but he	couldn't take a chance on either of these possibilities: the teacher	probably would make him stand face-to-wall in a corner instead of stay	in after school	4980.942437614851
15114. the only drawback now to the plan he'd	decided on was that someone else might fail to do his work too and the	teacher would have that person stay late along with jack	5342.146212297686
15115. but	i've got to take a chance on it he told himself desperately	780.047156425511
15116. to his surprise his plan worked perfectly	140.40719393514576
15117. all right if you	can't do your arithmetic during school hours you can do it after school	it out miss langford said firmly not smiling	2589.4983678343747
15118. you will	stay here thirty minutes after the others go home this afternoon and	work your problems	2131.3860079657316
15119. and so when the others stampeded out that	afternoon	jack remained docilely in his seat near a window looking out in	what he hoped was a pitiable manner while the other kids laughed and	yelled in at him and made faces as they dispersed going home	4672.079785456821
15120. his heart was pounding like a mighty dynamo and he was	trying to think his mind seeming to scream at him like a hurt or frightened	child how will i do it	5191.022729010732
15121. on the fringe of the amused throng of white onlookers stood a	young woman of remarkable beauty and poise	1728.0135382417568
15122. she munched little ginger	cakes called mulatto's belly and kept her green somewhat hypnotic	eyes fixed on a light-colored male who was prancing wildly with a 5-foot	king snake wrapped around his bronze neck	5507.299850355969
15123. the youth with	the snake had a natural pride and joy of life which appealed to the woman	1582.5711173319905
15124. lithe and muscular he had well-molded features and his light	color told of the european ancestors who had been intimate with the slave	women of his family	4280.234527364095
15125. the haughty white girl turned to a distinguished	hawk-faced man standing at her side and murmured: look	at your watch col garvier	2178.373268476855
15126. it is almost time for and calinda	to begin	391.40673596606837
15127. col henri garvier was one of new orleans'	most important and enlightened slave owners	938.9127824639551
15128. he chuckled and gave	the signal for the dance to start	754.7433870879713
15129. the slaves ran gaily to the center	of congo square and gathered around a sweaty youth they called johnny	no-name	1876.194784492224
15130. johnny vigorously pounded two bleached steer	bones against the gourd which served as his drum	1652.0343640911713
15131. he showed his gleaming	tusks of teeth and bellowed incoherently his brass earrings jangling	discordantly as he shook and trembled in ecstasy	2187.2166395656104
15132. the	drummer	flogged the gourd with frantic intensity as the dancers began the calinda	a sensual gyration which had long been a favorite of voodoo practitioners	and their disciples in the louisiana slave compounds	5512.332823462513
15133. the	dance was of haitian origin	43.580852347220436
15134. the white girl with the penetrating	green eyes sipped the lemonade handed to her by a handsome man of	about 30 who had coppery skin and beetling eyebrows	4476.456518344774
15135. he was possessive	in his manner and though a slave obviously was educated after a	fashion and imitated the manners of his owners	2333.857589677435
15136. he proudly wore the	blue livery of her house for the girl was madame delphine lalaurie	wife of the prominent surgeon dr louis lalaurie who bore one	of the south's oldest and most cherished names	5634.1681141896515
15137. delphine was	a pace-setter in high society	94.08854597685742
15138. she was a top horsewoman and one of	the city's most gracious hostesses	1185.5728083974896
15139. although new orleans was not	to learn of it for a spell she also was a sadist a nymphomaniac and	unobtrusively mad- the perpetrator of some of the worst crimes against	humanity ever committed on american soil	3950.1169643800945
15140. madame lalaurie	gestured with her riding crop toward the 20-year-old youth who was	stomping and writhing with the king snake still draped over his bare shoulders	4084.160098101433
15141. the slender handsome fellow was called dandy brandon by	the other slaves	640.865895553131
15142. he was gifted with animal magnetism and a potent allure	for women of any race	1643.3765669569748
15143. but dandy had had little experience with	girls on his master's plantation in bayou st john	1258.9662648192202
15144. shy	actually he avoided feminine overtures and seemed truly ignorant	of the girls' desires when they sought to make liaisons with him in	the open fields in carriages and in boathouses	4989.666001804873
15145. this young slave	was therefore quite unprepared when delphine lalaurie signaled	that she wanted him to draw near	1569.0757804866687
15146. the woman eyed the youth with the	avidity a coin collector might display toward a rare doubloon which is	not yet in his collection	3695.9136248983777
15147. what is your name boy	14.896350174046185
15148. come	a bit closer	4.4311359505111625
15149. i won't bite you know	14.97854212998547
15150. he gaped at madame	lalaurie and sniffed the paris perfume which emanated from her	1417.516324675258
15151. my name is dandy brandon missy	43.518071320663346
15152. i belong	to master alexander prieur	65.39521616352813
15153. she said with intense feeling:	come near let me feel your arms	640.711117668407
15154. you look quite strong and	healthy to me dandy	389.8494625253603
15155. mrs lalaurie impatiently propelled	the slave toward her waiting carriage	372.50093244737434
15156. lifting her skirts she climbed	in never relinquishing her grip on his arm	1176.8232715584386
15157. the woman seemed utterly	unafraid of the snake which coiled on the floor in a torpor	1263.7937542494337
15158. once inside the luxuriosly-upholstered landau she drew the curtains	and proceeded to give the startled youth the kind of physical examination	usually reserved for army inductees	4071.2174790253584
15159. satisfied at last and	after a few amorous gambits on her part which convinced delphine that	dandy was capable of learning new arts she opened the window and called	to her liveried driver	3528.2533812114525
15160. this was the big man with the proprietory	air and the beetling shaggy eyebrows	1419.9760179534483
15161. aristide! i	want you	to find monsieur prieur at once and give him this money for the	boy's purchase	1728.1316472206304
15162. there's $600 in gold in this chamois sack	247.80669477058467
15163. if the	old fool argues about the price tell him i shall order my husband	not to treat him as a patient any longer	2460.240551763353
15164. prieur has gout and depends	on louis' pills and bleedings	560.1848241144542
15165. besides he owns 300 slaves	14.859260079324326
15166. one	less shouldn't matter to him	65.43138287414918
15167. aristide devol the sardonic	manservant who had been brought in chains years before from his native	sierra leone smiled thinly and touched his well-brushed beaver	hat	2734.5316863704247
15168. his bold eyes raked the woman and a perceptive spectator might	sense that there was more to their relationship than that of slave to	owner	3875.1502625869316
15169. another youth madame	0.20041515
15170. the coachman said softly	4.4141873885769325
15171. this one is a tender chicken oui	94.09095353135892
15172. such delicate beauty	such fine flesh	65.06267575006594
15173. it will rip and shred easily for madame	165.72422138304847

15176. delphine	lalaurie took the reins in her gloved hands and drove dandy	brandon- cowering in the back seat of the carriage- to her mansion	at 677 perdido street	4460.320926843705
15177. dr louis lalaurie stood on the	veranda at the head of the driveway and watched his carriage as it approached	the pillared mansion	2327.8011634865975
15178. dandy curiosity overcoming his apprehensions	peered out at the doctor from the window of the vehicle	1883.7804800067647
15179. he	saw a pint-sized man with a graying spade beard and an unusually large	head	1096.2684509809626
15180. dr lalaurie wore a maroon smoking jacket and his myopic	eyes were blurry and glistened behind thick octagonal lenses	2587.0490834322345

15182. another young man my dear	22.04187545460343

15184. delphine presented her cheek for a kiss	and the physician pecked it like a timid rooster	1885.4480608216193
15185. dandy is	to be our house guest louis	166.58041272104452
15186. i want the room in the attic prepared	for him he is a most unusual lad quite precocious in many ways	3056.9928352791057
15187. he	deserves a better life than just rotting away on the prieur plantation	790.2652557082929
15188. his room will be ready shortly	64.69800778165985
15189. the physician led the horses to the stable after a cursory	glance at the cringing slave	1261.5287681590314
15190. had dandy been older or wiser instinct	might have warned him that he would be well advised to flee from the	lalauries' tender care if he valued his life	4670.137663630392
15191. but he liked	the smell of delphine's perfume	166.36931619395665
15192. besides her endearments and caresses	in the carriage had been new and stirring experiences to the simple	youth	2351.3038747532264
15193. also he was weary of plantation drudgery and monotony	260.2891537228989
15194. so dandy brandon trustingly entered the house with delphine	lalaurie and trudged up the rear steps to the attic room which was to	be his new home	4284.618017964388
15195. airless and dingy though it was the attic represented	luxury to a slave who had led a wretched life with six brothers and	sisters and assorted relatives in a shanty at bayou st john	3661.455049777915
15196. he bounced exuberantly on the sagging bed and was even more delighted	when madame lalaurie- after closing the door- showed the	slave that the bed was designed for something other than slumber	5168.186705836799
15197. it was just as well that the ignorant dandy enjoyed himself to the	hilt that first evening for the room was to become his prison cell	2713.466785719775
15198. when he finally left the sinister mansion on perdido street he was	carried out in a coroner's basket	2351.1930413332793
15199. just six weeks after	dandy brandon's arrival at the mansion the little surgeon and	his svelte young wife gave their annual open house and ball to which	only new orleans' oldest and wealthiest families were invited	3866.675457081171
15200. a stringed orchestra played softly behind the potted palms and delphine	circulated graciously among her guests chatting airily of the	forthcoming races the latest fashions from paris and louisiana	politics	4823.610087366227
15201. suddenly there was a commotion upstairs a despairing	boyish shriek and the strains of the waltz faltered and died as the musicians	and guests gaped at an apparition descending the marble staircase	3468.7032216926027
15202. it was dandy brandon clad only in a bloody loincloth	emaciated and quaking as if the devil were breathing hard on him	3283.4748876521758
15203. the	lad's once superb body was a mass of scars and welts	639.7281547974197
15204. his pinched	face showed the ravages of malnutrition	252.26628022625346
15205. feebly he pointed an	accusing finger at madame lalaurie and shouted: evil woman!	you did this h you like to hurt h to beat people h i want h	to go home	3458.859849233898
15206. these were the last words he ever uttered	249.08926894315832
15207. convulsively	he spat up some blood and collapsed into the arms of senator	gaston berche crimsoning the frilly shirt and waistcoat the politician	wore	2474.716256155837
15208. dr louis lalaurie examined the inert form of	the slave on the parquet dance floor and pronounced him dead	2604.3190090645953
15209. the ball	broke up in confusion	43.302822267022755
15210. guests stared with horror at madame lalaurie	and made speedy departures	757.5758837905212
15211. delphine stood like stone	her eyes alive	with hate as she looked down at the sheeted corpse	1422.966687062828
15212. but at	the coroner's inquest delphine told a forthright story	559.6701270077904
15213. i	saw the boy dandy at the congo square festivities and felt sorry	for him	1100.9229737975588
15214. it was our hope to educate him and to give him his freedom	when the right time came for he was a bright and friendly youth who	seemed worthy of our interest	5162.539724650649
15215. after i paid monsieur prieur for	dandy i brought him home but he was ill at ease and ran away the	same night	2328.1247495844
15216. how he returned in such a ghastly condition or why i	cannot say	1181.5004199697644
15217. dr lalaurie and i didn't even know he was in the	house until the night of our ball when he came down the stairs	2470.390790970862
15218. she daubed at her swimming eyes with a lacy handkerchief and said	with obvious emotion: that poor boy! he must have fallen in	with evil companions for he was a simple youth and quite trusting and	inexperienced	5904.179678636754
15219. ruffians must have robbed and beaten him before bringing	him back to our house to die	1262.3780167240686
15220. such a pitiful end!   though	the slave's dying words about the woman troubled the coroner's	panel dandy's accusation was adjudged an aberration by the jury	and disregarded	4326.947470903588
15221. the lalauries were at the top rung of the social ladder	and even a jury didn't feel privileged to doubt the veracity	of so illustrious a lady	2876.3124092455823
15222. moreover runaway slaves frequently got into	serious trouble in new orleans' dives	961.8913186584529
15223. so the verict was	death at the hands of a person or persons unknown and the elite	of the city accepting delphine's testimony welcomed her and the	doctor back into the fold	3449.4813364467327
15224. once again life went its serene way- soirees	fox hunts balls and dinners	1182.5401867590676
15225. the excitement over brandon's	bizarre death abated and madame lalaurie's stock soared when	she resumed her self-imposed chores of visiting the poor and bringing	cakes and comfort to destitute patients in the county hospital	3640.285979459597
15226. then	on july 2 there occurred another incident which set tongues to	wagging at a furious clip	2114.553055896154
15227. mrs victor dominique socially	prominent and a neighbor of the lalauries chanced to glance out of	her parlor window at dusk one evening and beheld an amazing sight	2990.073586091553
15228. the	manservant devol and his mistress delphine lalaurie were pursuing	a young girl- an octoroon of cameo-like beauty- across the front	lawn of the lalaurie mansion	4103.258062574765
15229. the girl was not more than 16	93.53306842608258
15230. she	was nude to the waist and her tumbled abundance of black hair did not	conceal the knife slashes on her back	3249.938937389442
15231. the bleeding girl was	tiring fast; the coachman and delphine were gaining on her as she raced	down perdido street	1879.9290086863452
15232. the fugitive cried out in an oddly	sibilant voice: help me somebody! they have pulled out all	my teeth and now she will carve out my tongue with her hacksaw!	bastards he would say all i did was put a beat to that vivaldi	stuff and the first chair clobbered me! since then and	since the pure grain had gotten him divorced from every decent- and	even indecent- group from greenwich village to the embarcadero	he had become a sucker-rolling freight-jumper	0.30166232349522504
15233. there ain't	nothin' faster or lonelier or more direct than a cannonball	freight	when you wanna go someplace feathertop would say	2045.9447038612784
15234. the accommodations	may not be the poshest but man! there ain't nobody	askin' for your	ticket stub neither	2344.15235367091
15235. he had been conning	the freights for a long long time now	642.5403643936962
15236. ever since the hooch and the	trouble with the quartet and midge and the child	1654.2294008175443
15237. it had been a very long time that had no form and no end	946.445630108404
15238. he was- as he told himself in the vernacular of a trade no longer	his own- riding the dark train out	3038.944894702917
15239. out and out and never to return	again	166.28962520798845
15240. till one day the last freight had been jumped the last pint	had been killed the last beat had been rapped	3060.3293122856476
15241. that was the day it	ended	43.24901239209192
15242. the freight car was cold early in the morning	390.9867215790167
15243. he was pressed far back into the corner of the car on his hay sacks	the rattling and tinning of the wheels on the rails almost covering	the sound of his ocarina	3455.0606846012183
15244. he held his elbows away from his	body and the little sweet potato trilled neatly and sweetly as he tickled	its tune-belly	3292.1333553587856
15245. the train slowed at a road crossing and	the big door slid open; at first gratingly caught by grains of corn-	then with a clash into its slot	2988.3182564543067
15246. the boy lifted the girl	by the waist and set her on the lip of the floor	2129.498700948419

15248. now that is a very nice	a very nice he murmured to himself back in his corner	2139.987248364011

15380. she grabbed	at feathertop's sleeve and shrieked help him! help him!	do something!	they neither liked nor disliked the old man	3058.5162119519327
15381. to them he could	have been the broken bell in the church tower which rang before and	after mass and at noon and at six each evening- its tone repetitive	monotonous never breaking the boredom of the streets	4041.300018942733
15382. the old	man was unimportant	22.02022603668049
15383. yet if he were not there they would have	missed him as they would have missed the sounds of bees buzzing against	the screen door in early june; or the smell of thick tomato paste-	the ripe smell that was both sweet and sour- rising up from	aluminum trays wrapped in fly-dotted cheesecloth	5135.560848965207
15384. or the surging whirling	sounds of bats at night when their black bodies dived into the blackness	above and below the amber street lights	3714.176390928123
15385. or the bay of female	dogs in heat	166.26987842402696
15386. they never called him by name although he had	one	567.3991180992764
15387. filippo rossi that's what he was called in the old country;	but here he was just signore or the old man	2032.2804440495468
15388. but this was	not unusual because youth in these quarters was always pushed at a distance	from its elders	2588.168718151698
15389. it went to church	on sunday and one saturday a month went to confession	944.3643217287047
15390. but youth	asked nothing of its parents- not a touch of the hand or a kiss given	in passing	2593.177972754688
15391. the only thing unusual about the old man had	long since happened	642.291582154098
15392. but the past was dead here as the present was dead	755.6437805560743
15393. once the old man had had a wife	168.37571379428596
15394. and once she too ignored him	65.72459515853475
15395. with a tiny fur-piece wrapped around her shoulders she wiggled her	satin-covered buttocks down the street before him and didn't stop	2032.9181193503996
15396. in one hand she clutched a hundred dollar bill and in the other a straw	suitcase	1888.2983678902194
15397. the way she strutted down the street the old man would	have been blind not to have noticed both	1738.5688206713517
15398. without looking at him	without looking at anything except drexel street directly in front of	her she climbed up into one of those orange streetcars rode away in	it and never came back	5321.905475535691
15399. but she shouldn't have come here	in the first place the women had said	947.8113681220042
15400. she thought she was bigger than we are because she came from	torino	1182.2122662885404
15401. eh torino! she gave herself fancy airs!	just because she had a part on the stage in the old country she thought	she could carry her head higher than ours	3230.7471218854903
15402. they had slapped	their thighs	22.33793038456693
15403. it's not for making pretty speeches about dante	those actresses get paid so good	942.3219775436537
15404. henh! calloused	fingers caressed only by the smoothness of polished rosaries had	swayed excitedly beneath puckered chins where tiny black hairs sprouted	never to be tweezed away	4280.947278383772
15405. mauve-colored mouths that had never known	anything sweeter than the taste of new wine and the passion of man's	tongue had not smiled but had condemned again and again	3117.546544132607
15406. puttana!	but if the old man even thought about his wife	now nobody cared a fig	1899.6971246742996
15407. it was enough for people to know that at	one time he had looked down the street at the fleshy suppleness of a woman	he had consumed- watching her become thinner and thinner in the	distance as thin as the seams on her stockings and still thinner	4770.735891904996
15408. his	voice had not commanded her to stop	248.76241295826694
15409. it had not questioned why	14.738686785531948
15410. the	women said they had seen him wave an exhausted farewell; but he	might have been shooing away the fleas that hopped from his yellow dog	onto him	4475.683448590383
15411. and his eyes- those miniature	sundials of variegated yellow- had not altered their expression	or direction	1256.832799563633
15412. the old man's very soul could have left him and	flown down that street but he wouldn't have had anyone know it	3284.706297014052
15413. perhaps he had known then where that hundred dollar bill had come	from and where it was taking his wife	1884.4981284384498
15414. but when he called for his	withered wrinkled sister rose to care for him and the children had	he guessed that all he would remember of his woman was the memory of	her climbing into that streetcar	5914.0840350985345
15415. there seemed to be a contemptuous	purpose in the way he sat there with his eyes glued to drexel	street and his back in opposition to the church behind him	3220.1623198634
15416. for all	he saw or cared to see this could have been a town in italy not the	outskirts of philadelphia	3051.0091906215052
15417. it could have been bari or chieti for	the way it smelled	643.905308031188
15418. what did it matter to him that the park at the foot	of ash road stretched beneath elevated trains that roared from the	stucco station into the city's center at half-hour intervals	5191.1199956037835
15419. or	that the tiny creek spun its silent course toward the	schuylkill	642.5086545781926
15420. this place was hatred to him just as hatred was his only companion	in his aloneness	1890.4721474529579
15421. to him they were one and the same	167.46800540925034
15422. sameness	for the old man was framed in by a wall of ginkgo trees which divided	these quarters from the city	3051.0942566919666
15423. sameness lined the streets with two-story	houses the color of ash	501.920871697245
15424. it slashed the sloping manure-scented	lawns with concrete steps which climbed upward to white wooden porches	1878.7591046210923
15425. it swayed with the wicker swings and screeched with the rusted hinges	of screen doors	1105.299291958729
15426. even the stable-garage which housed nothing	now but the scent of rot had a lawn before it	2131.5713880593485
15427. and the coffee shop	on drexel street where the men spent their evenings and sundays	playing cards had a rose hedge beneath its window	2474.5656663176665
15428. the hedge reeked	of coffee dregs thrown against it	388.36568670551947
15429. only one house on the street	had no lawn before it	505.9003284470559
15430. it squatted low and square upon the sidewalk	with a heavy iron grating supporting a glass facade	2125.9618588596923
15431. above it from a second-story showroom wooden angels surveyed	the neighborhood	501.01996271722044
15432. did the old man remember them there	139.73182177426014
15433. yet everywhere else sameness was stucco and wood in square blocks-	like fortresses perched against the slant of the hill rising with	the hill to the top where the church was and beyond that to the cemetery	3952.575073209715
15434. only paved alleyways tunneled through the walls of those fortresses	into the mysterious core of intimacy behind the houses where backyards	owned no fences where one man's property blended with the next	to form courtyards in which no one knew privacy	6480.827863685276
15435. love and hatred and	fear were one here shaded only by fig trees and grape vines	1266.441154318833
15436. and the	forked tongue of gossip licked its sinister way from back porch to	back porch	1887.0294253088246
15437. the old man silently fed upon these streets	167.35179880151102
15438. they	kept him alive waiting	22.238550083078778
15439. waiting for what and for whom only he could	tell and would not	793.523640413789
15440. it was as though he had made a pact with the	devil himself but it was not yet time to pay the price	3476.9879416378108
15441. he was holding	out for something	43.230276276047974
15442. he was determined to hold out	65.01089463846662
15443. the old	man's son threw himself down belly first upon a concrete step	taking in the coolness of it and dreaming of the day he would be rich	2987.110316792144
15444. at fifteen he didn't care that he had no mother that he couldn't	remember her face or her touch; neither did he care that aunt rose	provided for him	4657.81013097795
15445. he was named pompeii as a tribute to his	heritage and he couldn't have cared less about that either	1731.1985559127031
15446. to him	life was a restless boredom that began with the rising sun and ended	only with sleep	2362.2801260824353
15447. when he would be a man he would be a rich	man	642.9241895388925
15448. he would not be like the rich americans who lived in white-columned	houses on the other side of the park	2814.07088048225
15449. he would not ride the	eight-thirty local to the city each morning	639.0374880802362
15450. he would not carry a brief	case	141.24876024406856
15451. nor would he work at all	43.49237339226177
15452. he would square his shoulders and	carry a cane before each step	963.4947944966273
15453. he would sit inside the coffee shop	and pound a gloved fist upon the table and a girl would hear him and	come running bowing with her running calling out in her bowing at	your service	3848.6745689871595
15454. he would order her to bring coffee and would take	from his vest pocket a thin black pipe which he would stuff- he would	not remove his gloves- and light and smoke	5187.498196726784
15455. he could do that when	he would be a man	373.8344947999125
15456. hey laura! he called to his sister	on the porch above the steps	1183.5454894544496
15457. she was only ten months older than	he	166.52893057170928
15458. laura what would you say if i smoked a pipe	567.0302172462335
15459. laura	did not answer him	14.797243025906052
15460. she leaned unconcerned against the broken porch	fence brushing and drying her wet gilded hair in the sun	2360.885356761062
15461. one lithe	leg straddled the railing and swung loosely before the creaking	torn pales	945.7648100405893
15462. her tanned foot whose arch swept high and white pointed	artfully toward tapering toes- toes like fingers whose tips glowed	white	3060.430353747291
15463. all the while she sat there her sinewy arms swirled before her	chest	784.2851472633217
15464. her face showed no sign of having heard pompeii	389.5704070974266
15465. it	was a face that had lost its childlike softness and was beginning to	fold within its fragile features a harshness that belied the lyric lines	of its contours	3097.1055762521273
15466. the eyes blue and always somewhat downcast possessed	a sullen quality	751.6092718938758
15467. even though the boy could not see them he knew	they were clouded by distance	1093.4515146665085
15468. he was never sure they fully took	him in	389.55859441553787
15469. pompeii called again laura! but the only answer	that reached him was the screeching of the porch rail from her leg	moving against it	2457.4251367623283
15470. she's in a mood he thought there's	not a month she doesn't get herself in a mood	2109.1661187490176
15471. well	what did that matter when the sun was shining and there were dreams	to dream about	1403.647644778664
15472. and as for his pipe if he wanted to smoke one	nobody would stop him	1662.2146416391074
15473. suddenly he was interrupted	in his daydreaming by a warm wetness lapping against his chin	and his eyes opened wide and long at the sight of a goat's claret tongue	feasting against the salt taste of him	3953.955679910304
15474. above the tongue an aged	yellow eye sallow and time-cast encrusted within a sphere of marbleized	pink skin stared unfalteringly at him	3274.5022968058106
15475. christ sake	goat git! but the goat would not	263.5424630174099
15476. you're boiling	milk ain't you	22.36645777559756
15477. soothing it with his hand knowing the whiskered	jowls and the swollen smoothness of teats that wrinkled expectantly	to his touch	2022.4844320768493
15478. his head undulated gradually covering	space to come straining beneath the taut belly within the warmth	of those teats	2597.3247237694736
15479. with his mouth opened wide he squirted the warm	white milk against the roof of his mouth and his tongue savored the light	earthy taste of it	2851.2626481125762
15480. the boy's fingers and mouth operated with	the skilled unity of a bagpipe player pressing and pulling delighting	in what he did	3254.294482116441
15481. above him slid the evasive shadow of a storm	cloud	376.62463351766314
15482. its form was a heavy figure in a fluttering soutane	562.5757057058579
15483. but the	boy could see only the goat's belly	264.7186367810433
15484. the old man near the	corner let the shadow pass over him sensing something portentous in	it	2135.5512849247216
15485. he knew it was there knew also what it was about but he wouldn't	raise a finger except to smooth his yellow dog's back	2452.063941029767
15486. there would	be time enough perhaps the old man reassured himself to pay the	devil his due	2109.8169347088174
15487. time enough to give up his soul	94.15981613597661
15488. in the meantime	six sandals stained an ocher the same color as pompeii's shaved	hair edged up close to him	2822.454929339039
15489. the clapping they made on the concrete	interrupted him in the ecstatic pleasure he knew so that he quickly	released his hold on the goat and pretended to be examining its haunches	for ticks	3644.8506990994474
15490. he knew at a glance that the biggest sandals	belonged to niobe the neatest ones to concetta and the laced ones	to romeo concetta's idiot brother	4092.7996782984437
15491. pompeii expected romeo's	small body to sink closer and closer to the ground	786.8942604149368
15492. he expected concetta's	thin hand to reach down to grasp the boy and her shrill impetuous	voice to sound against the rotundity of his disfigured flesh that	was never sure of hearing anything	5305.5968001502
15493. people came in and out all evening to see the baby and hold it	942.6221271940097
15494. the room filled with smoke and maggie's head throbbed with excitement	and fatigue but stuart had such a happy earnest look of proud	possession on his face that maggie couldn't bear to do anything to	quench it	5938.463992718602
15495. little anne rapidly outdistanced her mother in recovery	164.9777049452967
15496. in two months she became a fat highly social baby with a fuzz	of flaxen hair all over her head	2823.3763234035973
15497. she stopped flying into rages and	started digesting her food; she developed a peaches and cream complexion	and a sunny disposition and she asked for nothing more of life	than that she be kept dry and comfortable and fed huge amounts of food	at stated intervals and be carried to where she could watch activity	going on around her	5470.584773210142
15498. she was so heavy that maggie's arms shook	from lifting her and taking care of her	1880.6503152001812
15499. maggie couldn't seem	to	get her strength back or catch up with herself with all she had to do:	there was the big basket of clothes to be coaxed through the rackety	old washer and lugged out and lugged back; there was the daily round	of household chores in which maggie insisted on participating	5189.627881231915
15500. worry	had a great deal to do with it; stuart had been laid off at the	produce company and had to go back to sitting in his father's office	taking what salary his father could hand out to him	6219.265647700698
15501. mr clifton	would have preferred death and bankruptcy to having his son stay with	his wife's people without contributing to his and his family's	upkeep and besides that there were the things that had to be bought	for the baby	milk and orange juice and vitamins and soap just plain soap	5023.162433113929
15502. maggie and stuart pored over figures every night trying to find how	they could squeeze out a few pennies more	2813.3495200421053
15503. in desperation maggie	consulted eugenia one afternoon: do you think you could	find me something i could do here at home to make some money so i could	still watch the baby and do the rest of the things	4154.356633163157
15504. it	seems to me you have enough to do as it is eugenia said	1411.556361412699
15505. she	had been watching maggie go from the washing machine to the baby to	the stove and back again	1743.504433898827
15506. i have plenty of odd moments when	i could be doing something maggie said	1411.2942869806404
15507. it would make me	feel a lot better but the woman's exchange isn't taking baked goods	any more and i can't leave the baby with grandma because she	isn't strong enough and the baby's too young to be put in a nursery	4407.415914015166
15508. i should think so eugenia said	65.21460412217488
15509. for one thing	you can stop keeping that child in starched dresses and changed from the	skin out nineteen times a day	2178.759923426743
15510. she's so beautiful	and i do like to keep her looking nice	965.7902672118768
15511. she picked	up the baby and nuzzled her fat warm little neck	640.9379933353265
15512. she'll	be just as beautiful in something that doesn't have to be ironed	eugenia said	1632.3061863850605
15513. evadna mae evans said she didn't put a thing on	her child but a flannel wrapper until it was nine months old	2172.5997737682105

15515. well now maggie you don't	have to snap at me eugenia said	637.3964043752619

15518. let's make	a list of your assets	140.02640138050276
15519. maggie started laughing and she laughed	so hard she couldn't stop and she kept on laughing while she lugged	the clothes out to the yard to hang them up while the sun was still	shining	3743.557318257176
15520. when she came back eugenia was sitting at the kitchen table	with a pencil and envelope jotting down words and figures	3058.7192341144237
15521. i have here that you could run a nursery of your own for working	mothers	eugenia said	1417.924421738729
15522. we could put up cribs on the second floor	sleeping porch and turn the front bedroom into a playroom where it's	nice and sunny but of course it would entail quite a bit of running	up and down stairs and chris said you were to be careful about that	7348.536238032335
15523. what else	0.20041515
15524. you might set up a dress	shop in the	living room	756.2893329407788

15526. what about a tea room then	65.10322829477002

15530. oh i'm sure i could do that maggie said	393.43082457330627

15540. all	of them for you	22.323821799865243
15541. it grew bitterly cold toward the end of november	contributing to the miseries of countless numbers of people	1559.58600192109
15542. the temperature dropped to twenty below at night and stood at zero during	the days	1643.2861640206163
15543. the cold settled like a tangible pall over the mile	high city locking it in an icy grip that harshened its outlines and	altered its physical appearance; it had a look of grim stark realism	resembling other cities whose habitual climate was cold instead of	the sprawling bumptious open-handed greedy western city basking in eternal	sunshine at the foot of mountains stored with endless riches and	resources	5851.782021902598
15544. the jobless huddled in the streets outside of employment	offices outside newspaper buildings in parks in relief lines	outside government agencies	3031.8510880738377
15545. there weren't facilities to take care	of them; there never had been a need felt for such facilities	1563.7751406260454
15546. that	kind of poverty was regarded as the exclusive property of the east	which created depressions with their stock markets and their congested	populations and their greedy centralization of industries protected	by discriminatory freight rates	5619.503981578831
15547. the east was popularly supposed	to have got the country into war and into depression dragging the west	along; and now the east was creating government agencies for which	the west doubtless would have to pay	3876.4120372000784
15548. the government offices	were being opened but they weren't being opened fast enough and meanwhile	the cold penetrated everything	2558.730929791673
15549. shivering people talked and	argued; all this government spending would have to be paid for somehow	but on the other hand desperate circumstances called for desperate	remedies and something had to be done	3559.70591711936
15550. something had to be done;	it was the theme song of millions of american people their personal	problems no less urgent than those of the government	4087.5391300508186
15551. something	had to be done	14.882713461551026
15552. the abernathys said it to each other a dozen times	a day	962.4298159477696
15553. something had to be done about the furnace the fuel bills	the washing machine the doctor and dentist bills about making	money stretch for food for the mortgage for taxes for shoes for half	soles for overshoes	for clothes for the new leaks in the roof for gas	and light bills; about keeping warm about keeping well about meeting	the minor emergencies that came up once twice fifty times a day	0.20124717349522497
15554. just dropping the baby's bottle and breaking it became a catastrophe	and stuart wore out his shoes so fast that he was termed a major	disaster	4106.786027677949
15555. the abernathy furnace consumed fuel like a giant	ravenous maw that had to be appeased by hurling tons of coal into its	evil red depths and no matter how much coal they put in the house remained	cold	4038.7694846654995
15556. cold came in the innumerable cracks that seemed to have sprung	up under doors around loosened window frames from the sleeping	porches the attic from the widened cracks between shingles on the	roof	5353.777095899959
15557. presently they had to give up running the furnace at full capacity	and depend on the old coal range in the kitchen which had never been	removed when the new gas range was installed and the fireplaces and	an electric heater in grandma's room	4548.263921651202
15558. it was so cold and so wretched	that a sort of desperate gaiety infected all of them like people	stormbound or shipwrecked or caught in some other freak of circumstance	so that time stood still and minor anxieties fell away and the only	important thing was to cling together and survive	7490.139395752785
15559. the pipes	burst and they all laughed and stood in ice water to their ankles while	they swabbed the bathrooms	1871.3752268047233
15560. they lived mainly in the kitchen; they	moved maggie's bed and the baby's basket there and the rest of	them undressed by the stove and ran groaning and shivering to the upper	polar regions and plunged into icy beds	6201.612343850769
15561. grandma said it was just	like the early mining camp days and it was the way people ought to live	only she was getting too old to take the pleasure from it that she	used to	3857.563675281747
15562. you said a mouthful eugenia said grimly	140.96482079952398
15563. eugenia	hated being cold worse than anything and she was beginning to	find the joys of poverty wearing thin	1723.0525915959
15564. she said to maggie that it was	one thing to meet an emergency and another to wallow in it and it was	beginning to look at if this one was going to last forever	5459.544171823415
15565. plenty of people are poor all their lives	166.63701244681033

15567. i know you when	you start talking about brains and talent maggie said	796.0353176541382
15568. you're	working up to something and if you don't watch out you'll ruin	your whole life one of these days just to prove that the abernathy	family is superior to everything even a depression	5493.917997803781
15569. the	only thing that worries me is how i'm going to prove it eugenia	said	1087.02154308964
15570. they begged grandma to let them put a bed in the kitchen	for her but grandma said she was getting too old to sleep in strange	beds and be seen with her teeth out and that she hoped to die in	privacy like a christian and if the lord willed it to be of pneumonia	than it would have to be that way	8457.235638754719
15571. she didn't want to be the only	one with a stove in her room especially as her life span was nearly	run out anyway and she insisted that hope have the heater	3449.4005374023604
15572. hope wouldn't	hear of it and she took the heater back to grandma's room	and grandma took it back to hope's room and the two of them dragged	it back and forth until grandma tipped it over and almost set her	bedspread on fire	6787.370462739986

15805. she remembered suddenly a night of savage	moonlight and scudding clouds when she and adelia having dared each	other had stolen out of their great safe house and come here hand in	hand hoping and fearing ghosts	3941.1935221175
15806. the momoyama family had come from miyagi prefecture in the	northeast of the main japanese island of honshu where there are still	traces of the mysterious ainu strain	4500.852900021383
15807. the ainus were a primitive	people already living on the island before the principal ancestors	of the japanese came from southern asia	2192.3048467290396
15808. apparently they were of caucasian	blood	64.73088335464627
15809. they had white skins and blue eyes; all their men	were bearded and many of their women were beautiful	1720.24648173363
15810. a pitiful few of	them are left now to subsist mainly on the tourist trade and to sing	their ancient tribal chants which have the same haunting sadness as	the laments of the american indians	5631.258634060345
15811. most of them have been assimilated	but sometimes a man in miyagi or akita prefectures is much more	hairy than the average japanese and occasionally a girl will be strikingly	lovely her coloring warmed and improved by a little of the	tawny honey-in-the-sun tint of the invaders from the south	4970.835261735959
15812. tommy	momoyama was one of these fortunate occasions	250.98060178879672
15813. she was taller than	most japanese girls and had the exquisitely willowy form of the	japanese girl who is lucky enough to be tall	2476.7915770490827
15814. her nose was higher of	bridge her complexion so pale as to be quite susceptible to sunburn	and the fish and vegetable diet of her forebears had given her teeth	that were white and regular and strong	5914.587527927962
15815. her mouth soft and full was	something for any man to dream about	782.4950349019023
15816. she had black eyes long and	intriguingly tilted and the way she walked was melody	1648.741190803969
15817. she had	been in japan just one week	168.3229438308921
15818. it was an alien land and she hated it	intensely; she was already considering putting in rebellious requests	for duty at san diego bremerton the great lakes pensacola-	any place the navy had a hospital- with a threat to resign her commission	if the request were not granted	7232.65898579707
15819. anywhere would be better than	the land of her ancestors	372.345695209332
15820. there was nothing wrong with her	job	140.44573024130847
15821. tommy had been assigned to the psychopathic ward	167.4012719316324
15822. there were	no depressingly serious cases: the ward doctor sometimes teamed up with	the chaplain to serve as a marriage counselor- sometimes the navy	sent people back to the states to preserve a marriage- but mental	health as a rule was very high	6708.439895549421
15823. at present the doctor's main concern	was in seeing to it that japanese salvage firms were not permitted	to operate on the hulks of warships sunk too close inshore because	the work involved setting off nerve-shattering blasts at all hours	4213.805076735402
15824. tommy	was interested in psychiatry because there was much an understanding	nurse could do to help the patients	2350.9913670964816
15825. but she suffered in	her	off-duty hours	93.49019209022646
15826. such as now when she sat at a table in the coffee shop	at the officers' club having coffee and a hamburger to sustain	her until dinnertime	4277.503119044239
15827. she had changed into a cocktail dress and the	whole evening should have been before her but already she was beginning	to get a tight feeling at the back of her neck	3449.1748280518077
15828. this was one of the navy's	crossroads- you find them all around the world	1413.0464404263064
15829. ships from	the west coast rotated on six-month tours of duty with the seventh	fleet and yokosuka was the seventh fleet's principal port for	maintenance upkeep and shore liberty	3111.1849356458856
15830. sooner or later all the gray	navy ships came in here; if tommy sat long enough she would be sure	to see all the young officers she had met in san diego and long	beach	5634.502239671861
15831. and she wanted desperately to see someone she had known back	there	642.001558722523
15832. she felt rather than saw the approach of the good-looking	young man	967.1424869003853
15833. he came through from the fleet bar which was stag	with the ice cubes tinkling in a glass he carried	1890.3399128273127
15834. when he saw tommy	sitting alone the tinkling sound stopped	566.9094879091521
15835. he was perhaps a trifle	tipsy having been long at sea where drinking is not permitted and consequently	out of practice; he wore a brown tweed sports jacket obviously	tailored in hong kong and he was of an age that marked him as	a lieutenant	4619.9430878030025
15836. probably off one of the carriers- an aviator	250.73999483004278
15837. there	was a fifty-fifty chance perhaps that he would be unmarried and an	even more slender chance that his approach would be different	2312.890708497166
15838. japan	did something to a man- and it wasn't just japan either because	the same thing applied anywhere overseas	2591.74960209634
15839. it was as if foreign duty	implied and excused license; it intimated that the folks at home would	never know about it and therefore why not	2737.449318685368
15840. then the young	man in the brown sports jacket spoke and it was no different	1636.8186589144523
15841. harro girl-san! he said turning on what was meant to be	charm	637.2742246415175
15842. you catchee boy-furiendo	0.30041514999999996
15843. maybe you likee date with me	43.40143495972398
15844. i beg your pardon! tommy said out of her cold	rage	745.2443573612818

15846. the nice-looking young officer fell back on his heels	open-mouthed and blushing	963.2745231140291

15849. all wrong ones! then she	jerked her thumb toward the door in a very american gesture and dropped	into navy slang	2029.1411599292132
15850. take off fly-boy!   uh-	sorry! he muttered and took off obviously feeling like a fool	1658.3665989151727
15851. the trouble was that there was no lasting satisfaction in this for tommy	783.9443389640367

15857. now having been sent halfway around the world on a job she had not	asked for tommy was being humiliated at every turn	2324.199953653442

15862. seeing these did nothing for tommy's mood	140.91831430683968

15884. doc doolittle's	scheduled appearance at captain's mast was a very unusual thing	because the discipline dispensed there is ordinarily for the young	and immature and a chief is naturally expected to stay off the report	5650.655004765709

15886. just why anybody should wish to start a riot the	executive officer didn't know	1424.299328250253
15887. in his opinion doc had not grown	up	167.26861312874033
15888. the lieutenant was not entirely wrong in the belief	391.6098874595865
15889. there	had never been a good reason for doc doolittle to grow up	788.5087440061698
15890. he had	come into the navy too young with the image of the fun-loving guns	appleby before him	2371.009808634748

15892. he remained young at heart with	an overdeveloped sense of humor	752.4993442998514

15894. he was doing	thirty years and the navy would take care of him	1190.91295195086

16233. he left	us	0.20041515
16234. little boys crowded together on long wooden benches and	in the center of the room sat the teacher	2362.7036555445334
16235. his black beard dripped down	over the front of his coat	503.96922345411974
16236. one white hand poised a stick above his	desk	391.1783864971819
16237. he turned his surly half-closed eyes toward us stared for	a second then shouted in yiddish one two three! rapping	the stick against the desk	2593.3823073436884
16238. the little boys shrilled out a yiddish translation	or interpretation of the five books of moses which they	had previously chanted in hebrew	3480.1436981326674
16239. they chanted a fixed tune in time	to the report of the stick	787.3440374894292
16240. each boy opened his small mouth wide and	rocked back and forth on the bench in the way his grandfather and	great-grandfather	had studied and prayed in the ghettos of europe	5017.80652962225
16241. they had large bright eyes the small upturned noses	of all babies everywhere and hair cropped short except for the long ringlets	of paot framing their little white faces	3110.35195577056
16242. they bent over	yellowed prayerbooks and looked up only to watch the teacher	1190.0989872993127
16243. since they	did not glance curiously at us once i guessed that there was a penalty	for distraction	1561.2291988053448
16244. the guttural language from the ghetto stopped	141.4943773198398

16246. one boy who rocked back	and forth over his worn book had bright red hair and freckles	2147.353267306789
