16319. he helped her meet people so she could	go out and do the work she wanted	1270.8953975437382
16320. there was	a refugee who was able to come here because of her	1170.5519186432296
16321. he came with his	son	14.772152806208965
16322. at first i thought they were relatives of your mother but it	was not so	1623.4010691388362
16323. this refugee was a middle-aged man a big handsome man	with a strut to his walk as i have never before seen	2183.212356203644
16324. he had the black	numerals on his arm so he had been branded in a concentration camp	2126.5410801682915
16325. yet he walked like a young man	94.64540246663361
16326. often he was terribly despondent	and talked to no one	561.1569162362978
16327. then he would walk off for a few days alone in	the direction of europe	1095.5347163461724
16328. all his family was dead except for his son	390.81298345339377
16329. your mother would always retrieve him when he wandered off and she	would send him home to his son	1735.693393641543
16330. he loved the son and was always glad	to be sent back to him	1407.9553321696571
16331. then his son did something- rachel threw	up her hands- i don't know what but something to an official	here- it was during the mandate- and the son was imprisoned	3208.3281633199786
16332. a	few hours after the son was arrested your mother was informed	960.5738392955385
16333. she	ran from a little group of us	166.52649714501203
16334. we were sitting together talking	22.15767342005802
16335. she	went to the father and found he had hanged himself	504.01959793766235
16336. it was silent in the stone alley	140.342016678912
16337. then she continued with energy	i myself did not see her until a week after she had run off to find	the father	2326.7273763020853
16338. no one saw her except the man reuveni	249.5157496243478
16339. i know him	0.20041515
16340. rachel gave me a direct bright-eyed	look	142.23009117462715
16341. she said reuveni wanted your mother to give up her deep	interest in this refugee	1093.4769741426576
16342. he said she would only hurt herself	141.72477792067866
16343. he complained	to me once that i must talk to her	496.9571066806411
16344. when i did she shrugged	her shoulders and said that reuveni wanted her to marry him	1873.5881553999147
16345. i asked	her if she would and she said she would not	645.4141778655619
16346. he had known when	he first helped her to meet the right people and work with them that she	did not intend to marry him	3881.9584588671664
16347. anyway i did not see her until two	weeks after the refugee hanged himself	938.902069915551
16348. she came to me one day	65.41553646053237
16349. she	was pale and skinny; she was terribly alone	262.05078321326175
16350. and she said that after	this man had been dead for a week she had gone to reuveni and accepted	his proposal	3269.271162851836
16351. he shouted at her and told her he loved her and couldn't	understand why she had upset herself	1568.7056418820675
16352. but now he was happy she	would let him straighten out her life and take care of her	2349.237480623672
16353. he would	never let her harm herself again	165.44489283027283
16354. for one whole week he never let her	stay alone	562.0110087770133
16355. she let him lead her around	43.44561352592124
16356. he took her to a doctor	for she was run down nervous did not care where she was	2352.007454018483
16357. reuveni took	her with him wherever he went	166.98164051019913
16358. he did not let her talk to people;	he did not let her choose her own food	2108.053963536863
16359. she was limp and beaten from	her loss; she did not care	641.8431900250631
16360. and i'll take you with me	65.1747443925289
16361. the two of them against the world	94.14526689085551
16362. that had been how she imagined it	139.9909878585409
16363. for when he began to talk and	dream all at the same time making his plans as he went she had begun	dreaming too	2469.2523723642257
16364. but now the dream was over	65.29321124489678
16365. the big waking up had happened	43.57809519899066
16366. what did i imagine	4.447067945102941
16367. she thought	0.20041515
16368. did i see	him about to swing low in a chariot	752.5859384158642
16369. or maybe poling up the south	fork of the forked deer river braving the wastes dumped in it	1570.7837563798014
16370. maybe	i saw him on a barge with a gang of ethiopians poling it	1410.6800900180058
16371. and i'll take you with me	43.479851710675504
16372. he had taken her all right	64.82253931420873
16373. wednesday nights after youth fellowship	14.72517602807252
16374. out of the church and into	his big car it tooling over the road with him driving and the headlights	sweeping the pike ahead and after he hit college his expansiveness	the quaint little pine board tourist courts cabins really with a	cute naked light bulb in the ceiling	like the one on the corner where you used to play when you were	a kid where you watched the bats swooping in after the bugs watching	a room complete with moths pinging	the light and the few casual cockroaches cruising the walls an insect	highway patrol with feelers waving	0.30166232349522504
16375. and the bed that sagged in	a certain place where all the weight had been put too many times before	and the walls fine and thin for overhearing talk in the next room when	gratt went out for ice the sound coming through the walls like something	on the other side of the curtain so you knew they heard you	when they were quiet and while you lay wondering what they had	heard you listened	0.20124717349522497
16376. and gratt shafer would be in memphis today	for the wedding rehearsal and then tomorrow he would marry just like	everybody knew he would just like everybody knew all along	4853.883599176177
16377. like	mattie and the mayor up there gripping the microphone and toonker burkette	back in his office yanking out teeth like they all knew he would	2721.5605634646518
16378. just like the balloon would go up and you could sit all day and	wish it would spring a leak or blow to hell up and burn and nothing like	that would happen	5373.344417128916
16379. or you could hope the parachute wouldn't open	just so you could say you saw it not open not because you meant any	harm to starkey	poe in his suit of red underwear but mainly because	you were tired of being an old maid- a thing which cannot admit when	it thinks it might be pregnant but must stand the dizzy feeling all	alone and go on like everything is all right instead of being able to	say to somebody in a normal voice: i think i'm pregnant	0.20124717349522497
16380. or you could wish your daddy would really do it-	kill gratt shafer like he said when you all the time all along	could feel the nerve draining out of him like air out of a punctured	tire when you are on a muddy road alone and it is raining and at night	7735.348016244502
16381. so you sit in the car and listen to the air run out and listen to	the rain and see the mud in front of the headlights waiting for you	for your new spectator pumps waiting for you to squat by yourself out	there in your tight skirt crying and afraid and trying to get that damned	son-of-a-bitch tire off because that is being an old maid too	if you happen to drive a car it is changing the tire yourself in the	night and in the mud and the rain hating to get out in it but afraid	to stay and afraid to try to walk out for help	0.20124717349522497
16382. and every sound that	might be the rain also might be the man who thinks after he has raped	you he has to beat your brains out with a tire tool so you won't tell	a combination like ham and eggs rape her and kill her and that	is being an old maid too	7798.179482962902
16383. it is not having his baby nestled warm	and fat against your breast and it is not having somebody that really	gives a damn whether some tramp cracks your skull	3222.4193762575246
16384. and most of all it	is not having the only man you could love whether he drives a bread	truck or delivers the mail or checks the berry crates down at the sheds	or owns seventeen oil wells and six diamond mines for if you are	anybody what he is or does makes no difference if he is the	one	8348.21295543278
16385. he can even be a mild-voiced little-town guy with big-town	ideas and level gray eyes and a heart even houdini couldn't figure	out how it is unlocked	2855.7442939824555
16386. and he can be on the way to memphis your	gratt shafer can and you discover you can stay alive and hate him and	love him and want him even if it means you want him- really want	him- dead	6357.593046622492
16387. because if you can't then nobody else can either	nobody else can have him	946.3138226825001
16388. for you don't share him not even with god	393.67210406901677
16389. if it is love you don't	43.94396758714258
16390. and i'll take you with me	65.1747443925289
16391. even if that's all the promise he ever gave or ever will give	the giving of it once was enough and you believed it then and you will	always believe it even when it is finally the only thing in the world	you have left to believe and the whole world is telling you that one	was a lie	5489.0880674036625
16392. even when he is on the way to memphis you will still	have the promise resting inside you like a gift and it is he inside	of you	4487.718363572803
16393. and in a way the promise works out true for whether he wants	you or not you go with him in your heart	2325.1009581799094
16394. you feel him every mile	further away	141.74185012307026
16395. you feel where he is and what he sees and at night you	feel when he is asleep or with the other woman the one that never could	love him the way you do the one who got him because she didn't	particularly give a damn whether she got him or didn't	5134.17520325708
16396. and you know	you will always wonder all of your life whether it was because you wanted	him so bad that you didn't get him and you can feel nearly sorry	enough to cry when you think of that other guy the chump who begged	you to marry him the one with the plastered hair and the car he couldn't	afford and the too-shiny shoes	8669.786704344426
16397. you think: did he feel	that way about me	260.3411784631138
16398. it comes to you that probably he did feel that	way	to let you use him like you did when you couldn't have gratt shafer;	that he must have since he was there like the radio for you to	turn on or snap off when you got tired of him that other guy	7699.09927002245
16399. it dawns	on you that instead of a lump to fill the seat across the bridge table	from you he was a man and that because gratt shafer was making	you miserable you were passing it down to him to gratt shafer's	substitute that other guy	4664.663584460979
16400. and you wonder if that is why the little	man lost his job and his car and stayed drunk about a year before he	straightened out and moved to st louis where he got to be a big	unhappy success	6337.087242309622
16401. you wonder if he looks at his wife now and thinks of	you	791.0550827031432
16402. you wonder about the christmas card with no name on it and it	comes to you that maybe it would have been better to have made somebody	else happy if you couldn't be happy yourself to give somebody else	the one they wanted- to give them you	7153.441875909901
16403. damn the world	she thought	14.786069509268287
16404. she looked out at the corn field the great green deep	acres of it rolled out like the sea in the field beyond the whitewashed	fence bordering the grounds	4671.74183568259
16405. the mayor envisioned factories there	14.755146949303892
16406. homes and factories and schools and a big wide federal highway instead	of peaceful corn to rest your eyes on while you tried to rest your	heart while you tried not to look at the balloon and the bandstand	and the uniforms and the flash of the instruments	7259.616433614979
16407. the bands were impatient	but they were the only ones	374.84972136078613
16408. the others the ones in the stands	were spellbound for hearing the mayor was for them like listening	to a symphony was for sophisticated folks in new york city	4631.740900834528
16409. it was	like being in the concert hall in the afternoon and hearing the piano	virtuoso rehearsing	1425.8097518763868
16410. he was good and they knew that what he was doing	for them he would do all over the united states some day	3481.579378074297
16411. so they	stayed quiet and hung not on what he said but on how he said it not	listening exactly but rather feeling	2303.3587420474855
16412. if a man was good if he	was going to be governor you felt it and you wanted him to go on forever	3480.6378734815
16413. you were sorry when he finished talking because while he was up	there you were someone else and the world was something else too	2459.7388196689426
16414. it	was a place full of courage and hope and you were part of it	1640.8570975481375
16415. you	laughed and then your chest swelled and you felt you could cry for a little	bit and then a feeling hit you like a chill in your stomach and	the goose bumps rippled along your arm	3970.9474690264424
16416. he hit the theme about dying	to defend your country and you were ready to do it right then without	a second thought	3478.0220262021853
16417. while he talked you wouldn't trade being a west	tennessee farmer for being anything else in the whole damned world	no matter if it hadn't in six weeks rained enough to wet a rat's	ass	3771.851387324078
16418. she glanced at the man nodding beside her a man with	weather cracks furrowed into his lean cheeks with powdery pale eyes reflecting	all the droughts he had seen reflecting the sky and the drought	which must follow now in august- yes with eyes predicting the	drought and here it was only june only festival time again and thoughts	of gratt shafer would not leave her	8712.407411407115
16419. i should have stayed at	the store she thought	260.7278034055515
16420. back at the factory-to-you with	the other old maids back there she was the youngest clerk and she was	thirty-four which made her young enough to resent the usual ideal working	conditions like the unventilated toilet with the door you had	to hold shut while you sat down	7235.944903313304
16421. there was no lock because herman didn't	allow a lock	376.07882803072846
16422. a lock on the toilet would encourage malingering	and primping	565.7466983772463
16423. the toilet hadn't had a sincere scrubbing in years and	there were things written on the walls of the little boxed-in place	because you couldn't keep the public out- entirely	3228.2335272847004
16424. she could not	count the times herman had rapped on the door just a couple of bangs	that shook the whole damned closet and might someday break away the	pipe connections from the wall	5508.95258569185
16425. the two little bangs meant that he	was getting impatient to have a crowd of customers waited on and that	if he had to he would jerk open the door and drag out by the opposite	door handle which she would be clutching whichever-the-hell clerk it	was who thought she could waste so much store time on the pot	5452.332104465723
16426. and the hours were six-thirty in the morning until eleven at night	on saturdays and during sales and there were no chairs and you couldn't	smoke and the cooling was overhead fans and there was no porter	or janitor	6195.4169656117665
16427. among us we three handled quite a few small commissions from	spot drawings for advertising agencies uptown to magazine work and quick	lettering jobs	2470.5593505472725
16428. each of us had his own specialty besides	252.68783665913574
16429. george	did wonderful complicated pen-and-ink drawings like something out of a	medieval	miniature: hundreds of delicate details crammed into an eight-by-ten	sheet and looking as if they had been done under a jeweler's	glass	3667.5478664426673
16430. he also drew precise crisp spots which he sold to various literary	and artistic journals the new yorker for instance or	esquire	3271.1231336027117
16431. i did book jackets and covers for paperback reprints:	naked girls huddling in corners of dingy furnished rooms while at the	doorway daring the cops to take him is the guy in shirt sleeves clutching	a revolver	3949.7463509371228
16432. the book could be the brothers karamazov but	it would still have the same jacket illustration	1874.4549883120908
16433. i remember once i	did a jacket for magpie press; the book was a fine historical novel	about edward 3 and i did a week of research to get the details	just right: the fifteenth-century armor furnishings clothes	4058.8476921354986
16434. i	even ferreted out the materials from which shields were made- linden	wood covered with leather- so i'd get the light reflections accurate	3481.7055299217886
16435. mckenzie the art editor took one look at my finished sketch	and said nothing doing rufus	1260.5745393762325
16436. in the first place it's static;	in the second place it doesn't look authentic; and in the third	place it would cost a fortune to reproduce in the first place-	you've got six colors there including gold	5935.486145052375
16437. i said mr mckenzie	it is as authentic as careful research can make it	949.2879875678306
16438. he	said that may be but it isn't authentic the way readers think	1180.0581333101734
16439. they know from their researches into television and the movies that	knights in the middle ages had beautiful flowing haircuts like little	lord fauntleroy and only the villains had beards	3239.5721703694417
16440. and girls couldn't	have dressed like that- it isn't transparent enough	748.1437431075941
16441. in the end i did the same old picture the naked girl and the guy in	the doorway only i put a lord byron shirt on the guy gave him a	sword instead of a pistol and painted in furniture from the stills of	a costume movie	4792.266421256306
16442. mckenzie was as happy as a clam	142.31231177484028
16443. as for donald he actually sold paintings	93.86167661118864
16444. we all painted in our spare time and we had all started as	easel painters with scholarships but he was the only one of us who made	any regular money at it	5146.230219359826
16445. not much; he sold perhaps three or four	a year and usually all to joyce monmouth or her friends	1724.8397616530115
16446. he had style	a real inner vision of his very own	758.6034786749266
16447. it was strange stuff- it	reminded me of the pictures of a child but a child who has never played	with other kids and has lived all its life with adults	3320.536416212948
16448. there was	the freshness of color the freedom of perception the lack of	self-consciousness	but with a twist that made the forms leap from the page and	smack you in the eye	5167.533297251867
16449. we used to kid him by saying he only painted	that way because he was so nearsighted	1415.5895518958498
16450. it may have been true for all	i know because his glasses were like the bottoms of milk bottles	but it didn't prevent the paintings from being exciting	4461.960260259622
16451. he also had	at times an uncanny absent-minded air like a sleepwalker; he would	look right through you while you were talking to him and if you said	for christ's sake donald you've got prussian blue all	over your shirt he would smile and nod and an hour later the paint	would be all over his pants as well	5487.646466504487
16452. mrs monmouth thought of	him as her discovery and she paid two to three hundred dollars for a	painting	2585.249135993643
16453. it was all gravy and donald didn't need much to live on;	none of us did	1242.5182351366097
16454. we shared the expenses of the studio and we all	lived within walking distance of it in cheap lodgings of one kind or	another	3680.5969472659576
16455. attending the life class was my idea- or rather askington's	idea but i was ripe for it and the other two wouldn't	have gone if i hadn't talked them into it	3321.9533364894437
16456. i wanted to paint again	22.144472641431747
16457. i hadn't done a serious picture in almost a year	374.4567052101693
16458. it wasn't	just the pressure of work although that was the excuse i often used	even to myself	2364.406850754779
16459. it was the kind of work i was doing the quality of	the ambition it awoke in me that kept me from painting	2310.6895324275147
16460. i kept saying	if i could just build up a reputation for myself make some real	money get to be well known as an illustrator- like peter askington	for instance- then i could take some time off and paint	6204.077724292079
16461. askington was a kind of goal i set myself; i had admired him	long before i talked to him	1729.849613725744
16462. it looked to me as though he had everything	an artist could want joy in his work standing in the profession	a large and steady income	4102.801789573034
16463. the night we first met at one of mrs	monmouth's giant parties he was wearing a brown cashmere jacket	with silver buttons and a soft pink viyella shirt; instead of a necktie	he wore a leather bolo drawn through a golden ring in which was set	a lump of pale pure jade	5102.241879755339
16464. this set his tone: richness of texture	and color and another kind of richness as well for his clothing and	decorations would have paid the brush-off's rent for a year	4841.884540559054
16465. he was	fifteen years older than i- forty-four- but full of spring and	sparkle	940.5177863076685
16466. he didn't look like what i thought of as an old man and	his lively and erudite speech made him seem even younger	3506.0538073244024
16467. he was one	of the most prominent magazine illustrators in america; you saw one	of his paintings on the cover of one or another of the slick national	magazines every month	3350.722359564352
16468. life had included him in its modern american	artists series and had photographed him at his studio in	the east sixties; the corner of it you could see in the photograph	looked as though it ought to have velasquez in it painting the royalty	of spain	7035.748449237099
16469. i had a long talk with him	93.86504525791938
16470. we went into mrs	monmouth's library which had low bookshelves all along the walls	and above them a modigliani portrait a jackson pollock twelve feet	long and a gorgeous miro with a yellow background that looked like	an inscription from a martian tomb	6704.613273138026
16471. the fireplace had tiles made	for mrs monmouth by picasso himself	502.77774571869776
16472. like certain expensive restaurants	just sitting there gave you the illusion of being wealthy yourself	1651.951470933497
16473. in the course of our talk askington mentioned that he	spent part of each week studying	1247.0014228408095
16474. no	i take classes with different people he said	391.40710116454267
16475. i don't	think i've reached the point yet where i can say i know everything	i ought to know about the craft	2184.320896923377
16476. besides it's important to the	way a painter thinks that he should move in a certain atmosphere an	atmosphere in which he may absorb the ideas of other masters as du^rer	went to italy to meet bellini and mantegna	6205.9357238047105
16477. he made	a circle with his thumb and fingers	261.76364343208627
16478. painting isn't this big	you know	65.92641742111995
16479. it doesn't embrace only the artist alone before his easel	377.6245965601708
16480. it is as large as all of art interdependent varied multitudinous	749.4352168061483
16481. he threw his arms wide his face shining	165.6584161010571
16482. the artist is like	a fragment of a mosaic- no he is more than that a virtuoso performer	in some vast philharmonic	3280.645465817373
16483. one of these days i'm going to organize	a gigantic exhibition that will span everything that's being	painted these days from extreme abstract expressionism to extreme photorealism	and then you'll be able to see at a glance how much artists	have in common with each other	4683.566747219293
16484. the eye is all inward or outward	141.63291290618923
16485. ah what a title for the exhibition: the eye is all!	what do you study	1105.2110798617916
16486. i asked	0.30041514999999996
16487. i was fascinated; just listening	to him made me feel intelligent	503.96854797268327
16488. i'm studying anatomy	with burns he replied	140.91411865923567
16489. he teaches at	the manhattan school of art	166.4254480604917
16490. i had studied with burns	ten years before during the scholarship year the manhattan gave me	along with the five-hundred-dollar prize for my paintings of bums on	hudson street	4664.560377942917
16491. burns and i had not loved each other	167.95977647285048
16492. i'm also	studying enameling with hajime iijima he went on and twice	a week i go to a life class taught by pendleton	3502.0741961278013
16493. my god is he still alive	43.36574854389876
16494. he must	be a million years old	142.51180619623216
16495. i went to a retrospective of his work when	i was eighteen and i thought he was a contemporary of cezanne's	2035.2107811492328
16496. he's about sixty	now	4.439704874821324
16497. still painting still a kind of modern impressionist beautiful	canvases of mountains and farms	938.6465723786794
16498. he even makes the city look like	one of thoreau's hangouts	758.1058599562672
16499. i've always admired him and when i	heard he was taking a few pupils i went to him and joined his class	2179.4621936167637
16500. yes it sounds great i said but suppose you	don't think of yourself as an impressionist painter	2124.6312742700998
16501. you're	missing the point he said	43.27806900458303
16502. he has the magical eye	22.363836819876347
16503. and	he is a great man	43.66008799455355
16504. contact with him is stimulating	22.245009236050766
16505. and that's	the trouble with so many artists today	262.26461373135834
16506. they	sit	alone in their rooms and try to paint and only succeed in isolating	themselves still farther from life	2815.5386570983164
16507. that's one of the reasons art	is becoming a useless occupation	503.6831938284208
16508. in the middle ages in the renaissance	right up to the early nineteenth century the painter was a giant	in the world	3290.767652365069
16509. he was an artisan a man who studied his trade and	developed his craftsmanship the way a goldsmith or a wood carver did	2326.925337432105
16510. he filled a real need showing society what it looked like turning	it inside out portraying its wars and its leaders its ugliness and its	beauties reflecting its profound religious impulses	4973.49717209219
16511. he was a propagandist-	they weren't afraid of the word then- satirist nature	lover philosopher scientist what you will a member of every party	and of no party	2976.0705830514335
16512. but look at us today! we hold safe little jobs	illustrating tooth-paste ads or the salacious incidents in trivial novels	and most of our easel painting is nothing but picking the fluff out	of the navel so it can be contemplated in greater purity	6795.77082735384
16513. a bunch	of amateur dervishes! what we need is to get back to the group to	learning and apprenticeship to the cafe and the school	2601.5178958121855
16514. the upshot of the evening was that i got the	address of pendleton's studio- or rather of the studio in which	he gave his classes for he didn't work there himself- and joined	the life class which met every tuesday and thursday from ten to twelve	in the morning	7331.271613550502
16515. it was an awkward hour but i didn't have to	punch any time clock and it only meant that sometimes i had to stay	a	couple of hours later at the drawing board to finish up a job	4023.728395330794
16516. after	a short time both george and donald joined the class with me so they	wouldn't feel lonely and we used to hang a sign on the door of the	brush-off reading out to work	5631.5220339594825
16517. it was mostly for the benefit of	the mailman because hardly anybody else ever visited us	1244.8696575499698
16518. in	a way askington was right	64.75648575963363

18476. richard's next interest seemed the product of his insularity	391.3580688189273

18480. and one	day on her own his mother came home with a present entitled the	book of the dead which she suspected richard would enjoy	3910.3911141226354

18490. richard was a solitary student in new york and acquired	in his remoteness a thorough if bookish knowledge of asian lore	literature life politics and history	4097.298607367122
18491. he was awarded a fellowship to	continue his studies in tokyo and he packed up his clothes the biwa	upon which he had been practicing and his image of acala and left	to spend a week at home before leaving the country	4392.3430044946645
18492. the week at	home was not comfortable	139.76249116201618
18493. his mother who had seen little of him for	four years appeared worried about his sailing off by himself for an	orient which she herself having slight knowledge of it had to be distrusted	3658.2553588748365
18494. she seemed to work to grow close to her son in the few days	he spent at home talking to him about some of the more pleasant moments	of his childhood and then trying to talk to him about those things	in which he alone was interested	7130.610267936556

18498. he was no longer able to relax in the	presence of his parents and found it difficult to keep up a conversation	with his mother or father no matter the subject	5004.790037600363
18499. as for the	book of the dead it along with his other books on religion had been	incarcerated in a furnace in the basement of the building in which	he had lived in new york	3763.9358299936466
18500. he had dusted each of the books carefully	and carried them all to the basement and trembling at having to open	the big furnace given them up to the flames	4837.763726761641
18501. then he sped from the	dark basement and returned to his room and cried	950.2388261436834
18502. richard left	america with his clothes his biwa and his image of acala and on the	freighter which took him to japan he plucked at the biwa trying	to make the sounds he wrought resemble an ancient japanese tune he had	once heard	6723.446106233832
18503. during his second week at sea he brought the curious melody	out of the instrument and suddenly wanted to force the biwa to remain	at just that moment in its history when it had given him pleasure	3940.6240269533837
18504. he stole from his cabin late that night and crept out into a gusty	north pacific wind and dropped the biwa into the water	3721.3405371863337
18505. it was so dark	that he didn't see it hit the water and the noisy rush of the ocean	kept him from hearing it	2467.1375854309854
18506. it was as though the biwa had been eaten	up	by the wind	1193.5938496782317
18507. in tokyo richard took up a life similar to	that which he had lived in new york except that he had replaced his	biwa with a friend	2853.5351274305985
18508. an american student named charlotte adams had	refused to take notice of his evident aversion to people and had at	last succeeded in getting him to talk to her	4642.276885948239

18511. in time he grew to depend upon her occasional	company and she at length was able to encourage him to participate	in more social activity	2583.9984273111822

18550. when he at last did go	to his room he couldn't sleep and instead paced up and down before	his little image of acala thinking first of charlotte's tale of	the man at ryusenji then of his biwa and the invisible pacific waters	6686.364174143053
18551. and the next morning not sure of why he went he took the train	to fudomae and walked to ryusenji	1875.3013957210933
18552. he was surprised by the sharp	sensation he experienced as he approached the pool which charlotte	had mentioned	2370.622574495292
18553. he went through a gate to stand at the edge of the	water and gazed at the two thin falls which dropped from large spigots	high at the back of the pool	3457.0567540097377
18554. on the hillside above was caged what might	have been an incarnation of fudo or perhaps a demon	2341.4007589801367
18555. the strange	creature housed in wire made him shudder	261.85625329049424
18556. the sensation he so overwhelmingly	realized was one which told him he had been there before	but he knew he had not and could not recall any place he had visited	to be likened to the limpid green water or the little fountain-falls	or the green demon imprisoned beyond his reach	7523.465784610804
18557. he left the pool	and climbed the steep stone stairs to the temple and the sense of	familiarity with the place would not leave him	2613.2440960515605
18558. into a little well before	the temple he dropped a hundred-yen coin and then he had an urge	to sound the bell before the temple to take hold of the rope and crash	it against the circle of bronze; but the spirit he wished to call	out would not he knew come in the person of the temple priest	8217.652508653735
18559. instead	he walked around the temple and mounted still another flight of	stairs and stood before the seated fudo at their head	2183.029843835172
18560. the black fudo	seemed to stare rigidly back at him and richard's eyes were caught	by the fudo's in fascination and then richard was shocked as	all at once flames shot out from the sharp features of fudo's face	and there was a terrible metallic scraping sound as if the large statue	were about to burst from some pressure within it	8355.83046375186
18561. then the flames	were gone the stillness fell upon the severe black face and richard	began to tremble violently	1721.1322883555047
18562. suddenly he emptied his pockets of all his	coins and dropped them into the box before the seated fudo and hurried	back down both stairways and away from the temple never looking	back	5358.628944989469
18563. he walked all the miles back to his room	263.1977777572837
18564. he seemed to	have picked up a virus that day because the next morning he had a small	cough and felt a bit hot	3702.6979942875123
18565. he stayed home reading and refusing to	think about his frightening experience at ryusenji	940.3415296029259
18566. but the process	of refusing to think about it was an active reminder in itself and he	couldn't rid himself of a consciousness of it throughout the day	4466.857794925797
18567. the	cold lingered making sleep difficult that night and he remained	in bed still the next morning now unable to keep from thinking about	the inexplicable sight of burning metal the wretched sound the unbearable	feeling of having been to a remote tokyo temple at some earlier	time in his life	5023.98874072292
18568. all of the elements of the experience were impossible	and yet the reality of them was heavy upon him and he resolved never	again to visit the temple at fudomae	4813.446751053856
18569. i was thinking of the heat and of water that morning when i was plowing	the stubble field far across the hill from the farm buildings	2736.2798051024606
18570. it	had grown hot early that day and i hoped that the boy my brother's	son would soon come across the broad black area of plowed ground	carrying the jar of cool water	5304.15627136885
18571. the boy usually was sent out at about	that time with the water and he always dragged an old snow-fence lath	or a stick along to play with	2986.4159222225812
18572. he pretended that the lath was a tractor	and he would drag it through the dirt and make buzzing tractor	sounds with his lips	3699.788763861145
18573. i almost ran over the snake before i could	stop the tractor in time	943.5436679433997
18574. i had turned at the corner of the field	and i had to look back to raise the plow and then to drop it again into	the earth and i was thinking of the boy and the water anyway and	when i looked again down the furrow the snake was there	7564.684253523359
18575. it lay half	in the furrow and half out and the front wheels had rolled nearly	up to it when i put in the clutch	2599.4768437327225
18576. the tractor was heavily loaded with	the weight of the plow turning the earth and the tractor stopped	instantly	2590.0829215566637
18577. the snake slid slowly and with great care from the	new ridge the plow had made into the furrow and did not go any further	2622.1782716072166
18578. i had never liked snakes much i still had that kind of quick panic	that i'd had as a child whenever i saw one but this snake was	clean and bright and very beautiful	5479.992006705274
18579. he was multi-colored and graceful	and he lay in the furrow and moved his arched and tapered head only	so slightly	2046.24830786014
18580. go out of the furrow snake i said but it did not move	at all	1632.8854979549678
18581. i pulled the throttle of the tractor in and out hoping to	frighten him with the noise but the snake only flicked its black forked	tongue and faced the huge tractor wheel without fright or concern	3861.9803773396975
18582. i let the engine idle then and i got down and went around	the wheel and stood beside it	2591.75467965038
18583. my movement did frighten the snake and	it raised its head and trailed delicately a couple of feet and stopped	again and its tongue was working very rapidly	2977.517533543978
18584. i followed it looking	at the brilliant colors on its tubular back the colors clear and	sharp and perfect in orange and green and brown diamonds the size of	a baby's fist down its back and the diamonds were set one within the	other and interlaced with glistening jet-black	7377.554584577718
18585. the colors were astonishing	clear and bright and it was as if the body held a fire of	its own and the colors came through that transparent flesh and skin	vivid and alive and warm	3769.1614373235157
18586. the eyes were clear and black and the slender	body was arched slightly	1182.1057389990538
18587. his flat and gracefully tapered head lifted	as i looked at him and the black tongue slipped in and out of that	solemn mouth	2468.5063266329967

18589. you	are much too beautiful	14.772170376475987
18590. i had killed snakes before when i was younger	but there had been no animal like this one and i knew it was	unthinkable that an animal such as that should die	5157.684961744708
18591. i picked him up	and the length of him arched very carefully and gracefully and only a	little wildly and i could feel the coolness of that radiant fire-colored	body like splendid ice and i knew that he had eaten only recently	because there were two whole and solid little lumps in the forepart	of him like fieldmice swallowed whole might make	5633.929583886094
18592. the body	caressed through my hands like cool satin and my hands usually tanned	and dark were pale beside it and i asked it where the fire colors	could come from the coolness of that body	5778.709772068736

19251. i wouldn't have missed it for anything	93.58358606232193
19252. they	were sincere- men of the too-hearty handclasp and the urgent	smile	971.6194650732407
19253. these boys acknowledged an introduction to anybody by gently	pressing one of his hands in both of theirs while they gazed misty-eyed	with care into the eyes of the person they were meeting	3533.9642541130843
19254. could such	unadulterated love for a total stranger be credited	563.5001815419475
19255. they were	always leaping to light cigarettes open car doors fill plates or glasses	and i mistrusted the whole lot of them to the same degree that	i mistrusted bake shops that called themselves sanitary bake shops	3956.178157090614
19256. o pioneers! i thought and wondered what	kind of homesteads such odd pioneers would establish in this suburban	frontier; pioneers who looked like off-duty gardeners even at parent-teacher	conferences and who never called the school principal mister	5897.866750854636
19257. i sighed thinking that among other things people here seemed	to be those who would have to cut down if they earned less than $85000	yearly; people who would give their teeth for a chance to get	on person to person; people who thought it was nice to be important	but not important to be nice; who were more ingratiating than	gracious more personalities than persons	5747.533455614329
19258. in my estimation they	were people who read daphne du maurier and discussed kafka; well	not discussed him exactly but said kafka! reverently	and raised their eyes as if they were at a loss to describe how they	felt about kafka which they were because they had no opinions about	kafka not having read kafka	7808.296409869389
19259. they were i felt people invariably	trying to prove not who but what they were and trying to determine	what not who others were	2432.8245704847186
19260. becoming aware that it was nearly	lunchtime i brought myself back to the tasks at hand	1875.3297956291367
19261. i made plans	for the afternoon- doing the breakfast and luncheon dishes all at	once making the beds and then maybe painting the kitchen	2471.7320611468235
19262. then i	remembered that the girls had had a banana for dessert every day for the	last week	2375.971118783884
19263. bananas! jennie had shouted each time	43.29279518389207
19264. they're	not dessert! they're not even food	140.8493535060153
19265. they're just something	you're supposed to put on cereal for breakfast	499.7567465283103
19266. i dug around	and found a mix and was able to surprise them with a devil's-food	cake with chocolate icing	2823.651606412496
19267. rule for cooking: if you can't put garlic in it put chocolate in	the cake was received in a stunned silence that was evidence	in itself of the dearth of taste thrills mama had been providing	3864.326631049183
19268. then jennie closed her eyes stretched forth her arms and said:	take my hand louise; i'm a stranger in paradise	2813.767443161254
19269. needless to say i was furious at this unparalleled intrusion	upon free enterprise	785.4013929905552
19270. how dared they demand to snoop in private	financial records disbursements confidential contracts and agreements	1648.3785282712427
19271. it is as though i said on the historic three-hour coast-to-coast	radio broadcast which i bought	and pre-empting the eddie cantor manhattan merry-go-round and	that man in the white house like some despot	of yore insisted on reading my diary raiding my larder and ransacking	my lingerie! my impassioned plea for civil rights created	a landslide of correspondence and one sponsor even asked me to consider	replacing the eddie cantor comedy hour on a permanent basis	0.20124717349522497
19272. but	what quarter could a poor defenseless woman expect from a dictator	who would even make so bold as to close all of the banks in our great	nation	4670.372400361883
19273. the savage barbarian hordes of red russian communism descended	on the athens that was mighty metronome sacking and despoiling	with their bolshevistic battle cry of soak the rich'! after	an unspeakable siege lasting the better part of two months it was	announced that the studio owed the government a tax debt in excess	of eight million dollars while i who had always remained aloof from	such iniquitous practices as paying taxes on the salary i had earned	and the little i legally inherited as morris' helpless relict	was stung with a personal bill of such astronomical proportions	as to wipe out all but a fraction of my poor hard-come-by savings	0.20124717349522497
19274. i was also publicly reprimanded dragged through the mud by the	radical press and made a figure of fun by such leftist publications as	the new republic the new yorker time and the christian	science monitor	5804.89118509066
19275. it was then that i availed myself of the	rights of a citizen and declared the income tax unconstitutional	1729.8799925347437
19276. the	litigation was costly and seemingly endless	141.1813127369118
19277. i fought like a tigress	but by the time i appealed my case to the supreme court	mr roosevelt and his henchmen had done their dirty work	all too well even going so far as to attempt to pack the highest	tribunal in the land in order to defeat little me	5027.381624853457
19278. presidential	coercion had succeeded not only in poisoning the courtiers toadies	and sycophants of the bench against me but it had been so far-reaching	as to discourage any lawyer in the nation from representing	me! i was ready like portia to present my own brief	6902.905337433122
19279. but the	supreme court wouldn't even hear my case! my plea was unanimously	voted down and thrown out	1574.0203385322907
19280. again my name was on all the	front pages	392.21881674387566
19281. i was it seemed persona non grata in every quarter	but not entirely without a staunch following of noted political thinkers	and students of jurisprudence	2583.190726868175
19282. as charles evans hughes said	miss poitrine's limitations as an actress are exceeded only by	her logic as a litigant	2820.104222773526
19283. albert einstein was quoted as saying:	the workings of the woman's mind amaze me	948.8336358844529
19284. henry ford spoke	of me as utterly astounding	250.79467192465805
19285. heywood broun wrote: belle	poitrine is the most original thinker since caligula and even	fdr had to concede that if the rest of this nation showed	the foresight and patriotism of miss poitrine america would rapidly	resemble ancient babylon and nineveh	4317.056967948215
19286. not only were	the court costs prohibitive but i was subjected to crippling fines	in addition to usurious interest on the unpaid debts which the governmen	claimed that metronome and i owed- a severe financial blow	5760.243475037788
19287. nor as manny said had the notoriety done my career any good	644.7179615104599
19288. my enemies were only too anxious to level against me such charges	as reactionary robber baroness and even traitor!	traitor indeed! i point now with pride to the fact that long ere	the committee on un-american activities the minute women the	economic council and other such notable watchdog organizations	were so much as heard of i was hollywood's leading bulwark against	communism fighting single-handedly creeping socialism against	such insuperable odds as the fascio-communist troops of the nra	pwa wpa ccc and an army of more than twenty-two	million mercenaries whom fdr employed secretly through	the transparent ruse of regular relief checks	0.30166232349522504
19289. needless	to say my art suffered drastically during this turbulent period	497.78489402669345
19290. could	it do otherwise	4.432225193789817
19291. even though i have always had a genius for	throwing myself into every role and playing it for all it's	worth no actress can be expected to do her best work when her fortune	her reputation her livelihood her home and her nation itself are	all imperilled	4753.361048367221
19292. such sweeping distractions are hardly conducive to	oscar winning performances	558.398149123979
19293. i tried my hardest with little help	may i say from my husband and leading man but somehow the outside	pressures were too severe	2452.6852348909165
19294. having	achieved stardom a fortune and a world-renowned	wife at an age when most young men are casting their first vote letch	proceeded to neglect them all	4281.054580237783
19295. never a quick study he now	made no attempt to learn his lines and many a mile of film was	wasted many a scene- sometimes involving as many as a thousand fellow	thespians- was taken thirty forty fifty times because miss poitrine's	co-star and helpmate had never learned his part	4963.914039835294
19296. each	time letch went up in his lines i was the one to	be patient helpful and apologetic while he indulged in outbursts	of temperament profanity and abuse blaming others going into sulks	and on more occasions than i care to count storming off the set	for the rest of the day	7611.243852918621
19297. as for his finances i was never privileged	to know exactly how much money letch had salted away	1565.8547265308575
19298. it was i who paid for our little home the food the liquor the servants-	even letch's bills at his tailor and the los angeles athletic	club	4306.308037641584
19299. never once did he buy me a single gift and for our third	anniversary he gave me a dislocated jaw	1880.828898582849
19300. as for his private monies they were rapidly dissipated in drinking	gaming and carousing	1401.0556250321401
19301. more than once i was confronted by professional	gamblers bookies loan sharks gangsters thugs	and finger men- people of a class i did not even know existed-	to repay my husband's staggering losses or else h i	shuddered to think that someone so dear to me could even associate with	such a sinister milieu	5189.637986979467
19302. and at three different times during our	turbulent marriage strange girls with the commonest of accents telephoned	to announce to me that letch had sired their unborn children!	having the deepest of maternal instincts my heart fairly bled when	i thought of the darling pink and white bundles from heaven i	would have proudly given my husband	8038.081033150198
19303. ah you're too old was	invariably his ungallant and untrue retort whenever i suggested starting	a family	1412.1492302473312
19304. letch had made it abundantly clear that he did	not care for the company of my own precious daughter	2579.725358032737
19305. i now felt it wiser	to keep baby-dear in school and- during the summers- at a camp	run by the society of friends all year around	2725.8799449975554
19306. her presence only	made letch more distant and irritable and in the hurry of buying chateau	belletch i had neglected to consider a room for baby-dear	so there was no place to put her anyhow	5649.687829288005
19307. in his infinite wisdom wants us to have these inexplicable little	yet i adored this man letch feeley why i cannot say	2166.9006478936767
19308. with	faint	heart and a brave smile i endured his long absences from chateau	belletch his coldness his indifference his slights and his abuse	3698.6756937495156
19309. the times i can recall when i was publicly humiliated by him- lovely	dinner parties in our trianon suite where the collation was postponed	and postponed and postponed only to be served dry and overcooked	at a table where the host's chair was vacant; a splash party	at the new pool which i had built in the hope of keeping letch	away from public beaches when letch and a certain aquacutie stayed	underwater together for the better part of an hour; a lovely epiphany	party at errol flynn's on which sacred occasion letch stole	away with an unknown starlet leaving me high and dry to	get home as best i could	0.20124717349522497
19310. these are but a sampling of the insults i	endured	560.8335053885675
19311. as mrs letch feeley was it any wonder that i once	the social arbiter of filmdom was excluded from the smart entertainments	given by the astaires the coopers the gables the colmans	the rathbones the taylors the thalbergs and such devout closely	knit families as the barrymores and the crosbys	4979.953484469169
19312. as letch's	antisocial conduct increased our invitations decreased and my heart	was in my mouth whenever i played hostess at a fashionable screenland	gathering	3686.1488582147163
19313. between 1935 and 1939 letch and i made ten	films together each less successful both artistically and commercially	than the one before it	2316.9732070544123
19314. our last joint venture sainted lady	a deeply religious film based on the life of mother cabrini and	timed so that its release date would coincide with the beatification	of america's first saint in november 1938 was a fiasco from start	to finish	6683.71711017205
19315. as i was playing mother cabrini the picture was actually	all mine with nearly every scene built around me	1723.3121228934147
19316. but in	order to keep letch in the public eye and out of trouble i wrote	in a part especially for him- that of a dashing ruffian who sees	the light and is saved by the inspiring example of mother cabrini	6435.661461194037
19317. and did he appreciate my efforts on his behalf	262.1338878593309
19318. did he trouble to	memorize the very small part which i had tailor-made to his specifications	a role eventually cut down to three short speeches	3888.221907918466
19319. did	he show the rest of the cast- numbering four thousand- the consideration	of arriving at the studio punctually- or even at all	2321.6658527847294
19320. he	did not! the shooting went on for eight months! most	of our working days were spent on the telephone calling bookies	illegal gambling dens a certain residential club for young actresses	more than a hundred different bars or the steam room of the	athletic club	7046.367027295497
19321. whenever he deigned to appear at the studio he was hung	over uncooperative rude and insulting	1257.2489277567968
19322. he made many tasteless	irreverent and unfunny remarks not only about me in the title	role but about religion in general	3044.1264690103167
19323. by the time the film was released	we were three million dollars over-spent war was imminent and the	public apparently had forgotten all about mother cabrini	2731.797463700043
19324. thanks to	letch feeley and the terrible strain he imposed on me the notices	were few and unfavorable	2360.798856225538
19325. only george santayana seemed to understand	and appreciate the film when he wrote: miss poitrine has perpetrated	the most eloquent argument for the protestant faith yet unleashed	by hollywood	3108.124543597272
19326. but it was small consolation	22.090347286328864
19327. in a rare	fit of anger and spite i farmed out my own husband to a small	and most undistinguished studio to make one picture as a form of punishment	3226.335800649183
19328. the film was called the	diet of worms which i felt was just what letch deserved	1864.5688542532778
19329. it	turned out to be a life of martin luther of all things! it was	a disaster! in clothes letch simply did not project	2441.2466042181536
19330. he was laughed	off the screen	65.95331735286369
19331. at the same time however i availed myself of the	services of that great english actor and master of make-up sir gauntley	pratt to do a quickie called the mystery of the mad	marquess in which i played a young american girl who inherits	a haunted castle on the english moors which is filled with secret passages	and sliding panels and unbeknownst to anyone is still occupied	by an eccentric maniac	0.20124717349522497
19332. it was a potboiler made on a shoestring	and not the sort of film i like as all i had to do was look	blank and scream a great deal	4861.151198008893
19333. my heart was not in it but oddly	enough it remains the most financially successful picture of my career	1718.6337900974522
19334. letch had	returned from his debacle unrepentant and more badly behaved than	before	1181.7153154560135
19335. i really loved that boy and in a feverish attempt to preserve	our marriage and to try to revive the wonderful wonderful person	letch had once been i took my troubles to momma hoping that her earthy	advice would help me	4274.634708896078
19336. if i could only think of something	at the studio near me to absorb his boundless energy i said	2586.954344278922
19337. what is letch interested in	14.784087782939782
19338. bookies booze and	babes momma said bluntly	139.99439532873032
19339. her reply stung me but this	was too important to let my hurt make any difference	1243.6476489494448
19340. i can't turn	the studio into a gambling hell or a saloon i said	1424.0732523261916
19341. up to date however his garden was still more or less of a mess	he hadn't even started his workshop and if there was a meadow pond	in the neighborhood he hadn't found it	3656.7041400770163
19342. it wasn't his fault	that these things were so	391.0282706823258
19343. the difficulty was that each day seemed	to produce its quota of details which must be cleaned up immediately	1710.6808650278442
19344. as a result life had become a kind of continuous make-ready	752.5472456435884
19345. once he disposed of these items which screamed so harshly for attention	he could undertake the things which really counted	1879.6512800354726
19346. then at last	his day would fall into an ordered pattern and he would be free to	read or garden or just wander through the woods in the late afternoon	accompanied by his dogs	5506.626020584041
19347. his dogs	0.20041515
19348. he had almost forgotten	them although they had played such an important part in his early	dreams	2111.325340166789
19349. then they had always been romping around him on these walks	yelping with delight dashing off into the bushes on fruitless hunting	expeditions returning to jump up on him triumphantly with muddy paws	3584.767695845979
19350. dogs did something to one's ego	64.88425311367618
19351. they were constantly assuring	you that you were one of the world's great guys	945.2209055994456
19352. regardless of how	much of a slob you knew yourself to be you could be certain they would	never find out- and even if they did it would make no difference	4998.652703276597
19353. now it became increasingly apparent that there were to be no dogs	in the picture	1089.0926900933548
19354. what in the world were you going to do with a lot	of dogs when you left for town on monday afternoons	3265.0147285074077
19355. you certainly	couldn't take them into the little apartment and if you tried to farm	them out for two or three days every week they would become so confused	that they would have nervous breakdowns	3763.695769517618
19356. why in the world couldn't	he live in one place the way everyone else seemed to	1888.4517805120347
19357. it	worried him this inability to get the simplest things done in the course	of a day	1413.6856399477006
19358. he would wake up in the middle of the night and fret about	it	1413.5634727391607
19359. how in the world had he formerly found time to build up a business	raise a family be on half a dozen boards work actively on committees	and either go out in the evening or plow through the contents	of a bulging brief case	4552.030706989751
19360. was it possible that as people grow	older the nature of time changed	1182.4678619705528
19361. could it be that it speeded up for	the aged in some mysterious way as if a bored universe were skipping	through the end of the chapter just to get it over with	3548.970476015652
19362. or was	the answer less metaphysical	64.78807012350315
19363. did older people work more slowly	43.94280126194103
19364. did it take a man of sixty-five longer to write a letter shave clean	out a barn read a newspaper than a man of thirty	3885.070617998647
19365. did men become	perfectionists as they grew older polishing polishing reluctant to	let go	941.9029540244012
19366. it might be that certain people were born with a compulsion	to complicate their lives while others could live blissfully	motionless almost indefinitely like lizards in the sun too indolent	to blink their eyes	5496.780389957648
19367. perhaps it was his misfortune or good fortune	whichever way one looked at it to belong to the former group and he	was struggling unconsciously to build up pressure in a world which demanded	none which was positively antagonistic to it	4289.656348765137
19368. and then	again perhaps the reason why he couldn't find time to do any of the	things he had planned to do after retirement: reading roaming gardening	lying on his back and watching the clouds go by was because	he didn't want to do them	6902.307643329608
19369. there was no compulsion behind them	43.2930551251371
19370. they	could be done or left undone and nobody really gave a damn	1185.7391359130393
19371. during	all his busy life he had only done things which had to be done	1108.4491894764926
19372. this	habit had become so fixed over the years that it seemed futile to do	anything for which no one was waiting	3268.381526431942
19373. he looked at the luminous	dial of his wrist watch	373.0530826156584
19374. it was five minutes after four	65.37204605870089
19375. on some	distant farm a rooster crowed and far down the valley an associate answered	1105.1131649317713
19376. he turned over impatiently and pulled the sheet over his head	against the treacherous encroachment of the dawn	2365.0591589691435
19377. at least	he could buy the equipment for his workshop	374.6311111878182
19378. thus committed action	might follow	22.05952807338476
19379. he went down to mills and bradley's hardware store	and bought a full set of carpenter's tools including a rotary	power saw and several other pieces of power machinery that mr mills	said were essential for babbiting and doweling whatever they	were	4375.851842554081
19380. he also bought a huge square of pegboard for hanging up his tools	and lumber for his workbench sandpaper and glue and assorted nails	levels and t squares and plumb lines and several gadgets that he	had	no idea how to use or what they were for	7129.811235987817
19381. that'll get you started	2.943241715662239
19382. best not to get everything	at once	139.64048170404342
19383. add things as you find you need 'em	167.84694692097946
19384. he didn't	even ask the cost of this collection	389.6966487206083
19385. after all if you were going	to set up a workshop you had to have the proper equipment and that	was that	2174.253271485308
19386. when he returned home the station wagon loaded with tools	jinny had gone with a friend to some meeting in the village using	the recently purchased second car	4481.621245460141
19387. it gave him a chance	to unload the stuff and get it down to the cellar without a barrage	of acid comments	2175.710176460528
19388. he had made such a fuss about buying that second car	that he knew he was vulnerable	2118.4448233499693
19389. he piled everything neatly in	a corner of the cellar and turned to stare at the blank stone wall	1731.1010673594465
19390. that was where the pegboard would go on which he would hang his hand	tools	1652.3380116721157
19391. in front of it would be his workbench	166.97047164340324
19392. the old nightmare	which had caused him so many wakeful hours came charging in on him	once more only this time he couldn't pacify it with a sleeping pill	and	send it away	5332.203572782291
19393. how in the world did one attach a pegboard to a stone wall	790.2141618000521
19394. how did one attach anything to a stone wall for that matter	958.6149591242868
19395. after the pegboard there would be the paneling	167.3883010126107
19396. he sat down on an	old box and focused on the problem	971.0323968015991
19397. perhaps one bored holes in the stone	with some kind of an electric gadget	940.8042717251441
19398. but then when you stuck things	into the holes why didn't they come right out again	1882.3459505923431
19399. it all	seemed rather hopeless	14.649926186659641
19400. he turned his attention to the workbench	140.7238742638946
19401. perhaps that was the first thing to do	168.27434500626924
19402. a workbench had a heavy	top and sturdy legs but how did you attach sturdy legs to a heavy top	so that the whole thing didn't wobble like a newborn calf and ultimately	collapse when you leaned on it	6218.186431750653
19403. mr mills had done	some figuring on a scrap of paper and given him the various kinds of	boards and two-by-fours which properly handled would he had assured	him turn into a workbench	3580.1772472230646
19404. they lay on the cellar floor in a disorderly	pile	568.9032702311463
19405. mr crombie poked at it gingerly with his foot	259.60277666341415
19406. how could	anyone know what to do with an assortment like that	963.7711847892979
19407. perhaps he	had better have someone help him put up the pegboard and build the workbench-	someone who knew what he was about	2319.634821288871
19408. then at least he would	have a place to hang his tools and something to work on	2131.8206289144946
19409. after that	everything should be simpler	43.715045536870875
19410. he went upstairs to phone crumb	65.13409522060859
19411. to his amazement he reached him	43.48218228333285
19412. mr crumb was laid up with a	bad cold	391.94876903211
19413. he didn't seem to think that attaching a pegboard to a stone	wall was much of a problem and he tossed off the building of the worktable	equally lightly	3100.947904027206
19414. the only trouble was that he himself was tied	up on the school job	1401.875762020483
19415. that was why he hadn't been able to finish	the porch	500.7297261080322
19416. no he didn't know of any handyman-carpenter	140.18615354788187
19417. there	wasn't any such thing any more	93.5855365426628
19418. carpenters all wanted steady work and	at the moment every mother's son for twenty miles around that could	hammer nails for twenty-five dollars a day was working on the school	job	5012.7548191483165
19419. there was a fellow named blatz over smithtown way	262.56365161657703
19420. nobody	liked to hire him because you never could tell when he was going	to be taken drunk	2351.4798446096293
19421. mr crumb would probably see him at lodge meeting	the next night	646.831620955398
19422. if he was sober which was doubtful he'd have	him get in touch with mr crombie	1880.5828933430803
19423. mr blatz had been	at least sober enough to remember to telephone and he turned out to	be the greatest boon that had come into mr crombie's life since	he moved to highfield in spite of the fact that he didn't work very	fast or very long at a time and he didn't like to work at all unless	mr crombie hung around and talked to him	5837.3682832383
19424. he said he was the lonely	type and working in a cellar you saw funny things coming out of	the cracks in the wall if they wasn't nobody with you	4861.245258455593
19425. so mr crombie	sat on a wooden box and talked in order to keep mr blatz's	mind from funny things	1889.462749569199
19426. at the same time he watched carefully to see	how one attached pegboards to stone walls but mr blatz was usually	standing in his line of vision and it all seemed so simple that he	didn't like to disclose his ignorance	6415.265796905717
19427. while mr blatz	was putting up the pegboards and starting the workbench mr crombie	told him of this idea about paneling the whole end of the cellar	2858.393075794863
19428. mr blatz agreed that this would be pretty	249.80820760938596
19429. without further discussion	he appeared the next morning with a pile of boards sticking over	the end of his light truck and proceeded with the paneling which he	then stained and waxed according to his taste	3867.6536710803507
19430. now he said	we got to put in some outlets for them power tools; then a couple	of fluorescent lamps over the workbench an' i guess we're about	through down here	4998.79833054384
19431. it all did look very efficient and	shipshape	167.91665649982173
19432. there was no question of that	64.4209704371298
19433. by the way said mr	blatz packing his tools into a battered carrier them power tools	needs extra voltage	1732.3098779844797
19434. i guess you know about that	65.26315791147466
19435. before you use	'em the light company's got to run in a heavy line and you'll need	a new fuse box for the extra circuits	2599.0479784193485
19436. that ain't too bad 'ceptin'	the light company's so busy you can't ever get 'em to do	nothin'	2366.1717074856842
19437. instead of being depressed by this news mr	crombie was actually relieved	636.7971243290569
19438. at least the moment was postponed when	he had to face the mystery of the power tools	2116.7669774048936
19439. he followed mr	blatz up the cellar stairs	168.12922928193956
19440. as usual mrs crombie was standing	in the midst of a confusion of cooking utensils	1641.852801093278
19441. mr blatz sat down	in the only unoccupied kitchen chair	376.1906077431359
19442. well he said got	your man fixed up nice down there	755.974671701708
19443. he oughta be able to build a	new house with all them contraptions	783.9237675510603
19444. mr crombie watched his	wife with an anxious expression	392.7690453840311
19445. i was just sayin' to him that i'm	all ready now for anything else you want done	1407.2032859018784
19446. mr crombie	couldn't remember his saying any such thing	389.1747886448693
19447. oh that's	wonderful cried mrs crombie	43.754128638152224
19448. i have a thousand things	for you to do	394.6743723147017
19449. doors that won't open and doors that won't close	and shelves and broken h   but those are the things i built	the workshop for protested mr crombie	2873.2033602206598
19450. those are	the things i can do now that i'm set up	961.16319712935
19451. i've	been waiting to get these things done for months she said	640.0262967921828
19452. we	won't live long enough if i wait for you besides which you don't	need to worry- there'll be plenty more	3050.919694767616
19453. but the discussion was	academic	14.868715252752697
19454. mr blatz was already taking measurements for a shelf	above the kitchen sink	1183.1313594580674
19455. nothing in english has been ridiculed as much as the	ambiguous use of words unless it be the ambiguous use of sentences	2177.999994109924
19456. ben franklin said clearly spoken mr fogg	140.95367413221987
19457. you explain english	by greek	14.746719788818933
19458. richard brinsley sheridan said i think the	interpreter is the hardest to be understood of the two	2123.706479305932
19459. and a witty	american journalist remarked over a century ago what is even more	true today many a writer seems to think he is never profound except	when he can't understand his own meaning	3681.472334608551
19460. there are many	types of ambiguity and many of them have been described by rhetoricians	under such names as amphibology parisology and other ologies	3698.060869278547
19461. in common parlance they would be described as misses- misinterpreters	misunderstanders misdirectors and kindred misdeeds	1099.3844463788175
19462. one species	of ambiguity tries to baffle by interweaving repetition	563.2047088207325
19463. did	you or did you not say what i said you said because jane said you	never said what i said	2024.9793922158162
19464. another woman addressing christmas	cards said to her husband: we sent them one last year but	they didn't send us one so they probably won't send us one this	year because they'll think we won't send them one because they didn't	last year don't you think or shall we	7320.8638586790885
19465. such ambiguous	exercises compound confusion by making it worse compounded and	they are sometimes expanded until the cream of the jest sours	2176.401736392892
19466. ambiguity	of a non-repetitious kind describes the dilemma one girl found herself	in	1184.5246608453251
19467. i'm terribly upset she told a girl-friend	94.04876627397931
19468. i wrote	bill in my last letter to forget that i had told him that i didn't	mean to reconsider my decision not to change my mind- and he	seems to have misunderstood me	5446.425316880499
19469. evidently bill was another of those	men who simply don't understand women	636.0454700865873
19470. another case involves	a newspaper reporter who tripped up a politician	753.5666109647643
19471. mr jones	you may recall that we printed last week your denial of having retracted	the contradiction of your original statement	2020.9720254365889
19472. now would you care	to have us say that you were misquoted in regard to it	1872.7969327400456
19473. questions	like this framed in verbal fog are perhaps the only kind that	have ever stumped an experienced politician	1723.1441774252758
19474. they recall byron's	classic comment: i wish he would explain his explanation	969.852714931674
19475. similarly when a reporter once questioned lincoln in cryptic fashion	lincoln refused to make any further statement	1411.8837961955137
19476. i fear explanations	explanatory of things explained he said leaving the biter bit-	and bitter	1646.2237337912782
19477. the obscurity of politicians may not always be	as innocent as it looks	785.0944267010485
19478. senator said an interviewer your	constituents can't understand from your speech last night just how	you stand on the question	2838.2490459667542
19479. it	took me five hours to write it that way	370.9775159871141
19480. the misplaced	modifier is another species more honored in the observance of obscurity	than in the breach	2125.19200652756
19481. this creates an amusing effect because its	position in a sentence seems to make it apply to the wrong word	1877.3956693740881
19482. a verse	familiar to all grammarians is the quatrain: i saw a man once	beat	his wife when on a drunken spree	3269.0333436833835
19483. now can you tell me who was	drunk- the man his wife or me	934.6794394827341
19484. the wooden-leg	gag of vaudeville another standby of this sort had endless variations	1174.9381609253503
19485. there's a man outside with a wooden leg named smith	375.8546399053042
19486. what's the name of his other leg	140.2362031322386
19487. another	stock vaudeville gag ran: mother is home sick in bed with the	doctor	945.2577819757837
19488. when radio came in it continued the misplaced modifier	in its routines as a standard device	1889.0254603875885
19489. do you see that	pretty girl standing next to the car with slacks on	942.169178071112
19490. i see	the girl but i don't see the car with slacks on	1188.6836653969644
19491. in	recent years gagwriters have discovered this brand of blunder and thus	the misplaced modifier has acquired a new habitat in the gagline	2327.7853017210155
19492. in one cartoon a family is shown outside a theater with the head of the	family addressing the doorman: excuse me but when we came out	we found that we had left my daughter's handbag and my wife's behind	6194.595628988863
19493. journalism supplies us with an endless run of such slips	374.8217490701127
19494. not long ago a newspaper advised those taking part in a contest	that snapshots must be of a person not larger than f inches	3671.4027084599184
19495. classified ads are also chockfull of misrelated constructions	167.68732215496578
19496. readers of the reader's digest are familiar with such	items which often appear in its lists of verbal slips like the ad in	a california paper that advertised house for rent	4998.513255555837
19497. view takes in	five counties two bedrooms	93.93070060941744
19498. since brevity is the soul of	ambiguity as well as wit newspaper headlines continually provide	us with amusing samples	2602.0089418089256
19499. many shapes	in bathtubs	2.939173904229179
19500. son and daughter of local couple married	139.05364907116683
19501. apart from misplaced modifiers and headlinese journalism contributes	a wide variety of comic ambiguities in both editorial and advertising	matter	1885.1935817272501
19502. a weekly newspaper reported a local romance:	h and the couple were married last saturday thus ending a friendship	which began in their schooldays	3702.8115758701197
19503. an item in the letters	column of a newspaper renewed a subscription adding: i personally	enjoy your newspaper as much as my husband	2331.6409364058063
19504. then there	was the caterer's ad which read: are you getting married	or having an affair	1891.8749415032012
19505. we have complete facilities to accommodate	200 people	166.51818322591586
19506. the newspaper too is the favorite habitat of the	anatomical	566.544369589491
19507. this slip is so-called because its semi-ambiguous	english always seems to refer to a person's anatomy but never quite	means what it seems to say	2581.4503184026535
19508. samples: he walked in upon her invitation	139.64037862016534
19509. she kissed him passionately upon his reappearance	93.3957458313313
19510. not without good reason has the anatomical been called	jocular journalese	754.6037918410332
19511. in news items a man is less often shot in the body	or head than in the suburbs	1581.4707492117163
19512. while henry morgan was escorting	miss vera green from the church social last saturday night a savage	dog attacked them and bit mr morgan on the public square	4475.934669126118

19514. the double meaning in the	anatomical made it a familiar vaudeville device as in the gags of	weber and fields	2832.446667702625
19515. when a witness at court was asked if he had been	kicked in the ensuing rumpus he replied no it was in the stomach	2467.3657165084505
19516. strangely enough this always brought the house down	251.92192136320136

19518. a conscientious girl became the secretary of	a doctor	391.99987862843744

19584. an excited woman was making an emergency	call over the phone: doctor please come over right away	2125.5834876305917
19585. my	husband is in great pain	43.422252591931226
19586. i called the other afternoon on my old friend graves moreland	the anglo-american literary critic- his mother was born in	ohio- who lives alone in a fairy-tale cottage on the upson downs	raising hell and peacocks the former only when the venerable gentleman	becomes an angry old man about the state of literature or something	else that is dwindling and diminishing such as human stature hope	and humor	8841.659618180385

19588. after gagarin became the greatest man in the world for a	nation that does not believe in the cult of personality or in careerism	moreland wrote me a letter in which he said: i am not interested	in how long a bee can live in a vacuum or how far it can fly	7700.773629693237

19619. moreland asked grimly	0.20041515
19620. they require for existence a brave spirit	and a high heart and where do you find these	2145.1461919976823

19623. last year your tennessee williams told	our dilys powell in a television program that it is the task of the	playwright to throw light into the dark corners of the human heart	3443.4363818893426
19624. like almost everybody else he confused the heart both as organ and	as symbol with the disturbed psyche the deranged glands and the jumpy	central nervous system	4318.544965341659

19900. in this	country the two guiding lights are without doubt felix fing and	anna pulova	1647.2738411253426
19901. fing a lean chiseled impeccable gentleman of the old	school who was once mistaken on the street for sir cedric hardwicke	is responsible for the rediscovery of verdi's earliest most raucous	opera nabisco	a sumptuous bout-de-souffle with a haunting	leitmotiv that struck me as being highly reminiscent of the mudugno	version of volare	5147.078021715179
